HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: HAWAII; 
In the 50th State, the End of the Democrats' 40-Year Streak

BYLINE:  By The New York Times

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
For only the second time since statehood, a Republican has captured Hawaii's highest office.
 The state Republican chairwoman, Linda Lingle, a former mayor of Maui, won 51 percent of the vote on Tuesday, defeating Lt. Gov. Mazie K. Hirono in a race to succeed Gov. Benjamin J. Cayetano, who is retiring. 
 The last Republican chief executive here, William F. Quinn, was appointed territorial governor in 1957, became the first elected governor when Hawaii joined the Union in 1959 and served until 1962. Since then, the Democrats had enjoyed an uninterrupted reign, built by their championing plantation workers, other union members and the state's diverse ethnic groups of Asian heritage. 
Political analysts said the victory by Ms. Lingle, 49, signaled rising dissatisfaction that stemmed largely from Democratic scandals and a faltering of Hawaii's economy, Ms. Lingle's appeal as an advocate for change, the growing influence of residents migrating from the mainland and erosion in party loyalty among Japanese, Filipinos and other ethnic groups that have traditionally voted Democratic.
"The old Democratic faithful are getting older, and the younger ones don't know what the faith is," said Dan Boylan, a history professor at the University of Hawaii-West Oahu.
That faith was far from entirely absent, though. The Democrats retained control of the Legislature, even strengthening their hold there in the 51-seat House, where Republican representation dropped to 15 seats from 19 -- below the crucial total of 17 required to wrest bottled-up bills from committee.
The voters also re-elected the state's two representatives to the United States House, both Democrats, including Patsy T. Mink, who died on Sept. 28 after 12 terms in Congress. Special elections will be held on Nov. 30 to fill the remainder of her term, and on Jan. 4 to fill her seat in the 108th Congress.
The candidates for governor, Ms. Lingle and Ms. Hirono, differed only slightly on the issues. Both signaled a desire to improve the public school system and to diversify the economy away from its dependence on tourism.
But Ms. Hirono failed to convince the voters that after 22 years in public office as a member of the governing party, she was up to the task of change.
Ms. Lingle lost to Governor Cayetano in 1998 by fewer than 5,000 votes. This time, analysts said, she had more on her side.
Two weeks before the election, she had spent nearly three times as much as her opponent. The Democrats, meanwhile, had been buffeted by scandal: members of the Honolulu City Council had been convicted of accepting kickbacks and misusing campaign funds, a state senator had pleaded guilty of tax evasion and campaign finance abuses, and the Honolulu mayor, Jeremy Harris, had become a subject of investigation over his campaign fund-raising practices; that inquiry continues.
"People bought the argument that we really do need change and that Mazie is too closely associated with the old-boy network," said Chad Blair, a political science instructor at Hawaii Pacific University. "Lingle convinced them. She almost did four years ago. It means the voters said the Democrats finally failed."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Linda Lingle addressing supporters on Tuesday night after becoming only the second Republican in Hawaii's history to be elected governor. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Anticholesterol Drug Found to Help Paralytic Mice 

BYLINE:  By DENISE GRADY 

 BODY:
Experiments in mice suggest that statins, drugs normally used to lower cholesterol, may also prevent or lessen paralysis in people with some forms of multiple sclerosis, researchers are reporting today. 
 But the researchers warned that people with multiple sclerosis should not start taking statins in hopes of fighting the disease. The drugs must still be tested in people for that use. They may or may not work, and could even make the disease worse. 
 "We really urge that patients do wait for the results of clinical trials," said Dr. Scott S. Zamvil, an assistant professor of neurology at the University of California in San Francisco, and the senior author of a report on the research being published today in the journal Nature. Co-authors included researchers from Stanford, led by Dr. Sawsan Youssef and Dr. Lawrence Steinman.
Dr. Zamvil said the research team hoped to begin tests next year in people with very early signs of the disease; the patients will be given Lipitor, the statin used in the mice.
The National Multiple Sclerosis Society also said patients should wait. Dr. Stephen Reingold, the society's vice president for research programs, praised Dr. Zamvil's study, but, he added, "As attractive as it may be, there is no data to support the use of statins in multiple sclerosis" in people.
Dr. Reingold and other researchers said that some patients with multiple sclerosis were already taking statins because they also had high cholesterol. But no one knows whether the statins are affecting their multiple sclerosis. 
Dr. Reingold said that normally, a mouse study would not receive a great deal of attention because such studies are considered an early phase of research. But in this case, he said, interest is high for several reasons. Statins are already on the market, and if they work, patients will welcome them, because existing treatments for multiple sclerosis are only moderately effective and must be injected several times a week, whereas statins come in pill form. 
Although statins were approved by the Food and Drug Administration only for lowering cholesterol, doctors could legally prescribe them now for patients with multiple sclerosis. Once a drug is approved for one use, doctors can prescribe it for others. 
The drug's manufacturer, however, is not allowed to label or promote the drug for a new use unless it goes through a new approval process.
A spokeswoman for Pfizer, which makes Lipitor, said she could not say "definitively" whether the company would seek approval for a new use of Lipitor if clinical trials showed it worked for multiple sclerosis. Lipitor is already the No. 1 selling drug in the world, with sales of $7 billion in 2001, according to IMS Health, which tracks the drug industry.
Pfizer did not pay for Dr. Zamvil's study, but did give him a $100,000 grant after the study was finished. His study was paid for by the National Institutes of Health, the National Multiple Sclerosis Society and private foundations. 
About 300,000 Americans have multiple sclerosis. It affects nerves in the spinal cord and brain, and can cause weakness, paralysis, fatigue, cognitive problems and vision loss. Symptoms may come and go, and vary from mild to severe. The disease is not fatal.
Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disorder, in which the body fights its own tissues as if they were foreign. In this case, the target tissue is myelin, a fatty substance that coats nerve fibers. Cells in the immune system attack myelin, causing inflammation.
Researchers thought statins might help because studies had shown that the drugs, in addition to lowering cholesterol, could reduce inflammation. To test that theory, they used strains of mice in which they induced a disease much like multiple sclerosis. The mouse disease is considered a good model of multiple sclerosis, but not perfect: some drugs that have worked in the mice have also worked in people, but others have not, and some proved harmful. 
The researchers gave Lipitor to small groups of mice, from 7 to 14 animals, with different forms of the disease, to see if the drug could prevent or treat relapses. 
"The majority of the mice had markedly lessened paralysis," Dr. Zamvil said.
"These drugs have to be given under very careful medical supervision," Dr. Steinman said. Side effects can include liver abnormalities and muscle damage.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: THE DEMOCRATIC LEADERSHIP; 
As Party Discontent Swirls, Gephardt Leaves a Top Spot

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, who has struggled for eight years to return the Democrats to power in the House, will step down as minority leader, a senior aide said tonight.
 Mr. Gephardt's decision comes a day after his party suffered a pivotal defeat at the polls, losing at least five House seats and the control of the Senate. The loss had caused open discontent among Democratic members with his leadership, and even his supporters said he would have to choose between running for president and leading the House Democratic caucus. 
 Mr. Gephardt's aide said his boss has not yet decided on his presidential plans. But Mr. Gephardt's regular visits to New Hampshire and Iowa, and his eagerness in raising money, have led many Democrats to assume he will be a candidate in 2004. Mr. Gephardt never intended to try to run for president while serving as leader, the aide said, but several Democratic members said his staff had made some preliminary calls today to sound out members on the possibility of doing both.
The leadership vacancy will create an immediate struggle for succession among different factions of the party, and two of the leading candidates began jockeying for position today. Representative Martin Frost of Texas, the chairman of the Democratic Caucus and a political centrist, issued a statement announcing his candidacy. Mr. Frost's spokesman, Tom Eisenhauer, said the party needed to take note of the nation's shift to the right in Tuesday's election and not select a leader from the party's left wing.
He was referring to the other leading candidate for the position, Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the Democratic whip, who also issued a statement announcing her intention to run. To win back the House in 2004, Ms. Pelosi said, the Democrats need to draw clear distinctions between their plans and those of the Republican Party.
Mr. Gephardt's aides said the congressman, who has represented a St. Louis district since 1977, spent the day discussing his future with his wife in their Washington townhouse. 
On Tuesday night, as he made his way around the hotel ballroom here, Mr. Gephardt clearly had a sense that his political hopes, both personally and for his caucus, had crumbled. His smile seemed mirthless and frozen for the local television cameras as he refused to give up hope, but he acknowledged in an interview that the Democrats could not compete with President Bush's popularity on security issues.
"Clearly voters are worried about security," Mr. Gephardt said. "Clearly the president and the Republicans have dominated that issue, in part because he's the president now. And he's trying to address those issues, as he should, and people are worried." 
He said his party's economic message was lost amid the special-interest cash that poured into the Republican coffers, citing in particular the contributions from the pharmaceutical industry that countered the Democratic platform of creating a prescription drug benefit under Medicare.
But many Democratic representatives have begun to express concern that the loss was not entirely due to external factors, and today several disappointed Democrats began openly suggesting that it might be time for someone else to lead them out of exile.
"When you get beat as bad as we've been beat, you've got to look at everything, including the management," said Representative Gregory W. Meeks of New York. "We've tried and tried for years and the old plays aren't working. The Mets fired Bobby Valentine because it was the best thing for the team, and now I think we've got to consider some similar big changes without worrying about anyone's feelings."
Several members said that Mr. Gephardt could not lead the caucus if he decided to pursue his presidential ambitions.
"It would be irresponsible of him to do both, both for the caucus and for America," said Peter Deutsch, a Florida representative. "It's been obvious for months that he's planning to run for president, and his staff right now is making calls to see whether there would be support for him to do that and remain as leader. I can tell you that the universal response he's gotten is that he cannot do both."
Mr. Gephardt ran for president in 1988, and was battered in the Super Tuesday primary of March, winning only his home state of Missouri. His message at the time was one of economic nationalism, urging a halt to what he said were unfair trading practices of other countries, but his stump speeches never caught fire with voters and he suffered a chronic shortage of cash.
His party has picked up seats during several of the election cycles of his leadership tenure, but control of the House has been firmly in Republican hands since 1994. He retains a great deal of support among the Democrats, and there was little doubt that if he chose not to run for president, he would have easily been re-elected as minority leader. 
"The notion of blaming him for what happened last night is utterly simplistic and unjustified," said Representative Howard L. Berman of California. "There were a lot of broad national and local trends at work, and it's important to remember that this is a guy who's given every waking hour for years to help the Democrats regain control. He's tried as hard as he possibly could."
Mr. Gephardt angered more liberal members of his party last month by signing on to President Bush's version of a resolution to authorize military force in Iraq. Some members said they wished he had more forcefully spoken out against the Bush administration's tax cut in the campaign, while others said the Democrats were simply in need of a fresh face at the helm.
"In the private sector, if you brought in results like Dick's, you probably would have been fired or relieved of your duties a while ago," said Representative Harold E. Ford Jr. of Tennessee, a frequent critic of Mr. Gephardt. "I think it's time to introduce some new faces and new ideas into the leadership ranks."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard A. Gephardt has considered running for president. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Corporations Revise Wish Lists; 
Republican Victory Sets Stage for Pro-Business Agenda

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH 

 BODY:
Waking to a new power configuration in Washington yesterday, business leaders began to revise their wish lists for action on contentious issues like taxes, health care costs, personal-injury lawsuits and the ability of government employees to strike.
 "This historic election sets the stage for aggressive action" on a pro-business agenda, said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. He listed the association's top goals as expanded tax cuts, a new law governing terrorism insurance, a prescription drug policy for the elderly and a resolution of asbestos-related lawsuits that have hurt the stock prices of manufacturers and prompted numerous companies to seek protection in bankruptcy court. 
 Other business leaders and executives, when asked what they most hoped the new Republican majorities in both House and Senate would be able to accomplish for American business, cited the swift passage of terrorism insurance rules, a lessening of environmental regulations and a bankruptcy law that will make it more difficult for people to escape their debts. 
Many also foresaw a more receptive climate for new limits on medical malpractice lawsuits and punitive damages awards. Lester Brickman, a professor at the Benjamin N. Cardozo Law School, recalled that President Bush gained popularity in Texas as "a direct outcome of the largely successful tort reform efforts," and would be emboldened by the Republican victories.
"I expect he will now elevate tort reform to a more forward position in his domestic political agenda," Professor Brickman said.
Perhaps so as not to jinx things, or perhaps so as not to appear to be gloating at the successes of the party that has traditionally represented business interests, most of the executives and business leaders interviewed stressed that the Republicans' majorities are slender. Even now, they said, they were not sure American business would achieve its most important goals.
"We're still going to have a very divided government," said John W. Snow, chief executive of the CSX Corporation and former chairman of the Business Roundtable, an elite group of the chief executives of large companies. 
Business leaders and their opponents in Washington agreed that if the Republicans overreach in their zeal to advance a pro-business agenda, they risk a strong protest. Public sentiment is still running high for shareholders and low for executives, they pointed out. That made some think there would not be any effort to rein in shareholder lawsuits, even though many corporate executives complain about them.
Nor are there widespread expectations of a rollback in recent legislation to hold executives and directors more accountable.
"I think that some people in business would like to weaken the Sarbanes-Oxley bill, but that is not going to happen," said Damon Silvers, associate general counsel at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., referring to one such corporate-accountability law. "Attempts to roll it back would hit a wall."
Despite their reservations, business leaders saw an advantage in having Republicans controlling Congressional committees, and therefore the legislative agenda.
R. Bruce Josten, executive vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said that with a Republican replacing Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, as chairman of the Senate labor and human resources committee, managers might now hope for new wage-and-hour laws, legislation promoting the use of arbitration instead of lawsuits, and an end to new rules governing retirement benefits.
"I think they'll still be introduced, but now we'll be better positioned to block them," he said.
Mr. Snow said he thought the greatest boon to business would be the Bush administration's ability to name federal judges and regulatory officials without an extended fight in the Senate. "I'm a Republican," he said. "I'm glad the Senate is in the hands of the Republicans. I feel more comfortable with that.
"But the country's still divided on health care, on education, on policies for the elderly," he added. "There are still major fights, and the underlying political divisions in the country are still not resolved."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Issues facing Washington include, clockwise from top, brand-name drugs, fuel-economy standards, energy and taxes. HEADLINE: Automobiles; 
An Even Stronger Tie to Washington

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
Detroit had considerable influence in Washington even before the election, and that will only become stronger now. Andrew H. Card Jr., the president's chief of staff, served as General Motors' top lobbyist in the 1990's, for example, and carmakers have a bipartisan coalition of Congressional allies made up of Republicans and Midwestern Democrats in auto-manufacturing states. 
 With Democrats like John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat and the longest serving member of the House, leading the charge, the auto industry had little trouble winning legislative battles even before Republicans gained control of the Senate. 
 The biggest recent victory came last March, when Congress killed a proposal to increase fuel-economy standards, which had not been significantly raised since the 1980's. Meanwhile, the popularity of sport utility vehicles has pushed the gas consumption of the average automobile to a 20-year high, making the issue hugely important to environmental groups like the Sierra Club.
Still on the table as part of the energy bill are tax credits for consumers who buy vehicles that use fuel-efficient technologies like hybrid gas-electric engines. Carmakers want credits worth up to $4,000 for all types of vehicles that use such technologies. Some Democrats objected to offering credits to owners of pickup trucks and S.U.V.'s, saying that it is counterproductive to give an incentive to buy vehicles that guzzle gas, even if they do use the newer technologies.
Gloria Bergquist, a spokeswoman for the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers, said the group would "stay on the course" toward the full range of tax incentives. DANNY HAKIM

HEADLINE: Taxes; 
Additional Cuts To Revive Growth

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Several business groups said their biggest concern was getting tax cuts that stimulate economic growth, while holding down government spending to avoid structural budget deficits that would persist even after the economy recovers.
 "We are most interested in a stimulus package," said R. Bruce Josten of the United States Chamber of Commerce. 
 He called for increasing the amount that businesses can write off immediately for investments in capital equipment, to $50,000 from the current $22,500.
The White House has already said it would seek to make permanent the tax cuts that Congress adopted last year; they are now scheduled to end in 2011. A revision of the estate tax, more breaks for retirement savings plans, greater deductibility for investment losses and other tax issues also are on the president's agenda, and they will receive a warmer reception in a Senate controlled by the Republicans. DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE ART; 
Tablet PC's: Computing Drawn Anew

BYLINE:  By David Pogue; E-mail: Pogue@nytimes.com

 BODY:
CONTRARY to popular belief, Microsoft isn't the 800-pound gorilla of the computer industry; it's the 800-pound pit bull. However mediocre its first attempt at something -- be it Windows, palmtops or online services -- the company doggedly plugs away, spending whatever years and dollars are needed to make its inventions successful. 
 The latest example of Microsoft's tenacity is a computer design called the Tablet PC, which it officially unveiled today. (Computers based on this design, from Compaq, Acer, Toshiba, Fujitsu and other companies will go on sale in the coming weeks.) It's the latest expression of a long-running Microsoft fantasy: a future world in which you'll write directly on the screen of your PC with a plastic-tipped pen. You'll take handwritten notes, mark up documents right on the screen and capture doodles on the digital equivalent of cocktail napkins. 
Pen computing, as this concept is known, has been catnip to investors and inventors for years, but Silicon Valley is strewn with the corpses of famous disasters. Microsoft's own WinPad and Windows CE devices were expensive flops. The GridPad and the Go Corporation's Eo are distant memories. Apple's Newton rests in pieces. As recently as this year, the innovative I.B.M. TransNote and the Sony Vaio Slimtop Pen Tablet slipped quietly into oblivion. 
But Microsoft is confident that this time, it has found the formula for pen-computing success. So confident, in fact, that Bill Gates told a recent trade show crowd, "Within five years, I predict it will be the most popular form of PC sold in America."
A key reason for its confidence is that instead of some home-grown operating system, these new machines run something called Windows XP Tablet PC Edition -- an enhanced version of Windows XP Professional that runs any Windows program. 
And in hopes of avoiding the ridicule heaped on Apple's Newton, Microsoft emphasizes that handwriting recognition isn't an important aspect of the Tablet PC. A keyboard is standard equipment. 
That statement may surprise anyone who, upon hearing the term Tablet PC, imagines a clipboard-shaped computer. Where would the keyboard go? 
As it turns out, only some Tablet PC's are actually tablets; these machines, which include the Compaq TC1000, Fujitsu Stylistic ST4000 and Motion M1200, come with separate or detachable keyboards. Other models, including the Toshiba Portege and the Acer TravelMate C100, look at first like traditional laptops. When you don't need to type, you can rotate the screen 180 degrees away from you and fold it back down over the keyboard. That makes a double-thickness slab, its touch-sensitive surface exposed and ready for handwriting. 
The screen responds only to the touch of a special magnetic-tipped stylus. You're free to rest your hand on the screen as you write, without worrying that your flesh will trigger random "mouse clicks." On the other hand, this arrangement doesn't allow you to use your fingernail or a toothpick in a pinch, as you can with a Palm organizer. If you misplace that stylus, your expensive touch screen goes numb.
Writing on the screen is fun. Still, it's not as satisfying as paper. Your work is frequently interrupted by the unwanted appearance of Windows shortcut menus, thanks to the unfortunate location of the "right mouse button" -- a switch on the pen shaft -- precisely where your fingers naturally grip. You miss the traction of real paper, too; trying to write on glass is like trying to pole vault on ice. 
The brightest spot of the Tablet PC is a new note-taking program called Windows Journal. It displays a photorealistic picture of lined writing paper, which you can fill with your own scrawl. After taking notes, you can move blocks of handwriting around, delete them or even format them in colors or "boldface" (fattened penstrokes). 
Incredibly, you can even search your entire "note pad" for certain words, even if you wrote them sideways in the margin or upside-down. That feature alone is so useful and smart, you almost start to believe Microsoft's assertion that there's no good reason to convert your notes into typed text. 
Then reality sinks in. Text didn't become the world's most popular electronic format by accident. For most people, typing is far faster than handwriting. Text is universally readable, too, which is more than you can say for a lot of handwriting. Text can be edited, checked for spelling, reflowed, formatted, copied, pasted, e-mailed and reused. To share your handwritten Tablet PC notes with other people, by contrast, you must export them as TIFF graphics files or Web pages, or ask your colleagues to download a free Journal viewer that Microsoft intends to put on its Web site. Neither approach will win you brownie points at the office. 
Typed text is also a global standard because almost every program understands it. But for the moment, only a handful of programs accept Tablet PC-style handwriting. For example, Tablet PC owners can download a free software add-on that lets them add handwritten comments in Microsoft Office programs. 
This Office Pack, as it's called, lets Outlook send handwritten e-mail -- an intriguing novelty. True, your recipients won't be able to search your correspondence, sort it or copy its contents, because your message is sent as an attached graphic. (In fact, recipients whose e-mail programs don't display graphics won't see your note at all.) Still, handwriting can add a whole new intimacy to e-mail, expressing personality in a way that typed text can't touch. 
On the other hand, Microsoft missed a big boat in the Word component of the Office Pack. You can't simply mark up a Word document with circles, arrows and crossout lines, as a proofreader might with a red pen. You can do that in PowerPoint, and you can import a Word file into Windows Journal as a frozen graphic and mark it up there. But in Word itself, your handwriting is confined to square boxes in the margins.
This handful of ink-enabled programs will get you only so far. You'll eventually want to enter text into some of the 10,000 other Windows programs, which means that you'll have to use handwriting recognition after all.
To use the Tablet PC's "write into any program" feature, you begin by calling up a floating window called the Tablet Input Panel. After you write a few words into it and pause, a typed interpretation of what you wrote is "typed" into your document. 
If your script or printing is very neat, the handwriting recognition is often accurate -- but often, "often" isn't good enough. The errors are tiny but infuriating, the tsetse flies of Windows: "I'll see you next week" becomes "Jill see you next weeks," and "This software is terrific" becomes "this software is trifle."
Each mistaken transcription, botched punctuation mark and improperly capitalized word forces you into an excruciating spasm of touch-screen microsurgery. Time ticks by as you try to correct the first transcription problem without introducing new ones. There's no way, furthermore, to input a word in all caps, as in "We LOVE computers," using this panel; such attempts come out lowercase.
A Microsoft spokesman admitted that even he doesn't bother entering text like e-mail and Web addresses using handwriting -- he uses the keyboard. On the laptop-shaped Tablet PC's, that's not such a problem. But if you have a slab-shaped model, you have to summon the miniature on-screen keyboard, whose keys you painstakingly tap with your pen. This is progress?
The Tablet PC offers rudimentary speech-recognition software, too. It requires a headset microphone (not included), a keyboard to correct the transcription, the tolerance of co-workers within listening range, and the patience of Job.
I tried out five Tablet PC models: two slab-style machines with optional docking stations (the Motion and the Fujitsu), two laptops with rotating displays (the Acer and the Toshiba), and an ingenious hybrid from Compaq. (It's a slab with a keyboard that hugs its back. You can rotate the keyboard through space until it locks into standard laptop position -- or remove it entirely.)
They're nice-looking, lightweight machines with some neat features. For example, you can rotate the screen image 90 degrees with the touch of a button. In fact, when the Compaq and Motion tablets are in their docking stands, the screen image rotates automatically when you rotate the tablet itself. 
On the other hand, every Tablet PC lacks serial ports and parallel ports, many have undersized screens (10.4 inches), and CD or DVD drives are generally external components you have to carry separately. To reduce heat and extend battery life, most of these devices incorporate cool-running but slowish processors. 
The slab designs work well in the office; you can pop one off of its dock (a $250 or $300 extra) and run to a meeting without having to shut the machine down. Yet you shouldn't consider one as a replacement for a standard laptop; strange as it may sound, it's a hassle to take these tablets on the road. Not only are there so many pieces to carry (slab, keyboard, external CD drive, power cord), but the delicate screen is exposed in transit. Add a padded slipcover to your equipment list.
The clamshell designs and the Compaq hybrid are more practical, because they're full-fledged laptops that become slabs only when necessary. Trouble is, most cost $2,200 and up --much more than comparably equipped, non-Tablet PC laptops. You're paying about $500 extra for that touch screen. (Compaq took a different economic tack. Its TC1000 costs only $1,700, about the same as a normal laptop--but the Transmeta processor isn't especially frisky, and the screen is disappointingly dim and grainy.)
Make no mistake: a touch screen can be a useful enhancement. You can use a Tablet PC standing up -- not something people do every day, to be sure, but handy in certain lines of work. Tablet PC-compatible drawing and sketching programs like Corel Grafigo and Alias SketchBook offer the unparalleled pleasure of drawing directly on the screen. (On models except the inexpensive Compaq, you get a fatter line the harder you bear down with the pen.) And for people who take handwritten notes in meetings but never need to pass them on, Windows Journal could be an attractive alternative.
But these are isolated perks for isolated situations: insurance investigations, graduate school classes, hospital rounds, package delivery, and so on. For everything else, writing on the screen is primarily a novelty, an expensive piece of demo ware that introduces pointless barriers to many tasks that would be swift and simple on a traditional laptop. Especially in this economy, it doesn't seem likely that the masses will beat a path to Microsoft's door, grateful to pay a $500 premium for the opportunity.
Meanwhile, Microsoft faces a tough competitor, the dominant player in the business-meeting note-taking market. It's a rugged, crashproof portable that accommodates any writing implement, feels just like paper and costs .02 percent of a Tablet PC. If it's prestige you're after, you can even tell your friends that it has a fancy name: Windows XP Legal Pad Edition.

HEADLINE: Bush's Validation Day 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE; E-mail: safire@nytimes.com

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
The re-election of the president's brother in Florida was the test Democrats chose to weaken George W. Bush's political clout. Bill Clinton and Al Gore stumped against Jeb Bush; Clinton's Democratic National Committee boss poured in millions. The Bush brothers greeted the personal challenge with enthusiasm.
 Jeb Bush won big; George W. won even bigger. In Florida and all across the country, the president laid his high ratings on the line to give national meaning to local elections. Had his party in the White House suffered the usual midterm losses in Congress and statehouses, Democrats would have said he had been repudiated. The opposite happened; his gutsy gamble paid off, and Bush's 2000 victory was resoundingly validated. 
 I was rooting for a shake-up of Congress, with control of both houses switching and a check on executive power maintained. But the change to G.O.P. leadership in the Senate -- with today's primacy of foreign affairs and judicial appointment -- was central. And the strange thing happened: the close Senate races did not average out but broke mostly one way, this time to Republicans. 
What message will Democrats take from Bush's validation day? G.O.P. partisans fervently hope defeated Democrats will say "No more Mr. Nice Guy," angrily return to class-war, peacenik principles and oppose Bush on the liberation of Iraq and on tax cuts, including the "death tax." However, the Clintons -- with control of the purse strings -- will likely keep their party on the moderate middle-road message of me-too. 
What will Republicans do with the across-the-board power position they have not had since Eisenhower's time? We can expect a surge of interest in "affordable health care," specifically an entitlement for prescription drugs that Democrats have blocked as not generous enough. 
In that connection, we can hope to see payback time for the trial lawyers who are the Democrats' chief source of big bucks. In return, politicians of the left have made possible huge payments to individual plaintiffs, with a large cut to their lawyers, thereby driving up medical insurance costs. Under New Bush, tort reform should be on the way. 
Partisan unionists who have jerked the chains of grateful politicians on homeland security legislation, demanding civil service protection from firing, will find fewer obstructionists beholden to them in powerful committee positions. Same with the Democratic teachers' unions opposing reformist education ideas: conservatives are still smarting at Bush's abandonment of vouchers in order to get any bill at all.
What about the underlying promise of the 2002 campaign -- that the U.S., with or without the backing of Russia and France in the U.N., would force Saddam Hussein out of office before he can blackmail us not only with germ and poison-gas weapons but with nuclear bombs? 
As Election Day drew near, Bush's tone grew more dovish. Colin Powell further watered down our already weakened resolution in the U.N. and the president began to waffle, allowing as how "regime change" didn't mean Saddam's removal, but merely a change in his weapons-development practices. 
If Bush permits the invasion winter to go by, as Saddam employs his sophisticated form of rope-a-dope with inspectors often fooled before, it would occur to Democrats that summerlong invasion posturing was a device to distract media attention from the economy. A charge of "phony war talk" would become a rallying issue. 
And should Iraq's regime remain unchanged -- a secret arsenal of terror ostensibly cooperating with inspections ("Gee, were we building that? It must be a rogue operation") -- then hard-liners as well as Wilsonian idealists will see themselves betrayed. They would hold the midterm referendum on Bush to have been won on spurious grounds; a multilateral wimpout would have been more honestly conducted by dovish Democrats.
Thus does the new political dominance focus responsibility. The Republican triad of president, speaker and majority leader has no excuse for failing to deliver. The opposition must conceive and articulate contrary views. The press is charged more than ever to investigate and expose. 
About the media: Thanks to a massive glitch, its audience was treated to election returns without a frenzy of early projections based on maybe-right exit polls. Viewers tasted a delicious throwback to reality numbers. Is this a great country or what?

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Bush Facing 2 Challenges: S.E.C. Choice And Economy

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
President Bush led his party to a stunning midterm election victory despite a series of daunting economic problems that might have been expected to produce the opposite result.
 The stock market fell more after his inauguration than during any similar period since the Hoover administration. The economy lost more than two million private-sector jobs, and investor confidence plunged amid corporate scandals that reminded some of the 1930's. 
 Even as the president was celebrating the election results on Tuesday night, his choice as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission was resigning and the Federal Reserve was preparing to cut interest rates to the lowest levels in decades. Both moves reflected worries that the situation was significantly worse than it appeared only a few months ago. 
Now a victorious president confronts a question most commonly asked by presidents who have suffered severe midterm election rebuffs: What will it take to get things back on track before he seeks re-election in two years?
In the economy, it is clear that the Federal Reserve's contributions to stimulus are coming to an end. After cutting the key interest rate it administers to 1.25 percent, the lowest since John F. Kennedy was in the White House, it indicated it did not expect to cut rates again soon. In any case, it cannot cut rates much further.
"It makes sense for the Fed to act very aggressively when it doesn't have much ammunition left," said Bill Dudley, the chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs. "But we shouldn't kid ourselves that this makes everything all right."
If further stimulus is needed for the economy, the Fed's situation makes it all the more likely that the burden will rest on fiscal policy. There is a widespread expectation that Mr. Bush will look for more tax cuts, while concentrating spending increases on the military and fighting terrorism. With Republicans controlling both houses of Congress, there is every reason to think he will get much of what he wants.
But his first challenge will be naming a new S.E.C. chairman to replace Harvey L. Pitt, who resigned on Tuesday night. Mr. Pitt is widely viewed as having botched the appointment of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, whose chairman, William H. Webster, is facing an investigation of his role as chairman of the audit committee of U.S. Technologies and is involved in a "who said what" dispute with the company's former auditor -- a firm that the new board will regulate.
Names of potential S.E.C. chairmen circulated widely yesterday, but there was no indication that any of them met with the approval of Mr. Bush, who must decide which constituency to appease in making an appointment that will be scrutinized.
When Mr. Pitt was chosen, it was reported that other candidates had been blocked because they were viewed as too eager to impose new regulations. That, of course, was before scandals at Enron and WorldCom led to passage of the Sarbanes-Oxley law, which established the new accounting regulator and called for a series of new regulations.
A new chairman, if chosen quickly, will have to decide what to do about the accounting oversight board. That will involve choosing a new chairman if Mr. Webster steps down, as many expect he will do, or it will involve deciding whether to ask Mr. Webster to do so. To lure a new, high-quality chairman, it might be necessary to offer that person some choice in whether other board members should also leave.
In choosing a new chairman, Mr. Bush may have wider latitude because the confirmation will be up to a Senate controlled by his party. But any choice comes with risks. Choosing a tough prosecutor would no doubt win public acclaim, but if that person knows little about securities laws it could be a major handicap.
"You want someone who is technically proficient," said Joel Seligman, the dean of the Washington University law school in St. Louis and a historian of the S.E.C. "This is a very hard job to learn."
Indeed, the S.E.C. faces major issues in many areas, ranging from the structure of securities markets to reforming the way research is done.
Mr. Seligman pointed to the 1973 appointment of Ray Garrett Jr., a highly respected securities lawyer, after his predecessor, G. Bradford Cook, was forced out as a result of a scandal that made his honesty suspect. "That is the kind of person you want, probably someone with an accomplished career in securities law, someone who will be a healer and a consensus builder," Mr. Seligman said. (Mr. Garrett's executive assistant when he was chairman was a young lawyer named Pitt.) 
But any lawyer who had represented a wide variety of clients would also face questions of conflicts of interest, as followed Mr. Pitt in his first year in office. To others, it is important to avoid such questions.
With the S.E.C. having been politicized to an extent that is unusual in its past, with Democrats having called for Mr. Pitt's ouster and voiced suspicions that he was doing the White House's bidding in opposing one candidate for the accounting board, there is clearly a case to be made for a chairman who does not appear to have strong political ties or leanings. Some wonder whether a veteran commission staff member, like Steven Cutler, the director of enforcement, might have a chance.
On the economy, Mr. Bush may need to decide quickly whether to change any members of his economic team. He will also have to decide whether to propose large block grants for the states, whose fiscal problems will probably get more attention now that the election is over and the winners must confront large deficits that -- unlike the federal one -- must be closed somehow. To do so would increase the federal deficit, but to not come to the aid of the states would run the risk of their budgets acting as a severe drag on the economy in coming months.
The results of those decisions will become clear only over the next couple of years. But by then, they could have a major impact on whether Mr. Bush can win a second term.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: THE AGENDA; 
Republicans Have Edge, But Passing Bush's Plans May Require Compromise

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER

 BODY:
Winning control of the Senate will clearly help Republicans pass some of President Bush's legislation, but how much will depend on when and how Democrats choose to fight.
 Mr. Bush campaigned long and hard not only for Republican candidates, but also for several measures that Senate Democrats have stalled, like a Homeland Security Department, where he could override Civil Service rules, and the Republican version of prescription-drug legislation. 
 The first test may come, even this month in the lame-duck session, over the domestic security legislation. Some Democrats expected their colleagues to quit insisting on civil service protections for workers, but others said that was unlikely. 
A major effort next year will come when Mr. Bush seeks to make permanent the tax cuts enacted in 2001. 
They are set to expire in 2011. But while some tax cuts can be enacted with 51 votes, under Senate rules permanent changes will require 60. That would mean assembling some Democratic supporters, too, and that would almost certainly require concessions from the Republicans, like an extension of unemployment benefits.
On these and other issues, having the presidency and both houses of Congress could make the Republicans insist on having their way down to the last detail. But it could also offer a reason for compromise. When Mr. Bush runs for re-election in 2004, he will want a record including more domestic accomplishment than he has recorded so far. President Bill Clinton and the Republican-led Congress compromised in 1996, and both won re-election.
One obvious opportunity for compromise is a prescription drug benefit for the elderly. House Republicans have repeatedly passed bills with a large role for insurance companies. 
Their Senate allies have blocked Democratic efforts to run the program through Medicare. But if he wants an accomplishment to run on, Mr. Bush may have to deal with centrist senators and their ideas of compromise.
At a White House briefing, Ari Fleischer, the press secretary, took a cautiously optimistic tone yesterday. "I think there's no question that last night's results increased the likelihood of getting things done for the American people," Mr. Fleischer said.
But the numbers alone cannot make that true. With their new majority of 51 or 52 senators (depending on the Louisiana runoff), Republicans can propose a legislative agenda, and they can control committees. But these days, no one can control the Senate. Almost any remotely controversial bill must overcome a potential filibuster, and that takes 60 votes.
Instead, political realities could persuade Democrats to go along. The historic dimension of Republicans' recapturing the Senate and increasing their majority in the House might convince the new Senate minority that the nation demands action, even acquiescence.
Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, said yesterday that Democrats should seriously fear the consequences if they instinctively fight the president time after time.
"How often do they want to be seen as the obstructionist party?" Mr. Gingrich asked. "Can 'no' be their only answer?"
Senate Democrats were still licking their wounds yesterday and had not begun developing a strategy. But even Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, who is known for preferring accommodation to confrontation, said he doubted that many of his Democratic colleagues would surrender to the president.
Indeed, after the bitterness of the election, Mr. Breaux said, "some might be a little less likely to help."
One Senate aide pointed out that Democrats had taken worse beatings, in 1980 and 1994, and so were not shattered by Tuesday's results.
Democrats, no longer facing an imminent election, could also push some legislative measures of their own or fight to increase spending in such areas as education. They might try that this month. And without the obligation of trying to hold everyone from Paul Wellstone to Zell Miller together on an issue, Senator Tom Daschle may find the role of minority leader easier than that of majority leader.
"It's easier to play defense," one Democratic aide said.
But the initiative will lie with the Republicans. They may try again to authorize oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, though there is little reason to think they could break the filibuster that would certainly be mounted. Fifty-one votes will also be enough to confirm many judicial nominations that would be buried in committee under the Democrats. But that certainly does not apply to a conservative Supreme Court nominee, whom Democrats would feel obliged to filibuster.
The partisan gridlock of this fall had many legislative casualties, including reauthorization of the 1996 welfare law, a model of Clinton-Republican cooperation. The House passed legislation to renew the law, but a Senate Finance Committee approach never came to a vote. Democrats want more money for child care than Mr. Bush has proposed, and they also want more credit given for education and training to satisfy the minimum work requirements in the law. 
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, who is about to resume his old role as majority leader, said yesterday: "So much of what we need to do is obvious. Just take the list of what we didn't get done this year, and we need to work on those. We need to have a budget, to begin with. We need pension reform, welfare reform. We need to do more in education. Let's quit talking about doing something for low-income elderly that need prescription drugs. Let's look at what we can do to target some tax cuts that would help the economy. Let's have fiscal restraint. Let's begin to get control on the spending."
But Mr. Lott also acknowledged that it would take a while. He said: "The Senate was designed by our forefathers to be very slow and difficult to move. And boy, they succeeded."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ari Fleischer, White House press secretary, said the election "increased the likelihood of getting things done for the American people." (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Victory, and Challenges

BYLINE:  By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

 BODY:
Like Ronald Reagan, who was underestimated by those who saw him only as a superficial actor, President Bush is often taken too lightly by opponents preoccupied by his mangled syntax and his seemingly shaky grasp of issues. That is less likely to happen after Tuesday.
 The Republican victories in the midterm elections were remarkable in historical context. No other president since Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1934 has seen his party gain ground in the Senate and the House two years into his first term. Mr. Bush and his chief strategist, Karl Rove, devised a closing campaign blitz-krieg for the president that paid dividends, especially in the party's Southern stronghold. 
 Still, the Republican pickups in the House were relatively small, and in the Senate the entire margin of control was provided by narrow victories in a pair of races where the Democrats fielded replacement candidates -- in Minnesota, where former Vice President Walter F. Mondale stood in for Paul Wellstone, who was killed in a plane crash last month, and in Missouri, where Senator Jean Carnahan, who was seeking to fill out the rest of the term won by her husband, Mel, killed in a similar accident two years ago.
In a CBS News poll taken on the eve of the voting, only 27 percent of voters said their Congressional votes would be cast in support of Mr. Bush. The majority, 55 percent, said the president would be no factor in their voting, and 15 percent said they would be voting against him. But if Mr. Bush favorably influenced a quarter of the electorate, that was a lot, especially in a hard-fought campaign.
How much Mr. Bush will be able to achieve on Capitol Hill remains to be seen. On many issues, party lines do not hold, as Senator Tom Daschle found to his regret, and the president has few votes to spare. Sixty votes, not 52 or 53, often constitute real working control in the Senate.
Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, hoping soon again to be the majority leader, gave much of the credit for Republican victories to Mr. Bush. "He put his prestige on the line," Mr. Lott said yesterday, "and I believe it made a huge difference in the election."
Trying to sound brave in the face of a stinging defeat, Mr. Daschle said yesterday of himself and his fellow Democrats: "We're not going away just because we lost. We're going to fight on for our beliefs."
But with a popular Republican in the White House, and Republicans sitting atop slim yet solid majorities in both chambers of Congress, who is to lead the fight for Democrats? From what power base? On what set of issues? Those were the most important questions facing the Democrats in the wake of their electoral failure Tuesday. There were no quick, easy answers.
Mr. Bush's successes in the election underscored a leadership vacuum within the Democratic Party in which its leaders in Washington may once again lose influence to newcomers at the state level.
Mr. Daschle was defended as an accomplished leader yesterday by Mr. Mondale. But recriminations were rife within the party, with many well-known figures questioning Mr. Daschle's decision to oppose Mr. Bush's plan for a Department of Homeland Security, which enabled Mr. Bush to build a campaign on the theme of national defense. That approach paid dividends in Georgia, among other places, where Representative Saxby Chambliss, a Republican, unseated Senator Max Cleland, who had voted against Mr. Bush.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, who is expected to relinquish his job as House minority leader, said that rekindled memories of Sept. 11 and the prospect of war in Iraq made it impossible for the Democrats' economic message to be heard. But that message was never very clear, if only because many Democratic incumbents supported the president's huge tax-cut package last year.
The outcome significantly weakened the presidential prospects of both Mr. Daschle and Mr. Gephardt in 2004, top Democratic handicappers said. Mr. Daschle is likely to hold onto his leadership post within the party; no challengers are currently in sight. He can take some solace from the fact that he apparently won his proxy battle with Mr. Bush in South Dakota, where Senator Tim Johnson, a close Daschle associate, eked out an exceedingly narrow victory, perhaps subject to recount, over the president's handpicked candidate, Representative John Thune. But the loss of the Senate is a dubious presidential credential.
As for Mr. Gephardt, he is widely expected by his colleagues to give up the leadership to devote more time to a second run for the White House. But quite apart from the fact that House members have historically found it difficult to win nomination for the presidency, Mr. Gephardt will carry an additional burden: for two years, he put all his chips into an ultimately futile bid to recapture the House, and he will shoulder some of the blame.
Another Democratic loser was Terry McAuliffe, the party's national chairman. Mr. McAuliffe was derided yesterday by New York Democrats who said he undermined the party's nominee for governor, H. Carl McCall, by publicly stating that he had withheld funds from the McCall campaign because he doubted the Democrat could win. Mr. McAuliffe is also linked to former President Bill Clinton, whose centrist policies, once highly successful, are now seen as a handicap to a party in need of a better-defined identity.
Although former Vice President Al Gore, the party's presidential nominee in 2000, could point to few achievements in Tuesday's results, he was singled out by disgruntled Democrats for the aggressive way in which he sounded the party's economic message during the campaign. If he chooses to run for president in 2004, he now looks like a slightly more formidable contender for the nomination.
But much of the leadership for the Democrats will have to come from their big-state governors.
They now control the governorships in four of the eight largest states, having held on to California and added Illinois, Pennsylvania and Michigan. Gov. Gray Davis of California, who won re-election, has not so far been able to cut much of a swath nationally. But the party has high hopes for Ed Rendell, the governor-elect of Pennsylvania, who is a well-seasoned Philadelphia and national politician, and for Michigan's governor-elect, Jennifer Granholm, the state's attorney general.

LENGTH: 606 words

HEADLINE: Thursday Morning Quarterbacks 

 BODY:
If Richard Gephardt goes through with plans to pass up another term as House minority leader, it could provide an opportunity for the Democrats to figure out exactly what they intend to stand for during the upcoming period of Republican domination on both sides of Congress. Mr. Gephardt certainly can't be blamed for everything that went wrong on Tuesday, but there's nothing like a bad election night to get a party focused on its identity problems.
 Both parties actually should be careful about the lessons they draw from the election. President Bush has a right to be a very happy man this week. It was his willingness to put his prestige on the line in three weeks of tireless, well-aimed campaigning that won the day for his party. Nevertheless, he would be mistaken to read too much into the results. 
 The president's personal popularity coupled with his party's savvy campaign strategy certainly could become the basis for a solid Republican majority in the future, but it is not there yet. On Tuesday the country continued to be split almost exactly down the middle. The Democrats' two most crippling losses occurred in Minnesota and Missouri, where the voting margins narrowed to practically nothing.
Obviously, a narrow win is better than a narrow loss, but Mr. Bush has a habit of interpreting even the tiniest margins of victory as mandates for sweeping change. The last time around he seized on an election in which he lost the popular vote as justification for pressing forward with a lopsided tax plan and other programs beloved by business interests and the conservative G.O.P. base. Now, having run to the center in order to win their critical races, the Republicans will be tempted to embark on an aggressively conservative agenda -- saddling the country with right-wing judges for the next 30 years or resurrecting some of their more repellent energy strategies, like opening up the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil drilling.
The Democrats, for their part, don't seem to be having much problem taking their defeats seriously. The one thing the party had plenty of yesterday was self-criticism, although there didn't seem to be a large supply of people willing to take personal responsibility for the loss of control of the Senate and the increased Republican majority in the House. Nancy Pelosi, the House minority whip, said the Democrats had failed utterly to distinguish themselves from the opposition. Representative Martin Frost of Texas, who like Ms. Pelosi wants to be a candidate for the leader's job if Mr. Gephardt steps aside, was arguing that the election proved the country was moving to the right and that the Democrats needed to follow suit.
Democrats are certainly frustrated by Republicans' skill at co-opting the rhetorical center. But it doesn't take a genius to realize that a party that wants to run on the nation's economic problems needs to have a coherent economic strategy first. Instead of explaining to the public why they felt long-term tax cuts for the wealthy were a bad idea, most Democrats in tight races either dodged the issue or voted with the president.
Mr. Bush's political genius has always been in defining a narrow list of issues he supports and then sticking to his message. The Democrats could do the same thing, rallying behind their popular positions on the environment and Social Security. But they must also figure out whether they are a party that disapproves of huge long-term tax cuts for the wealthiest sliver of the American population. If they can't agree on that one, there will be good reason for the rest of the country to wonder what exactly they stand for.

HEADLINE: Mr. Pitt's Belated Departure 

 BODY:
The most overdue concession statement on election night came not from a candidate but from Harvey Pitt, the beleaguered chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Under cover of the election returns, Mr. Pitt tendered his letter of resignation, advising President Bush that "the turmoil surrounding my chairmanship" was impeding the work of the S.E.C. 
 That's an understatement. His stewardship of the S.E.C., the key regulator of the stock market and of publicly traded companies, was nothing short of disastrous. The White House played a role in this debacle. It allowed Mr. Pitt to stay on the job just when the country most desperately needed strong leadership to restore investor confidence. In addition, the timing of the resignation was totally cynical. Not until the polls closed was Mr. Bush prepared to concede that he had put the wrong man in the job. 
 What sealed Mr. Pitt's fate was his hasty and ill-considered appointment of William Webster to run the new accounting oversight board, instead of a plausible watchdog over the industry. He failed to disclose to either the White House or the other S.E.C. commissioners that Mr. Webster had headed the audit committee of a company accused of serious improprieties. This could not have been appreciated by Andrew Card, the White House chief of staff, who had unwittingly urged Mr. Webster to take the job. 
President Bush must now hasten to appoint someone of stature -- preferably someone with a strong record regulating financial markets or prosecuting malfeasance -- to lead the S.E.C. The embattled agency's mission has never been more critical to the nation's well-being. For those needing a reminder of just how vital it is to restore confidence in the integrity of financial markets, Election Day also brought news that WorldCom's fraudulent accounting is now estimated to have exceeded an astonishing $9 billion.
The void created by Mr. Pitt's lack of credibility as a regulator empowered officials like New York's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, to pursue inquiries into Wall Street's tainted research. But the country is even better served if a stronger S.E.C. takes the lead in protecting investors. We hope the new auditing oversight board will also play an important role in preventing future Enrons and WorldComs. Mr. Webster is clearly not the right person to lead the board. He should resign, along with the S.E.C.'s chief accountant, Robert Herdman, who was involved in Mr. Webster's appointment.
The economy is in a frail state, as evidenced by yesterday's aggressive half-point interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. A crisis of confidence in the fairness of the financial system has contributed to the economy's woes. The S.E.C. now has to become a part of the solution.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: NEW YORK; 
If Pataki Has a Grander Wish, 3rd Term Could Be a Charm

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki woke up yesterday morning with an impressive victory behind him, but as he looks ahead he faces a governmental and political landscape very different from the one in which he has flourished during his first two terms.
 For most of the last six years, Mr. Pataki had the wind at his back. The economy was booming and revenues poured in from Wall Street at record levels, allowing him to cut taxes while expanding spending on popular government programs like health care, education and the environment. In an increasingly Democratic state, this fit nicely with his political ambitions, helping the Republican governor build a powerful winning coalition with support from reliably Democratic constituencies like unions, environmentalists and Hispanics. 
 Even as the economy slumped during this election year, Mr. Pataki managed to avoid deep cuts or tax increases that might have offended some of these supporters by using clever fiscal legerdemain and spending most of the savings the state had built up during the late 1990's. 
Now, however, Mr. Pataki must close a budget gap for the next fiscal year that most experts say will be at least $6 billion. The resulting pressure to cut spending will make it much harder for him to keep his new friends happy, especially if he keeps his promise not to raise taxes.
Even old allies in Albany are already signaling their distaste for cuts in the education and health care programs he promoted as successes during his campaign.
"I don't believe the governor is going to be looking backwards and going backwards," said the Republican majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno. "I don't see him cratering a quality of life that New Yorkers have been brought to enjoy."
But just as Mr. Pataki's political and governmental ambitions reinforced each other during his first two terms, they may do so again if the governor decides to seek national office during his third. Just as his spending initiatives helped build political relationships with New York liberals, shrinking the government could become an important credential for building bridges to conservative national Republicans if he tries to position himself for higher office or a job in the Bush administration.
The governor studiously avoids acknowledging national aspirations, but he is just as careful to avoid promising to serve out his term. "I'm very excited by my political future, serving as the governor of this great state," Mr. Pataki said yesterday.
But his advisers are not as reluctant to speculate about the next step for a politician who has risen to the pinnacle of state politics. If the vice presidency were to become available in the next election cycle, they say, President Bush might find it expedient to put a moderate Northeastern Republican who favors abortion rights on the ticket.
Much of that is out of Mr. Pataki's control and depends on what the national mood is in 2004. 
Should the most important issues in most Americans' minds shift from terrorism and war back to domestic matters like health care, then Mr. Pataki, a fiscal conservative who is viewed as a moderate on social issues, might become a more attractive candidate for vice president, these strategists said.
"If you are looking for a model of a Republican that can go into any Democratic constituency and get votes, George Pataki is at the top of the short list," said Kieran Mahoney, a Republican political consultant.
Mr. Pataki's victory on Tuesday was impressive by many standards. In New York City, where Democrats outnumber Republicans five to one, he received 39 percent of the vote, the best showing for any Republican since Nelson A. Rockefeller ran in 1970. Hispanics gave him about 38 percent of their vote, according to a study of election districts conducted yesterday by John Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. That is also a record for a Republican.
He defeated the Democratic challenger, H. Carl McCall, by 704,000 votes, or 16 percentage points. The only worse defeat for a Democrat in a governor's race came in 1998, when Mr. Pataki trounced Peter Vallone by one million votes, a margin of 21 percentage points.
"Clearly, back-to-back landslides in a five-to-three Democratic state has got to catch people's eyes," said Michael McKeon, the governor's campaign spokesman.
Representative John Sweeney, an upstate Republican who is close to the governor, said the party leaders "have to look at George Pataki at a national level for the lessons of how to survive in a tough environment."
The environment in Albany, however, is likely to get tougher. Democrats in the State Assembly increased their majority on Tuesday to 103 members, from 99. The Republicans who control the Senate also picked up a seat, giving them a 37-member majority.
The Senate and Assembly leaders both indicate that they will resist severe cutbacks, as will the unions. The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said yesterday that he would urge Mr. Pataki to go to his Republican colleagues in Washington and request more federal aid before considering cutting popular programs. He also suggested that Mr. Pataki's pledges not to raise taxes, lay off workers or increase tuitions and fares would be impossible to keep.
For his part, Mr. Pataki is confident about his ability to solve the state's fiscal problems, though he has not provided details.
"We will have our budget proposal when we have our budget proposal," he said yesterday. "We don't want to raise tuitions or taxes or fares."
Denis M. Hughes, the president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O, said that labor leaders would probably have greater access to the governor than ever before, thanks to the endorsements of many of the largest unions, but that it was unclear whether that will translate into fewer budget cuts.
"I've been doing politics for a long time, over 20 years, and I can't imagine a worse situation for working men and women than the situation we face, in terms of budget problems," said Mr. Hughes, whose organization did not endorse a candidate for governor.
Mr. Pataki rarely talks politics in public, so it is hard to know how he views the shifts in the political winds. He said that in his third term he would focus on the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan, a project that doubtless will be one of his legacies, good or bad. So far, he has played a low-key role in the plans for the site where the World Trade Center stood, partly out of political caution, but there is a general consensus within the administration and Legislature that the pace of redevelopment will pick up now.
Mr. Pataki also says one of his major goals will be to make upstate New York into a haven for emerging high-technology industries. He has sown the seeds, in the form of state grants and tax incentives, for research and development centers in all of the rusting cities along the old Erie Canal. 
He often talks about wanting to replace the old manufacturing industries that were born and thrived in the last century with a new wave of industries, like nanoelectronics, bioinformatics, genetic engineering and other cutting-edge technologies.
The governor wants to leave his mark on environmental policy, too. He has promised to make New York a leader in cutting greenhouse gases and promoting renewable energy sources like fuel cells, windmills and geothermal technology.
These goals may have to wait until the budget gap is dealt with, legislative leaders said. The true test of Mr. Pataki's new coalition with traditional Democrats may come when he introduces his budget proposal in January.
"In a real way, the budget will be a test of these new relationships," said one legislative aide.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Kids Today? Sharpton Grimaces

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK

 BODY:
IT began predictably enough, a political chat yesterday with the Rev. Al Sharpton. He blamed Democrats for their own Election Day rout, said they should have fought the president on Iraq and the economy, said the party had to get back to its roots.
 "They forgot: you don't imitate the opposition, you oppose it," he said. "There was no voter registration drive, nothing. I think they got what they asked for. Nothing." 
 Then the conversation changed direction. He said he was saddened by the younger generation of black America, saddened that too many young people are captivated by hip-hop, inured to violence, dismissive of public life and politics.
"I'm not speaking only as a civil rights leader," he said. "I have two daughters, 15 and 16. Who are they going to marry? Guys who think it's O.K. to call them a 'ho'? Here's the real problem: The drive, the ambition, the desire to reach higher goals seem to have been lost in this new generation, particularly of black men. This whole glorification of decadence, of acting like this is black culture. Black culture is striving, it's achieving."
Now this is Al Sharpton, who could be reinventing himself once again, molding himself into a more middle-class figure as he contemplates a run for president and promotes his new book, "Al on America" (Dafina Books, 2002). But he did sound, as he sat in his Harlem office yesterday, as if he meant what he was saying.
"We've allowed a whole generation to just say, 'Hey man, it's like that and it's cool and that's the black thing.' These kids don't aspire to anything. We've got to stop that." It was, he said, the responsibility of blacks -- political leaders, D.J.'s, preachers, teachers and others with influence -- to turn things around. "This is something that cannot be done by the white community."
Statistics showing that many more women than men attend the City University of New York, which has large black population, were revealing of the damaging values, he said; black women are not under pressure to be "macho," to deride education. Mr. Sharpton tells of a black student who was the first in her family to go to college. When her brothers and sisters learned that she was making straight A's, they said to her, " 'Oh, you acting white now?' Like there is something black about flunking."
THERE are Sharpton critics who would say he and other liberals created the problems he cites by contending that African-Americans have been victimized and by favoring permissive policies. Mr. Sharpton said that there had probably been too great an emphasis on victimization but, he added, "We've always fought for equal opportunity, never for irresponsibility."
Then what is the cause? He mentioned a few, including affluence, indulgence, progress that has given young people more options and a less urgent need to struggle, and the aging of political leaders. Mr. Sharpton, 48, noted that at pre-election rally the other night for H. Carl McCall, he and Bill Clinton were among the youngest political figures present. "And come on, with all due respect, you can't make Bill Clinton the leader of black America. It's insulting." 
But clearly the leadership of the Democratic Party is not prepared to risk alienating more conservative white voters by treating Mr. Sharpton as the leader of black America. Just as it wasn't comfortable giving Jesse Jackson too prominent a platform. Which could be why Mr. Sharpton may run for president so he can command his own platform.
Not that he wants for attention, some of it unwelcome. There's the persistent criticism of his controversial past and some unwanted popularity. Mr. Sharpton said it saddens him that he's often hailed on the streets by black men, impressed because he served jail time for demonstrating in Vieques.
"Well, I went to jail for a cause, not for snatching a pocketbook," he said. "That is a distorted, jaded credential. It's the baggy pants, it's 'Did you go to jail?' Nobody is challenging that this whole violent, sex-crazed type of matrix is not black culture."
Al Sharpton, going mainstream in middle age? "I don't care if you're Giuliani or Sharpton," he said, allowing a laugh. "When it hits home, it's another thing."

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: TRENDS; 
Victorious Democrats Credit Message and Machine

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Marveling at the ease with which Frank R. Lautenberg won New Jersey's United States Senate race, New Jersey Democratic leaders said today that Tuesday's election results were a testament to both the party's message and its political machine.
 Bonnie Watson Coleman, chairwoman of the Democratic State Committee, said that once Mr. Lautenberg replaced Senator Robert G. Torricelli on the ballot, he assumed control by preaching the core Democratic issues of abortion rights, gun control and environmental protection. Ms. Coleman said that the county chairmen also mounted a big get-out-the-vote effort that contributed to Mr. Lautenberg's comfortable 10-point margin of victory over the Republican Douglas R. Forrester. 
 "The party apparatus was up and running," she said gleefully at a press conference in the State House.
But Republicans, still reeling from last November's election, when they lost control of the governor's mansion and both houses of the Legislature, said they, too, could take some comfort from Tuesday's results. Republicans maintained their hold on 6 of the state's 13 seats in the House of Representatives and fared well in many local races.
The state Republican chairman, State Senator Joseph R. Kyrillos Jr., said that if the State Supreme Court had not allowed Mr. Lautenberg to replace Mr. Torricelli after the deadline for replacing candidates had passed, Republicans would have won their first United States Senate seat in New Jersey in 30 years.
"The trend would have been in reverse had the election taken place a month ago with a different candidate," he said. He added that Republicans have "half of the State Senate seats, nearly half of the Congressional delegation, half of the County Boards of Chosen Freeholders."
"We're going to have a lot of local successes," Senator Kyrillos said.
While some of members of the Forrester campaign have privately criticized the state Republican Party for failing to provide enough money and field support, Mr. Forrester himself had only kind words for the party. Speaking at a press conference today, Mr. Forrester said his defeat was caused by the candidate switch and the fact that he had to run two campaigns against better-financed opponents.
Among Republican activists, the loss re-ignited the simmering dispute between the moderate and conservative wings. The moderates, who have long dominated New Jersey's Republican Party, said Mr. Forrester's positions on gun control, abortion and the environment were simply too far to the right for a moderate state like New Jersey.
But some conservatives said that Mr. Forrester had spent so much time hedging on the positions that he had failed to energize the right-wing voters who make up the Republican base.
"The election results should be a wake-up call to Republicans," said Marie Tasy, director of New Jersey Right to Life. "They don't have the pro-life base to kick around any more."
While Mr. Lautenberg's victory extended the Democrats' winning streak over Republicans, it did little to alter the balance of power between the parties, and some political analysts warned that the Democrats should not mistake their current success for a mandate.
While James E. McGreevey was elected by a resounding margin last year, the Democrats' victory in the State Legislature was due more to a favorable redistricting map than any ideological shift toward the party. The fact that Democrats replaced Mr. Torricelli with a retired elder statesman like Mr. Lautenberg also suggests that the party has few rising young stars.
With legislative races scheduled for next year, Democrats also have to remember that for all the spoils of power, there is a built-in burden.
"The Democrats this year could just point the finger at Washington and blame Bush for the economy," said David Rebovich, a political science professor at Rider University. "Next year, New Jersey voters who are upset about high property taxes and a freeze in state aid to schools are going to be pointing the finger at them, and if they haven't produced, by making a difference in people's lives, they will pay the price."
