HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: THE OVERVIEW; 
VICTORIOUS REPUBLICANS PREPARING A DRIVE FOR BUSH AGENDA AND JUDGESHIP NOMINEES

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Republicans began setting plans yesterday to push forward a domestic agenda of tax cuts, a national energy policy, creation of a vast homeland security department and the confirmation of conservative judges as they savored a sweep of the midterm elections that gave them complete control of the Capitol.
 The Republican resurgence came after an election in which President Bush's party defied historical trends and expanded its control of the House and retook the Senate. Republicans captured three Democratic seats in the Senate, and held all but one of their own vulnerable seats. They were assured at least 51 seats in the 100-seat Senate. 
 The shift in power had deep implications for government policy and for the next presidential election, with Mr. Bush and Congressional Republicans emboldened and Democrats in disarray. 
Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, was ready to reclaim the role of majority leader only 17 months after he unexpectedly lost power when Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont became an independent. Mr. Lott was making plans for the lame-duck session of the outgoing Congress next week and for the 108th Congress, which takes office in January.
"We're ready to go to work," said Mr. Lott, who was already in his office at 7 yesterday morning when he took a congratulatory call from the president. "As I've said to others, 'Let's roll.' "
The jubilation among Republicans was captured in a memorandum that Matthew Dowd, Mr. Bush's campaign pollster, sent to party leaders saying, "The unprecedented, historic nature of last night's results cannot be overstated."
Even so, Republicans remembered how they had overestimated their mandate in the era of Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the House, and vowed not to repeat that mistake. One senior Republican leadership aide said: "I don't think we're going to overreach. If you overpromise, you usually underdeliver and create a whole bunch of problems for yourself."
The Republicans' control of the Senate was sealed when Senator Jean Carnahan of Missouri conceded defeat early yesterday morning. Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, recruited as a last minute stand-in for Senator Paul Wellstone, who died in plane crash, was also rebuffed in his comeback bid.
Senator Mary L. Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, will have to defend her seat in a runoff election in December because she failed to draw 50 percent of the vote.
A new cast of senators, some of them prominent conservatives, stood ready to take control of the Senate's committees. In some significant changes, Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah takes control of the Judiciary Committee. Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma becomes chairman of the budget committee, and Senator James M. Inhofe of Oklahoma assumes the chairmanship of the environment and public works panel. 
Mr. Bush, who put his prestige on the line and campaigned doggedly for vulnerable Republicans, was credited by both parties with providing the energy and personal popularity that propelled Republicans to victory, strengthening his own position as the parties now turn their attention to the 2004 presidential election.
The White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer, portrayed the outcome of the election, which caught even many Republicans by surprise, as a statement that Americans wanted an end to Washington gridlock.
"I think what Democrats and Republicans and independents and people who just plain don't care about politics want from Washington is leaders who come to Washington to get something done," Mr. Fleischer said. "And that's the part of Washington that the president would like to expand."
He said Mr. Bush would now "fight for his ideas and fight for his principles," putting a sharp focus on the weak economy and domestic security.
Mr. Bush chose not to speak publicly yesterday about the results, a silence that Mr. Fleischer characterized as a "touch of graciousness."
Following the president's lead, Republicans in Congress were carefully choosing their words and seeking to avoid the triumphant tones of 1994 when they swept into control of the House and Senate.
Still, Mr. Fleischer's remarks appeared to put battered and dispirited Democrats on notice that they risked political peril if they tried to block Mr. Bush's agenda by using the Senate power of unlimited debate.
Despite the Republicans' success, Democrats retained enough strength to have the ability to tie the Senate in procedural knots.
A defiant Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, said: "We're not going to go away. We may not be in the majority, but we're going to fight just as hard for the things we believe in now as we have before."
Still, Democratic leaders disagreed over how to proceed and found themselves arguing over what went wrong in a campaign in which they had hoped to ride the weak economy to traditional midterm gains in Congress. 
The election dealt setbacks to the presidential aspirations of Mr. Daschle, of South Dakota, who once again becomes minority leader, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader.
Mr. Gephardt, who is exploring a presidential run, decided yesterday not to seek re-election as minority leader, a senior aide said, a step that left him freer to pursue his own independent stand on issues.
In the recriminations over the Democrats' losses, two House members had already called for him to move aside. "It is now clearly time for him to step down," said one, Representative Peter Deutsch of Florida.
A fierce leadership race erupted between Representatives Nancy Pelosi of California and Martin Frost of Texas.
Congress is set to return next week for a lame-duck session, and it is possible that Republicans could take control swiftly. The timing will depend on whether Dean Barkley, an independent whom Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota named as a short-term replacement for Mr. Wellstone, decides to caucus with the Republicans.
Republicans could also take control if James M. Talent, a former Republican representative, is quickly seated to replace Mrs. Carnahan. Their matchup was a special election for the remaining term of Mrs. Carnahan's husband, Mel, who was elected in 2000 after he died in a plane crash. She was appointed to the seat.
Mr. Lott made clear that he hoped to wrap up the session within days and put off most major legislation until next year.
"I'm not an advocate of lame-duck sessions whether I'm in the minority or the majority," he said.
Some Republican priorities were instantly clear.
"So much of what we need to do is obvious," Mr. Lott said at a news conference. "Just take the list of what we didn't get done this year." Other new initiatives were expected to be advanced by Mr. Bush in his State of the Union address early next year.
Republicans said they would push to rein in spending and make Mr. Bush's 10-year $1.35 trillion tax cut permanent, and possibly propose other tax cut measures, like a new capital gains reduction and larger breaks for investor losses. They hoped to revive Mr. Bush's stalled national energy plan, including his call for drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. They also want to press for passage of legislation creating a vast domestic security department.
They also wanted to pass stalled legislation on welfare, on creation of a prescription drug benefit, on giving religious charities a larger role in providing social services, and possibly a measure banning an abortion procedure that Republicans have dubbed "partial-birth abortion."
Mr. Lott also homed in on judicial appointments, and other Senate Republicans said they expected the handful of Bush judicial nominees who have been delayed in committee to receive swift consideration.
But he also indicated that he was cautious about moving forward too precipitously. 
"I've learned from experience," he said. "I'm getting a second chance to do this job. I hope I will do it, you know better than last time, and learn from those experiences. And one of them is, you don't take off down the trail, saying what you are going to do, without a lot of consultation."

A chart yesterday showing the balance of power in the House and the Senate based on election results at 8 p.m. on Wednesday misstated the Republican margin in the House. It was 24 seats, not 10.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTIONS: THE MINORITY PARTY; 
Democrats Catalog Mistakes; Gephardt Ceding House Post

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
The Democratic Party turned on itself yesterday in a bitter if familiar round of recriminations over what many officials described as an election night debacle. Democratic leaders said the outcome had left the party without any clear leaders and hampered its hope of winning back the White House.
 One of the party's two most prominent elected leaders, Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, said through aides last night that he would not seek re-election as minority leader when House Democrats caucus next week. They said he was stepping down from his leadership post to prepare for a likely presidential race, but other Democrats said that Mr. Gephardt faced the prospect of a challenge from dispirited party members critical of how he waged an election in which Democrats lost seats to the Republicans. Page B6. 
 Across the nation, Democratic leaders argued that the party and its candidates had failed in this campaign season to offer voters a clear alternative to Republican policies, and had done little beyond trying to stir existing anxieties about the state of the nation and the economy. 
In particular, some Democratic leaders said the party had made a mistake in failing to engage President Bush on his tax cut -- one clear area of economic disagreement between the two parties -- and by falling in line behind Mr. Bush when he pressed the issue of Iraq in the midst of a fall election 
"The national Democratic Party never defined the Democratic agenda," said Dick Harpootlian, the chairman of the South Carolina Democratic Party. "Other than being sort of whiney as we got drug into the Iraq war, we never really defined our position on the economy, we never said what we would do differently."
"We have no message this year other than we're not Bush," Mr. Harpootlian said. "Well, guess what? Eighty percent of the people like Bush."
Douglas Sosnik, the White House political director under Bill Clinton, said: "I don't think that the Democratic Party gave the folks out in the states any reason to have passion about the midterms, in order to energize them to vote. That's an arduous task in the best of circumstances -- which this is not."
Al Gore, the former vice president and a potential candidate for president, said in an interview with ABC News that Democrats should not "mistake the magnitude of this loss -- there has to be a major regrouping."
"It means that the Democrats have to be the loyal opposition in fact and not just name," Mr. Gore said.
In California, Mayor Willie Brown of San Francisco was unsparing in his criticism of party leaders last night.
"I don't think we Democrats are speaking to our base with the level of enthusiasm we should and we don't make it a priority," Mr. Brown said. "In any campaign, you first maximize your own strength, and then add to it. We've been doing just the reverse, doing the best we can to get swing voters and then assuming our base was there. Well our base was there, but it was at home and not at the polls."
The loss forced a day of soul-searching and hand-wringing among Democratic officials intent on figuring out what had gone wrong, and what it meant for the vibrancy of a party that is now completely shut out of power. While Democrats had grown increasingly pessimistic about the prospect of winning back the House as Election Day approached, few expected that they would lose more seats in the House, while losing complete control of the Senate.
The outcome posed a particular problem for Mr. Gephardt, because he had invested so much time and prestige into trying to win back the House. Mr. Gephardt's aides had said before the election that, assuming his party did not win the majority, he was almost certain to step down to run for president as soon as the election was over.
Mr. Gephardt moved ahead with that decision in the midst of one of the darker days for Democrats in recent times, and on a day of turmoil in his conference. "Having suffered historic losses in the House is not the best way to introduce yourself as a president," said one senior Democratic strategist who is sympathetic to Mr. Gephardt.
The day loomed as well as a huge loss for the party's high-flying national chairman, Terry McAuliffe. Mr. McAuliffe appeared staggered by the outcome as he went through a day of appearances, trying to explain why his predictions of victory had been so wrong.
Mr. McAuliffe disputed criticism from some Democrats that the party shared much of the blame for what went wrong, arguing that Democrats had not been able to overcome Mr. Bush's popularity or Republican spending. "I could clearly make the argument that George Bush should have done a lot better last night," the Democratic chairman said.
While there was criticism in some quarters of Mr. McAuliffe, most was focused on elected officials -- in particular, Mr. Gephardt and Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader, another prospective presidential contender for 2004.
But again and again, Democrats argued that the source of the party's problems this year was that it had failed to provide voters with a reason to throw out a party in power. 
"We needed to be more specific," said Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida. "To be effectively heard, you have to be both the diagnostician -- what is your definition of the problem -- and second, the prescriber, where you suggest what to do about the problem."
The main point of dispute among many Democrats was whether the party should have directly engaged the Republicans on the $1.35 trillion tax cut passed under Mr. Bush, or on the president's push for a resolution to allow him to oust President Saddam Hussein of Iraq from office. Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Daschle had decided in the midst of the campaign to agree to Mr. Bush's request for authority, a decision that some liberal Democrats criticized as a political calculation.
Joe Lockhart, a White House press secretary under Mr. Clinton, said Democrats might have made a mistake in failing to draw a clear line between the parties on the issues that dominated the Congressional agenda this year. 
"It wasn't crazy to follow this strategy," Mr. Lockhart said. "But I think that given that it failed, we have to sit down and figure out what to do -- and the first thing we need to do is how to engage people directly."
But Chris Lehane, who served as Mr. Gore's press secretary in his failed 2000 presidential bid, said: "We have no one to blame but ourselves. In a time where we saw the greatest loss of wealth in the history of the world, we were devoid of a message -- namely, not taking on the Bush tax boon for the wealthy."
Other party leaders, though, said that the Democrats could not reasonably argue against the tax plan, since so many members had supported it when it passed, and that coming out against tax cuts would hardly have been helpful to embattled incumbents in states like Missouri and Minnesota. Indeed, Mr. Gore gave a speech on economic policy in the middle of the campaign and repeatedly declined to say whether he thought Mr. Bush's tax cut should be rescinded.
To make matters worse for Democrats, the problems that the tax cut caused for Democrats this year seem likely to persist over the next two years as Democrats prepare to for the presidential campaign. 
"The tax cut put the Democrats into a box that we still have not figured our way out of," said Howard Wolfson, the executive director of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. "We are going to have this argument in 2004: It is unavoidable."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 8, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about Democrats' assessment of their electoral defeat referred incorrectly in some copies to the size of the tax cut passed last year, which some leaders said the party should have criticized more strongly. It was $1.35 trillion, not $1.3 billion.

SECTION: Section A; Column 3; Foreign Desk; Pg. 4

HEADLINE: Cairo Journal; 
Saddam's 'Weapons' Costly, 'Bush-Sharon' Cheap

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
The dates nicknamed "Saddam Hussein's Weapons of Mass Destruction" were not selling so well today, the first day of Ramadan, at the wholesale market where thrifty Cairenes purchase their holiday treats. 
 It is something of a tradition for purveyors of the dates, hazelnuts, dried apricots and other delicacies used to break the daily fast at sundown to give pet names to their dozen or so date varieties. 
 "Yasir Arafat" and the revived best seller from last year, "Osama bin Laden," were already all but gone -- a reflection that the plight of the Palestinians and the fight against terrorism remain the preoccupations of the moment. 
"The names attract the attention of the clients," said Khaled Hussein, shouting above the din in the market, situated underneath the ramps leading to one of the main bridges across the Nile. "Even if they are sad, they stop and look and laugh." 
The "Mass Destruction" moniker went to a particularly long, somewhat costly date imported from Iraq. 
"Look at them, they look just like Scud missiles," said another seller, Sayid Mahmoud, scooping one out of an overflowing burlap sack. "Sales are just O.K. I think people are waiting to see what happens with America. I'm sure if he uses his missiles, sales will improve."
Mostly, shoppers seemed to find the "Mass Destruction" dates too expensive. Sellers too, acknowledged that it was a bad year. With the Egyptian pound sinking against the dollar, prices for some imported goods were up 50 percent over last Ramadan. 
"The holiday spirit of Ramadan is basically gone, especially among the young people with all their unemployment, their frustrations," said Ashraf Mustafa Amin, the 33-year-old owner of a factory for Pharaonic souvenirs. "The problem is that every year the situation does not improve. In fact, every year it gets worse and worse."
To relieve their doldrums, most Egyptians and, indeed, people across the Arab world look forward to the special programs that television stations roll out to take advantage of the mass audience gathering to eat. Ramadan marks the holiest month on the calendar, but over the generations the original spirit of religious reflection and good works has gradually been overshadowed by extended nightly meals. 
Usually one program pulls out ahead of the pack, because of its stars or controversial nature. Last year the issue was polygamy, with a show that glorified a middle-class man who married the maximum four wives allowed under Islam. 
This year the early lead seems to be going to "Knight Without a Horse," a series that has already received worldwide attention, even though the first episode was not scheduled to be shown until late tonight. 
The Bush administration encouraged Arab governments to ban the series because it incorporates ideas from the long discredited "Protocols of the Elders of Zion," an anti-Semitic forgery by the czarist secret police that purported to lay out a plan by Jews to dominate the world. 
With some 20 Arab stations set to broadcast "Knight Without a Horse," the producers, script writers and actors held a news conference Monday to defend the program, saying it merely depicted the early Arab struggle against Zionism and foreign occupation. 
Muhammad Sobhi, the screenwriter and a main actor, said he recognized that the protocols were a forgery, but said that in any event, it appeared to be the blueprint of Israeli plans to deny the Palestinians a state of their own. 
There was a certain degree of gloating among the creators because of the attention, not least because so many Arab intellectuals say they are weary of being preached to about human rights and other values when Washington does nothing to stop Israel from using missiles against Palestinian homes. 
"If this series scares the United States and the Zionist entity," Mr. Sobhi said, using the name for Israel favored by those who abhor its existence, "then we will make many more like it."
The Egyptian government spokesman, Nabil Osman, issued a three-page statement expressing surprise at the outcry.
"It is neither acceptable nor reasonable to selectively heap accusations of anti-Semitism on artists simply because they sympathize with the plight of the Palestinian people and thus are critical of Israeli policies and practices," the statement said, adding that banning the series would stifle artistic creativity. 
Oddly enough, at the same time that the government was rising to its defense, Dream TV, the mostly privately owned satellite station that produced the 41 episodes, was being officially reprimanded for an earlier broadcast -- a talk show last month that discussed female masturbation. An oversight board barred the piece from being rebroadcast and admonished the station to treat delicate topics with greater sensitivity. 
Of course, many in television circles believe that the real root of the warning lay elsewhere. Dream TV had also recently broadcast remarks by Muhammad Hassanein Heikal, a towering figure among Egyptian thinkers, in which he disparaged the idea that President Hosni Mubarak might be succeeded by his son Gamal. Mr. Heikal said it was unthinkable that Mr. Mubarak, 74, could seek a fifth term when his current one expires in 2005 and noted that the president himself had rejected the idea of a dynasty.
Both topics -- the matter of succession and Mr. Mubarak's son -- are off-limits in Egyptian media, and either is likely to send Mr. Mubarak into a rage. 
Egyptians shopping for their holiday dates today waved away such questions, saying they were too burdened by economic troubles to worry about things like succession or outside criticism of what appeared on Egyptian television. 
One sure sign of that was that lots of people were buying the absolute lowest quality of dates, nicknamed "Bush and Sharon."
"They are the worst; not sweet at all, very bitter," said one seller, Mr. Hussein. "The others are all healthy, very sweet, from good palms. We expect people to buy these cheap ones either for charity or maybe to throw at each other."
One shopper was buying two brimming bags of "Bush and Sharon" dates, about 22 pounds for about $5. 
"At least they are so tough that I know they won't have any mites in them," he said, adding, "It's the most I can afford."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cairenes shopping for dates yesterday, the first day of Ramadan. "Saddam Hussein's Weapons of Mass Destruction" are in the third bag from left. (Mohamed el-Dakhakhny for The New York Times)

 ATTRACTIONS

Museums and Sites

ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. Tomorrow at 3 p.m., "Shattering the Glass House: 19th-Century Women Photographers," a lecture by Denise Rompilla of St. John's University. Also on view, "Looking Back at Clear Comfort," photographs that Austen took of the house (formerly called Clear Comfort) when she lived there. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; children under 6, free. Information: (718) 816-4506.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 36-01 35th Avenue, at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens. One of the largest collections of moving-image artifacts. On display: "Robert De Niro: Costume and Character," with more than two dozen costumes. Opening tomorrow, "Directed by Martin Scorsese," a screening series running through Dec. 29. Screenings tomorrow, at 2 p.m., "Mean Streets" (1973) and "Italianamerican" (1974). Sunday at 2 p.m., "Who's That Knocking at My Door?" (1968), "What's a Nice Girl Like You Doing in a Place Like This?" (1963), "It's Not Just You, Murray" (1964) and "The Big Shave" (1967); at 4:30 p.m., "Mean Streets." Mr. Scorsese will also discuss his film career tomorrow at 5 p.m.; the discussion is sold out. Also screening, tomorrow and Sunday at 6:30 p.m., "Duel in the Sun" (1946), directed by King Vidor. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; and by appointment. Film and video screenings are free with admission unless otherwise noted. Museum admission: $8.50; 65+ and students, $5.50; 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and younger, free. Information: ammi.org or (718) 784-0077.

MERCHANT'S HOUSE MUSEUM, 29 East Fourth Street, East Village. This preserved late-Federal brick house with a Greek Revival interior, once owned by Seabury Tredwell, a wealthy hardware dealer, was built in 1832. The house holds the original furniture, clothing and personal articles of the Tredwells, who lived there for nearly 100 years. Self-guided tours are available on weekdays; guided tours on Saturdays and Sundays. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and 62+, $3; members and children under 12, free. Information: (212) 777-1089.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
White Hot: From Rap To Riches

BYLINE:  By ELVIS MITCHELL 

 BODY:
THE mission of "8 Mile" is essentially to garner sympathy for a white rapper involved in an old-school shootout -- a rap contest. This may be the final frontier for pop, more unbelievable than the prospect of launching a member of 'N Sync into orbit. The film's star, Eminem, doesn't appear to have a great deal of range, but he can play himself. Even though the protagonist is named Jimmy Smith, the thoughtful "8 Mile" is a raw version of the rapper's own story.
 This is basically an 80's go-for-it movie (the picture feels like some odd combination of "Flashdance" and "Purple Rain"), and the director, Curtis Hanson, working with a screenplay by Scott Silver, has done a fine job of giving it a soul, though it's a gloomy, peeling-paint one. The movie has the echoey, haunted heart of Johnny Cash's cover of Nine Inch Nails' "Hurt": maybe the project doesn't make sense in the abstract, but once you submit to it, it works. 
 One of a handful of films made in Detroit, "8 Mile" doesn't feature the Motown renaissance that Mayor Coleman A. Young dreamed of in the 1970's. Instead it's the beaten-down city: 8 Mile refers to the line of demarcation between Detroit and suburban, mostly white Oakland County. (The joke is that Oakland County is home to both the megastar white rapper Eminem and the parents who are most afraid of his influence on their kids.)
Mr. Hanson's last two pictures, "L.A. Confidential" and "Wonder Boys," were about the trouble that words can cause. And Jimmy Smith, who is called Rabbit and is determined to be a rapper, spends a great deal of time in hot water because of his mouth. When "8 Mile" begins, Rabbit has moved back into the trailer park home where his mother (Kim Basinger) and little sister Lily (Chloe Greenfield) live, to find that one of his high school friends is now involved with his mom. Rabbit has just broken up with his girlfriend and belongs nowhere. "8 Mile" could be set in a Johnny Cash song, since Rabbit unabashedly refers to himself as white trash.
Rabbit doesn't even fit in at the rap contests in the Detroit club run by his black pal, the dreadlocked entrepreneur Future (Mekhi Phifer). The gray, rust-belt industrial tones captured by the cinematographer Rodrigo Prieto ("Amores Perros") add ominousness to the restroom where Rabbit is sweating as he anxiously waits to take his turn onstage. It's Mr. Hanson's way of cooking up tension. We're always waiting for something to happen, and it occurs at the strangest times and in the strangest juxtapositions, for example, a fight at a radio station. The struggle plays out silently in the background, while the foreground action -- an interview in a soundproofed studio -- goes on undisturbed.
And it is backstage at the Detroit club, before Rabbit goes out to confront the crowd and compete, that we become aware of his odd remoteness. This is partly because Eminem gives little as an actor. In some ways he's very similar to another white pop-star-turned-actor, Mark Wahlberg. Both have soft, sandpapery voices and a stern politeness when they speak. They're going to make each word count, right down to never dropping a G from the end of an -ing.
Eminem, though, has a relentless, unblinking stare. (It's the expression seen on gifted kids in horror movies.) In contrast to the intensity of his gaze, Eminem's facial muscles are often slack. He has lost weight for his first starring role, and the cleft in his chin has deepened, becoming another shadowy place where he seems to be hiding things. He holds back, waiting, a little nervous. It's only when he gets angry that he comes to life and his voice takes on a shank's edge, dull and rusty.
Rabbit's main competitors -- Papa Doc (Anthony Mackie) and his Leaders of the Free World squad -- often dismiss him as "Elvis," a white boy appropriating black culture. But when Rabbit starts hollering or rapping, he does indeed give off the explosion of vitality that Presley had while singing in his very early movies. (Here, he becomes the real Slim Shady.)
And like Presley in most of his films, Eminem is given an actressy flirt of a love interest. Her name is Alex, played by the smudge-eyed Brittany Murphy, who can't even walk into a room without sizing up the camera. Exuding a baby-girl narcissism, Alex -- who wants to become a model and get out of Detroit -- looks at Rabbit as just another opportunity. Taryn Manning, in a much smaller role as Rabbit's ex-girlfriend, is far more believable and makes a bigger impact.
Rabbit keeps his rocket-from-the-crypt ambition focused, doing day work for little money at an auto stamping plant. His real life begins at night when he goes out to compete in hip-hop contests. But he is so unnerved by appearing onstage that, for most of the picture, Future's faith in the white rapper's skills seems misplaced. Only Future and the millions of record buyers in the moviegoing audience have any idea of Rabbit's abilities. The film is like a rap version of "The Incredible Hulk," and when Rabbit triumphantly rocks the joint at the end, he's flushed, every vein in his body distended -- the underdog giving vent to his rage and winning the crowd over. The movie exploits Eminem's slight physical presence, saving the pop-star magnetism for the climax.
"8 Mile," which opens nationwide today, is full of Detroit in-jokes, like Rabbit's referring to himself as "810," one of Oakland County's area codes. And there's a grand-slam joke using the song "Sweet Home Alabama," an omnipresent Motor City radio favorite that has extra resonance in Detroit, a place that refuses to give up its rock 'n' roll roots. It's too bad the movie can't acknowledge that although Detroit was late to rap, it was the birthplace of everything from Motown to the MC5 to Kid Rock. (Kid Rock can also be found on the soundtrack, alongside rap stars like Eric B. and Rakim.) In musical terms, Detroit is like Weimar Berlin, a place where economic and social turbulence create art.
The question is, does "8 Mile" do a convincing job of evoking hip-hop culture? Is the movie real enough for the rap world to take seriously, a question that, applied to himself, has dogged Eminem personally throughout his career. It should be noted that standards are a lot lower for rap movies. After all, Eminem had an almost secret cameo a year ago in "The Wash," a slovenly comedy starring his mentor, Dr. Dre. "8 Mile" is neither as real nor as harrowing as the recent crime film "Paid in Full," which may be the "Mean Streets" of rap. The spirit of rap suffuses "Paid" just as "Streets" encapsulated the intensity of pop.
And what Mr. Hanson has done with "8 Mile" is make a pop movie instead of a movie about pop. There's nothing disreputable about this. The movie is a success on its own terms because the director doesn't condescend to pop music. (As evidenced by the way he used music in "L.A. Confidential," he respects its powers.)
Mr. Hanson keeps the picture alive with the interplay between Rabbit and his crew, which gives it a verbal slapstick flow. The director is great with guys letting down their guard when women aren't around, rapping an impromptu "Pimpin' Ain't Easy" and breaking into brawling locker-room chatter. A winning touch is giving Rabbit's sweet, hapless friend Bob (Evan Jones) the big-money nickname Cheddar.
But the revelation is Mekhi Phifer, who shows a witty cool as Future. Between "8 Mile" and "Paid in Full," he's given his career a revivifying jolt, playing these big-brother roles with an impassioned trust. By not straining to show he's up to the demands of a major picture, he succeeds.
It's too bad "8 Mile" isn't totally as generous as Future -- whose real name in the movie is David Porter, which could well be a tribute to Isaac Hayes's songwriting partner. (The movie is full of flavorful pop allusions, including a scene that shows Douglas Sirk's race melodrama "Imitation of Life" playing on a television set. Like Sirk, Mr. Hanson makes movies about coming to grips with one's true identity.)
"8 Mile" could do without an unnecessary class swipe. In a final throwdown, Rabbit clowns a competitor by revealing that the guy went to suburban Detroit Cranbrook, one of the finest private schools in the country. The death of Jam Master Jay, the turntablist of Run-DMC, whose members all hailed from middle-class backgrounds in Queens, reminds us that what's important is the talent you bring to the stage.
On the other hand, the film embraces the absurdity of a white rapper who takes down a brother in a club full of black people -- perhaps more black people than own Eminem records. But this fantasy does acknowledge that rap has conquered the world of the young. It's the primary way kids of all races communicate. It's inadvertently hilarious that Eminem scores in this way; with his long, noble nose and porcelain skin, he could be one of the Mies van der Rohe structures on the Cranbrook campus.
"8 Mile" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes strong language, joint smoking, sex scenes and smoking-barrel violence.

HEADLINE: Debt Crisis For Venture In Cellphones In Mexico 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH MALKIN 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
Vodafone Group and Verizon Communications spent over $2 billion in Mexico to buy what was once a promising wireless telephone company in one of the world's fastest growing markets. Their gamble has not paid off.
 On Wednesday the company -- Grupo Iusacell, the No. 3 wireless provider in Mexico -- said it would have a hard time repaying its $840 million in debts as they were currently structured and was seeking talks with creditors about restructuring them. Up to $415 million of the debt will come due in mid-2004. 
 The announcement came a day after Standard & Poor's downgraded Iusacell's credit rating to CCC+, well below investment grade, and said a further reduction was possible. 
"The downgrade and credit-watch placement reflect growing concerns about Iusacell's liquidity and refinancing ability in a time of increased financial market volatility and uncertainty in the telecommunications industry," Patricia Calvo said in her report. 
Iusacell's American depository receipts, which traded as high as $4.58 in January, closed unchanged today at 68 cents. 
Iusacell has been steadily losing revenue and market share to its two larger rivals -- America Movil, the dominant carrier with almost 80 percent of the Mexican wireless market, and Telefonica Moviles of Spain, which has stepped up its investment in Mexico and surpassed Iusacell to become the No. 2 provider. 
Analysts say that Iusacell's problems stem from a decision to concentrate on the kind of service common in the United States, where customers sign a service contract and are billed for calls after they are made. In Mexico, such service is practical only for high-income customers.
The vast majority of the explosive growth in Mexican cellphone use -- it has grown more than eightfold in four years -- has come in prepaid service. Users pay in advance for a set number of calling minutes by buying a calling card. That system lets lower-income people control carefully how much they spend on the phone, and it relieves the phone provider of most of the credit risk. 
"My opinion is simply that they missed the opportunity on the prepaid side," said Ignacio Ponce de Leon, a bond analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities in New York. "If they had gone with that earlier, they would have done better." 
Even Iusacell's current customers are defecting. Its subscriber rolls fell by about 1 percent in the third quarter, and revenue was 25 percent lower than in the third quarter of 2001. "They are losing to competitors," Mr. Ponce de Leon said.
A Verizon predecessor, Bell Atlantic, first bought a small stake in Iusacell in 1993. It then expanded the stake to 39.4 percent and took operating control in 1997, investing $1.2 billion in all. The company's Mexican founder, Carlos Peralta Quintero, sold his 34.5 percent stake to Vodafone for $974.3 million early this year. The remaining shares are publicly traded. At current prices, its total market capitalization is just $61 million.
To revive the company's fortunes, its chief executive, Carlos Espinal Guifarro, has laid off workers and cut back investment. But most importantly, he has promised that the company will soon offer seamless service in both Mexico and the United States. "That might be what turns the tide," Mr. Ponce de Leon said.
Iusacell executives declined to comment for this article.

HEADLINE: Australian Bank's Earnings Soar on Housing Lending 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

 BODY:
The housing boom in Australia is buoying the country's big banks, but it is being tempered by weakness overseas.
 Yesterday, the country's largest lender, National Australia Bank, reported $1.9 billion in net income for the year ended Sept. 30, a 62 percent increase from the previous year. But when one-time items were excluded, the bank's earnings increased 56.1 percent. 
 The bank, based in Melbourne, said home mortgage lending had risen 18 percent, but income from insurance and fund management had fallen 26 percent because of what its chief financial officer, Richard McKinnon, told shareholders were "the worst investment markets for over a decade."
The bank also cut its earnings forecast for this fiscal year. Investors responded by bidding the bank's stock down 5.4 percent yesterday.
"In April, we were expecting to see signs of a reasonable recovery in the U.S. and in Europe; this will not now be the case," said Frank J. Cicutto, the bank's managing director and chief executive.
National's nearest rival, Commonwealth Bank of Australia, warned last week that falling global stock prices would hurt profits, so shareholders were braced for similar news from National, analysts said. But weaker results from corporate banking and from banks it owns in Britain and Ireland were more of a surprise. 
Analysts said the banks' faltering results signaled that Australia's consumer-driven economy could not shrug off the effects of a severe drought and lower demand for Australian exports much longer.
"It's a reflection of the fact that we've had two economies in Australia: a housing-led boom and a fairly subdued business sector," said Ross Brown of Deutsche Bank in Sydney.
On Wednesday, Australia's prime minister, John Howard, warned that the country's economy would probably grow only about 3 percent this year, lower than the nearly 4 percent the government had forecast.
Anyone watching property markets in Sydney or Melbourne could be forgiven for thinking that Mr. Howard was talking about a different country. Aided by government incentives and low interest rates, Australia's housing market is so hot that rents are falling as tenants line up to become homeowners. But Australia's benchmark stock index has fallen roughly 11 percent this year.
National's results benefited from much smaller one-time charges this year than last. It managed to book a small profit on the sale of its American mortgage lending unit, HomeSide Lending, to Washington Mutual; last year it wrote down its investment in the unit by $2.2 billion. 

CORRECTION-DATE: November 12, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in World Business on Friday about results for the National Australia Bank for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 misstated the change in its net income excluding one-time items. The figure fell 5.9 percent; it did not rise 56.1 percent.

HEADLINE: Productivity Is Up Sharply In Good SignFor Long Term 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Productivity, the amount of goods and services Americans produced in each hour they worked, grew rapidly in the third quarter, the Labor Department reported yesterday. The gain was the fifth consecutive quarterly increase, a much stronger performance than usual in times of economic weakness. The continued progress suggested that a significant share of the step-up in economic efficiency achieved during the boom of the late 1990's could continue over the longer run.
 But even though the stronger growth in productivity could lay the foundation for higher incomes, economists said the gains did not necessarily foreshadow a quick upturn in today's slack economy. In part, that is because the sources of productivity gains have changed. Corporate leaders who turned their attention outward in the late 1990's, looking for advanced technologies to expand their businesses, are returning to the search for internal efficiencies -- how to be better, rather than bigger. 
 "We're very much seeing a refocusing on the traditional productivity issues," said Michael van Biema, a professor at Columbia University who recently completed a study of productivity in the service sector. "Companies are looking at trying to do a lot more with less."
Compared with the second quarter, the productivity of workers in nonfarm businesses rose 4 percent in the third quarter while the number of hours they logged changed little. The Labor Department also announced yesterday that first-time claims for unemployment benefits slipped to 390,000 last week, but most Wall Street economists still foresaw a weak fourth quarter.
The notion of doing more with less may already be taking hold in industries that make long-lasting items like refrigerators and furniture. In the summer months, productivity zoomed up 8.8 percent in that area, and hours worked dropped 4 percent. In October, after a string of weak economic reports, layoffs by makers of cars and industrial goods returned to levels not seen since January, said John A. Challenger, chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, an outplacement specialist that tracks job losses.
Several experts have observed that companies are more willing to move quickly to lay off thousands of workers than in previous slumps. In the past, companies often tried to hold onto workers in bad times because hiring was a costly process. When demand for goods and services fell, leaving less work for the same number of people, productivity would often drop. Now that habit of retention may be disappearing.
"I think the 1990's changed that whole paradigm -- that you rode with your people through the down times," Mr. Challenger said. "We're in a just-in-time environment right now. There are a lot more vehicles for companies to find people, so they're much more accessible. People change careers much more often."
Trends in inflation and executive pay may also have helped to shift the dynamics of hiring and firing.
"Corporate efforts to cut costs are, if anything, even stronger than in previous recoveries," said Jan Hatzius, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs. Because inflation is low, dollar figures for sales may look less impressive than in times when prices are rising fast, he said. Reducing expenses may be providing an easier way to improve the profit figures that Wall Street focuses on.
The bulk of savings and profits achieved by higher productivity appears to be flowing to owners and shareholders. In the last 12 months, the Labor Department reported, inflation-adjusted compensation for workers increased 1.7 percent, on an hourly basis, though their productivity shot up 5.3 percent. 
"While the recession was mild last year, the profit decline, at least in the S.& P. 500, was horrible," Mr. Hatzius added. Moreover, "the fact that management's compensation is more directly linked to stock market performance might also have given them an incentive to cut costs more ruthlessly."
Dr. van Biema said managers at several service companies, which are far more numerous than manufacturers, have told him that strategic plans aimed mainly at expansion have given way to intense drives for productivity.
"The response I would get during the preceding four years," Dr. van Biema said, "when everybody was on the Internet bandwagon, was, 'We're not really interested in productivity improvement, we're interested in new growth, new sales and using the Internet.' With the change in the economy, people are focusing on making corporations more productive."
The economy also posted above-average gains in productivity during the Internet boom. But Dr. van Biema said that according to his research, the bulk of the efficiencies were incidental to grand projects for new, often Internet-based businesses. Now, he said, companies are enhancing productivity deliberately, by paying attention to traditional management strategies and, in some cases, by stripping out recently created infrastructure that was never used to its potential.
Even between companies in a single industry, gaps in productivity in the last few years were surprisingly wide. "It was typical that you could find differences of 3 to 1," Dr. van Biema said.
In the future, Mr. Hatzius predicted, productivity gains will settle at a slower, but still historically high, rate. "In terms of the long-term trend, my best guess is still that you are somewhat higher than you were from the mid-70's to the late 90's," he said. "Rather than 1.5 percent, 2 percent seems achievable for the long-term trend."
Yet that forecast should not provide much solace to investors and workers worried about a return to recession.
"The strong productivity growth is a wonderful thing for your long-run living standards, but it doesn't mean you can't have recessions," Mr. Hatzius said, echoing many economists' views. "Talking too much about productivity in a business cycle context makes it sound like a panacea, which I don't think it is. There's certainly a danger that we slip back into recession. It's a pretty significant danger, actually."

HEADLINE: Into The Wilderness 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
For those of us who think the nation has taken a disastrous wrong turn these past two years, Tuesday's election changed everything and nothing. 
 Clearly, we're going to have an extended sojourn in the political wilderness. Even criticizing the Bush administration's policies will become far more difficult. It will be hard even to find out what it's up to; the most secretive administration in the nation's history will now be even less forthcoming. And anyone who criticizes the administration, even on purely domestic issues, will be accused of lacking patriotism. After all, that strategy worked even against Senator Max Cleland, a genuine war hero who lost three limbs in his country's service. 
 What hasn't changed is the fundamental wrongness of this administration's direction. Too many pundits, confusing politics with policy -- or engaging in sheer power worship -- imagine that a party that wins a battle must be doing something right. But it ain't necessarily so. Political victory doesn't make a bad policy good; it doesn't make a lie the truth. 
But what do we do about it? 
Some of my friends are in despair. They fear that by the time the political pendulum swings, the damage will be irreparable. A ballooning federal debt, they say, will have made it impossible to deal with the needs of an aging population. Years of unchecked crony capitalism will have destroyed faith in our financial markets. Unilateralist foreign policy will have left us without real allies. And most important of all, environmental neglect will have gone past the point of no return.
They may be right. But we have to behave as if they aren't, and try to turn American politics around.
It won't be easy. There are essentially no moderates left in the Republican Party, so change will have to come from the Democrats. And they are deep in a hole.
It's not just Sept. 11. As Jonathan Chait points out in The New Republic, the Republicans also have a huge structural advantage. They can spend far more money getting their message out; when it comes to free publicity, some of the major broadcast media are simply biased in favor of the Republicans, while the rest tend to blur differences between the parties.
But that's the way it is. Democrats should complain as loudly about the real conservative bias of the media as the Republicans complain about its entirely mythical liberal bias; that will help them get their substantive message across. But first they have to have a message. 
Since the 2000 election, and especially since Sept. 11, much of the Democratic leadership has argued that the party must play it safe -- don't criticize the Bush administration too much, don't propose anything drastic that will offend corporations and the wealthy. What we should have realized, and what Tuesday's election disaster confirms, is that this plays right into Republican advantages. Talk radio and Fox News let the hard right get its message out to its supporters, while those who oppose the juggernaut stay home because they don't get the sense that the Democrats offer a real alternative. 
To have a chance of breaking through the wall of media blur and distraction, the Democrats have to get the public's attention -- which means they have to stand for something. 
It's obvious what the Democrats should stand for: Above all, they should be the defenders of ordinary Americans against the power of our burgeoning plutocracy. That means hammering the Republicans as they back off on corporate reform -- which they will. It means defending the environment against the administration's sly, behind-the-scenes program of dismantling regulation. 
And it means doing what the party has refused to do: coming out forthrightly against tax cuts for corporations and the rich -- both the cuts passed last year and those yet to come. In the next few months the Bush administration will once again demand tax cuts that benefit a tiny elite, in the name of economic stimulus. The Democrats mustn't fall for this line again; they must insist that the way to stimulate the economy is to put money in the hands of people who need it.
If the Democratic Party takes a clear stand for the middle class and against the plutocracy, it may still lose. But if it doesn't stand for anything, it -- and the country -- will surely lose.

HEADLINE: Chief of Utility In Kansas Is Indicted Over a Loan 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
A federal grand jury in Topeka, Kan., indicted David C. Wittig, the chairman and chief executive of Westar Energy Inc., today on fraud, conspiracy and money laundering charges relating to a loan he took from a bank in Topeka.
 While the indictment focused solely on the personal loan Mr. Wittig received from Capital City Bank, the stock of Westar -- his employer and the owner of the largest electric utility in the state -- plummeted more than 20 percent after the grand jury's action was announced. 
 Federal prosecutors accused Mr. Wittig, 47, a former Wall Street investment banker, and his personal banker, Clinton O. Weidner III, 49, of falsifying banking records last year to invest $1.5 million in a real estate project in Scottsdale, Ariz. 
Shares of Westar had already fallen by more than 35 percent before today because of mounting losses and soaring debt at the company. They lost another $2.35 today, tumbling to $8.50 a share before the New York Stock Exchange halted trading before noon.
According to the indictment, Mr. Weidner, a loan officer and the former president of Capital City Bank in Topeka, asked Mr. Wittig to invest $1.5 million in a real estate development project in Scottsdale.
Mr. Wittig declined, according to the indictment, but agreed to lend Mr. Weidner the $1.5 million if Mr. Weidner agreed to increase Mr. Wittig's personal line of credit by $1.5 million -- to $5 million. In April 2001, Mr. Weidner increased the line of credit, the indictment said, and then took the money designated as a loan to Mr. Wittig and wired it as a down payment to get a 50 percent interest in the Scottsdale project. He agreed to repay Mr. Wittig, court papers said.
In bank records, Mr. Weidner said that Mr. Wittig would use the additional money to complete renovation of a mansion and for other use, according to the indictment.
Prosecutors accuse the two men of falsifying records and disguising the loan. The indictment says that the loan was discovered last March by the bank. Capital City said today that Mr. Weidner resigned that same month.
A week ago, Westar, which supplies power to over 640,000 customers in Kansas, said that it would restate its earnings for the first half of the year and report an even larger loss for the period after uncovering accounting errors.
In September, Westar -- formerly known as Western Resources Inc. -- announced that a federal grand jury had subpoenaed records and testimony from company officials about the use of corporate aircraft and their conduct of annual shareholders meetings.
Westar, which is based in Topeka, issued a terse statement late today that said Mr. Wittig had asked to be placed on administrative leave so that he could defend himself against the charges. He has worked at Westar for more than five years.
"The board of directors has agreed to this request and has placed Mr. Wittig on administrative leave without pay," the company said. "The board intends to appoint an acting president and chief executive officer promptly."
Westar declined to say if Mr. Wittig remained chairman.
Analysts said the indictment darkens a cloud over the company, which had revenues of $2.1 billion last year.
"This is a personal issue, but it raises more concerns about the possible misuse of the corporate aircraft and the possibility of shareholder lawsuits," said Markos Kaminis, an analyst at Standard & Poor's.
Neither Mr. Wittig nor Mr. Weidner would comment.
James Eisenbrandt, a lawyer for Mr. Wittig, issued a statement saying his client is not guilty.
"The line of credit provided to Mr. Wittig was proper," Mr. Eisenbrandt said in a statement. "It and the loan to Mr. Weidner were paid in full, plus interest; and neither the bank nor any federal agency lost one penny."
In a telephone interview, Robert Eye, a lawyer for Mr. Weidner, added, "Once the evidence is presented, Mr. Weidner will be vindicated."
Mr. Wittig, a former investment banker who worked in New York at Kidder, Peabody & Company and rose to become co-head of mergers and acquisitions at Salomon Brothers before leaving in 1995, grew up in Prairie Village, Kan., and graduated from the University of Kansas at Lawrence with a degree in economics in 1977. He returned to Kansas in 1995 to join Western Resources, which bought Kansas City Power and Light in 1998.
Last year, at hearings over a rate increase, a consultant to the state's consumer advocate said that Mr. Wittig and other executives appeared to have used Westar's corporate jet for personal use.
The United States attorney's office is investigating the company's use of the corporate jet. 

CORRECTION-DATE: November 9, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the indictment of the chief executive of Westar Energy on fraud and other charges referred incorrectly to the company's bid to acquire Kansas City Power and Light in 1998. The two companies did agree to merge, but the deal was never completed; Kansas City Power and Light is now a unit of Great Plains Energy.

HEADLINE: Peace Plan By U.S. Splits Netanyahu And Sharon 

BYLINE:  By JOEL GREENBERG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
A dispute between Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and his new foreign minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, over an American blueprint for peace emerged here today, reflecting the strains between them as they prepare to compete for the leadership of the Likud Party.
 Mr. Netanyahu took office on Wednesday, promising to work harmoniously with Mr. Sharon, but signs of tension between the two men quickly appeared. They are to face each other in a party primary in the next few weeks that will determine the Likud's candidate for prime minister in national elections expected in January. 
 After a meeting between the two on Wednesday night, in which they reportedly discussed policy differences and the timing of the primary, there were public indications today that the two men did not see eye to eye.
Their policy disagreement was over a recently proposed American "road map" to peace, which envisions a Palestinian state in three years. Although Mr. Sharon has criticized the plan, he has been careful not to dismiss it out of hand, saying Israel would study it carefully before responding.
Mr. Netanyahu, in contrast, told reporters after he took office that the American road map was not on the agenda at the moment. The expected war in Iraq would put off discussion of it, he said. Mr. Netanyahu opposes a Palestinian state, while Mr. Sharon has said he accepts the idea.
According to Israeli media reports, Mr. Sharon complained to Mr. Netanyahu about his remarks in their meeting on Wednesday. Mr. Sharon made his views public today.
"I will not tolerate harm to our international relations, harm that might seriously damage our international standing and our efforts to bring economic assistance to the State of Israel," he said in a speech. "That is why I announced that I will not harm the deep strategic understandings with the United States, and the special relationship formed with the American administration."
After Mr. Sharon's coalition with the Labor Party fell apart last week, his aides gave assurances that he would keep all of his commitments to President Bush, including a pledge not to harm Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. Mr. Sharon said he would not depart from the government's policy guidelines, adopted when he formed his coalition.
Mr. Netanyahu, for his part, said on Tuesday that an American attack on Iraq that would topple Saddam Hussein would provide a good opportunity to banish Mr. Arafat.
In the West Bank today, a Palestinian suicide bomber wearing an explosive belt and another Palestinian were killed when the device blew up under army fire at a checkpoint near Nablus.
After an alert went out for a suicide bomber heading for Israel, soldiers at the checkpoint stopped a taxi and ordered passengers out, telling them to lift their shirts, an army spokesman said. The soldiers saw that one man was wearing an explosive belt, and when he ran toward them, they opened fire, detonating the bomb, the spokesman added.

HEADLINE: Pataki Plans Larger Role Downtown 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
After remaining largely removed from the details of the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan over the last year, Gov. George E. Pataki plans to take a more direct role in the process, state officials say, starting with considering major changes in the leadership and structure of the rebuilding effort.
 Among the changes being discussed are ways to satisfy New York City officials' desire for more influence over what happens at the former World Trade Center site, officials close to the governor say. 
 In addition, some people close to the governor are pushing for the replacement of John C. Whitehead as chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the agency coordinating the rebuilding. Mr. Whitehead said yesterday that he had not been asked to resign and that he had no intention of stepping down. 
During Mr. Pataki's re-election campaign, critics said he was not taking a leadership role in the rebuilding because forceful decisions could anger constituencies vital to the campaign.
He has more control over the process than any other official. He appoints half the directors of the development corporation and, with the New Jersey governor, controls the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the site. Also, much of the federal money related to the recovery effort runs through state agencies. 
With his re-election secured, Mr. Pataki has less reason to worry that decisions about the rebuilding could become a political liability. 
The anticipated change in focus by the governor is intended to speed the pace of redevelopment and to set clear goals for the next stage, which begins next month when a new round of design plans will be released to the public. From those plans, three designs will be chosen early next year.
Rebuilding officials say that while they believe much has been accomplished so far -- for example, in getting money for projects, beginning transit repairs and planning a memorial -- city and state officials are aware there is little concrete evidence of progress to display to the public. 
Among the changes now being contemplated are ways of giving New York City a more direct role in the rebuilding, state officials say. Although the mayor appoints half the development corporation's directors, the agency's staff is full of Pataki allies, and the city has almost no influence over the Port Authority.
Louis R. Tomson, the president of the development corporation and a close ally of Mr. Pataki, said in an interview Wednesday evening that the governor wants to include Mr. Bloomberg in any changes. 
"He feels very strongly that he's got a responsibility as governor to collaborate with the mayor in making sure that Lower Manhattan is rebuilt," Mr. Tomson said, adding, "I think we'll find a way to accommodate them having more say."
Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development and rebuilding, said the city's main focus has been "on making sure that the planning process doesn't overly focus on the World Trade Center site itself, but instead meets the needs of Lower Manhattan as a whole and the city as a whole."
Mr. Bloomberg has said the city is working on its own rebuilding ideas, and city officials say those are expected to be released in two weeks. 
The city, facing a $5 billion budget gap next fiscal year, will need money to make all those things happen. Money is one thing the development corporation has -- as much as $7.3 billion, including $4.5 billion in money allocated to the Federal Emergency Management Agency that will be used for transportation projects, and $2.8 billion in Community Development Block Grant money allocated to the development corporation for housing grants and other development projects.
With the state also facing a large budget gap, and with New Jersey making claims to some of the transportation money through its control of the Port Authority, the development corporation's bank account is all but certain to be the focus of intense wrangling.
When the development corporation was created one year ago, Mr. Pataki appointed Mr. Whitehead as its chairman, in part because, as someone who held high positions on Wall Street and in Washington, he would be seen as not easily influenced by politics. 
Officials in the governor's office, though, grew irate at Mr. Whitehead's repeated displays of independence, including criticism of some state business grant programs. Now, speculation about Mr. Whitehead's imminent replacement is widespread. 
Michael McKeon, the communications director for Mr. Pataki, said yesterday that there were no current plans to replace him. "It's always natural after a year of time to evaluate what has happened and how to improve on something," Mr. McKeon said. 
Mr. Whitehead said that although he was reluctant at first to take the job, "I'm into it now." He added, "I have no plans to quit, and I have no desire to be relieved of my responsibilities."
State officials said efforts might be made to restructure the development corporation's functions, possibly by removing the function of planning for a memorial from the rebuilding effort. 
Mr. Tomson himself also has been the subject of speculation about whether he will leave his job soon. He commutes weekly to his home near Albany and is said by people close to him to be eager to reduce his workload. 
In an interview, Mr. Tomson said that he intended to remain in his job until a clear plan for the trade center site is decided upon, but that he intended to leave soon thereafter. He said he believed that should be accomplished "in the near future," almost certainly by midyear.

HEADLINE: Notes Show Fed Concern Over Limits 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
Some Federal Reserve policy makers expressed concern in September that the current low rate of inflation might limit their choices in cutting short-term interest rates to bolster the economy, according to meeting minutes released today. 
 "Some observed that a significant decline in inflation from current levels could imply an unwelcome tightening of monetary policy in real terms," according to minutes of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Sept. 24. 
 "In addition," the minutes said, "further sizable disinflation that resulted in a nominal inflation rate near zero could create problems for the implementation of monetary policy through conventional means in the event of an adverse shock to the economy that called for negative real policy interest rates." 
The discussion may shed some light on why the Fed left interest rates unchanged at the September meeting, on a 10-to-2 vote, as the central bank worried that it could be edging closer to running out of ammunition in the form of rate cuts. 
At its meeting on Wednesday, policy makers cut the federal funds rate to 1.25 percent, a four-decade low. 
According to the minutes, two committee members -- Edward M. Gramlich, a Fed governor, and Robert D. McTeer Jr., president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas -- argued that the potential costs of cutting rates in September were low compared with the risk of additional economic weakness. 
The Fed cut rates 11 times in 2001 in an attempt to stave off recession but had held rates steady through 2002 until Wednesday's surprisingly large cut of half a percentage point. 
The minutes said forecasts pointed to "quite low and perhaps declining inflation over the next several quarters," and the panel members "did not rule out the emergence of appreciably lower inflation."
The Fed members also pointed out that heightened "geopolitical risks," assumed by Fed watchers to be a reference to a possible war with Iraq, were a "major source of uncertainty" in the economy. 
But the members did not intend to signal they would take a specific action, the minutes said.

HEADLINE: Refusing to Follow Move by Fed, Europeans Hold Key Rate Steady 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
Bucking both the Federal Reserve and the increasingly plaintive calls of European politicians, Europe's central bank said today that it would leave interest rates unchanged.
 A day after an unexpectedly steep cut in interest rates in the United States, the European Central Bank said it would wait for more evidence that the economy there was faltering before it lowered its benchmark rate. 
 The Bank of England also left its key rate unchanged today, though with Britain's economy in generally better shape than those of the three big Continental nations -- Germany, France and Italy -- the decision was less contentious.
With new statistics showing rising unemployment in the largest economy, Germany, economists say a cut in the European benchmark rate, which now stands at 3.25 percent, is long overdue. The Germans, they say, need a looser monetary policy to revive an economy on the brink of a double-dip recession. 
"All the economic arguments were in favor of cutting rates today," said Martin W. Hufner, chief economist at Hypovereinsbank in Munich. "They'll have to do it in the next month or two months."
Mr. Hufner and other critics said that in holding the line now, the European bank seemed motivated less by economic calculations than by the desire to avoid looking like a handmaiden of the Fed. "It's never a good thing when the Fed cuts rates on a Wednesday and the E.C.B. cuts them on a Thursday," Mr. Hufner said. "It gives them the image of a junior partner, which they don't want to have."
The bank also does not like the appearance of capitulating to pressure from political leaders in the 12 countries in the euro zone, for which it sets monetary policy. Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany and other officials have urged the bank to lower rates, as have major companies like Siemens.
"These are all quite petty reasons," said Cesar Molinas, the head of fixed-income strategy at Merrill Lynch in London. "But like it or not, these institutions find themselves immersed in politics."
Some economists say the bank may have wanted to avoid the mixed market reaction to the Fed's half-point rate cut. Stock prices jumped after the announcement on Wednesday, then fell back sharply before rising again as investors sought to make sense of the altered economic landscape in the wake of the election. Today, United States stock indexes fell more than 2 percent. 
With European interest rates remaining well above those in America, the euro continued to rise against the dollar after the bank made its announcement. But despite the sluggish performance of the American economy, it is expected to do better than those in Western Europe, helping to sustain the capital flows into the United States that are needed to finance a huge current-account deficit.
Stock markets across Europe tumbled today, though few investors had truly expected the central bank to cut rates. Investors were more focused on signals that the bank might be preparing to ease its stance later.
The bank's president, Wim Duisenberg, noted for the first time that the governing council had engaged in a spirited debate whether to cut rates. He also said the bank would watch closely for further signs of erosion in growth -- declaring that the data so far painted a conflicting picture.
Mr. Duisenberg reiterated that the bank's primary mission was not to spur growth, but to curb inflation. Inflation is now running at a rate of 2.2 percent, above the 2 percent ceiling set by the European Union. Mr. Duisenberg said he was not overly concerned as long as oil prices did not spike.
Picking up a theme of the Fed's, Mr. Duisenberg said confidence in Europe had been rattled by "geopolitical tensions" -- an allusion to President Bush's intended military strike against Iraq. The uncertainty, he said, was enough to derail an expected recovery in European economies.
Germany, which reported its jobless figures for October, provided the starkest evidence of that weakness. The number of people out of work rose by 22,000, to 4.12 million on a seasonally adjusted basis -- its highest level in nearly four years. The unemployment rate increased to 9.9 percent from 9.8 percent.
Germany also reported unexpectedly weak manufacturing orders in September, suggesting that the worst might be yet to come. Some experts say unemployment is likely to climb above 4.5 million this winter.
Ralph Solveen, an economist at Commerzbank in Frankfurt, said, "Relaxing monetary policy would be a positive impulse for Germany, but it will not solve the underlying problems in the economy." 
Other experts noted that tailoring European monetary policy to the economy of Germany would put healthier countries at risk. Ireland, for example, is still growing; lower rates could spur inflation there.
"The problem with a one-size-fits-all monetary policy is that it fits only the most average country," Mr. Molinas said.
Mr. Duisenberg disputed the suggestion that the European bank was somehow responsible for the misery in Germany. He urged European political leaders to adopt sound fiscal policies and to overhaul their economies.
Asked whether he was taking a hard line on interest rates as a way to punish the politicians for their profligate spending and budget deficits, Mr. Duisenberg paraphrased Queen Victoria: "I am not amused."

HEADLINE: I.R.S. Says 9/11 Grants To Businesses Are Taxable 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
The Internal Revenue Service says that government money to help Lower Manhattan small businesses recover from the September 2001 attack is subject to federal taxes, even though grants to individuals for personal expenses like housing are not.
 In a letter sent Wednesday to New York's Congressional delegation, Charles O. Rossotti, on his last day as I.R.S. commissioner after recently announcing his resignation, said that current law required this. But he also said that a business receiving the aid would generally not pay taxes on the full amount, because it could offset against the grant amount the deductible business expenses paid with the money. 
 But members of Congress and spokesmen for small businesses in Lower Manhattan, who had been pressing for the I.R.S. to declare flatly that the grants would be exempt from federal taxes, were critical of Mr. Rossotti's letter after receiving copies yesterday. 
They said that despite expense-deduction provisions in the tax code, much of the grant money would still be returned to the government in taxes, and that using the deductibility provisions to minimize taxes on the grants would be complex and burdensome for most small businesses, in contrast to a simple exemption of the grants from taxes.
"Downtown business owners don't need to be spending their time on tax-avoidance planning, as the commissioner is suggesting," Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, Democrat of Manhattan and Queens, said. "They need to be spending their time rebuilding their businesses."
And Senator Charles E. Schumer said, "My overall reaction is that in many instances small businesses will be required to pay taxes on the grants, and that was never the intent of Congress." He said that if the I.R.S. did not change its interpretation, he would press for legislation "so that no grant recipient would pay taxes" on the money. 
The grants come from the two major programs intended for small-business recovery and revival in Lower Manhattan, both run by the state and city with federal funds. 
One program provides businesses with up to 500 employees compensation for up to 25 days' worth of revenue losses. Under the other program, many businesses that have up to 200 workers, and that sign new or renewal leases of at least five years in the area by the end of 2004, can seek up to $5,000 per employee.
In explaining why expense-deduction provisions in the tax code would not necessarily wipe out taxes on a grant, Michael Hirschfeld, a Manhattan tax lawyer, gave the examples of two businesses receiving $20,000 grants late in the same year. 
One spends all $20,000 for business costs in that year, and no taxes have to be paid on the $20,000. The other spends only $10,000 of the grant that year, and the remaining $10,000 early the next year. It has to pay taxes in the year it received the grant, on the $10,000 not spent that year.

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Sues Hedge Fund Manager 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The hedge fund manager Beacon Hill Asset Management was sued yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which accused the firm of failing to disclose huge portfolio losses earlier this year. 
 The lawsuit, filed in federal court in New York, accuses Beacon Hill of overstating the values of two hedge funds it manages, Bristol and Safe Harbor, between July and September while the funds lost $400 million, or 54 percent. 
 The suit seeks both civil penalties and the transfer of fund assets to a new investment manager independent of Beacon Hill. Beacon Hill has agreed to move the assets of the funds to a rival, the Ellington Management Group, a spokesman said. 
Beacon Hill, founded in 1997, told investors in early October that its funds had lost 25 percent in September. A few weeks later, the group more than doubled loss estimates and said it would close the funds over the next six months. A spokesman, Armel Leslie, said the firm "has agreed to effect an orderly transition of the funds to a new investment manager." 
The S.E.C. suit attributed the losses largely to short positions taken on Treasury securities, which have rallied in recent months as interest rates fell to their lowest level in almost 40 years. 
Beacon Hill is one of the biggest hedge fund managers in the mortgage-bond market, and the short positions in Treasuries were intended to "mitigate the effects of interest rate movements" on its portfolio, the S.E.C. suit says. 
Beacon Hill, based in Summit, N.J., also has offshore offices in the Cayman Islands. It is 50 percent owned by the Asset Alliance Corporation, the investment company run by Bruce Lipnick, its chairman and chief executive.
