HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
In the Politics Of New York, Popularity Tops Cash

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
It was the most expensive political race in New York history and probably the most expensive ever in the United States, outside of a presidential contest. But when the polls closed on Tuesday, it was hard to say exactly what the politicians had bought with a combined investment of at least $140 million.
 Turnout as a percentage of registered voters was the lowest in at least 70 years for a governor's race in New York. And the winner was the candidate who anyone with even a modest interest in the contest could have predicted. 
 The final spending tallies for the individual candidates are still not available. But spokesmen for candidates estimated that Tom Golisano spent about $70 million and H. Carl McCall about $15 million. Gov. George E. Pataki invested at least $45 million in the race. And Andrew M. Cuomo, who dropped out of the Democratic primary against Mr. McCall, spent an additional $12 million.
The previous record in a nonpresidential campaign in the United States was the $119 million spent in the 1998 California governor's race. No other race in the United States this year appears to have come close to New York's, even in Texas and in California, contests where wealthy candidates relied at least partly on their own fortunes.
So what lessons are to be learned from New York State's gold-plated campaign? There are at least two, campaign finance experts and political consultants said. No matter how rich you are, if you do not have the backing of the Democratic or the Republican Party, it is extremely difficult to win a statewide election in New York. And even if you come from a major party, if you are trying to oust an incumbent as popular as Mr. Pataki, you have to have a large reserve of money in the bank.
"The problem is, how do you oust someone who is popular?" said Robert M. Stern, president of the Center for Governmental Studies, a campaign finance research group. 
Affluent candidates willing to bankroll their own campaigns have been successful in American politics. But they generally win an election -- as did Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and United States Senator Jon S. Corzine -- only once they have the endorsement from a major party.
Mr. Golisano, who ran as an Independence Party candidate, spent just about as much as H. Ross Perot did nationwide in 1992 as a Reform Party candidate, once the numbers are adjusted for inflation. Yet neither got more than 20 percent of the vote.
Having spent about $110 for each of the 634,000 votes he won on Tuesday, Mr. Golisano, a billionaire businessman, did raise his name recognition. And he earned more votes in this race, his third, and the one in which he spent by far the most.
His campaign spokesman said that Mr. Golisano knew his candidacy was a long shot, but that, if he was going to go for it, he might as well go full throttle. "He is an entrepreneur," said Ernest Baynard, the spokesman. "As a man who has smartly taken chances in his life, he believes it is better to dare mightily and fail, than to not be on the field at all."
Mr. Pataki always led in the polls, and he was able to collect millions from individuals and companies that do business with the state.
Among his largest donors were Douglas Durst, the Times Square developer; Charles B. Wang, the chief executive of Computer Associates, which is a state contractor; and Steven Roth, who owns shopping malls and office buildings. 
Even in the final days of the campaign, Mr. Pataki was able to pull in large sums -- more than $1.1 million in donations of more than $1,000 each, compared with just more than $210,000 for Mr. McCall -- including at least $25,000 each from Harris Beach, the Rochester law firm; Jack J. Dreyfus Jr., founder of the Dreyfus Corporation; and Michael B. Picotte, an Albany real estate developer, according to campaign finance documents. 
As for Mr. McCall, he came out of the Democratic primary with $2 million in the bank. Mr. Pataki had more than $20 million. Mr. McCall's campaign manager says it was a handicap from which Mr. McCall could never fully recover. "The negative advertising was effective in distorting Carl McCall's record," said Allen P. Cappelli, the campaign manager. "And we did not have the resources to adequately respond."
Even if Mr. McCall had raised as much as Mr. Pataki, it is not clear he would have won, Mr. Stern and others said. But one lesson that no one could debate is that with each year that passes, the price tag for entering the game of politics in New York State seems only to go higher. Mr. McCall learned that the hard way.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Leaving Ghosts Behind in a Quest for a Better Life

BYLINE:  By ARTHUR BOVINO 

 BODY:
Valerie Ujueta lives less than 20 feet from Linden Hill Cemetery in Queens. It's the only house on the block, a place where, from time to time, black cats can be seen chasing each other up and down the stairs.
 "It's peaceful; nobody bothers us," she said. 
 To outsiders, the house may seem haunted. And the woman who lives there? In some ways, she is. 
For Ms. Ujueta, abandonment and loss have been running themes in a 43-year life. She has been widowed twice, and after the Sept. 11 attacks she lost a job at a company that sorted mail for the World Trade Center. The work helped pay the bills for her and her six children: Jastin, 18; Gisselle, 17; Jordan, 12; Jilliann, 11; Joshua, 10; and Jeremy, 8.
But there is one thing Ms. Ujueta refuses to lose: her hope for a brighter future. Aided by agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, she is trying hard to keep the ghosts at bay.
Ms. Ujueta's resilience was born of hardship. Her first husband, Jastin and Gisselle's father, died. She returned to Queens and rented the house near the cemetery, renovating, cleaning and painting the inside herself. In 1987 she remarried, to Carlos Ujueta, who did computer repairs. She had four more children with him.
The Ujuetas had planned to drive to Orlando the month Mr. Ujueta died in 1996 of a brain aneurysm. They were going to take the children to Disney World, and maybe even move to Florida. Instead, Ms. Ujueta was left to care for the six children.
Ms. Ujueta was determined to keep her family together, although her husband's relatives suggested that the children might be better off with them. She told her brother, Ronnie Tringali, " 'I'm not giving them away,' " she remembered.
"To me, they're all I really have," she said, looking at four of the children, who had joined her in their home. "They're everything to me." 
Ms. Ujueta had the support of her brother. But he fell ill in 1995, and Ms. Ujueta cared for him until he died.
In 1997, she took a job at Global Research Distribution in Queens, where she worked nights sorting financial mail going to and from the trade center. Ms. Ujueta received merit raises after three months, and more raises and responsibilities followed. So did 9/11.
Ms. Ujueta was preparing her children for school on Sept. 11, when she saw the holes that had been ripped in the buildings across the river. They all watched the towers collapse.
"But I saw this, never thinking it would affect my job," she said. "My whole world fell apart."
Her company found itself forced to cut costs. Ms. Ujueta was laid off. Though eligible for disaster relief funds from the Red Cross, she has not been able to find steady work since Sept. 12, 2001.
Ms. Ujueta makes purses out of burlap and the legs of old jeans, selling them for $10 to make ends meet. But it has not been enough. Her grandmother, who is 91, sends her money when she can, and the children help her around the house. But caring for her children and trying to find work are difficult, and she no longer receives disaster unemployment benefits.
The Red Cross gave her a phone number for the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of seven agencies that receive money from the Neediest Cases Fund. Ms. Ujueta called and spoke with Diana Naftal, a social worker at the agency's Atlantic Avenue office.
With winter approaching, the agency gave $600 to Ms. Ujueta to buy each child a new coat and a new pair of boots. It also gave her $308 to pay her three-month-old phone bill.
Catholic Charities, another agency that receives funding from Neediest Cases, gave her $486 to prevent her electricity from being turned off.
"What impressed me most was that she made this vow to herself that she'd always be there for her kids," Ms. Naftal said. "Through all this, she's been a normalizing presence. She's made it O.K. for them. They know that she can do that. She's willing to do anything." 
Ms. Ujueta is benefiting from Ms. Naftal's agency in other ways. Intent on changing her life, she is learning how to write a resume and is registering for computer classes. Gisselle wants to be a beautician and is looking into taking classes, and Ms. Ujueta has been enrolling the children in after-school activities.
Ms. Ujueta has begun working for a cousin who owns a beauty salon in Merrick, on Long Island -- sweeping the floors and washing hair three days a week -- while continuing to look for work elsewhere. She also dreams of renting a house from her in Bellmore. There, Ms. Ujueta hopes, her daughter will not have to worry about being harassed by gangs, and the children will be able to attend better schools.
And all those ghosts may seem a little farther away.
"It made all the difference to have somebody on my side," she said.

HEADLINE: Council Votes To Raise Pay For 50,000 In Health Care 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The City Council unanimously approved a union-supported bill yesterday that would raise wages for more than 50,000 workers employed by agencies that have city contracts to provide day care, home care and help for people with cerebral palsy. 
 The sponsors of the so-called living wage bill say the legislation is needed because it is wrong for city contractors to pay some workers so little that they live in poverty. 
 Under the new bill, day care, home care and cerebral palsy workers employed by companies with city contracts must receive at least $8.10 an hour with health coverage, or $9.60 an hour without coverage. Over four years, those minimums will rise by $1.90 an hour and then be indexed to inflation. 
The Council passed the bill, 46 to 0, after months of wrangling with the Bloomberg administration, which had criticized an earlier, more ambitious version of the bill as too expensive. Mayoral aides estimated that the earlier bill would have cost the city $100 million when it faces a $5 billion deficit.
In the hope of winning mayoral support, Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, worked with other council members to scale back the bill last week. Mr. Miller said the revised bill would cost the city about $1 million this year and $2 million next year. "In bad times, a good investment is still a good investment, and perhaps even more important to make," he said.
The new version of the bill excludes several groups covered by the original version: about 250 employees at business improvement districts and 2,700 workers -- mostly janitors, security guards, cooks and mailroom workers -- at businesses that received grants or tax subsidies to persuade the businesses to remain in the city. The revised bill also excluded cleaning workers and security guards at buildings where the city rented a large amount of space.
Three unions lobbied strongly for the bill: 1199/S.E.I.U., the health care union that represents 50,000 of the home care workers covered by the bill who average $7.50 an hour; the United Federation of Teachers, which represents nearly 1,000 employees at United Cerebral Palsy; and District 1707, which represents about 8,000 day care workers. The bill was also backed strongly by the Working Families Party and by the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now and the New York City Central Labor Council. 
Almost all the money to finance the raises for the workers will come from Albany. 
"This is not merely a pay raise for deserving workers, it is a lift for the local communities and businesses where the money will be spent," said Brian McLaughlin, president of the New York City Central Labor Council. But Mr. McLaughlin said the bill fell short because thousands of workers were excluded. Several council members said they would seek to expand the bill's coverage in future legislation.
"Those corporations that got out of the net, we're going to come back with a bigger net," said Bill Perkins, one of the bill's main sponsors.
The city's largest janitors' union, Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, had unsuccessfully lobbied for the bill to include the janitors and security guards later excluded. But that union gained a victory yesterday when the Council voted, 45 to 1, to approve a bill that would bar new building owners or new cleaning companies at buildings from laying off the building's old janitorial staff for 90 days. 
Larry Engelstein, the union's general counsel, said hundreds of janitors were thrown out of work each year when new landlords or cleaning companies came in. "We've had a series of contractors that came in, threw the workers out, and that unsettled their situations and left their families without income," he said. 
Mr. Miller said he was optimistic that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would sign the bills. Jordan Barowitz, a City Hall spokesman, said, "We will review the bills, but we have concerns." 
During the vote, more than 100 members of Local 32BJ sat in the balcony of the Council's chambers and chanted their union's name. Several council members interrupted their speeches to lead the chants.

HEADLINE: To Shrink Education Budget, Klein May Halve Tuition Grants for Teaching Fellows 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein may cut financing for a program that has drawn people from other careers into teaching and helped New York City fill hundreds of vacancies in its poorest, lowest-performing schools.
 Under the two-year-old program, New York City Teaching Fellows, the Department of Education pays the entire bill for people from other careers to get master's degrees while they teach in troubled schools. The department pays about $12,000 for each fellow to get a master's degree in education during the first two years of teaching, but Mr. Klein is considering cutting that amount by up to half as he looks for ways to trim the school system's $12 billion budget. 
 Teaching fellows might be able to cover the loss with grants from AmeriCorps, a national service program that provides tuition reimbursement for people who work in poor communities, education officials said yesterday.
The city no longer has a severe shortage of certified teachers, because of the fellows program, other aggressive recruitment efforts and a recent contract that raised teacher pay by up to 22 percent. But the city still projects that it will need at least 8,000 new teachers a year as baby boomers retire and attrition rates remain high. Since a new state policy requires all public school teachers to be certified by September 2003, Mr. Klein cannot afford to eliminate the fellows program altogether, the officials said.
David Chai, a spokesman for Mr. Klein, said yesterday that, in fact, Mr. Klein liked the teaching fellows program and wanted to continue increasing the number of fellows. But Mr. Chai confirmed that the chancellor was looking for outside funds for the fellows' tuition.
"He believes there is an enormous cadre of talent there, and that there is tons of potential to increase the numbers," Mr. Chai said. "But he is also mindful of the current budget constraints."
Harold O. Levy, the former chancellor, created the fellows program in 2000, when he was under a court order to hire only certified teachers for the city's 100 worst-performing schools. The State Education Department created an alternative form of certification just for the fellows, who needed no teaching experience but had to be college graduates with a grade point average of at least 3.0.
To get the alternative certification, the fellows needed only to take a summer crash course in teaching, pass two state certification exams and start their master's programs when they began teaching in September.
Thousands of lawyers, accountants, social workers, businesspeople and others have applied to the program, whose first advertisements trumpeted the fact that most New York City fourth graders read and wrote below grade level and asked, "Are you willing to do something about it?" 
Though the program was originally aimed at people who had tried at least one career and were seeking more meaningful work, it has drawn an increasing number of recent college graduates, lured by the promise of a free master's degree in tough economic times.
About 320 fellows started teaching in September 2000, and the total has grown to almost 3,000 this fall. Interest in the program rose sharply last year after the Sept. 11 attack, and many applicants told the department that they wanted to do something more meaningful with their lives. But the program was also attracting people who craved job stability. About 15,000 people applied to be teaching fellows last year, 1,925 entered the program in the summer and 1,759 remain. A total of 414 fellows have quit the program and left the school system, according to the department.
Several officials involved with the program said one option was for AmeriCorps to finance part of each fellow's master's program. Teaching fellows are already eligible for AmeriCorps grants of up to $4,725 a year for two years, which they must use for student loan repayment or other higher-education expenses.
But fellows cannot get the AmeriCorps money until they complete a year of teaching. It was unclear yesterday whether Mr. Klein expected future fellows to pay part of their tuition out of pocket and wait two years to get reimbursed, a scenario that might discourage people from applying.
Mr. Chai said Mr. Klein was looking for ways to shrink not just the amount the Department of Education pays for fellows' tuition, but other program expenses as well. Recruitment and advertising are other costly pieces of the program, along with mentoring by experienced teachers -- required for all fellows during their first year of teaching -- and the $3,000 stipends that the school system pays fellows while they complete the summer training. Altogether, the department pays about $25,000 per fellow.
"He is looking at all aspects of the program to see if there are indeed cases where we can get a better bang for the buck," Mr. Chai said.
Alfred S. Posamentier, the dean of education at City College, where many teaching fellows are getting their master's degrees, said he thought that fewer fellows would abandon the school system if they had to pay for part of their master's programs. "People value things more if they have a financial investment in it than if they're given it completely for free," he said.

HEADLINE: El Museo Is Thinking Outside the Barrio; 
Incoming Leader Inherits Debate Over Museum's Cultural Mission

BYLINE:  By MIREYA NAVARRO 

 BODY:
El Museo del Barrio officials were ecstatic: their Frida Kahlo exhibition was a blockbuster.
 Before it ended in September, the exhibition drew more than 70,000 visitors over four months, tens of thousands more than usually visit the museum in an entire year. It even brought the stars and the paparazzi out one night for a showing of the movie "Frida," with the actress Salma Hayek among the hip New York crowd that strolled from the museum's theater to the gallery where Kahlo's self-portraits were on view along with works by Diego Rivera and other Mexican modernist painters. 
 It was the kind of exhibition that fit in with the officials' ambitions to make El Museo, on Fifth Avenue at 104th Street, a world-class cultural institution for anything Latino.. 
"El Barrio" is the East Harlem neighborhood that created El Museo in the 1960's as a place of cultural pride for Puerto Ricans, and as space for art not represented elsewhere. But around El Barrio, there are fears that exhibitions showcasing the likes of Frida Kahlo are helping subvert the museum's original function by gradually displacing the community-based artists it was intended for. 
The debate over the long-term vision for El Museo is about to fall into the lap of Julian Zugazagoitia, 38, El Museo's newly appointed director, the first who is not Puerto Rican. A museum administrator and curator who was born and raised in Mexico, Mr. Zugazagoitia (pronounced soo-gah-zah-go-ee-TEE-a) takes the helm on Nov. 18 at a time not only of heightened criticism, but of post-Sept. 11 belt-tightening that has put a damper on the museum's dreams of expansion.
With his decidedly outsider's background, Mr. Zugazagoitia, who was executive assistant to the director of the Guggenheim Museum, could become a lightning rod for complaints from those worried that the museum is becoming estranged from its neighborhood. 
"All we have is El Museo del Barrio," said Juan Sanchez, a painter, photographer and printmaker who is part of a campaign to keep El Museo true to its roots. 
"Latin America never includes Puerto Rico as part of the Latin American experience in art, while we're also marginalized from the American scene," said Mr. Sanchez, who was born in Brooklyn to Puerto Rican parents. He has exhibited at El Museo and at major museums like the Museum of Modern Art. "The threat of El Museo losing its identity as a Puerto Rican institution is very critical for us."
Mr. Zugazagoitia has a doctorate in philosophy and aesthetics from the Sorbonne and vast international experience that includes serving as director of visual arts for the Spoleto Festival in Italy and as special adviser to the director of the Getty Conservation Institute and a consultant to it.
Until 1999, when he arrived in New York, he lived in Paris and elsewhere in Europe for nearly 20 years.
In an interview at El Museo's offices, Mr. Zugazagoitia was unfazed by the criticism. He said he hoped to channel "all this effervescence" into something constructive that moves beyond discussion to make El Museo's voice even stronger in the art world. "The community is close to the museum, and that's a positive thing," he said.
To some Puerto Ricans, El Museo's working-class, socially conscious origins make it a symbol as emotional as Vieques, the Puerto Rican island used by the United States Navy for target practice. The search for a new director over the summer set off a petition drive, rallies and calls for community participation in the selection, to no avail. 
Now the same advocates, including artists, scholars and members of the cultural affairs committee of Community Board 11, are pressing for representation from their ranks on the museum's board in a campaign called "We Are Watching You." Museum officials said there was consensus among them to add such representation.
"It's not just about paintings; it's about our history," said Arlene Davila, an assistant professor of American studies at New York University who is among those who have met with museum officials. 
But El Museo, which was so mismanaged in the mid-1980's that the city froze its government financing, has been able to thrive financially and gain more visibility by striking a balance between its mission and what is popular. In the 1990's, its mission was broadened to preserving and promoting "the cultural heritage of Puerto Ricans and all Latin Americans in the United States," taking into account New York's increasingly diverse Hispanic population.
It has made room for more works from Latin America, which Museo officials say connect that population with its historical and aesthetic past.
"We can't limit ourselves," said Tony Bechara, a painter who is chairman of El Museo's 23 trustees, 12 of them Puerto Rican, he said. "We tried that, and we were going bankrupt." 
Critics say they welcome inclusion; El Museo has always shown other Latin American artists. But they want it to remain a Puerto Rican institution. Their wish list also includes proposals that Mr. Zugazagoitia said he would happily carry out, like permanent space for an exhibition documenting El Museo's history and new programs to train Latino curators and artists. But he said the real challenge is how much can be done in a more constrained financial climate.
"Sept. 11 can be seen as a turning point for many things, especially the ability of capturing and seizing corporate generosity," he said.
While El Museo remains on solid financial ground, officials said, it expects its financing from the city and private sources to shrink in the economic downturn. So far, board officials said, El Museo's budget continues to grow, and plans for a $6 million renovation, including a new courtyard cafe, are going forward.
But El Museo's expansion plans suffered a blow this year when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg decided to give the renovated Tweed Courthouse in Lower Manhattan to the public schools system rather than to the Museum of the City of New York. That museum is just a block from El Museo, which had hoped to expand into its neighbor's site and acquire five times its current space.
The expansion may still happen, but for now El Museo must make do with only three gallery spaces, a 599-seat theater and offices scattered on two floors of the city-owned Heckscher Building.
The limited space allows for only a permanent exhibition of Taino art, from the indigenous people of the Caribbean; an exhibition of items from the museum's 6,500-piece permanent collection that range from pre-Columbian objects to contemporary paintings and sculptures; and, in the third space, changing exhibitions of contemporary and historical art. 
Mr. Zugazagoitia said finding more space, even outside the neighborhood, would be a priority. "For cutting-edge dance you go to BAM," he said. "For something of good quality that's Latino, you come here."
Mr. Zugazagoitia said that the museum represents Puerto Rican, Latino and Latin American communities "in that order," but that he also believes in balancing "the best of our past and the best of our contemporary art." While many are withholding judgment on him, the fact that he is not Puerto Rican reinforces what Mr. Sanchez, the artist, said was "a progressive move to convert El Museo to something else."
Mr. Bechara said Mr. Zugazagoitia was chosen for his knowledge of the art world and his personality, but also has a mandate to keep El Museo involved with its immediate community. For his part, Mr. Zugazagoitia said he was ready to talk with the museum's critics.
"I'm starting with a clean slate," he said.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE ARABS; 
Syria Fears Isolation More Than War

BYLINE:  By DANIEL J. WAKIN 

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Bouthaina Shaaban, an articulate former professor of English and translator for the president, runs the government's new office to reach out to foreign media and present a friendlier face to the world. But ask her about American policy in the Middle East, and specifically Iraq, and get ready for a tongue-lashing. 
 "This is Israel's agenda," Ms. Shaaban said. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon is a "butcher." War on Iraq would serve no purpose. Syria has no place on the United States list of terror-sponsoring nations, especially given the key help it has provided American officials in hunting down militants from Al Qaeda. 
 Much of Syria's public oratory has been similarly angry in recent weeks. But Western diplomats and analysts say that privately, its tone has been milder. At the same time, they say Syria has deep concerns about its security if a pro-American government is installed in Iraq, its neighbor to the east. 
Syria would, in a sense, be isolated in its opposition to Israel, with pro-America Turkey to the north and Jordan, which has a peace treaty with Israel, to the south. Syria's foreign policy for decades has revolved around its role at the forefront of opposition to Israel. It will never give up that role, analysts say, but adhering to it without regional allies would condemn Syria to the political and economic backwaters.
"It's very difficult for them to accept the reality" of an American offensive against Iraq, said Ibrahim Hamedi, a Syrian who is bureau chief for Al Hayat, a pan-Arab newspaper in London controlled by the Saudis. "It's against the whole Syrian strategic interest," he said. "Syrians are thinking, 'What is the best way to make the minimum losses out of all this war? We don't want to upset America, but we have to defend our interests.' " 
At the same time, there is a sense that after Iraq, Syria would be next. That feeling has been fed by several recent statements by John R. Bolton, the under secretary of state for arms control, regarding Syrian programs for chemical and biological weapons and nuclear power.
As recently as last week, Mr. Bolton repeated concerns that Syria has a stockpile of a nerve agent and the ability to produce small amounts of a biological agent. In October, he also said Syria had benefited from Russian technology for its nuclear program. That drew a rebuke from the Syrian government, which summoned the American ambassador, Theodore H. Kattouf, to explain. The Syrians were pleased to note that in last week's comments, Mr. Bolton omitted the nuclear issue. 
Syria insists said its nuclear program is for research and civilian purposes, and denies having chemical and biological weapons programs. In a speech in May, Mr. Bolton said Syria has a stockpile of sarin, the nerve agent, and is working on the more lethal agent VX. He said Syria was improving the process to make its own chemical weapons so that it could rely less on foreign suppliers. 
Many interpret such statements as an attempt to intimidate Syria, or to force it to acquiesce to American action in Iraq. 
"It is very foolish, and poor pressure," said Imad Fawzi Shueibi, a professor of sociopolitics at the University of Damascus, whose office is dominated by a portrait of President Bashar al-Assad. "You have to try another way." 
Syrians also note that mention is never made of Israel's nuclear weapons, the existence of which Israel neither confirms nor denies. 
Privately, Western analysts say the country's chemical and biological weapons programs are less advanced than Libya's or Iraq's, and are seen as a deterrent against an attack with those weapons by Syria's enemy, Israel. They say the tight control the government has on society makes it unlikely the agents would fall into terrorists' hands.
Others here wonder if another message was sent Monday, when an American plane patrolling the skies over northern Iraq strayed into Syrian air space. The United States quickly expressed regret over what it termed an accident, but suspicions linger. 
Significantly, though, the official Syrian press was silent on the issue. Moreover, President Assad was said to be annoyed when the government spokesman said this week that Syria would reject the resolution on Iraq that the United States and Britain have proposed to the United Nations Security Council. According to local news media, the president felt it was unwise to single out the American proposal rather than continue Syria's policy of calling for the enforcement of earlier resolutions. 
Both events are signs that Syria wants to stay in Washington's good graces as best it can. 
At the same time, Syria is seeking to shore up a bulwark to counter American threats to Iraq. President Assad met last month with Iran's intelligence minister, Ali Yunesi, and Syrian officials recently met with Jalal Talabani, one of the key leaders of the Kurdish area in northern Iraq.
The question on many minds is what exactly Syria will do if there is an invasion of Iraq. 
Professor Shueibi said that if it happened under a United Nations resolution, "then Syria will accept that, but it will not agree with it." Haitham Kelani, a military historian here, said an army mobilization was unlikely, given the high financial cost.
Another delicate issue is Hezbollah, the armed political force in Lebanon's central valley, the Bekaa. Arms supplied to Hezbollah by Iran are widely believed to travel through Syria, and Syria maintains a heavy troop presence in Lebanon. 
Many in the Middle East worry that if the United States invades Iraq, Israel would take the opportunity to attack Hezbollah, which could widen the conflict.
Mr. Hamedi, the jounralist with Al Hayat, believes the United States and Syria are approaching a bargaining stage, in which the United States would seek promises from Syria, like keeping a lid on Hezbollah, refraining from its own military intervention and from opposing an opposition government, and providing logistical cooperation for activities like search and rescue.
As one non-American Western diplomat put it, "The Syrians want to keep the relationship on a reasonably even keel, but the question is, are they willing to pay the price?"

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: SOUTHEAST ASIA; 
Qaeda Meeting in Thailand Reportedly Plotted Attacks on Tourists

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
A group of Al Qaeda operatives met in Thailand and discussed plans to attack bars, nightclubs and tourist resorts throughout the region months before the October bombing in Bali killed more than 190 people, Asian and Western officials said this week. 
 The group was led by a senior lieutenant of Osama bin Laden and included a Qaeda explosives expert, who was later arrested and told American officials of the January meeting during his interrogation. 
 "They talked about hitting soft Western targets throughout Southeast Asia," an American official said. The blast at an Indonesian resort area in Bali may have been the first such attack, Western diplomats said. 
"Is Thailand next?" is the question being asked by seemingly everyone here, from bartenders to hotel owners, to businessmen and diplomats, as well by many Thai officials when they are speaking privately.
The presence of Al Qaeda in Thailand, with its free-wheeling culture, chaotic cities and porous borders, is greater than the Thai government has been willing to acknowledge, or than Western governments, including the United States, were aware of, diplomats from several countries said in interviews. 
An attack here could further unsettle a region where Thailand serves as the economic engine and the hub of tourist industry that draws more than 10 million visitors a year to this country alone. 
A Western intelligence analyst said Thailand was a vital link in the "international terrorist's underground railroad." 
Two of the Sept. 11 hijackers traveled from Afghanistan to Malaysia and then in effect laundered themselves through Thailand before entering the United States, Western officials said this week. 
Last month, a dozen suspected Qaeda operatives fled to Thailand from Malaysia and Singapore, and then disappeared, to the embarrassment of the Thai government, Asian and Western officials said. 
A Thai government spokesman, Sita Divari, said today that the government was certain that there was no Qaeda network in Thailand and that there was no serious threat of a terrorist attack. 
It is an assertion that diplomats here have been hearing for months and which they do not take seriously. "People who claim this country is devoid of any prospects of terrorism are naive," one ambassador said.
Officials investigating the Bali attack are now looking closely at Thailand and suspect that the plan to set off a car bomb in front of a popular nightclub on Oct. 12 was hatched during the meeting in January. 
The meeting, these officials said, was called by a man who has become the most wanted terrorist in the region, Al Qaeda's top man in Southeast Asia, Riadun Isamuddin, known as Hambali. 
Also attending, they said, was a Qaeda explosives expert, Mohamed Mansour Jabara, a Kuwaiti national with a Canadian passport who was picked up in Oman in March and is now in American custody. Precisely when he told American officials about the January meeting is not clear. 
Mr. Jabara was one of the main planners in a plot to blow up the American, Australian and Israeli embassies in Singapore last December. When the plot was uncovered, he and several others fled undetected to Thailand, Asian and Western officials said. 
Counterterrorism experts say Al Qaeda, no longer dependent on camps for its operations, is probably working in small groups, much like the one that met here. The Bali operation, an American official said, may have been the work of cells in several countries, none of them larger than six or eight men.
The fear now is that Thailand will not only provide an easy base of operation for terrorists working in smaller cells, but also that the country itself is high on the list of potential targets as Al Qaeda shifts its focus to tourist sites. 
"We have already seen in recent months more and more information that tourist centers are under threat," the chief of German intelligence, August Hanning, said this week. "It is because tourist centers cannot be guarded." 
He named the Philippines, Indonesia and Thailand as the likely next targets. 
Thailand has long been a route for drug traffickers and people smugglers, a country where guns and explosives are readily available and where preparing fraudulent documents is a developed industry. 
"It is easy to get a false passport in Thailand," a European ambassador said. adding, "A professional terrorist can enter this country and leave quite easily, after having launched an attack."
Even a Thai intelligence official acknowledged that it would be relatively easy for a terrorist "to hibernate" in Bangkok, a teeming city of 12 million people, thousands of whom are tourists or transients. 
Western diplomats agreed. Until recently, visas were not required here for citizens of most countries, including those from the Middle East. The government did not ask a lot of questions of visitors, especially of the foreign men who patronize the bars and nightclubs that form the center of Bangkok's tourist industry.
"Who knows who's here," an ambassador said.
Deepening worries is the relative inexperience and disorganization of Thai intelligence agencies, which are short on manpower, training and resources, officials from several countries said. Generally speaking, they are considered better than the intelligence services in Indonesia, the officials said, but not in league with a country like Singapore.
"I don't think anyone's intelligence here is terrific," a Western ambassador said. 
But diplomats and others also said the Qaeda presence in Thailand, a largely Buddhist country of 62 million people, is not as big as in Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim nation. 
Nonetheless, in recent weeks Germany, several other European nations and Australia have issued warnings to their citizens to exercise extreme caution in certain popular tourist areas in Thailand. The United States has issued a new travel advisory covering all of Southeast Asia. 
The Western intelligence analyst summed up the reactions here since the Bali blasts as "hysteria, and a false sense of confidence." Western governments have overreacted with their travel warnings, he said, while the Thai government has refused to face up to terrorist threat it faces. 
It is not clear why the travel warnings vary from country to country, since they are sharing intelligence, diplomats said. "We interpreted it differently," an American diplomat said. 
But several ambassadors acknowledged that the warnings were heavily influenced by the domestic political concerns of governments seeking to protect themselves against charges, in case of another attack, that they did not take all precautions.

COMPANY: AL MUDON INTERNATIONAL REAL ESTATE CO KSCC (50%)

 The Republican takeover of the Senate as well as the House (front page, Nov. 7) is a direct result of the Democrats' failure to challenge the Bush war rhetoric and advocate for those of their principles that Americans care most about, including public health, the environment and the economy.

HEADLINE: Be Careful What You Ask For 

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF; E-mail: nicholas@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Republicans are really in a pickle now.
 No, it's true. Just consider the picture in the fall of 2004 as President Bush battles to hold onto Congress and his own house: 
* The new Scalia Supreme Court has accepted an abortion case that could overturn Roe v. Wade and abortion rights in America. The federal budget deficit has hit $400 billion, and the expanded 2003 tax cuts mean that the federal debt is out of control. This has kept the Dow below 7,000. 
* The '02 election has emboldened conservatives to take hard-line positions and overshoot their mandate, just as they did under Newt Gingrich in 1994, so that more high school students now learn about creationism than about condoms. The result, once again, is rising public anger at right-wing ideologues.
* In response to huge budget deficits, states have had to slash school spending. Test scores are dropping, and a growing number of children are being left behind. Even centrists are angered by logging of old-growth forests and the administration's fervent push to drill for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
* The occupation of Iraq is increasingly unpopular at home, with an average of one American killed there every two weeks and Iran gaining influence in the anarchic south. The catastrophic failure to engage North Korea has led that country to start up its Yongbyon reactor, churn out many nuclear weapons and test its new three-stage Taepodong 2 missile, which can reach New York.
The above paragraphs will self-destruct next year, well before they could embarrass me by being juxtaposed with reality. As Mark Twain said, the art of prophecy is difficult, especially with regard to the future. But it does seem plausible that Republicans will overinterpret their mandate (if 22,000 votes had gone differently, the Senate could have remained Democratic in January). 
President Bush is, like President Reagan but unlike his father, a natural leader who is unafraid to use political capital and even borrow some from the bank. If he pushed an aggressive platform before, with a minority of the popular vote and a divided Congress, imagine what he'll seek now. Already the Republicans are oozing hubris.
(You can't much blame them. As David Letterman observed about the Democrats, You know you're in trouble when your bright young star of the future is Frank Lautenberg.)
Yet the reality is that this will be an excruciating economic climate in which to govern. New York State alone will face a $6 billion shortfall next year, and war spending and tax cuts could easily push the federal deficit to between $200 billion and $400 billion in 2004, up to a precarious 4 percent of G.N.P. Services and school programs around the country will be cut, and voters will find someone to blame in two years' time. The Democrats, out of power, won't make a convenient whipping boy.
John Ellis, a Bush cousin and longtime conservative political analyst, gets it exactly right on his Weblog: "The 2002 result is a strong vote of confidence for the Bush administration. It is not a mandate. The great danger that now looms for the G.O.P. is that it will mistake the vote of confidence for a mandate."
In his press conference yesterday, Mr. Bush gave no sign he is intoxicated by election vapors; even when goaded by reporters looking for a good story, he didn't speak dreamily about appointing John Ashcroft to the Supreme Court, drilling for oil in Yellowstone or exiling liberals to Guantanamo. The key test, though, will be in the coming weeks as we see whether he reads the soon-to-be-passed U.N. resolution on Iraq the same way everyone else does.
Mr. Bush's problem is that he has launched a diplomatic process in which he has little faith. The reality is that he went to the U.N. to get international legitimacy, not weapons inspections. So he may soon be tempted to short-circuit the diplomatic process.
The resolution, as it is presently drafted, requires Saddam Hussein to make a full declaration of his secret programs within 30 days. It's a good bet that there'll be a lot of doubt that his declaration is completely truthful, and so hawks will encourage Mr. Bush to launch a war at that time. They will urge him to announce that the declaration is false and constitutes a "material breach" -- and then send the bombers.
If that happens, we could be at war by year's end. We might be paying for such hubris for years to come.

HEADLINE: The President and Lame Ducks 

 BODY:
President Bush's measured tone and modest demeanor at his post-election news conference yesterday provided a timely reminder of why he has the support of so many voters who appear to disagree with so many of his policies. Tuesday's results had obviously put him in a good frame of mind. But he did not gloat, and indeed seemed at pains to avoid the triumphalism that some Republican leaders couldn't resist expressing when the election returns showed that their party had captured the Senate and enlarged its majority in the House. The image he projected was one of inclusive leadership rather than narrow partisanship, and while the country is clearly in for some bruising ideological battles come the next Congress, the president's manner -- at turns affable and somber, and wholly disarming -- seemed well suited to the needs of the moment. 
 Among these needs, as Mr. Bush observed, is to make sure that the 107th Congress makes good use of the few weeks remaining to it before it passes into history. The president set two very appropriate goals for the necessarily brief lame-duck session that begins next week. Neither will be easy to finish but both are achievable. One is to complete work on a Department of Homeland Security. The other is to approve terrorism insurance. We would add a third: helping the unemployed. 
 Homeland security has been blocked by Democratic opposition to Mr. Bush's plan to reduce civil service protection for the employees of the new department. This is no longer a fight worth pursuing. While we believed the Democrats had the better position, the one thing voters made clear on Tuesday is that they support the president on the homeland security issue. The Democrats should go along, and Senator Robert Byrd, the powerful Democrat from West Virginia who believes that the antiterrorist apparatus was constructed too quickly, should drop his threat to filibuster the bill. 
Mr. Bush was right to put a high priority on terrorism insurance, which is needed because some real estate development projects around the country are in danger of being stalled by the difficulty in getting coverage for a cataclysmic disaster like the one that struck the World Trade Center. Both the House and Senate have approved versions of a terrorism insurance measure. The only obstacle to final passage has been a quarrel between Republicans who want to use the bill as a vehicle for tort reform -- that is, to rein in large damage awards in lawsuits -- and Democrats who are afraid to offend the trial lawyers. A sensible compromise is within easy reach if the two sides will suppress their political egos.
Though Mr. Bush did not mention it, Congress could do several things to help the nation's unemployed while boosting the fragile economy. It should extend temporary unemployment benefits beyond the Dec. 31 deadline, while continuing assistance to about a million workers who have exhausted their benefits or will do so shortly. These people need help, and it will not bankrupt the government to provide it. Such assistance would also be fully consistent with the conciliatory and helpful tone the president sought to project yesterday.

HEADLINE: BOLDFACE NAMES 

BYLINE:  By James Barron 

 BODY:
A 2nd Term and a 3rd Husband
 Having won a second term this week, LT. GOV. MARY DONOHUE plans to say "I do" next week for the third time. Ms. Donohue, 55, will marry ANTHONY J. RICCI, 56, who works for the accounting firm KPMG. The Associated Press said that they grew up in Troy, N.Y., and that he accompanied her to President Bush's inauguration last year. And where is the wedding? Her spokesman would not say. A spokesman for GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI, who chose Ms. Donohue to be his running mate in 1998 after a feud with BETSY McCAUGHEY ROSS (she went through her own second divorce while in office), said he did not know if Mr. Pataki would attend. 

A Bondish Encounter
JULIANNA MARGULIES once wanted to be a Bond girl. "I was supposed to test for one of the Bond movies" while still on "E.R.," she said. But the Bond producers wanted a five-month commitment, and she did not have that kind of time.
Eventually, she quit "E.R." And made a movie with PIERCE BROSNAN.
Not a Bond film, but "Evelyn," a drama set in Ireland in the 1950's about an unemployed single father's struggle to get his children back.
So did she enjoy their rather long screen kiss? "Both Pierce and I, when the director went, like, 'Great, cut, O.K., let's move on,' we were like, 'Hang on, we've been waiting the entire film,' " she recalled.
By now she was at a party in the Fifth Avenue apartment of the photographer NANCY ELLISON and her husband, WILLIAM D. ROLLNICK. Her co-star did some rough-housing with the Rollnicks' dog, Buzz, who may or may not have been impressed. "Last week Buzz jumped into MEG RYAN'S lap on that couch over there," said Mr. Rollnick. "He loves Meg Ryan."

A Tough Morning After
Think that getting up before dawn and doing a network television program is tough? KATIE COURIC said yesterday that she was "a nervous wreck," and what she was talking about was a benefit she has been helping to plan. 
Four days to go. The benefit, at the Waldorf-Astoria, is for a center for gastrointestinal health at New York-Presbyterian Hospital that will be named for her husband, Jay Monaghan (he died of cancer in 1998). It will feature songs from "West Side Story" performed by the likes of ROBIN WILLIAMS, MERYL STREEP, KELSEY GRAMMER, BEYONCE KNOWLES and BETTE MIDLER, among others.
"I'm looking forward to Tuesday night," she said, "and Wednesday morning even more."
Would she take a morning off from "Today"?
"I looked into that possibility but was told no way," she said. "It's sweeps, honey." Ah, November, the first ratings "sweep" month of the season, when the networks try for the biggest audiences and thus the most favorable advertising rates.

He of the Gleaming Flute
It sounded like "My Big Fat Greek Wedding," except that the flutist JAMES GALWAY said he had not seen the film. But there he was, talking about using Windex on something besides glass: his flute.
Explanation, please.
One of the characters in "My Big Fat Greek Wedding" raves about Windex as a wonder drug that can heal cuts, among other things.
Mr. Galway said he uses Windex to remove fingerprints from his flute before photo sessions for his albums. And that led a conversation about how things have changed since his first album was released in the 1970's. "You have to have a past, a notorious past, now," he said. "You have to have been arrested. Either that, or you have to be Hollywood photographic material. VANESSA MAY might make such a career, but there are others who haven't been photographed in a wet T-shirt playing a white violin going over a wave."

Quibble With the Home Office
BOBBY VALENTINE sounded as if his strategy was to blame DAVID LETTERMAN'S writers. Or, who knows? Maybe the host.
When not signing autographs at KEITH HERNANDEZ'S Field of Dreams gala on Wednesday, he talked about his appearance on the "Late Show" earlier in the week. He read a top-10 list -- "Top 10 things I, Bobby Valentine, want to get off my chest." No. 1 was, "I had no idea there's a baseball team in Anaheim."
"They weren't quite my lines," Mr. Valentine said, "and they were changed at the last second. So I wasn't all that comfortable with them."

President Bush said that his top priority after the Republican triumph in the midterm elections was creating a new Department of Homeland Security, stalled by Democrats over issues of worker rights, and that he wanted it done before the end of the year. A24

After a series of failures at Wal-Mart, organized labor is seeking to unionize stores in 20 states where they are enduring embarrassment for not having a presence at the nation's largest private employer. A28

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTION: NEW MEXICO; 
Resume and Message Help Ex-Clinton Official to Victory

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., Nov. 7 

 BODY:
It has been a longstanding tradition in the Richardson family to pummel Republicans. As center for Tufts in its 1913 football game against Army, William B. Richardson took credit for ending Dwight D. Eisenhower's gridiron career by breaking his leg in a pileup.
 "Eisenhower was quoted later saying 20 people claimed to be responsible, but my father told me he heard the bone crack," Mr. Richardson's son, Bill, said with a laugh. "And my father was a Republican." 
 Bill Richardson, a lifelong Democrat at 54, insists he has not broken any Republican legs, but in a 20-year political career that reached another milestone on Tuesday, he has broken quite a few Republican hearts.
A former congressman, United Nations representative and energy secretary, Mr. Richardson was elected governor of New Mexico, defeating a Republican, John Sanchez, by 20 percentage points, the largest margin in the 23 races for governor. 
In addition, Mr. Richardson became the only senior official in the Clinton administration who won. Three other cabinet members seeking to become governor of their states never made it out of the primary: former Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich in Massachusetts; Andrew M. Cuomo, the former housing secretary, in New York; and former Attorney General Janet Reno in Florida. Erskine B. Bowles, a Clinton chief of staff, lost his North Carolina Senate bid to Elizabeth Dole.
The only other ranking Clinton aide who did win on Tuesday was Rahm Emmanuel, a political consultant, who was elected to a House seat from Illinois.
Mr. Richardson said he did not follow his Clinton colleagues closely enough to assess why they lost. But his own success, he said today in an interview, derived from his ability to articulate an economic message that proved effective in a state facing a host of social and financial ills. It was also a message, he said, that might have helped more Democrats prevent the kind of losses they suffered on Tuesday.
"I ran on bread and butter issues of economic growth, cooperation between labor and business, modernizing the stagnant New Mexico economy," Mr. Richardson said, ticking off specific ideas, like cutting taxes and offering tax credits to businesses paying above minimum wage. "I told people, 'I want to put more money in your pockets.' "
He also promised greater access to health care, higher teacher salaries and negotiating reasonable compromises between environmental and energy interests.
Any of that sound familiar? And former President Bill Clinton, who left office in 2000, did not even come to New Mexico to campaign.
"The truth is, none of these races had anything to do with Bill Clinton," Paul Begala, a television commentator and former Clinton political consultant, said of races that former Clintonites and Democrats, in general, lost. "What it did have to do with was Bill Clinton's ideas, tactics and techniques that were forgotten by Democrats, that you have to campaign with ideas. You have to stand for something."
In succeeding the Republican governor, Gary E. Johnson, who was barred by law from seeking a third term, Mr. Richardson had several natural advantages over Mr. Sanchez, a roofing contractor and one-term state lawmaker. With a strong base of support across northern New Mexico and a Clintonesque lust for campaigning, Mr. Richardson had won eight terms to Congress, always with comfortable margins. As a special international envoy for Mr. Clinton and later as United Nations delegate, he honed skills as a negotiator and mediator. As energy secretary, he plunged into issues vital to Western interests.
Further, he ran in a state where registered Democrats outnumber Republicans three to two.
By the time Mr. Richardson announced he would run for governor, he was perhaps the best-known politician in the state. Billy Sparks, Mr. Richardson's spokesman, said the Guinness Book of World Records had accorded him the record in the arcane category of most hands shaken by a politician in one day, 13,392, breaking President Theodore Roosevelt's record of 8,515.
"He's very experienced, he had a lot of money and, with his message, he won the swing vote, conservative Democrats," said Gilbert St. Clair, a professor of political science at the University of New Mexico. "He took Republican issues, and that appealed to conservative Democrats."
As one of 11 new Democratic governors-elect Mr. Richardson is part of the lone bright spot for his party this week. He called the nationwide results "a debacle for Democrats but a temporary debacle" and said the outcome would put new pressure on Republicans to unite the country and pass sensible legislation.
"We should admit we took a shellacking, regroup and learn, not just put our heads in the sand," he said. "We can recover. We can even talk about tax cuts; there's nothing evil about them when you can put money in people's pockets. Now we have to develop a national economic message that's clear and concise, with an emphasis of giving more money back to families."
There is little wonder that the message worked in New Mexico. By 2000 census data, 17.7 percent of its residents are poor, the highest percentage of any state. It is among the leaders in the percentage of people without health care and the rate of violent crime, and near the bottom in teacher salaries.
"We've got a lot of problems, and I've got a lot of work to do," Mr. Richardson said, conceding that with a Democratic-controlled State House and Senate, he would have few excuses for failure. "Just give us a little time. It's not going to be easy."

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Bill Richardson, a Democrat who was elected governor of New Mexico, referred incorrectly to his 20-percentage-point margin of victory. It was the largest in the 23 races that resulted in the election of new governors, not the largest in the races for governor.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTION: THE PRESIDENT; 
After G.O.P. Triumph, Bush Sets Security Department and Tax Cut as Priorities

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that his top priority after the Republican victories in the midterm elections was creating a new Department of Homeland Security, long stalled in Congress, and that he wanted it done before the end of the year.
 Mr. Bush also said it was essential for Congress to make his $1.35 trillion, 10-year tax cut permanent after its planned expiration in 2010, a centerpiece of his domestic agenda that the Democratic-controlled Senate had blocked. 
 In a 47-minute news conference in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building, the president made it clear that he would use his party's victory in Tuesday's election to muscle forward large parts of his agenda, even though he promised to reach out to Democrats to help him in governing. 
Mr. Bush also said for the first time that Vice President Dick Cheney would be his running mate in 2004 because "he is a superb vice president, and there's no reason to change."
But the president added a caveat, saying that he was still recovering from his brutal campaigning schedule during the 2002 races and that Mr. Cheney would be on the ticket "should I decide to run."
The president avoided the kind of gloating that his advisers believe doomed the Republicans after they captured the House and Senate in 1994. Mr. Bush refused several times to call Tuesday's results a mandate for his presidency and said the candidates deserved the credit, not him.
"I think candidates win elections because they're good candidates, not because they happen to have the president as a friend, or a foe, for that matter," Mr. Bush said.
The president added later: "I really don't put this in personal terms. I know people in Washington like to do that. You know, George Bush won, George Bush lost. That's the way they do it here. Zero sum, in Washington." 
Mr. Bush kept to a careful tone of humility even though White House advisers have been ecstatic about how the Republicans recaptured the Senate and made gains in the House.
Mr. Bush, who was credited by both parties for providing the excitement that propelled his party's candidates to victory, appeared to be heeding, if not agreeing with, cautionary voices in the party who said that narrow Republican victories in Minnesota and Missouri proved the election was not a fundamental realignment or a repudiation of the Democrats.
"I've talked to leaders of both parties and assured them I want to work with them," Mr. Bush said, his manner subdued after 10,000 miles of campaigning took him to 15 states in the five days before Election Day.
The president said that he had spoken to Senator Tom Daschle, the South Dakota Democrat who will lose his position as majority leader, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Missouri Democrat who said today that he would step down as minority leader.
Despite the generous words, Mr. Bush said he would insist that the Senate, which will still be led by Mr. Daschle in the closing days of a lame-duck session, pass legislation creating a Homeland Security Department, even though Mr. Daschle had blocked it because of objections over protections for workers' rights. 
"The election may be over, but a terrorist threat is still real," Mr. Bush said. "The Senate must pass a bill that will strengthen our ability to protect the American people."
The president added that it was imperative that Congress send him a bill to sign before the session ended. Congress is scheduled to return to Washington early next week, and leaders have said they hope to wrap up their business with little delay.
Mr. Bush said he would push for virtually every other significant piece of legislation on his agenda that had been stalled or blocked by the Senate, among them a prescription drug plan for Medicare, terrorism insurance for businesses, a partial privatization of Social Security and an energy plan that would include drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
"Listen, there's going to be a huge laundry list of things people want to get done," Mr. Bush said, "and my job is to set priorities and get them done."
Mr. Bush ignored a question about whether he would push for new restrictions on abortion, as some conservative Republicans have pressed him to do. "I appreciate all the advice I'm getting," Mr. Bush said, to some laughter. "One of the things about this job, if you listen carefully, you get a lot of advice."
But Mr. Bush said that he did not "take cues from anybody," including the conservative wing of his party, and that he was not changing the political philosophy he ran on in 2000.
"I'm the same guy after the election I was prior to the election," Mr. Bush said.
The president said he wanted to see his federal judge nominees who have been defeated, delayed or blocked by the Senate get "a fair hearing and get approved." 
He added that he would push for the Senate Judiciary Committee, which will be controlled by Orin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, to approve Justice Priscilla R. Owen of the Texas Supreme Court and Charles W. Pickering Sr. of Mississippi for appeals court posts.
The nominations of both had been bottled up, by a single vote, in the committee when it was led by Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont. 
Mr. Bush offered up a warm public endorsement of Harvey Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission who had privately infuriated the White House and resigned as the polls closed on election night. Mr. Bush said today that Mr. Pitt, who created a political firestorm over his selection of the head of a new board overseeing the accounting profession, had resigned on his own.
"He made the decision himself that he thought that he couldn't be as effective as he needed to be," Mr. Bush said. "I received his letter. I appreciate his service."
The president praised Mr. Pitt for working hard to reopen the financial markets quickly after the attacks of Sept. 11 and for weeding out corporate fraud.
Mr. Bush also praised William H. Webster, whom Mr. Pitt had selected to lead the accounting oversight board. Mr. Webster is under investigation by the S.E.C. inspector general for his role as the head of the audit committee of a virtually insolvent company facing accusations of fraud. 
"There's a I.G. investigation going on at the S.E.C.," Mr. Bush said. "We'll see what that says. But I will tell you, William Webster is a fine man. He is a decent, honorable public servant who has served our country well."
Mr. Bush also defended his team of economic advisers, who have been criticized even by many Republicans as ineffective while the economy has continued to stumble. 
"Listen, my economic team came in during very difficult times," Mr. Bush said. "There was a recession, there was a terrorist attack, there were corporate scandals."
Mr. Bush said his team had done a good job of developing, selling and enacting his tax cuts, "and for that, they deserve a lot of credit."

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTION: THE DEMOCRATS; 
House Democrats Seeking Leader to End Losing Trend

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 

 BODY:
House Democrats, trying to regroup after this week's bruising election losses, began searching for their new voice today through a leadership fight that could define the party's direction. 
 Representatives Nancy Pelosi, a liberal Californian, and Martin Frost, a Texan viewed as more moderate, began their campaigns to succeed Richard A. Gephardt as minority leader after Mr. Gephardt failed for a fourth time to lead his party in retaking the House. 
 The competition was being framed as a choice between a woman from one of the party's anchor states who could reinvigorate House Democrats with new ideas and leadership style and a man who has tangled successfully with tough Texas conservatives like Representative Tom DeLay, who will be the new majority leader in the House. It presents lawmakers with a crucial decision on which candidate they think can shape a message and an agenda that can broaden the party's appeal to voters. 
Mr. Frost went quickly on the offensive in a morning news conference, saying Mrs. Pelosi would lead the party left, condemning Democrats to permanent minority status.
"I think that her politics are to the left," said Mr. Frost, who said the election demonstrated that the nation was moving in the opposite direction. "And I think that the party, to be successful, must speak to the broad center of the country."
Mrs. Pelosi, 62, the No. 2 Democrat in the House and the early favorite in this race, said in a statement that she would lead with "clarity and firmness" and not "allow Republicans to pretend they share our values and then legislate against those values without consequence." 
The intramural face-off, waged a bit like a contest for class president, drew more attention than leadership contests usually do because of its implications for the party's future. House Democrats wasted no time on Wednesday in assigning blame for the loss of at least five seats, with several members saying the party needed a new approach. Though no one immediately challenged Mr. Gephardt, he chose to step down.
Mr. Frost, 60, a lawyer from Fort Worth who has been in the House since 1979, cautioned against too abrupt a change, particularly when Mrs. Pelosi and 125 other Democrats -- a majority of the caucus -- opposed the resolution giving President Bush authority to take unilateral action against Iraq. "If you're seen by the country as not standing for a strong America, the country will not listen to you on other issues," he said.
Mr. Frost, the chairman of the party caucus, struggled in explaining where he split with Mrs. Pelosi on domestic issues. But he said his main objective as leader would be to highlight economic problems. 
Republicans were watching the contest with some amusement, though one top aide said they would be willing to go "door to door" for Mrs. Pelosi, thinking she would be the best foil as a liberal who represents most of San Francisco.
In reality, several Democrats said, the candidates have similar voting records and each would be attacked by Republicans. For instance, Mr. Frost received an 85 percent rating from the liberal group Americans for Democratic Action in 2001 while Mrs. Pelosi scored 100 percent.
"I don't think there is anybody in the race who is not a fairly liberal Democrat," said Representative Mike Thompson, Democrat of California, who supports Mrs. Pelosi but belongs to the moderate Blue Dog Coalition. "This is not about personal philosophy. She will take the caucus in the direction we need to go."
Mrs. Pelosi started out the race that will be decided by secret ballot next Thursday with several built-in advantages, including strong support from her home state, which will send 33 Democrats to the House. She also has natural appeal to women and other liberal members. 
But Mr. Frost and his allies disputed suggestions that she had the position wrapped up.
"This is a real race," said Representative Peter Deutsch, Democrat of Florida, who said he believes Mr. Frost provides the best opportunity to regain the majority.
Mr. Frost and Mrs. Pelosi have raised large amounts of money for fellow Democrats, and Mr. Frost noted that Democrats picked up 14 seats when he ran the party's House campaign arm in 1996 and 1998.
Some Frost supporters said they worried that moderate and conservative Democrats would be tempted to switch parties should Mrs. Pelosi take over, though Mr. Frost said he would urge members to stay in the party no matter what happened. 
A spokesman for Mrs. Pelosi discounted the idea that there would be defections or that Mrs. Pelosi's election would represent a swing to the left. "Her record is her record, but she has been very good at reaching out to all members of the caucus," the spokesman, Brendan Daley, said. 
Representative Lloyd Doggett, a Texan who is supporting Mrs. Pelosi over his state colleague, said the party needed new energy. 
"It is not a question of geography or ideology," Mr. Doggett said. "It is a question of who is going to be able to get as much as they possibly can from the talent of our caucus and get away from a leadership clique."
