HEADLINE: How the City Pays for State's Sins 

BYLINE:  By Andrew White; Andrew White is director of the Center for New York City Affairs at New School University.

 BODY:
In state offices turnover was almost nil in this week's elections. Gov. George E. Pataki and all but three incumbent members of the state legislature won re-election.
 One of the consequences of New York's immovable political system, which trades budget fairness for political benefits, is the fiscal crisis in New York City and other counties across the state. These deficits are not simply the result of a cyclical (and thus predictable) economic downturn. They stem from decisions made in Albany on tax cuts, public-sector pensions, Medicaid expansion and more, which shift costs to local governments. 
 Because of tax cuts Mr. Pataki has signed since 1994, state revenues will be $14.4 billion lower this year than they would have been otherwise, according to the Fiscal Policy Institute. More than a dozen other cuts are slated to take effect in 2003. New York once ranked near the top nationally in terms of the state's tax burden on personal income. No longer: it is now among the bottom 20 states.
But it's a bait and switch. When state and local taxes are combined, New York still ranks at the top in terms of taxes as a percentage of personal income. As state taxes are slashed, local taxes grow.
It didn't used to be this way. Fifteen years ago, state and local governments shared the cost of public services in the state, with help from Washington. (The federal government pays for about 10 percent of New York City's budget, mostly for social services.) Back in the 1980's, the state-local tax burden was split evenly. Today, localities cover nearly 10 percent more of these costs than the state. As Albany has shared less revenue, state mandates have driven local spending increases.
Fiscal conservatives holler that profligate local governments must show more restraint. But local governments don't have much room. Of New York City's $42 billion budget, for example, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council have direct control over only about $15 billion. The rest is inaccessible -- thanks to federal and state mandates, pensions and debt payments.
Facing a deficit of $5 billion or more, the city's budget decisions will inevitably hurt low-income mothers, teens in foster care, parents in Family Court and others who rely on social programs but never vote in large enough numbers to gain the favor of Albany dealmakers. Meanwhile, some politically connected unions have won substantial pension deals in recent years from Albany. In 1999, for example, Mr. Pataki, with the help of the legislature, circumvented New York City's collective bargaining process and signed into law new pension benefits for jail guards worth $100 million annually. City taxpayers will foot the bill.
New York City has little power to defend itself from Albany's manipulations. Consider Medicaid, the health insurance program for low-income people and the single greatest state mandate. While the federal government funds half the cost of Medicaid, and the state covers about one-third of the city's costs, City Hall must pay the rest. This year, city taxpayers will spend $3.7 billion on Medicaid, according to the City Council, up from $2.5 billion in 1998.
This rise in Medicaid spending is driven in part by rising health-care and nursing-home costs. But it is also the result of recent Albany political deals: the extension of subsidized health insurance to hundreds of thousands of working-class New Yorkers, a much-needed hike in salaries for some low-wage health care workers and higher reimbursement rates for hospitals. These initiatives won the governor critical electoral support from the state's powerful health care workers union, as well as from the medical establishment.
It's not the substance of the deals that is the problem. These workers deserve more pay and better benefits. It's that Albany refused to postpone tax cuts to cover the $260 million bill city taxpayers will have to absorb between now and 2005.
There are other reasons why New York City mayors tend to dislike New York governors. The repeal of the commuter tax in 1999, for example, opened up a recurring $360 million city budget hole. Last year Albany eliminated the 23-year-old stock transfer incentive fund, costing the city $114 million annually.
The governor and most members of the state legislature will cut taxes and shift costs whenever they can. But their political opportunism has a cost. In New York City that cost may well be service cuts, rising indebtedness and a soul-crushing squeeze for a city that spent 10 long years climbing out of its last crisis-driven nightmare.

HEADLINE: Shuttle's Crew Is Poised to Continue Building of Space Station 

BYLINE:  By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 

 BODY:
If the next space shuttle mission to the International Space Station seems familiar, that's because it is. Next week's planned voyage of the shuttle Endeavour is almost a mirror image of an October mission that added a large support beam to the station.
 The Endeavour, carrying seven American and Russian astronauts, is scheduled to blast off on Monday morning from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on an 11-day mission. The shuttle will carry another 28,000-pound truss segment to expand the space station and a new crew of three to take over operations at the station for the next four months. 
 When the Endeavour returns to Earth, it will bring back the station crew that has been aboard since June, Valery G. Korzun and Sergei Y. Treschev of Russia, and Dr. Peggy A. Whitson of the United States.
The station, which has been continually staffed for two years, will get its sixth resident crew: Capt. Kenneth D. Bowersox of the Navy, who will serve as commander; Dr. Donald R. Pettit, a chemical engineer who will serve as science officer; and Nikolai M. Budarin, a Russian engineer employed by the RSC Energia aerospace company.
The shuttle's cargo bay is filled by the 45-foot-long Port 1 truss, an aluminum girder that will be attached to the station to support other equipment. The $390 million segment, built by the Boeing Company, is crammed with wiring, cables and piping that will be a major part of the station's communications, data relay and cooling systems.
Using the robot arm of the space shuttle and a larger robotic crane aboard the station, astronauts will fasten the truss to the port side of a central beam segment attached to the Destiny science module. Last month, crew members from the shuttle Atlantis hooked an almost identical truss to the starboard side of the structure.
With the addition of the port segment, the truss will span 134 feet. This beam will eventually grow to 356 feet to support four giant solar power arrays and several new modules for the station.
During its five years of construction, the station has become the largest man-made object ever in space. The research outpost is now 171 feet long, 240 feet wide and 90 feet high, and has a mass of 197 tons.
The project, a partnership of 16 nations including the United States, Russia, Japan, Canada and many European nations, is expected to cost more than $60 billion to build and at least $30 billion to maintain over a 15-year life span.
Last month, William Gerstenmaier, NASA's space station program manager, said the construction schedule had been revised to stretch out assembly through 2008, about two years longer than previously planned. The main American segments should still be completed on schedule, by February 2004, but addition of a Japanese module and a centrifuge unit will be delayed for budgetary reasons, he said.
All the project's partners have been challenged by its price tag as budgets shrink because of the world economic downturn and unexpected cost overruns. The American part of the project is believed to be $4.8 billion over budget and several United States additions to the station have been canceled.
The Endeavour crew, under the command of Capt. James D. Wetherbee of the Navy, who has flown on five previous missions, will conduct three spacewalks to attach the truss to the station. The spacewalks will be conducted by two Navy men: Captain Michael E. Lopez-Alegria, a veteran of two previous missions, and Cmdr. John B. Herrington, who is making his first flight and is the first American Indian astronaut. Lt. Col. Paul S. Lockhart of the Air Force, the mission's pilot, has flown on one previous shuttle mission.
Also aboard the shuttle will be about 1,500 pounds of supplies for the station, including food, film, batteries and clothing, as well as new research equipment. On its return, the spaceship will bring back several completed scientific experiments and station refuse.
After the shuttle completes its stay at the station but before it returns to Earth on Nov. 21, it is to release into orbit two satellites, each the size of a toaster, that are tethered together by a 50-foot line as part of a Defense Department experiment.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cmdr. John B. Herrington, the first American Indian astronaut, is scheduled for a spacewalk. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Pataki's Success Among Latinos Worries Some Democrats 

BYLINE:  By MIREYA NAVARRO 

 BODY:
Latinos, the group of voters most courted by Republicans in New York's election for governor, appear to have rewarded Gov. George E. Pataki for his extensive efforts, leaving Democrats arguing over the long-term impact on their party.
 Some Democrats say Latino voters merely responded to an assiduous attempt by Mr. Pataki to get their vote -- an effort that included a television commercial with him speaking Spanish and the opening of an Amigos de Pataki outpost -- but that Latinos remain Democrats at heart. 
 Others say Mr. Pataki's success was no fluke; that Latinos are increasingly open to appeals by Republicans even though they still favor Democrats most of the time. 
Political analysts can offer only rough estimates of what the vote was this year, because detailed surveys of voters leaving polls are not available. But analysis of results in election districts that are heavily Hispanic indicate that Mr. Pataki won a third or more of the Latino vote, a personal best for the three-term governor and evidence that the Republicans succeeded in driving a wedge in the black-Latino coalition that has come together in the past to support Democratic candidates.
One analyst, John Mollenkopf, director of the Center for Urban Research at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, calculated that Mr. Pataki's Democratic opponent, H. Carl McCall, got more than 90 percent of the overall black vote, but only 56 percent of Latino voters supported him. Mr. McCall was the first black candidate from a major party to run for governor in New York.
While some Democrats acknowledged the Republican gains in a state where three-quarters of Hispanic voters are registered as Democrats, many more insisted any inroads went only as deep as the candidate. Even when Latinos voted for Mr. Pataki, these Democrats said, they went for the Democratic party line for the rest of the ticket.
"Did the people leave the party? Absolutely no," said Representative Jose E. Serrano, who said that his largely Hispanic district in the South Bronx gave Mr. Pataki about 30 percent of the vote, while majorities of up to 90 percent and more went to Mr. Serrano and other Democratic candidates on the ballot. 
Surveys confirm that most Latino voters are sticking with the Democratic Party despite their marked willingness to cross party lines for individual candidates. A survey of 400 Latino voters in New York last month by the Tomas Rivera Policy Institute in California found that while a plurality favored Mr. Pataki over Mr. McCall, they still considered the Democrats best suited to solve the nation's problems.
Rodolfo de la Garza, a vice president of the institute and a political science professor at Columbia University, noted that moderate Republicans who have carved out sizable Latino support in New York elections, like Rudolph W. Giuliani and Michael R. Bloomberg and now Mr. Pataki, have had no coattails. 
Outside New York, he said, in states like Texas, Arizona and Nevada, many Republican candidates campaign on issues that reinforce the anti-immigrant impression many have of the Republican Party, repelling Latino voters. "We see no evidence of this Republican appeal, even in New York," he said.
Carmen Leyton, 48, a Democrat who is Dominican and lives in Washington Heights, is among the voters who validate the research. Mr. Pataki was the first Republican she ever voted for, she said. She appreciated his stance in favor of legalizing the status of some undocumented immigrants in New York and his support for the families who lost relatives last year in the crash of American Airlines Flight 587, bound for Santo Domingo. 
But every other candidate she chose last Tuesday was a Democrat and she has no plans to switch parties. "I'm 100 percent Democrat," she said. "The Republicans go where the money is."
Still, Washington Heights, which is heavily Dominican, just inaugurated its first Republican club a few days ago and counts on leaders like Fernando Mateo, president of the New York State Federation of Taxi Drivers, who is a Pataki supporter. Mr. Mateo said younger Hispanics find the Republican Party appealing because they are not looking for programs or handouts, just access to economic and political opportunity.
"The Democrats want to keep you poor so they always have a poor base," he said.
Michael McKeon, spokesman for the Pataki campaign, said New York's Republicans plan to keep working at chipping away at the Democratic base.
"New immigrants come here to build business and build a better life for their families," he said. "The governor absolutely believes that the Republican Party offers the Latino community a much better home than the Democratic Party."
An increasingly diverse Hispanic population has indeed created openings for Republican candidates, particularly those who like many Latino voters take both liberal and conservative positions and do not fit tightly into an ideological category. 
Mr. Mollenkopf said Mr. Pataki seemed to do better in electoral districts with a large South American population than in those where Puerto Ricans and Dominicans predominate. In one district covering Elmhurst, Queens, where many Colombians, Ecuadorians and Peruvians live, for instance, Mr. Pataki got 61 percent of the vote, compared with 38 percent in sections of Washington Heights and 28 percent in Puerto Rican sections of the Bronx, he said.
Some Democrats said the results in the governor's race did not bode well for the party, if only because the more often people cross party lines, the more comfortable they get.
"Latinos already did it with Giuliani and Bloomberg and now with Pataki," said Luis Miranda, a strategist who worked on the McCall campaign. "You have to worry."
Democratic leaders like the Bronx borough president, Adolfo Carrion Jr. and Representative Gregory W. Meeks of Queens said the time had come for their party to address the vote drain and get back to basics.
"We end up with these philosophical debates about abortion or gay marriages, and the issues get attached to the Democrats and we can't get our message out about working families," Mr. Carrion said. "The message should be, 'I'm going to fight for you, and you should be able to have what everybody else has.' "

HEADLINE: McDonald's Cuts Forecast And Will Close 175 Outlets 

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would fall short of earlier forecasts and announced plans to close 175 underperforming restaurants in 10 countries and to completely shut its operations in three other countries.
 McDonald's officials did not issue a revised estimate for the fourth quarter but said the closing and restructuring efforts would reduce pretax income by $350 million to $425 million. The company also said it would cut 400 to 600 jobs worldwide, with 250 job reductions in the United States. The company did not identify the countries that will be affected by its plans. 
 The announcement is the latest piece of bad news from McDonald's, which has reported declining earnings for seven of its last eight quarters. For the last three years, the company has been struggling to compete against its traditional fast-food rivals while facing new competition from healthy-food chains like Subway and the new fast-casual dining category, which includes companies like Boston Market. 
"They're losing market share across the board," said Mitchell J. Speiser, a senior restaurant analyst with Lehman Brothers. "As the competition has focused more on particular demographics, McDonald's is trying to be everything to everybody and in the process is losing their point of differentiation, even with children."
Jack M. Greenberg, McDonald's chairman and chief executive, said the actions were the right thing to do to secure the health of the company's business.
"We remain focused on growing our existing restaurants' sales, and we're committed to making the changes necessary to succeed in the challenging worldwide economic and competitive environments in which we operate," Mr. Greenberg said.
McDonald's strategy has been to compensate with growth, opening new restaurants at a pace of nearly 1,000 a year. In October, the company introduced a $1 value menu that includes some of its premium sandwiches, like the Big 'N Tasty, in an effort to win back lunchtime customers from its rivals. The deep-discounting program has fallen short of expectations, according to analysts. It drew more customers into stores, but failed to generate a significant sales increase because the prices were so low that sales of the more expensive items suffered, leaving the company in the position of eating its own lunch. 
The dollar menu also touched off a price war with Burger King and Wendy's that has already shown signs of damaging both those businesses. On Thursday, Diageo, the owner of Burger King, said the price war had slowed its sales and discouraged Burger King's potential buyer, an investment group led by the Texas Pacific Group, to balk at a previously agreed-upon $2.26 billion sale price. Wendy's also said on Thursday that it would not meet its earnings forecast for 2002.
Investors sent McDonald's shares down $1.52, or 8 percent, to $17.79.
McDonald's franchisees were more concerned yesterday with the company's business strategy than its declining profit forecast, said Dick Adams, a consultant to 500 McDonald's franchisees in America. Mr. Adams said profitability was his clients' chief concern and that promotions like the $1 Value Meal were hurting their bottom lines.
"That's another effort to force growth when it's not really there," Mr. Adams said. "As the industry becomes more saturated and more competitive, the constant struggle to build top-line sales becomes more difficult for the franchisee." 
Though ailing, McDonald's is still the leader in the domestic hamburger market with a 43.1 percent share, garnering more than $20 billion in sales, according to Technomic, a restaurant consulting firm. Burger King posted $8.59 billion in sales in 2001, with 18.5 percent of the market, while Wendy's had $6.15 billion in sales, with a 13.2 percent share.

HEADLINE: AMHERST-WILLIAMS: The Biggest Little Game in America; 
Where Winning Breeds Criticism

BYLINE:  By BILL PENNINGTON 

DATELINE: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 8 

 BODY:
At Williams College, the fall sports teams are fabulous again. And that is the problem, at least to some on campus.
 The football team has not lost in two years, the women's cross-country team is favored to win the small-college national championship, three other teams are nationally ranked and no team will have a losing record. 
 It would be one thing if this were a one-year bonanza. But for more than a decade at Williams, one of America's most selective liberal arts colleges, the sports teams have been far superior to those at any other college its size (enrollment is roughly 2,000). All this winning has made some faculty members and students uneasy and has stirred a debate more common at the nation's largest universities. 
At Williams, and similar colleges in the region, the question is: Can an institution prized for its academics harmoniously house a powerhouse athletic program, even as it is defined by Division III, in which recruiting and athletic scholarships are prohibited and in which the football coach can double as the assistant track coach?
"We must assert the primacy of academics; we're not here to produce professional athletes," said Stephen C. Sheppard, a Williams economics professor who helped write an in-house report last spring that outlined an overemphasis on athletics. "We're getting uncomfortably close to the Division I model. A great athletic experience does not mean your football team must be undefeated. We always hear about the life lessons sports teaches, so wouldn't the odd loss here and there be therapeutic?"
What would George Steinbrenner, Williams class of '52, think of that?
As Williams takes its 7-0 football record against rival Amherst College on Saturday in what is called the biggest little game in America, each college has spent the last year in a hand-wringing tug of war over how to balance the pursuit of athletic excellence without impinging on lofty academic missions. This year's freshman classes at Williams and Amherst, for example, were the first shaped under new guidelines established to constrict the number of students admitted because they were top athletes.
These students are referred to as coaches' "tips" because they were designated on a list devised by coaches and submitted to the college admissions department during the application process. These students, Williams officials say, have average SAT scores of 1300 to 1350 and are ranked in the top 10 percent of their high school class. The average SAT score for the latest freshman class at Williams, including athletes, was 1408, and those students typically had a class rank in the top 5 percent.
The disparity may not seem great, but because 80 percent of applicants to Williams are rejected, every slot in an incoming freshman class of 525 is scrutinized and highly valued. With 66 tipped athletes gaining admission and another 20 applicants admitted who are termed athletic "protects" -- those whose grades and scores meet the usual academic standards and who were also singled out by coaches -- the number of athletes admitted has led to a campus controversy. Until the recent release of the in-house report, many Williams faculty members had no idea that athletics played some role in the admission of roughly 16 percent of the student body.
"When the faculty heard those numbers, there was more than surprise; it was perhaps outrage," said Lee Y. Park, chairwoman of the chemistry department. "There is a significant portion of the faculty that thinks we've gone too far in our pursuit of athletic success."
Not surprisingly, members of the athletic community have been bewildered that their success has become a source of contention. With 31 varsity teams, nearly 40 percent of the Williams student body plays an intercollegiate sport. Last year, Williams won 84 percent of its games and earned, for the sixth time in seven years, the Sears Directors' Cup, awarded to the nation's top Division III athletic program.
"We should be feeling a lot better than we're being allowed to feel," the Williams athletic director, Harry Sheehy, said. "Although it is a luxury to have these conversations with the faculty. People at other schools wish they had our so-called problem."
Still, Williams athletes have sensed a backlash in some quarters. Some say they have been careful not to wear a Williams sports team jacket in the classes of certain professors, who by their public comments are perceived as anti-athlete.
"Almost all of the faculty has been supportive," said Garrett DiCarlo, a senior tackle on the football team who is majoring in mathematics and economics. "But I have been treated differently in a negative way by a few teachers because I was an athlete. And on our teams, we will talk about that amongst ourselves: 'Look, you might want to take off that Williams football sweatshirt before you go to his class.' "
Joyia Chadwick turned down volleyball scholarships at Division I colleges to come to Williams. "It's funny that anyone could call this a jock school," Chadwick, a sophomore, said. "Everyone comes here first for the academics. We want a very challenging, competitive academic environment, but a lot of us also want to have a challenging, competitive athletic experience. So we have the best of both. What's wrong with that?"
Few at Williams would disagree, but some faculty members and students would add that it is a matter of balance. They have cautioned that unbridled athletic success can come at the expense of academic excellence.
"There is no question the vast majority of athletes I've encountered are committed to their academics," Park said. "But I have had a few students in my classes who were athletes and I wondered why they were here. Academics were secondary to them. We have to do something about that, and we're not the only schools looking into the role of athletics in the same way."
Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., joined Williams and Amherst this year in reducing the number of tipped athletes admitted to 66. Bowdoin College in Brunswick, Me., reduced its number from 99 to 79. The four schools are part of the 11-member New England Small College Athletic Conference.
"I didn't disagree with the reductions because we've always had periodic reviews of this kind of thing," said Jeffrey Ward, Bowdoin's athletic director. "I also don't think anything was out of whack. We just reaffirmed our values. But smart kids want good athletics, too. We're probably as successful athletically as we've ever been, and I don't expect that to change."
Amherst's athletic director, Peter Gooding, said he thought the reductions in tipped athletes fostered greater harmony between the faculty and the athletic department.
"Many of our faculty had no concerns at all, but for those that did, they appreciated that something was done to control the arms race," he said. "I'm not sure there was good reason for concern, but there was a perception that something was amiss. That changed the atmosphere."
A key factor in the discussions at each of the colleges was the 2001 publication of "The Game of Life: College Sports and Education Values," by James Shulman and William Bowen, a former Princeton president. The book was harshly critical of the effect athletics has on academics and focused on how small elite colleges, like those in New England, are not immune.
The book advanced the phrase "culture of athletics," and it was meant to describe how athletes take over the social fabric of some colleges and hurt the classroom dynamic in others. Some of that was borne out when Williams surveyed its students recently.
Morton Owen Schapiro, Williams's president, calls Bowen a mentor and has recently overhauled some housing and classroom policies to moderate some of the effects delineated in "The Game of Life" and in Williams's own study of athletics. He also said that the admissions department would continue to be more stringent about the academic qualifications of all athletes admitted.
But Schapiro insisted that Williams would not diminish as a Division III athletic power or lessen its commitment to wildly successful sports teams. He said he thought that athletes had been unfairly blamed in the past year.
"It's too easy these days to blame athletes for everything," said Schapiro, whose office shelves contain not just books but also a football. "It would be ridiculous not to court athletes, but it should be done in proportion to how we court other things. We let kids into this school for all kinds of reasons. We're not just good at athletics, we're good in art, theater, at the symphony.
"The vast majority of our athletes do very well academically. We're making some adjustments. Soon, it's going to be all athletes doing very well academically."
Meanwhile, in his office near the Williams athletic complex, the football coach, Dick Farley, whose record in 16 seasons is 108-16-3, has been focusing on keeping his team's winning streak alive against the only opponent that matters to most alumni.
"I've never told the admissions department who to admit and they've never told me what play to run during a game," Farley said. "We respectfully disagree, and sure, there is a tug of war going on right now. But say what you want, when that game starts Saturday, I know what they will want. They'll want us to win."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
TEAMSTERS' EFFORT FAILS NARROWLY AT AMERICA WEST

BYLINE:  Reuters

 BODY:
 An effort by the Teamsters union to organize thousands of airport customer service, reservation and tour sales agents at America West Airlines failed narrowly yesterday, the labor group and the airline said. 
Organizers fell 240 votes short of gaining majority support from more than 3,600 workers who were eligible to vote. Balloting was conducted by telephone in recent weeks and tabulated by the National Mediation Board in Washington. It was one of the largest organizing votes by the Teamsters this year. The airline workers, the largest employee group at America West, are the only ones at the carrier not in a union. America West is based in Tempe, Ariz.

LENGTH: 1510 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Commerzbank R eflects Germanys Many Banking Ills

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Nov. 8 

 BODY:
Klaus-Peter Muller has what may be the worst job in German banking.
 Commerzbank, where Mr. Muller has spent most of his career and is now the chairman, has virtually every symptom of the multiple ills that afflict Germany's banking system. The malaise runs so deep that when an unknown 24-year-old credit analyst at Merrill Lynch mused in a leaked e-mail message that Commerzbank faced a cash shortage, it was enough to set off a panic that the bank, Germany's fourth largest, might collapse. 
 Yet Mr. Muller, a blunt, bantam-size Dusseldorfer who spent the formative part of his career in New York, is not moping. 
"I'm having fun, I swear to you," he said in an interview in his 48th-floor office at the bank's mist-shrouded headquarters here. "If you ever get on a rocky ship, you should have someone like me on board."
Next week, Commerzbank will report third-quarter results, which most analysts expect will show a loss. It is also expected to disclose plans to lay off as many as 1,500 employees, including one of every four people in its investment banking division, in an effort to slice $495 million out of its $5.4 billion in annual costs.
This is the latest round in a grueling cost-cutting regime that is transforming a sprawling global institution into a smaller, more domestically focused bank. But while Mr. Muller said the harsh medicine would put Commerzbank back in the black, its long-term prospects remain gray.
Germany, the economic sick man of Europe, has many more banks and local branches than it needs. It has not updated its banking laws since World War II and its lenders with global ambitions are hemmed in by fierce local competitors. As a result, banking here has become a hand-to-mouth business.
"We're one of the few countries in the world which still has a banking system of this kind," Mr. Muller said. "It's outdated, it is old-fashioned and it does not offer a level playing field."
The biggest trouble is that German retail banking is dominated by savings institutions and cooperatives owned by cities and states, which are run on a less commercial basis than their publicly traded rivals. This creates a fragmented industry, in which even the biggest banks are minnows.
Commerzbank, with 750 branches, has barely 2 percent of the total branches in Germany. Together, the five largest banks account for only about 10 percent of Germany's 54,000 banking establishments.
Opportunities to expand are cramped because so much of the industry is in public hands. As a result, Commerzbank has not been able to match the growth of European rivals like Barclays, which has 12 percent of all branches in Britain, or BNP Paribas, which has 9 percent of the French market.
"We do not need thousands of co-op banks; we do not need hundreds of savings banks," Mr. Muller said. "What I would like to see is what has happened in every other country -- a chance to consolidate."
None of these impediments mattered much when times were flush. With a buoyant German economy and Frankfurt's designation as the home of the European Central Bank, the big banks were thinking globally. Like its crosstown rivals, Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank, Commerzbank expanded aggressively outside its home market, and into activities beyond commercial banking.
It bought Jupiter, a leading British asset management firm, as well as the asset management arm of Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. It spent millions to build an investment banking operation from scratch, with high-priced bankers in New York, London, and Tokyo.
Commerzbank hired Norman Foster, the celebrated British architect, to design a dramatic 50-story headquarters building in Frankfurt. It is Europe's tallest skyscraper and features garden terraces planted with exotic trees.
"They had a good life for many, many years," said Fred B. Irwin, a vice president at Citibank in Frankfurt. "But Germany is overbanked, and when revenues dropped, their high cost base was exposed."
Mr. Muller, 58, took control of Commerzbank in mid-2001, just as the dimensions of the downturn were becoming clear. Net profit plunged to 74 million euros ($74.7 million) in the first half of 2002, from 302 million euros ($304.9 million) in 2001. The investment banking business dried up, after four years of profits.
Worse, German and foreign companies began to fail, leaving Commerzbank with millions in uncollected loans. It set aside $200 million in provisions for loans to Leo Kirch, the fallen Munich media tycoon, and more than $100 million for Warnaco, the bankrupt American apparel maker once run by Linda J. Wachner.
All told, Commerzbank expects to declare 1.3 billion euros in loan-loss provisions in 2002 -- a forecast it increased twice.
Mr. Muller said his staff deserved credit for avoiding some corporate black holes, like WorldCom, to which it had once lent $800 million but no longer has any outstanding loans. Still, with 42,000 corporate insolvencies in Germany -- and bankruptcies still being filed every day -- the prospects for relief are dim.
"Even if you have good risk management, a weak economy does not give you great business opportunities," he said.
Faced with falling revenue and rising bad loans, Mr. Muller had little choice but to attack Commerzbank's costs. He announced 4,300 layoffs and closed more than 200 branches. On Tuesday, people close to the bank's planning said, he will announce 300 layoffs in the investment banking unit, which will be folded into Commerzbank's corporate banking division, as well as more than 1,000 job cuts throughout the rest of the bank.
Mr. Muller said he would not abandon the bank's foray into investment banking. But he will consider selling any business that does not yield an adequate return. He is currently trying to sell Montgomery, and only recently withdrew Jupiter from the market because of the poor climate.
Despite his genial manner, Mr. Muller has been remorseless with those inside the company who do not measure up to his standards. Describing the recent departure of one executive, he said, "I fired my colleague who was in charge of asset management, and I didn't do it because he was too successful."
Such plain talk is remarkable in a German banker. It may reflect his years in New York, where he worked in the bank's branch from 1968 to 1973 and again from 1982 to 1986. Mr. Muller's daughter was born in Manhattan, and he still has deep ties there. After the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, he arranged for 300 relatives of the victims to fly to Germany, where the bank was host to them at a resort in the Bavarian Alps.
Mr. Muller's manner has won him the respect of analysts, even as they downgrade his company's stock.
"He's seen as a lot more sensible than his predecessor, more honest with the market," said David Williams, an analyst at Morgan Stanley in London. "But the material he's got to work with is not so good."
Before the downturn, Commerzbank topped most lists of merger or acquisition candidates in Germany. Given its raft of problems, it is no longer an obvious target for even a healthier rival, like Deutsche Bank.
"This is not a very expensive company; it would be a short lunch for Deutsche Bank," said Mark Hoge, an analyst at Bank of America Securities in London. "But Commerzbank doesn't have any profitable businesses. There's no anchor for a new owner to fall back on."
Indeed, Commerzbank's very survival has been called into question. Last month, in an e-mail message that was leaked to The Financial Times, a credit analyst at Merrill Lynch in London speculated that the bank had suffered big trading losses from the sharp decline in world stock markets.
Commerzbank denied that it was in crisis, and Merrill Lynch apologized, saying the message was a private communication that had been blown out of proportion. But Mr. Muller has spent much of the last month reassuring customers and shareholders about the creditworthiness of his bank.
Commerzbank has tried to put the affair behind it by thanking its customers for their forbearance in an advertisement this week in German newspapers. Under a photo of a black rubber duck floating in sudsy water, a headline says, "The most dangerous animal in the shark tank is a duck."
Relishing the ad's sly humor, Mr. Muller explained that in German as in French, the word "duck" means an untruth.
He said Commerzbank had about $30 billion in excess liquidity at the time that the bank was rumored to be in a cash squeeze. Reports that the credit derivatives operation had suffered huge losses were also wrong, he said.
Still, the damage had been done. Commerzbank's shares tumbled to 18-year lows, and Standard & Poor's downgraded the bank's debt rating to A- from A, with a negative outlook.
Mr. Muller was stung by the episode, and he complained that the news media and S.&. P. had not given Commerzbank an adequate hearing. But he is not one to shift blame or gild the lily.
Asked whether selling the bank might be the simplest way out of its troubles, Mr. Muller said: "I think we better do something to get a better deal for our shareholders. Let us do those jobs first."

HEADLINE: Global Trade Looking Glass: Can U.S. Have It Both Ways? 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Policies adopted by the Bush administration to advance specific domestic and international goals are undermining the White House's own efforts to open markets through trade's global rule-making body, some foreign officials say.
 In particular, new farm subsidies and other barriers to the American market have led some of America's trading partners to doubt Washington's commitment to free trade, in spite of its ambitious proposals to reduce distortions in world markets. Those doubts, combined with the United States' pursuit of trade agreements outside the World Trade Organization, have also diminished the pre-eminence of the W.T.O., the critics say. That change may impede a crucial round of global trade negotiations begun substantially through American diplomacy last November in Doha, Qatar. 
 "The United States was very supportive of some of the positions that those of us from the developing countries took at Doha," Kofi K. Apraku, Ghana's minister of trade and industry, said in a telephone interview. "What happened at Doha gave us hope that we could work together." 
But the mood has changed in the last year, he added. "There is a lot of concern and a lot of worry in our country about the United States' commitment to carry forward the momentum that was created in Doha," Dr. Apraku said.
In response, Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, said that all negotiators have to balance domestic concerns with those of their trading partners. "Many countries had to stretch politically and then had to deal with sensitivities back home," he said in an interview earlier this week, "so a pause for repositioning is understandable." Mr. Zoellick added that he was optimistic that the talks would succeed on schedule. "We're not refusing to discuss anything," he said. "I believe we can get the Doha negotiation done by 2005, if key developed and developing countries make the effort."
Chief among Ghana's concerns is the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002, generally referred to as the farm bill. The law will protect American farmers from slumps in the business cycle, but critics say it may also encourage farmers to overproduce. That would depress world prices for crops. Ghana does not export all the same crops as the United States, but Dr. Apraku said the bill set a bad precedent.
"It is a major concern for us in Ghana," Dr. Apraku said. "We are a developing country. Agriculture is very important to us." Farming accounts for 36 percent of Ghana's economy and 60 percent of its jobs.
Ghana is not alone. "It is clear that the United States farm bill is not very popular in Canada, either," said Pierre S. Pettigrew, Canada's minister for international trade. "It certainly requires more explanation on the part of the United States."
Experts estimate the farm bill, signed by President Bush last spring, could increase federal spending on agriculture by 70 percent over the next six years, to as much as $180 billion, potentially violating limits for farm support set during the last round of global trade talks, but Mr. Zoellick's office disputed that.
Supachai Panitchpakdi, the director general of the W.T.O., said the increase in subsidies under the farm bill had hampered the new round of global trade talks. "It has created some questions, some doubts in the mind of some countries," he said, "and has sometimes been used to delay some of the proposals."
Dr. Supachai also noted that the talks were behind schedule. Negotiators missed a deadline for submitting a report on trade preferences for poor countries to the W.T.O.'s general council. "When the members missed the July deadline," he said, "the prevailing view of the developing countries was a bit of disappointment -- that they were let down."
Mr. Zoellick said that the deadline had come too soon, since the overall shape of the negotiations -- whether they would apply to tariffs, subsidies, quotas or other items -- was still unclear.
He also said critics were overstating concerns about the farm bill. "The farm bill does nothing in terms of tariffs or market access," he said. "It doesn't change our policy on export subsidies." Additional annual appropriations to subsidize farmers, he asserted, could make the situation problematic.
In addition to complaints about specific policies, some critics have also objected to Mr. Zoellick's simultaneous pursuit of trade pacts with individual countries, with regional bodies like the Free Trade Area of the Americas and with the W.T.O. While that approach ensures against any one set of talks collapsing, diplomats say it also puts some negotiating partners at a disadvantage. Small countries in particular often lack the expertise to engage in three sets of talks, and the comprehensive negotiations at the W.T.O. could be shortchanged.
"The fact that our trade negotiators are so busy with the W.T.O., with the F.T.A.A. and with the bilaterals, causes a problem for all of us, not only for smaller countries," Mr. Pettigrew of Canada said.
The Workers' Party of Brazil, which will soon govern that country's economy, the biggest in South America, plans to make the Free Trade Area of the Americas -- not the W.T.O. -- a top priority. "The schedule is more urgent on that," said Giancarlo Summa, a party spokesman, "and of course there will be much more diplomatic pressure."
The Free Trade Area of the Americas would lower and eliminate tariffs on goods traded among 34 countries on the two continents, and could shape the rules for trade in services and foreign investment.
For Chile, by contrast, a long-awaited bilateral agreement with the United States is "in the front of the road," said Osvaldo Rosales, the country's top trade negotiator.
Though Mr. Rosales asserted that bilateral and regional trade agreements would serve as an important test for American leadership in the W.T.O., he also said that the existence of such pacts could make the negotiations at the W.T.O. more difficult.
Dr. Apraku was even blunter. "These negotiations will reduce the scope of the W.T.O.'s influence," he said. 
Though a proliferation of trade deals could enhance African countries' negotiating skills and influence, it could also deflect attention from the overall effort to improve the living standards of the poorest countries by bringing them more fully into the global trading system.
Mr. Zoellick affirmed the United States' commitment to seeing negotiations through at all levels. He said he intended to complete free trade agreements with Chile and Singapore by the end of this year, and the pan-American and W.T.O. negotiations by the end of President Bush's current term.
Yet worries about populist governments in Argentina and Brazil seem to have made neighboring nations more eager to sign bilateral deals. Panama, the Dominican Republic, Bolivia, Colombia, Peru and other countries have approached the United States, Mr. Zoellick said.
"They don't want to be left out," he said.
That suits Mr. Zoellick. "We will work with Brazil because its participation is important," he said, "but if it doesn't work, we've got to have alternatives."
Developing countries have also taken issue with Mr. Zoellick's opinion of the United States' importance to the global trading system.
"Doha wouldn't have happened if it weren't for the United States," he said. "The United States has an added responsibility for the trading and international economic system as a whole," he added later.
Rafidah Aziz, Malaysia's minister of international trade and industry, said that view might be overblown. She predicted that Mr. Zoellick would be "tearing his hair out" if he tried to strong-arm smaller members of the W.T.O. "No one can force anyone to do anything there, least of all the United States," she said. 
Sherman E. Katz, a scholar of trade policy at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a policy center here that Mr. Zoellick used to head, said that the United States still provided much of the intellectual energy behind talks on complex issues like intellectual property and trade in services. He concurred, though, with Ms. Aziz's central point.
"We can't throw our economic clout around on the W.T.O. table as much as we used to," he said.
Poorer members of the W.T.O. do not face an easy task. At least 50 issues related to carrying out the last global trade pact -- a primary concern of developing nations -- are on the table to be discussed before the end of this year.
"We are mobilizing ourselves so that we can have some leverage, make some difference, in these meetings," Dr. Apraku said. "We do not want to be marginalized."

HEADLINE: We're Not in Florida Anymore 

BYLINE:  By FRANK RICH; E-mail: frankrich@nytimes.com

 BODY:
The most shocking thing about American politics is how "shocked" we are every time the obvious happens.
 You'd think it would be a no-brainer to call an election in which a popular, barnstorming president is pitted against a leaderless political party whose only coherent message is that the other guys aim to toss the elderly into the street. But almost everyone got it wrong, including the network stars who giddily imagined that deadlock 2000 would repeat itself and Louisiana would become the new Florida, thus allowing them to ruin our Thanksgivings by bloviating from New Orleans for a solid month. History has a way of moving on, even as pundits and politicians alike keep fighting the last war. 
 The Democrats are farcically -- or, if you choose, tragically -- even more mired in the past than the press is. Terry McAuliffe has been fond of saying that defeating Jeb Bush was his top priority this year. The notion that avenging 2000 could be more important than, say, holding onto the Senate into 2004 is so nonsensical that only a party chairman cryogenically entombed in the Clinton-Gore fin de siecle could say it with a straight face. 
This obsession with a lost battle was doomed in any case, and Tuesday brought final proof of "the complete failure of the 'Florida anger' strategy as a motivating force for Democrats," in the words of Byron York of National Review. Not only did Jeb Bush win easily but Democratic turnout in the party's south Florida stronghold was down 17 percent from the 1994 Bush-Lawton Chiles race, despite campaign appearances for Bill McBride by Al Gore, 2000 anger incarnate. The fault this time was not in the chads.
"I'm not sure what we did wrong," Mr. McAuliffe declared on Wednesday, no less clueless in defeat than in anticipating victory. Denial, the first of Elisabeth Kubler-Ross's five stages of death and dying, is his party's order of the day. (No. 2, anger, is rapidly yapping at its heels.) Tom Daschle's position is that President Bush drowned out the Democrats by talking about Iraq and North Korea. "We felt we did have the economic plan," he told Paula Zahn on CNN. "We just weren't successful in getting you to cover it."
Nearly every Democratic leader is offering a variation on Dick Gephardt's excuse -- that 9/11 shrouded the election, to the White House's advantage. But if conservatives are rarely more irritating than when they wrap themselves in the flag, liberals are surely at their most annoying when donning the veil of victimhood. The Democrats were not done in by Osama bin Laden or the media or anyone other than themselves. Their intellectual vacuity in this year's campaign was apparent well before 9/11.
It was in May 2001 that the House Democrats issued a cautious energy plan whose cover depicted an all-American family happily washing its S.U.V. It promised that the party would never advocate environmental policies that might jostle "our standard of living." It was in August 2001, as both the economy and George W. Bush's poll numbers were tanking, that Mr. McAuliffe was asked to explain his party's economic plan. "What are the Democrats going to do?" asked Gloria Borger of CBS. "Do you want to repeal this tax cut? Do you want to repeal parts of this tax cut? What?" 
Mr. McAuliffe replied: "I want George Bush . . . when he comes back from vacation, to pull everybody together and put a plan together." A year after 9/11, this non-policy still survived as a major plank in the Democrats' campaign arsenal, with Messrs. Daschle and Gephardt this fall calling for the president to hold a new economic summit.
As the reigning cliche had it, 2002 was the "Seinfeld" election -- an election about nothing. But how could an election in the midst of one war and on the eve of another be about nothing? How could an election at a time of economic torpor be about nothing? Even Jeb Bush, in an arguably Freudian episode of one-upmanship after his victory, said flatly on TV that while Florida was doing well, "the national economy is weak." This election was not about nothing; it's the Democrats who were about nothing. That is hardly the ideal stance from which to fight someone like George W. Bush.
The Bush administration has big ideas. It believes that toppling Saddam Hussein is the slam-dunk gambit that will remake the Arab world to our liking (and Israel's). It has codified a security strategy built on the notion of pre-emptive war. It believes in the partial privatization of Social Security, in rewarding the very wealthiest with a repeal of the estate tax, and in tailoring every conceivable policy, including those governing human, fiscal and environmental health, to the needs of its corporate sponsors. Many Democratic politicians are opposed to these ideas -- or at least to those not supported by Mr. McAuliffe's high-rollers -- but that's not the same as having big ideas of their own.
Foreign policy is a nonstarter with Democrats. At home, we know that they are in favor of "protecting" Social Security and that some of them dream of energy independence, or of universal health insurance in a nation where 41 million people have none at all. But they put forward no serious plans to accomplish such goals, let alone plans specifying a price tag and the means by which to pay the bills. All politics may be local, but the local mimics the national: Bill McBride's star fell when, in a debate with Jeb Bush, he called for mandating smaller public-school class sizes but punted when asked where he might find the billions required to do so.
This lack of seriousness is sometimes matched by a soullessness that all the eulogizing of Paul Wellstone could not obscure. Fear of the N.R.A. led poor Jean Carnahan to invite reporters to watch her shoot skeet. Defending Bob Torricelli, Mr. McAuliffe enthusiastically observed that the controversy over his sleazy gift-grubbing was "creating excitement out there and helping raise more money." 
Two Democratic Senate campaigns a continent apart were marked by gay-baiting. In one of them, Alex Sanders of South Carolina apparently seized on a column I wrote about Rudolph Giuliani in August 2001 to mock the then-mayor's decision to bunk with "two gay men and a Shih Tzu" after he moved out of Gracie Mansion. "Is that South Carolina values?" he pandered in a debate, heedlessly trashing his and his party's record on civil rights.
Mr. Torricelli, Ms. Carnahan and Mr. Sanders are now history. With Mr. Gephardt leaving his leadership position, many Democratic politicians are calling for Mr. McAuliffe's head. Everyone wants "new faces" -- not an easy task for a party whose 11th-hour new faces in this campaign were Frank Lautenberg and Walter Mondale and whose favorite form of ingenue, "new" Kennedys (Andrew Cuomo and Kathleen Kennedy Townsend), went belly-up in the friendly confines of New York and Maryland. The bench is so sparse that Gary Hart's name was tossed around this week. Next up, no doubt: Eugene McCarthy, George McGovern, Jimmy Carter and Mike Dukakis.
Of course there are Democrats who are far less shopworn, but changing the messengers cannot compensate for a lack of message. The Clinton political creed of triangulation, effective in the Gingrich era, no longer works when a triangulating "compassionate conservative" has the White House and can co-opt such Democratic staples as education and prescription drugs. A unified vision composed of actual policies and principles, as opposed to knee-jerk liberal sloganeering, cynical political strategies and anti-Bush whining, is now required. 
Yet Clintonism without Clinton (or even up-to-date takes on Mr. Clinton's best ideas) remains the party's fantasy. This is exemplified not only by a huckster like Mr. McAuliffe but by the relentless search for a telegenic savior, ideally from neither coast, who might magically finesse the difference between the party's liberal base and the American middle (at least until Hillary is ready to run). 
That's the role John Edwards is meant to play, but his timidity to date makes even Al Gore sound like Harry Truman. As for Mr. Gore, he turned up in full sanctimonious lather the day after defeat to instruct Democrats, via Barbara Walters, that they "need to draw clear lines" about their policy differences with Republicans -- a task he utterly failed to accomplish in his own October speech assailing the administration's economic record.
The only truly shocking thing about Tuesday's election is that the Democrats didn't do far worse, or as badly as they deserved. Mr. Bush's high approval ratings notwithstanding, the election numbers reveal a vast opposition to where he is taking this country. But those numbers will not add up until there is an opposition party worthy of the name.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTION: THE DEMOCRATS; 
Pelosi Says She's Secured Votes To Be House Democrats' Leader

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 

 BODY:
Representative Nancy Pelosi said today that she had secured the votes necessary to be elected the new House Democratic leader, putting her in position to become the first woman to head a party in Congress.
 Her chief rival, Martin Frost of Texas, cleared the way when he dropped out of the race early today and endorsed Ms. Pelosi, a liberal from California, after earlier warning that her election could move the party too far to the left. 
 At a news conference at her district headquarters in San Francisco, Ms. Pelosi, 62, said she had at least 105 public commitments from Democratic House members, with more coming in after Mr. Frost's departure from the race. Her office later released a list with 111 names of House Democrats that covered a range of states and ideologies within the party. Both numbers exceed half of the caucus of 208. 
"This race is over," she said of the competition that will formally be decided in a secret ballot next Thursday.
Still, a late entry into the race, Harold E. Ford Jr., a 32-year-old moderate from Tennessee, said he would continue to seek the position. He said he offered a new vision of leadership but would not quantify his support. Many Democrats said he did not have a chance.
Mr. Frost's withdrawal and the apparent coalescing around Ms. Pelosi showed that Democrats were moving quickly to replace the current minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, who said he would leave the post after his party failed for the fourth time during his tenure to regain control of the House. 
The apparent selection of Ms. Pelosi, who now holds the No. 2 post, minority whip, produced contrasting views on whether her taking over as leader of the House Democrats would enhance or harm the party's chances in future elections. 
Some Democratic operatives said her unambiguous stances on a number of hot-button issues would provide voters with a clear alternative to the White House at a time when some Democrats were grousing that the party was not doing enough to distinguish itself from the Republicans. In contrast, some Republican strategists said Ms. Pelosi's liberal stances were too far out of step with the country and would alienate many voters. Page A16. 
The election would elevate Ms. Pelosi to a leadership role alongside Senator Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota, who said today he would again run for Senate Democratic leader.
Ms. Pelosi, who voted against granting the president authority to take unilateral action against Iraq and has a solidly liberal record on social issues like abortion rights, gay rights, expanded health care and economic programs, wasted no time in challenging Republicans.
"There is no question that the Democratic Party is the party of the public interest," said Ms. Pelosi, who said she intended to make the economy and education among the party's priorities. "A big difference with the Republicans is they are the party of special interest; we have to make that clear to the American people."
She also dismissed the perception that she would allow the party to be tagged as left-leaning. "I don't think they chose me as an outspoken liberal," she said of her colleagues. "I think they chose me as a person who can lead the caucus to victory, as a person who can build coalitions among the various sectors of our caucus."
But Republicans said they were pleased with the selection, saying Ms. Pelosi would provide a stark contrast to President Bush. "She is very liberal," said one top Republican staff member. "She opposed the president on tax cuts, on homeland security, Iraq, welfare reform."
But her supporters said they believed the liberal label would not stick, noting her tenure on the Intelligence Committee, which is enmeshed in security matters. "She is a refreshing woman who has championed progressive causes, yet at the same time she has served with distinction on the Intelligence Committee," said Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, calling the liberal tag a "mischaracterization."
It was expected that Mr. Frost and Ms. Pelosi would engage in a pitched battle to take over from Mr. Gephardt, but the fight was brief as Mr. Frost realized he could not catch Ms. Pelosi. "Martin knows how to count," said one ally, who said Mr. Frost did obtain a substantial number of commitments.
In a letter to Democrats releasing them from their pledges to him, Mr. Frost called Ms. Pelosi "a talented and capable party leader." But, in a reference to his worries about the philosophical tilt of the party, Mr. Frost said he would "continue to be an outspoken advocate for the mainstream, centrist views that will lead us to the majority."
Both Ms. Pelosi and Mr. Frost are veteran campaigners and proven fund-raisers, but several Democrats said they believed the telegenic and personable Ms. Pelosi represents a chance to develop a new image of the party.
Mr. Ford, considered to be a future Democratic star, jumped into the race today after first leaning toward Mr. Frost. "Democrats have to offer something more than 'no, no, no,' " said Mr. Ford, a member of the moderate Blue Dog Coalition who is trying to become the first black lawmaker to lead a party.
"If you want something different, if you want a change, if you want to lead in a bold and new direction, if you want to aspire to be a better party than we are right now, I say, give my candidacy a chance," he urged his colleagues at a news conference.
But Democrats said the race appeared to be over and that Ms. Pelosi would rise from the No. 2 position to be the chief spokeswoman for House Democrats, responsible for developing the party's position on the many issues before Congress.
First elected to Congress in 1987 in a special election, Ms. Pelosi has been a member of the Appropriations Committee, an assignment she used to steer funding to her home region. She has been an outspoken critic of China on human rights issues and has opposed renewing favored trade status for that country.
She has said that her opposition to the Iraq resolution grew out of her expertise from her work on the Intelligence Committee, which recently completed public hearings into intelligence lapses surrounding the Sept. 11 attacks.
Ms. Pelosi promised today that she was willing to work with the Bush administration and Congressional Republicans on issues on which they agreed.
"But where we do not have our common ground, we must stand our ground," she said.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: VOTES IN THE BALANCE; 
Mexico's Influence in Security Council Decision May Help Its Ties With U.S.

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8 

 BODY:
President Vicente Fox's decision to support the United States' resolution on Iraq after nudging the Americans toward compromise may produce a double benefit for Mexico. 
 By refusing to support the tougher resolution first proposed by the United States, Mr. Fox has won applause at home for appearing to take a stance against Washington and against a war. And by supporting the final draft of the resolution, he may be able to finally revive his relationship with the United States, which has essentially been frozen since last year's attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. 
 Diplomats from several nations say Mexico played a small but crucial role in forging the consensus that led to today's unanimous Security Council vote, submitting compromise language eventually adopted by all 15 members. It used its position as an elected member of the Security Council to help ensure that a war with Iraq would be "only valid as a last resort with prior explicit authorization from the Security Council," said its United Nations ambassador, Adolfo Aguilar Zinser.
By sticking to its decision in September to side with France's more cautious position in the internal debate, diplomats say, Mexico helped convince the United States to revise the resolution with an eye toward unanimity.
Speaking today, Mr. Fox said of the unanimous vote: "It strengthens the United Nations, it strengthens multilateralism, and it also strengthens Mexico. I think Mexico had a lot to do with the final outcome."
Mexico's foreign minister, Jorge G. Castaneda, said Mexico acted as a go-between among the permanent members of the Security Council in urging the United States toward a middle ground.
"The French and, to a lesser extent, the Russians felt more comfortable saying they were not doing this alone, but that a country close to the United States, a president known for his ties to President Bush and his pro-American stances, was also standing up for a set of the same principles," Mr. Castaneda said.
This engagement on the world stage marks an end to years of diplomatic detachment. It is a new role for an increasingly globalized Mexico, which is the world's 10th-largest nation, and by far the largest of the 10 countries now holding two-year seats on the Security Council. 
Back in the 20th century, when Mexico had a one-party government, it had a one-dimensional foreign policy that could be summed up in one word: nonintervention. When it engaged other nations, as it did in trying to broker peace during the Central American conflicts of the 1980's, it usually did so in a purely Latin American context.
"Perhaps we were a bit isolated, because we were ashamed about not having reached full democracy," Mr. Fox said. Now, he added, "we have matured enough to go out in the world and take part."
Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair, put it more strongly last year, a few weeks before Mexico joined the Security Council: Mexico, he said, has become "a major political force in the world." 
But Mexico recognizes, as do most other nations, that the military, economic and political power of the United States makes the rest of the world look Lilliputian. And the role it played at the United Nations might be interpreted as tying Gulliver down, surrounding the United States with United Nations principles -- rules which, after all, Washington largely wrote when the world body was first formed.
Both sides say the United States and Mexico had no tit-for-tat arrangement in this vote. There was no deal that if Mexico voted with the United States, the Bush administration would begin to back the agreements Mr. Fox is seeking on issues including migration and trade.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, Attorney General John Ashcroft and other cabinet members will visit Mexico City later this month for talks on such issues. And hopes are high in Mexico that the United Nations vote will help restart a relationship Mr. Bush once called as important as any to the United States.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 ELECTION: THE ELECTORATE; 
Some Democratic Losses Linked to White Defections

BYLINE:  By JIM YARDLEY and DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Democrats who are examining some of their most disappointing losses on Tuesday are learning that minority voters turned out in respectable numbers and voted Democratic -- but that the party apparently lost thousands of moderate white voters who supported Bill Clinton and helped elect Southern Democratic governors in 1998 and 2000.
 In the governor's races in South Carolina and Georgia, where Democratic incumbents were defeated, minority turnout met expectations. 
 But Republicans seemed to carry white moderates, according to early Democratic analyses, and turned out unexpectedly high numbers of white conservatives. Gov. Jim Hodges of South Carolina saw his support among whites drop to an estimated 30 percent, from 40 percent in 1998. 
In Maryland, Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend carried Democratic strongholds in her race for governor but lost to Representative Robert L. Ehrlich Jr. because of strong turnout in predominantly white counties. Mr. Ehrlich had a black running mate, Michael S. Steele, for lieutenant governor. 
In Florida, Gov. Jeb Bush turned a close race into a rout largely by winning predominantly white areas where Democratic leaders thought their candidate, Bill McBride, had a chance to compete. 
"I don't think we paid attention to white voters," said Gayle Andrews, a consultant who coordinates advertising and marketing to blacks for the Democrats in Florida and who worked in the McBride campaign.
Of Governor Bush, Ms. Andrews said: "He won overwhelmingly because white folks voted for that man. Black folks didn't vote for that man."
The question of who voted -- and who did not -- is of particular significance for the Democrats' internal fight about which direction to head after their midterm losses. Should the party move left to sharpen its differences with Republicans, or move right in hopes of attracting moderate and independent voters?
Democratic Party officials have not fully analyzed voting from Tuesday, and the decision by Voter News Service not to poll voters leaving the booth has created an absence of the demographic information often used to detect voting trends. Instead, they based their early analyses on independent surveys of voters at the polls and an examination of turnout in crucial counties.
Many Democrats have criticized the national party as failing to offer voters a coherent message or inspire supporters to go to the polls. They also credit President Bush with "nationalizing" the midterm elections by making them a referendum on him and the war against terrorism.
Dick Harpootlian, the Democratic chairman in South Carolina, said Mr. Bush's campaign appearances for Republicans in South Carolina were critical in motivating conservatives and dampening moderates' enthusiasm for Democrats. Mr. Harpootlian said early voting breakdowns suggested that black voters made up 26 percent of the state's overall turnout, a higher figure than in 2000 and in 1998, when Mr. Hodges was elected governor in a mild surprise.
But Mr. Harpootlian said that this year Mr. Hodges nose-dived in popularity with whites. "I think independent white people did not vote," he said. "The folks who turned out were folks who responded to Bush's nationalization of this election."
Even more surprising than the Hodges loss was the defeat of Gov. Roy Barnes of Georgia, who had been mentioned as a prospective 2004 vice-presidential candidate. His Republican challenger, Sonny Perdue, defied the polls and won by five percentage points, generating a heavy turnout in largely white rural areas. In Forsyth County, which is 99 percent white, turnout increased to 32,000 on Tuesday from 20,000 in 1998, the last midterm elections. The numbers in largely white Cherokee County, in Atlanta's outer suburbs, jumped to 41,000 this year from 31,000 four years ago.
Tim Phillips, Mr. Barnes's campaign manager, said the governor carried Fulton and DeKalb Counties in metropolitan Atlanta -- both with large black populations -- by 100,000 votes and got about 450,000 votes from blacks statewide, roughly what the campaign had thought it needed.
Mr. Phillips dismissed speculation that Representative Cynthia McKinney's loss in an August primary kept many of her black supporters from voting. "Cynthia McKinney's district turned out," he said. "That backlash notion has no evidence at all."
But, he added, "we did not, and the nationally the Democratic Party did not, have a sufficiently compelling message."
The Democrats' drubbing in Florida is especially embarrassing after the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Terry McAuliffe, predicted that the party would unseat Governor Bush. Many Democratic leaders had been elated when Mr. McBride narrowly defeated former Attorney General Janet Reno in the party's primary because he was thought to be the sort of white moderate who could attract swing voters in the tradition of the state's last Democratic governor, Lawton Chiles. 
But Mr. Bush won by 13 percentage points, and state Democrats are arguing about whom to blame. An analysis of exit polling sponsored by The Miami Herald and The St. Petersburg Times estimated that Mr. McBride got 94 percent of blacks' votes. Black turnout was 43 percent, more than in the 1998 governor's race, but far less than the record 72 percent set in the 2000 presidential election. The same survey put nonblack turnout at 55 percent.
Still, David Bositis, senior political analyst at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies in Washington, which specializes in issues related to blacks, noted that black voters made up only 11 percent of the electorate -- not enough to have reversed Mr. Bush's 13-point win.
"If McBride was in a real neck-and-neck contest about who was going to be the next governor of Florida, that would be one thing," Mr. Bositis said. "But McBride wasn't. McBride did not generate enough support among white voters to win the election."
Aubrey Jewitt, a political science professor at the University of Central Florida, said Governor Bush's attacks against Mr. McBride on tax issues, coupled with the popularity of his brother the president pushed white moderates to the Republicans.
"Democrats had a tough time attracting swing voters," Mr. Jewitt said, adding, "They have to draw some distinction between what Republicans want and what they want. They have to point out where the Republicans have gone too far right."
Turnout was also pivotal in the two most populous states, California and Texas. In California, a Democratic stronghold, analysts are estimating that only 36 percent of eligible adults voted, a record low. Gov. Gray Davis won re-election even though he trailed his Republican challenger by three percentage points among whites. Turnout among minorities was so low that Mr. Davis won by only five points after polls gave him a double-digit lead among all voters.
In Texas, Democrats built their campaign strategy on drawing record numbers of black and Hispanic voters. The candidate for governor, Tony Sanchez, was Hispanic; the Senate candidate, Ron Kirk, was black. Democrats hoped their presence would bring out minorities while their moderate message would attract white swing voters.
But Republicans dominated. Estimates of Hispanic turnout range from 16 percent to 21 percent of the total, nowhere near enough to counter heavy voting in largely white Republican suburbs. Polls of voters conducted for Gov. Rick Perry showed that he received 72 percent of the white vote; over all, he defeated Mr. Sanchez by 18 points.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, left, tries to help figure out what exactly went wrong for the Democratic Party, analysts note that black turnout held in core areas, but that whites who had previously voted for Democrats appeared to vote Republican. A big setback to Democrats was the victory Gov. Jeb Bush enjoyed over Bill McBride, who was thought to appeal to the very people who re-elected Mr. Bush. (Associated Press)
