HEADLINE: NO CHILD LEFT BEHIND; 
On the F List

BYLINE:  By Abby Goodnough; Abby Goodnough covers education for The Times.

DATELINE: Elmira, N.Y. 

 BODY:
I DON'T remember much about my middle school years. There was the intricate way we folded notes before tossing them to each other across a classroom; the ice scraper I made in shop class; the talent show in which my friends and I danced to the theme from "Fame" and (deservedly, in retrospect) got booed. Though I cannot dredge up a single memory about academics, I always thought I had gotten a sound enough education. 
 But there it was, on the list of 487 failing schools that New York State released in September: Ernie Davis Middle School, Elmira -- my own school, where almost everyone in my upstate hometown enrolled without a second thought. 
 As an education reporter, I had written many a story about these lists of shame and the dismal New York City schools that dominated them. To be fair, the list that Ernie Davis landed on is different from the annual state list of "schools under registration review," whose test scores are so consistently awful that they are under threat of being closed. This list was mandated by No Child Left Behind, the new federal act that requires states to cite not only the worst-performing schools but also those with high levels of poverty and disappointing scores that have not met improvement targets over several years. My school fell into that less onerous category. 
Still, the news was bad. How could Ernie Davis have fallen so far since 1983? Elmira, a city of 33,000 in the middle of the state's border with Pennsylvania, had many educated, middle-class residents who cared about the quality of its schools. But Elmira was economically depressed even in my youth; like other upstate cities, it had lost manufacturing jobs and residents and would continue to do so after my family left in 1992. 
Now, on a rainy morning this past October, it seemed even more faded. More downtown stores were shuttered; others looked as if they had the same dusty merchandise in their windows as when I was 13 and trolled them for Journey records and Izod shirts. The Elmira 1-2-3 had gasped its last cinematic breath in September.
Worse, the Arthur W. Booth Elementary School, where I tried to read every book in the library from the second through the sixth grade, is to close because of dropping enrollment. It looked melancholy as I drove past, its playground scarred and its dark red window casings like drooping eyelids.
Ernie Davis Middle School -- named after the late Heisman Trophy winner, who grew up in Elmira in the 1950's -- is in one of the poorest parts of town, next to a housing project that looks quaint compared with the behemoth complexes that surround many schools in New York City. It serves 800 students -- about 175 more than in my day, but only because sixth graders now attend along with seventh and eighth graders.
About 25 percent of the students are black, most of the rest are white. But poverty in Elmira has always crossed racial lines: 40 percent of Ernie Davis students qualify for the free-lunch program, a larger number than when I attended.
From the outside, Ernie Davis looked the same: fortresslike with dull, sand-colored brick. But through the heavy doors, everything seemed bright. The hallways were not as dingy; the lighting no longer gave off a greenish-yellow cast. The school had been renovated about five years ago, and the inside was pleasantly unrecognizable.
Christopher Spezialetti, who has been the principal for just over a year, gamely welcomed me. Over his desk hung a picture of Mark Twain -- who wrote parts of Huckleberry Finn in Elmira, by the way -- with his quote, "I never let my schooling interfere with my education." What might the officials who monitor failing schools think of that?
Mr. Spezialetti came up through the ranks in Elmira, working at three other schools before coming to Davis in July 2001. An astounding 40 percent of Davis's teachers left that summer, many from my era and ready to retire. The exodus worked well for Mr. Spezialetti, allowing him to handpick several dozen new teachers and, in his words, "build my own team." As it happened, the school's eighth-grade test scores rose sharply his first year, by 9 percentage points in math and 14 in reading.
"It was the previous three years that got us on the list," he said wryly. Under No Child Left Behind, schools that had large numbers of students who failed high-stakes tests in 1999, 2000 and 2001 and did not make adequate yearly progress, as determined by the state, were put on the list. Ernie Davis's recent progress will not get it off; it just missed its target on the reading test in 2002 and will have to show even steeper improvement in each of the next two years.
I asked Mr. Spezialetti and Laura Sherwood, the district superintendent, how my school had ended up on the list. 
New York State introduced tough new tests for fourth and eighth graders in 1999 as part of a drive to set and enforce higher academic standards. Well over half of the state's students failed the tests that year, and while performance has improved, hundreds of schools are still struggling to get their students over the significantly raised bar.
Middle school scores have been especially low, and educators have offered a number of possible reasons: a shortage of qualified math teachers, the difficulty of teaching students who are struggling with the turbulence of early adolescence, a reluctance to adjust curriculums and teaching methods to the rigorous new standards.
Ernie Davis has wrestled with the last problem in particular. For decades, Ms. Sherwood said, its staff embraced the "private practice" approach to teaching.
"Teachers taught what they thought was important, so alignment of curriculum and testing got to be a big problem," she said. "The days of teachers being able to choose their loved areas of study and teach them in isolation are over."
Another problem, Mr. Spezialetti said, was the tendency to emphasize memorization of facts instead of the higher-level thinking and writing skills that the new state tests measure. 
At that, I did start to recall having to copy boring outlines off the blackboard day after day and memorizing dates, names, literary terms and periodic table symbols. No wonder it was all a blur.
I also began remembering how Ernie Davis students had been divided into two tracks: high-achieving students like me -- most white and upper middle class -- were "Regents track," meaning we took more rigorous courses that prepared us for the college-preparatory Regents exams. But most students, including just about all the minorities, took "local" courses that led to the far less demanding Regents Competency Tests. We honors students referred to our classmates as "locals," as if predicting they would never make it out of Elmira and into the big, exciting world that we could not wait to make our mark on.
"We used to say, 'Ten percent of our students are not succeeding; that's not too bad,"' Mr. Spezialetti said. "Now those 10 percent are being put under a microscope. The focus now is on every single child."
The news that Ernie Davis had landed on the ignominious list came just a day before school started in September. When Mr. Spezialetti told the staff, "It was really hard for them to swallow," he said. The No Child Left Behind Act requires "schools in need of improvement," as most on the list are known, to inform parents of their status and give them the option of transferring their children to a higher-performing school.
A local talk-radio host slammed Ernie Davis on his show that week, calling the school terrible and urging parents to yank their children out. But not a single student has transferred to Elmira's other choice, Broadway Middle School. In fact, parents called that week to pledge support and vent about unreasonably high standards. Several wanted to start a letter-writing campaign to the governor. Mr. Spezialetti talked them out of it.
Schools on the list have to develop a detailed improvement plan by December, and Mr. Spezialetti is on the case. He is breaking down the test data into "itty-bitty pieces" to see what kinds of questions stumped students and which children need the most help. He has discovered, for example, that students who spend all three years at Ernie Davis do much better than the many who parachute in from other schools in seventh or eighth grade.
Special-education and black students have disproportionately low scores, and Mr. Spezialetti is trying to give them extra help too. Until recently, test results were not broken down by race, and special-education students did not take standardized tests at all, so many schools let these groups languish.
In every subject, the curriculum is now focused like a laser beam on the skills measured by the eighth-grade tests. On every classroom wall, posters broadcast test-taking tips like TS-SS-C to remind students that expository writing samples should include a topic sentence; supporting sentences that use facts, examples and details; and a conclusion. Language arts teachers are coaching math and science teachers on how to strengthen writing skills with word problems and lab reports. Students are even nudged to ask and answer questions in complete sentences to better prepare for the short-answer and essay questions on the state reading test.
To improve performance on multiple-choice questions, Ernie Davis is experimenting with active reading, in which students underline, make notes and even draw pictures by words or phrases they find confusing or important. The main idea is to improve reading comprehension, a section of the test that the students struggle with.
Brenda Baker, who started teaching English at the school 14 years ago, now spends much of her time helping teachers in various subjects strengthen their students' test-taking skills. Having to focus so intensely on tests frustrates her.
"I eat, sleep and drink that baby," she said of the reading exam, which eighth graders take in January. 
Mary Ellen Tuttle, a science teacher, said she realized just how test- and standards-oriented the curriculum had become when a seventh grader preparing to write a lab report asked, "Is this expository writing or is this narrative writing?"
Popping into classes, I found the opposite of what I anticipated: there was a lot of energy in the rooms; teachers seemed dead serious about preparing students for the state tests, and students appeared eager to soak up the test skills and strategies that have become the emphasis of most lessons.
While Mr. Spezialetti believes Ernie Davis will come off the list in the next few years, he worries about variables that are beyond his control. Because of the floundering economy, many more new students enrolled than usual this year, including some who could no longer afford Catholic school and others whose families had moved to Elmira to live with relatives. Some of those students will need lots of extra help preparing for the tests.
Mr. Spezialetti also worries that the test questions might be more difficult this year, the scoring tougher. Regardless, it will be a little harder for Ernie Davis students to get over the bar this year, since the improvement target set by the state will be a little higher.
"I'm not sure we can move as fast as the state wants us to," Mr. Spezialetti said.
SHOULD they have to? I was torn. Ernie Davis had defied my expectations; it seemed to be providing a better education in 2002 than in 1983. A lot of the credit goes to the state for ratcheting up standards, dropping its two-track system and requiring all students to pass the rigorous Regents exams.
But mostly on its own initiative, the school has created opportunities that were woefully absent before: after-school and weekend tutoring; a "character club" for students with good grades, attendance and attitude; even regular field trips. The school has divided its students and teachers into teams that stay together all year, providing a far more intimate environment than I had experienced and improving every child's chances of getting special attention. 
Yet the test-taking tips posted everywhere and Mr. Spezialetti's piles of data suggest a single-minded mission. Surely there was less time now to linger over great short stories, write poems, embark on creative history projects or goof around with showy science experiments, the kind where the teacher blows something up and the students gleefully applaud. 
There weren't nearly enough of those inspiring, memorable lessons in my day, but with expectations rising so sharply, creativity and intellectual debate should be prized.
As I drove off, my thoughts returned to the Mark Twain poster above Mr. Spezialetti's desk. Suddenly, its presence made a lot of sense.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The author and her yearbook from Ernie Davis Middle School, a casualty of the new federal education law. (Naum Kazhdan/The New York Times; Kevin Rivoli for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Other One 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN; Jodi Wilgoren is Midwest bureau chief of The Times.

DATELINE: Iowa City 

 BODY:
Which of the following statements is not true about the ACT, the college admissions exam that has been the SAT's quiet competitor for nearly half a century?
 a. More colleges and universities accept ACT scores than SAT scores. 
 b. The overhaul of the SAT currently under way will make it more like the ACT.
c. The ACT was invented by a member of the College Board, the organization that runs the SAT.
d. The ACT predicts success in college based on intelligence and innate ability. 
The answer is d. Since its debut in 1959, the ACT Assessment -- formerly known as the American College Testing Program -- has emphasized achievement over aptitude. Questions on the three-hour, four-part test are drawn from high school curriculums, not general knowledge, designed to test how much students have learned rather than how smart they are. There are no trick answers.
"We really believe that tag line that we have: education for life's transitions," ACT's chief executive, Richard L. Ferguson, said over lunch in the humble cafeteria of the company's headquarters here in the heartland. "Assessment ought to have a real-life meaning for individuals. The assessment is part of a process. It's not an endpoint."
This should be the golden moment for the ACT. 
Over the last decade, its style of standards-based testing has become ubiquitous in kindergarten through 12th grade, amid a strong national consensus that such assessments are crucial to prepare students for college. Two states, Illinois and Colorado, have recently made the ACT mandatory for all high school juniors, and seven others have adopted the company's 8th- and 10th-grade exams, which are modeled on the ACT and intended to get younger students focused on, and ready for, college. More than 1.1 million of last spring's graduating seniors took the ACT, not too far off the 1.27 million who took the SAT.
In February 2001, when Richard C. Atkinson, president of the University of California system, raised serious questions about the reliability and fairness of the aptitude-based SAT, his speech sounded much like one given decades earlier by ACT's founder, E.F. Lindquist. In response, the College Board announced plans last May to revamp the SAT by 2005, ditching its trademark verbal analogies in favor of short critical reading passages, adding more advanced math problems -- in short, remaking itself in the image of its lesser-known, less-controversial counterpart.
But it remains unclear how the convergence of the two competing exams will affect the smaller, softer stepsister, which is dominant in the large state universities of the country's midsection and South, yet scarce among elite private institutions and on the coasts. 
The ACT has long been like Pepsi to the SAT's Coke, Avis to its Hertz -- for some in the college admissions game, the SAT is Kleenex, the other test the brand whose name you often forget. After decades as the anti-SAT, the ACT -- which is more popular now among students and schools than ever before -- may face a new challenge in distinguishing itself as the differences between the two tests disappear.
"The mystery is, why doesn't everybody use the ACT?" asked Nicholas Lemann, author of "The Big Test: The Secret History of the American Meritocracy" (1999), the definitive book on the SAT. "If the College Board had decided to go the route of resistance" when Dr. Atkinson threatened to drop the SAT I reasoning test, he said, "then there would have been much more opportunity for ACT. Since they went the route of accommodation and adjustment, there's less opportunity." 
If the SAT is copying the ACT's testing tactics, executives here in Iowa City are, at the same time, mimicking the aggressive marketing strategies of the Manhattan-based College Board. ACT has quadrupled its output of news releases and begun a syndicated column about preparing for college that is carried in some 50 newspapers. It has sent representatives to hundreds of high school workshops in the crucial state of California and to national business and school-board conferences, armed with posters outlining how each point on the ACT corresponds with a specific curriculum standard. Since 1998 ACT employees have spent a day at 272 of its top client colleges for "service reviews," intended to help administrators better use the test data. The wonks on the organization's board have been replaced with high-profile names in education, including Richard W. Riley, former secretary of education, and Roy Romer, superintendent of schools in Los Angeles.
"Imitation is not always the sincerest form of flattery," admitted Mr. Ferguson, a professorial statistician who lacks the sound-bite expertise of his counterpart at the College Board, Gaston Caperton, the former governor of West Virginia. "Making the SAT more like the ACT? The real thing is where I come from. Now it's up to me to show how much more we represent."
Mr. Caperton dismisses any suggestion that the SAT is turning into its rival, pointing out that ACT announced plans for an optional writing segment after the College Board unveiled similar blueprints; the board was also first in deciding to stop flagging scores of disabled students who get extra test time. "We are the leader and we are the innovator," he said. "That's the history of the ACT: they see what we do and then they follow behind."
ACT'S dens of anonymous cubicles sit on a quiet campus just off Interstate 80, 232 miles west of Chicago. It is far both physically and psychologically from the ivy-covered ivory towers that dominate the higher education debate, and also from the media swirl of New York and California. 
Dr. Lindquist, who died in 1978, was a professor of education at the University of Iowa down the road. Before the ACT, he invented the Iowa Tests of Basic Skills, still one of the premier standardized assessments for grade schoolers, and its high school version, the Iowa Tests of Educational Development; he also helped create the original high school equivalency exam, the G.E.D. Next came a machine known as Mark I, which quickly scanned bubble sheets, counting 50,000 right answers in a second -- and doing in a week what it had taken 60 women to do in six.
The College Board was among the early users of Professor Lindquist's Mark I for what was then called the Scholastic Aptitude Test, an I.Q. type of exam first given in 1926 to help the Ivy League and other top-tier institutions filter the best and brightest from their piles of wealthy, well-educated applicants. 
In 1958, Dr. Lindquist, a member of the College Board, urged his colleagues to develop a test for the legions of less selective universities overwhelmed by the postwar expansion in applicants, a test of broad competencies, not of memorization, gauging mastery of curriculum, not God-given mind capacities. "The examination must make him feel he has earned the right to go to college by his own efforts, not that he is entitled to college admission because of his innate abilities or aptitudes, regardless of what he has done in high school," Dr. Lindquist said at a testing conference at the time. "The examination must be regarded by him as an achievement test or as a test of his acquired or developed abilities. The tasks constituting the examination must therefore obviously correspond to recognized high school learning experiences."
When his proposal was rejected by the College Board, Dr. Lindquist decided to create his own alternative. He partnered with Ted McCarrel, Iowa's dean of admissions, who helped persuade his counterparts at other state institutions to drop the entrance exams they had developed on their own in favor of the ACT. On Nov. 7, 1959 -- 33 years after the advent of the SAT -- 75,406 students took the first ACT test. 
The exam cost $3 then; today it is $25 (the SAT is $26). The company had six full-time employees; now it has 1,150. In 1970, 49 percent of those who took the test were women and 80 percent white. Today, 56 percent are women and 69 percent white. 
The biggest shift in the exam itself came in 1989, when the two reading tests, in social sciences and natural sciences, were replaced with today's more general reading section and a science section; math got a little harder, partly in response to engineering schools that wanted to better discern among high-level applicants. Many items in the English portion, though, could have appeared in any of the last 43 years.
As with the SAT, teachers and college professors from around the country write the items. The content, however, is guided by a national curriculum survey that ACT has conducted every three or four years since 1976, asking some 15,000 teachers in grades 7 through 12, and a similar number of professors, to rank the relative importance of skills in their subjects.
"The assessment has changed as the curriculum has changed: it's not a revolution, it's an evolution," said Donald J. Carstensen, vice president for educational services at ACT. "Probably more important is the change that's occurred in the educational environment. It is fashionable to be thinking about assessment as a measure of achievement."
Though the ACT and SAT were born of contrasting philosophies and to serve starkly different markets, they are now, in large measure, seen as interchangeable. The most virulent test-haters tend to have far less venom for the ACT than the SAT, but they deride both for being weak predictors of success in college. Research shows that each is about 25 percent effective in predicting success in college (high school grades are a better tool).
"At their roots they're quite different; in the reality they're not all that different," said Bob Schaeffer of the group FairTest in Cambridge, Mass. "It is still a one-shot test. It's all multiple choice; it's largely factual regurgitation. No test can measure creativity, perseverance, capability to overcome obstacles. It measures how well you've mastered the particular set of skills and knowledge that are on the test."
AT the Kaplan test prep center in downtown Chicago, seven high school students chewed on No. 2 pencils as they practiced strategies for conquering the ACT. One of the very first things they learn is that there are no penalties for wrong answers -- unlike on the SAT, which is designed so that if someone guessed on every item, right answers would be canceled out by wrong ones, for a score of zero.
"If you can eliminate any of the wrong answers on the test," explained the Kaplan teacher, Jim Holcomb, "you're going to do a much better job and improve your test scores dramatically."
The English section has 75 grammar, punctuation and writing-style items to complete in 45 minutes. Kaplan's rule: Read until you have enough information to select the best answer. The Kaplan method: Predict the answer before looking at the options; eliminate answers you know are wrong; plug in the remaining choices; select the best one.
For math, with 60 algebra, geometry and simple trigonometry items in 60 minutes, Kaplan offers "four questions for problem solving": What do I want to know? What do I know already? What can I do with what I know already? Is that what I want to know (am I done)?
The funny thing about taking a test-prep class for the ACT is that everyone involved with the test, including Kaplan test-preppers, pretty much agrees that the best way to prepare for it, besides taking practice exams to get familiar with the directions, is to study hard in school. 
"It's like a high school exam, where it mostly tests did you learn what you were supposed to learn -- every question is designed to see whether a student paid attention in high school," explained Eirik Johnson, who has taught ACT and SAT courses at Kaplan in Chicago for 24 years. "Ordinary high school teachers could probably help students prepare for the ACT. I doubt most high school teachers could help students prepare for the SAT in a meaningful way, because most high school teachers aren't very good critical thinkers."
Kaplan is a bit stingy with its figures but does allow that the ACT accounts for about 10 percent of its business nationally, mostly in the central region of Chicago and six Midwestern states (where it is 52 percent of the total) and the Great Lakes region of five Midwestern states (28 percent). There has been a recent boom, though: ACT business is up 35 percent nationwide this year over last; SAT business has increased 11 percent.
Of the seven students -- five seniors, two juniors -- in Mr. Holcomb's class, only one planned to take both the SAT and the ACT: Lanelle Lanton, who said, "I'd just rather have it so colleges can look at both." Jose Rivera, the lone man in the class, was there to try to raise his score from a 16 to the 18 he needs to play Division I baseball, or even the 21 required for an athletic scholarship. Others had taken the ACT as juniors under the new state requirement but hoped to increase their scores by 7 or 8 points before applying to colleges this fall. 
"It'll pay off once I get a good job," said Ms. Lanton, 16, whose first choice is Tennessee State University. "You get into a good college, the better chance you have of getting a good job." Iffath Hussain, 17, said that "it depends on the person as well -- if you're strong in English and math, you'd take the SAT," whereas the ACT allows people to strut their science knowledge, too. Martina Smith, 16, said that "if you attend public school, you may not be as prepared for the SAT."
"We learn more about the ACT rather than the SAT," she explained. "In class, we're taught we have to prepare for the ACT."
A map showing where the two tests are most prevalent looks a lot like the red-and-blue map showing Republican (ACT) and Democratic (SAT) electoral votes. A student in New England may never have heard of the ACT, while one growing up in Illinois would be unlikely to consider taking anything else. This geographic pattern began with the tests' founding but has been twisted by quirks of history, like the adoption of the SAT in the 60's to determine certain scholarships in California (now, the committee accepts either test). 
It is largely about context -- and habit. Mr. Lemann suggests it is "the phenomenon economists call path dependence."
"Once you start doing things in any particular way," he said, "and then many, many millions of people and institutions get accustomed to dealing with whatever way that is, then the cost of change becomes incredibly high. That explains the persistence of things like the typewriter keyboard layout that make absolutely no rational sense."
Ninety-one institutions do not accept SAT scores, including several campuses of the University of Wisconsin and private Christian institutions like Bob Jones University. Far fewer, 11, say no to ACT scores -- notably Wake Forest in North Carolina, the California Institute of Technology and two campuses of the City University of New York (Baruch and Staten Island). "Wake Forest has always used the SAT I as the required test and has rarely had complaints from students," Martha Allman, director of admissions, wrote in an e-mail message about why her institution would not consider ACT scores. "We have been satisfied through the years with use of the SAT as one factor in our process and currently have no plans to change our testing policy."
Harvard College, too, has been using the SAT for generations -- it was mandatory for applicants starting in 1935. About 10 years ago, with an eye toward attracting students from public high schools in the heartland who were typically underrepresented, Harvard decided to accept the ACT as well. Marlyn McGrath Lewis, its director of admissions, said that 1 in 5 of last year's 19,609 applicants submitted ACT scores, but a third to a half of those offered SAT scores as well. "The ACT is a good test, and we know how to use it," Ms. McGrath Lewis said. "We don't admit people on the basis of tests anyway."
IN a conference room at its Iowa City headquarters, three ACT vice presidents were going over a PowerPoint presentation for a national business conference. The odd thing was, college entrance exams barely came up. Instead, Cynthia Board Schmeiser, head of the development division, was focused on what she calls the "readiness crisis."
Forty percent of college-bound students are not taking enough core courses. Half need remedial English or math when they get to campus. A third of freshmen don't make it to sophomore year. Less than half get their degrees.
"We do have to help kids be more prepared, that is driving a lot of what we do -- getting to kids earlier," Dr. Schmeiser said. "If we get kids in the right courses it can make a difference. If we can make those courses better it can make a difference. Our priorities are to help every kid to get ready and be ready for what they want to do when they walk out of high school."
For years -- well, decades -- ACT struggled to persuade institutions to accept its scores. Now its focus is on helping colleges and universities better use the data ACT provides, for course placement and to more fully know their applicants through ACT's student surveys.
More recently, though, ACT has focused on younger students with an assessment system incorporating a test for 8th graders (called Explore) and for 10th graders (Plan). Taking these earlier versions of the ACT -- not unlike the PSAT, which is used to determine National Merit Scholarships -- enables students to find gaps in their education early on and fill them while there is still time. 
Last year, about 833,000 students took the 10th-grade test, which was introduced in 1986, and 480,000 took the eighth-grade test, which was started in 1991.
ACT officials point to states like Oklahoma, where the assessment package was adopted in 1993 and nearly 90,000 students now take one of the tests. During that time, the state's average ACT score rose from 19.5 to 20.5; the percentage of seniors headed to college increased to 49 percent in 2001 from 32 percent in 1987, while the number of students at the state's universities needing remediation dropped and graduation rates increased. 
For ACT, California is the next -- and most important -- frontier, if only because of its size: 40,744 of the state's seniors took the ACT last year, while 161,975 took the SAT (compare that to Iowa, ACT's home state, where nearly every college-bound senior takes the test -- 23,805 last year, compared with 1,764 SAT takers). About 27 percent of applicants to the University of California over the last four years have taken both the SAT and the ACT, assuming one or the other test would better display their talents, or that the combination would somehow offer a fuller portrait. But just 1.4 percent submitted only ACT scores, while 71 percent offered just SAT's. 
When Dr. Atkinson made his landmark speech last year calling for achievement rather than aptitude tests, many at ACT were gleeful. But they grew frustrated when, instead of simply embracing the ACT, the University of California worked with the College Board to reengineer its offering. ACT also moved quickly to add an optional writing test -- the new SAT will have a required essay portion -- so it could compete in California. 
"We should be having tests that are aligned with our expectations, that's a lot of what's behind our going after content-driven exams," said Barbara Sawrey, chairwoman of the University of California board that develops policy on admissions. "We want students to have choice, we don't want to be in the position to say, 'This is the one and only test."'
While the ACT is driven by high school curriculum, Mr. Caperton said, the new SAT will test "college success skills" -- critical thinking through reading, writing and arithmetic. The College Board also offers the SAT II subject tests, which go in depth on a narrow curriculum area like chemistry or American history.
"What do they have that compares with Advanced Placement?" Mr. Caperton said. "What do they have that compares with our 22 subject-matter tests? ACT is basically a test that looks at how well somebody has done in high school. That's different than what the SAT is." As for aptitude, he said: "We've moved away from that, but we haven't moved away from looking at one's ability to think and reason."
With the new SAT, the debate on aptitude versus achievement will dissipate, if not die, leaving ACT to reposition its argument against Brand X. 
Mr. Ferguson is quick to point out the remaining differences: SAT still has no science test. Writing as an option will save students who don't need it time and money. The ACT, now, has more experience at this kind of testing than its older competitor.
"The ACT stays intact, we've got all the research and all the data behind it," he said over a bowl of lightning chili, an egg salad sandwich and a half pint of skim milk in the ACT cafeteria. "And we have all these support systems in place that weren't developed in a year or two to respond to a requirement but were developed over decades. We're not making it up now."
The question is whether people on the faraway coasts hear him.

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE 

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
'American Icon'
While most artists evolve, moving from one style or concept to another, Will Barnet's journey through social realism, abstraction and figurative works produced works so different from each other that they could have been done by several artists, all of them displaying consummate skill and a gift for engaging one's undivided attention.
 Mr. Barnet, 91, has won numerous awards in the United States and abroad and has been a teacher and mentor to generations of students at the Art Students League, Yale, Cornell and the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. 
 "Will Barnet: An American Icon," an exhibition of 23 paintings, etchings and lithographs is being presented at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield through next Sunday. 
The works are mainly portraits of friends and family from the 1970's through the 1990's; there are two from the 1940's, including a drypoint self-portrait resurrected from plates that were wrapped in newspaper and discovered in a closet. Visiting hours are Monday through Thursday from noon to 5 p.m.; today and next Sunday from noon to 4 p.m.
Information: (203) 365-7650.

Chamber Music Concert
A 16th-century work titled "Magnificat Quinti Toni" by the Italian composer Andrea Rota will be presented in an arrangement for 12 brass instruments when Yale's Chamber Music Society gives a concert of early Renaissance and modern music for organ, brass and percussion Tuesday at 8 p.m. in Battell Chapel. Yale faculty members and the Yale Brass Ensemble will also play works by Hovannes, Dupre, Gabrielli and Frescobaldi, among others. Tickets are $12, students $6.
Information: (203) 432-4158. 

Global Warming
Bill McKibben, a visiting scholar in environmental studies at Middlebury College in Vermont, has written numerous books on environmental subjects. He is best known for "The End of Nature," a book about global warming that has been translated into 20 languages and is in a 10th anniversary printing.
Mr. McKibben will present two lectures this week. On Thursday at 4 p.m. he will speak on "Crossing Thresholds: The Environment as Moral Challenge" at the Dodd Research Center on the UConn campus in Storrs. Admission is free. Information: (860) 486-4500. 
On Friday from 8 a.m. to 10 a.m. he will be the keynote speaker at the 22nd annual economic conference of the Tunxis Community College Foundation and Advisory Board at the Hartford Marriott in Farmington. His subject will be "The Connection Between Environmental Policies and Economic Prosperity." Admission is by a tax-deductible donation to student scholarships.
Reservations: (860) 679-9526. 

'Pleasures of Collecting'
The Bruce Museum in Greenwich has scheduled several programs in conjunction with its "Pleasures of Collecting" exhibition.
Today from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. a panel discussion by a group of art dealers will shed light on collecting art in the current volatile market. They include Richard L. Feigen of Richard L. Feigen & Company, Philippe Alexandre of Alexandre Gallery and Polly Sartori of Sotheby's 19th-century European paintings department.
An hourlong film titled "Van Gogh in Arles: In a Brilliant Light" will be shown Wednesday at 10:30 a.m., followed by coffee and discussion. Admission to both programs is free with museum admission of $5, $4 for older adults. Reservations: (203) 869-0376.

Art and Justice
The murder trial and execution some 75 years ago of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, avowed anarchists, generated explosive political protests around the world and inspired a flood of art in every discipline. One example was Ben Shahn's series of paintings and prints on the subject, which is on view in an exhibition called "Justice on Trial: Ben Shahn's Case for Sacco and Vanzetti" at the Yale Art Gallery through Dec. 29.
Several related programs were organized in connection with the exhibition, including Thursday at 4 p.m. when a conversation about Sacco and Vanzetti and the Italian-American Community will be led by Patricia Klindienst, a writer and Neil Thomas Proto, lawyer and adjunct professor at Georgetown University's School of Public Policy. 
A guided tour of the exhibition and screening of "In Search of History: The True Story of Sacco and Vanzetti," produced by the History Channel and A & E television will follow the discussion. Admission is free.
Information: (203) 432-0600.

Facelift for Warner Theater
In 1931, the Warner Theater in Torrington was opened as an 1,800-seat Art Deco movie palace by the Warner Brothers Studio, described as "Connecticut's most beautiful theater." The theater was badly damaged when the Naugatuck River overflowed in 1955. The studio repaired and reopened it but federal mandates at the time required that the studios divest themselves of their theaters and it was sold. The nonprofit Northwest Connecticut Association for the Arts raised $132,000 to buy it in 1980 and reopen it as a performing arts center in 1983.
An extensive face-lift has been in progress since last summer, and on Saturday at 6:30 p.m the ribbon will be cut for yet another reopening with Linda Eder, a Broadway star, as the headliner at 8 p.m. 
Information: (860) 489-7180.

Larson's Farm Lives
A farm built in 1825 once thrived for generations where New Milford High School now stands on Route 7. The farm inspired Lorraine Ryan to create "Larson's Farm Trilogy," three paintings reproduced in limited edition prints as a record of life in Connecticut as it used to be.
Components of the trilogy: "Larson's Farm Market," "Chores Done on Larson's Farm" and "The Larson's Farmhouse" will be part of a three-day show called "Connecticut Artists at Woodbury's Old Town Hall," containing the work of nearly three dozen award-winning artists and craftsmen. Organized by Fine Line Gallery in Woodbury, the show's hours are Friday from noon to 6 p.m., Saturday and Sunday from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.
Information: (203) 266-0110.

Open House for Artists
Today is the last day of the Stamford Loft Artists Association's open house.
From 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., the public is invited to tour the studios, talk to the painters, sculptors, ceramicists, photographers, printmakers and collagists, among others. The building, which once housed the Yale and Towne Lock company, is at 737 Canal Street, one block south of Exit 8 of I-95. Information: (203) 323-4153. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island; 
School Projects Are Designed for Use by the Public

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE 

 BODY:
AS school districts update aging facilities, more school buildings are being designed for use both by students and the public. 
 "The walls between school and community are crumbling everywhere," said Philip Cicero, superintendent of the Center Moriches Union Free School District in Suffolk County, which is constructing a new library media center designed for access by its residents. "We are working collaboratively and sharing resources," he said. "That mentality was not there 20 years ago." 
 The collaboration has come about as districts attempt to take full advantage of costly construction projects, according to Charles Szuberla, coordinator of facilities management and information services for the New York State Education Department. 
"Over the past 10 years, the buildings have gotten larger to provide additional services," he said. "Construction has involved a fairly significant investment, so people want to know the buildings are being used more than just eight hours a day. Districts are anxious that if they made the investment in capital construction, they would like to have the community feel they had a part in that investment." 
Although the number of capital projects approved in Nassau and Suffolk's 129 school districts decreased to 478 in the 2001-2 school year from 485 the previous year, the total project costs increased by more than 38 percent, to $969.6 million from $699.1 million, according to the state's office of facilities planning. 
About 25 percent of the projects approved in Nassau in the 2001-2 school year were new buildings or additions, while in Suffolk, where there is more land for expansion, the percentage was more than 50 percent.
In the town of Brookhaven, the Longwood School District, which covers three communities and 53 square miles, has undertaken a $107 million project that includes major additions to its high school and middle school. New multipurpose rooms and gymnasiums have been designed to play a dual role -- for students and the public, said Joseph Medina, the director of facilities. The areas that will be used by the public are being placed so they can be sealed off and served either by a separate entrance or through the school's main entrance. 
A short distance to the west, the Sachem School District, which has 15,000 students, is building a second middle school and high school as part of a $228 million project. All parts of the building are being designed so that they can be open for public use during nonschool hours, including swimming pools, classrooms with computers and the home economics kitchens, said Bruce Singer, the assistant superintendent. The district looks at the new construction as "more opportunities for more people," he said. 
The Center Moriches and East Williston school districts have each planned library-media centers as separate buildings attached to the school and designed to be open to the public after school hours. 
"This is a new approach to design in addressing usability by the public and has come up in other districts as they see themselves serving the public on many levels," said Paul Anderson, an architect at the Spector Group of North Hills, which is the architect for both districts. "The key is to design a function so they don't have to open the whole building," he said. 
In such designs, public areas and bathrooms are located strategically so they are accessible while other areas not in use are blocked off, thus saving on maintenance and security costs, he said.
THE two school districts had different needs in planning their media centers, said Michael Spector, the principal at the Spector Group.
Center Moriches, a suburban community with a periphery of farmland, is midway between Montauk and the Nassau-Queens border. It is "like a school in the Midwest," Mr. Spector said. "It is the icon of the community, where people congregate on a Saturday night." 
The East Williston high school -- called the Wheatley School -- is in the village of Old Westbury, which lacks a public library. There is a total enrollment of 1,758 students in the East Williston district. It serves the village of East Williston, which has 5,000 residents, and parts of the surrounding villages of Old Westbury, Mineola, Albertson, Roslyn Heights and East Hills.
A proposition approved by voters in 2000 included $17.8 million for additions, including media centers, to the district's three schools. The high school's 5,000-square-foot media center, which was completed in September, cost $1,265,000. 
There are plans to open the high school's center to the public some time in the future, said Carolyn Harris, the district's superintendent.
"We felt that in this particular community because there is no public library available to the people of Old Westbury, the media center would be part of a vision to learn together," she said. "It would be wonderful to have an intergenerational program, with students helping older people with technology."
The fan-shaped media center building is attached at its narrowest point to the school's lobby. Students will enter through a main passageway in the school, which is gated where it meets the lobby when school is not in session. The lobby is adjacent to the school's main entrance, through which the public could enter.
Besides the traditional racks of books and reading areas, the high-tech center includes 75 ports for plugging in laptop computers and 37 permanent computer stations.
The futuristic design of the center's steel, aluminum and glass exterior is echoed in the glass wall of the school's entry, which soars at an angle from 15 to 27 feet high. The exterior and the curved lines of the center's widest edge distinguish it from the plain, straight-lined main building. 
The center's straight tinted green glass side wall, which faces south, has a sunscreen, made of horizontal strips of aluminum that are similar to a Venetian blind, but permanently kept at a 45-degree angle to filter the sunlight. 
The reading area borders the interior of this wall and the screens allow for natural, yet usable, light and also prevent glare on the computer screens, according to Michael Mannetta, the project's designer. 
In Center Moriches, the concept of opening a school to the public is not new, said Dr. Cicero, whose district has 1,390 students. "We make all our facilities available to the public," he said. 
He said the publicity about opening the media center for residents' use "had to have helped" in persuading residents to approve the $23.6 million bond issue, which included construction of a 5,700-square-foot media center with a separate public entrance for use after school hours. The center is expected to be completed by September 2003.
Although Center Moriches has its own public library, the school's library-media center will supplement what is in the community, Dr. Cicero said.
As part of the project, the district is building a new 30,000-square-foot middle school, which is to be attached to the existing high school. 
Aside from the middle school, the rest of the project, which includes a new cafeteria and gymnasium in the high school, involved "taking existing space and changing the functions," said Mr. Anderson, who is the project designer. 
The 4,500-square-foot former cafeteria "with its 16-foot ceiling and large space lent itself to a media center because it was nicely proportioned, centrally located, and sits at the front of the building for easy public access," he said.
About 1,200 square feet will be added to the former cafeteria in creating the new center. It will include a bank of 22 computer stations, 12 laptop computer ports, reading and study areas. 
A separate entrance for the public will be built about 25 feet away from the school's main entrance. Students would get to the media center from an inside doorway during school hours.
Adjacent to the vestibule of the public entrance, which will contain a skylight, will be a 250-square-foot conference room and a 125-square-foot work room. A prominent curved 2,000-square-foot glass window will be part of the media center's facade "to announce its presence to the public," Mr. Anderson said. "It will say, 'This is our media center; come on in.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: The East Williston School District has plans to open the new $1,265,000 media center at the Wheatley School in Old Westbury to the public. (J. S. Moses for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: In Worldwide Survey of Retail Rates; 
Fifth Ave. Rents Are the Highest

 BODY:
New York's retail Gold Coast -- Fifth Avenue between 52nd and 58th Streets and East 57th Street to Madison Avenue -- has retained its position as the most expensive place in the world for a store, according to a recent survey by Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and real estate services company.
 Rents in the area averaged about $700 a square foot annually, as of the end of June. 
The highest rent outside the United States was $577 a square foot along the Champs-Elysees in Paris, followed by Causeway Bay in Hong Kong, where the rents average $500 a square foot, and Oxford Street in London, where the rents average $434 a square foot. 
 In the United States, the fastest rising retail rents were along Madison Avenue, with rents averaging $650 a square foot in June 2002, a 25 percent increase from the average in June 2001.
"Despite the events of 9/11 and the slowing of the economy," said David M. Gialanella, Cushman's executive vice president for national retail services, "the top New York retail areas have experienced improved fortunes in 2002." In secondary areas in the city there is less demand, but while asking rents have not gone down, neither have they increased, he said.
Worldwide, the greatest growth in retail rents was in downtown Kuwait City, with an increase of 180 percent because of the opening of Western-style malls.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Downtown Newark; 
Calculating Impact Of Proposed Arena

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
CONSTRUCTION of a professional sports arena in downtown Newark -- which became more likely last month when the city secured funds to finance a major portion of construction -- would be "like the third leg being put on a stool," said the veteran broker Dudley D. Ryan of Trammel Crow.
 "Business development, cultural development and now entertainment development -- all set the platform for residential development and a true 24-7 city," in Mr. Ryan's view. While each aspect of redevelopment has come slowly and only after tremendous effort, each is necessary for completing the revival of the sprawling metropolis decimated by race riots 35 years ago, he said. 
 Mr. Ryan said he had sold or leased more than 2 million square feet in downtown Newark over the past decade and is currently marketing space in the proposed 100,000-square-foot Riverfront Two office tower, for which the foundation was laid 15 years ago, but then covered with a parking deck. Over the years, Mr. Ryan said, he has become steeped in the city's development history. 
Mr. Ryan said there were efforts to begin rebuilding downtown immediately after the 1967 disturbances. By 1971, the 26-story Gateway One office tower opened next to Pennsylvania Station, its construction having been partly financed by federal grant money. A couple of years later, the Gateway Two building was completed. 
It was not until the mid-80's, though, that office building construction really got rolling again, Mr. Ryan noted. Then, four major buildings went up in rapid succession: the third and fourth buildings in the Gateway complex, One Newark Center and the Legal Center building, all near Penn Station.
More than another decade passed before another significant development occurred, Mr. Ryan said. In 1997, the New Jersey Performing Arts Center was built on the fringe of the central business district, transforming one of Newark's most decrepit and dangerous neighborhoods.
"Now, there is another lag," he said, "until the Devils-Nets arena is built and operating, somewhere around '05 or '10."
There are still some nonbelievers when it comes to the arena, which Mayor Sharpe James has pushed unrelentingly for five years. Its prospects have hit more high and low moments than any Beethoven symphony resounding through the halls at the Performing Arts Center. But many Newark real estate market specialists -- Mr. Ryan among them -- are convinced it will happen.
Last month, Mr. James negotiated a long-term lease with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for use of Newark's seaports and Newark Liberty International Airport, thereby securing a large part of the financing for the arena. Part of the lease proceeds will go to balance Newark's budget, but $165 million is to be set aside for the proposed $355 million 18,500-seat arena to be built right next to the Penn Station and the Gateway complex. 
The city would borrow another $35 million through bonding to pay for infrastructure improvements and to finish the process of assembling the 40-acre site using its powers of condemnation.
Mayor James says he is confident that a deal can be struck with the Yankees-Nets organization to invest $140 million to provide a new home for both the New Jersey Nets basketball team and the New Jersey Devils hockey team. That still leaves the parties $15 million short of covering the cost of the arena. And the deal with the Yankees-Nets has not yet been completed.
BUT many downtown real estate specialists, like Jon Mikula of the commercial mortgage brokerage Holliday Fenoglio Fowler, describe it as a "done deal." Mr. Mikula's firm has arranged financing for some of the major buildings that have changed hands in the past few years downtown and is currently handling the refinancing of 744 Broad Street -- a block from the proposed arena -- for Cogswell Realty.
"I think Newark is a very good market," Mr. Mikula said. "The prospect of the arena takes my opinion to a whole new level."
Richard Charles at Insignia/ESG agreed that the arena would be built and that it would have a major positive impact on the central business district and the city as a whole. "Newark still carries the burden of perceptions that are more than three decades old," he said. With the Performing Arts Center, he added, "there were a lot of naysayers who said it would never get built, and no one will show up. Then, when it opened, people said, 'Wow! This is Newark?' They were shocked."
Mr. Charles said the arena would aim a limelight on what Newark is really like now, through television coverage of sporting events and by drawing more people into the city who have never been there or have not been there in a long time. Mr. Charles and other market specialists talked of how Newark is still not on many big companies' lists of acceptable addresses for offices.
"The arena will change that," he said, "not right now, but fast forward a year or three from now and there will be a host of speculators buying up properties all around the arena and extending south."
Bryn Cinque, a first vice president at GVA Williams, said he was aware of several deals that companies are ready to make in Newark when it becomes certain the arena will be built. "One is for a sports entertainment project," Mr. Cinque said, "and the developers are considering a build-to-suit of 200,000 to 250,000 square feet.
"I also know of several large financial institutions considering large deals in Newark based on the arena," he said, "with the belief it will bring a great deal more traffic to downtown streets and help the city become an acceptable address for a lot more companies."
Richard F. X. Johnson, the senior vice president for development at the Matrix Development Company, which owns the Legal Center at One Riverfront Plaza, said there is ample evidence things are headed in that direction. He cited Cogswell's recent purchase of the entire "Hahne's block" -- a group of buildings between Market Street and the Rutgers-Newark campus -- after the New Newark Foundation's mixed-use redevelopment plan fell apart.
"The arena is simply another vote 'yes' for the continuing renaissance of Newark," Mr. Johnson said. He also said the improvements to roads and utilities that are part of the arena plan would be extremely valuable to Newark's comeback. 
"The arena will help solidify the infrastructure base," he said, "and it will have a ripple impact. It's going to generate hotel demand, office demand, retail demand. This is a city with a daytime population of 650,000 and a residential population of 270,000. The arena will allow Newark to capture its share of the 380,000 people who come in every day and leave right after work."
Mr. Johnson said Matrix had done a "walking study" that shows how quickly and easily people would be able to get to the stadium from their office buildings or Penn Station. From the Legal Center, it is an 8 or 10 minute walk, he said, depending on the chosen route, to the arena site. From Penn Station, it takes 6 to 8 minutes to walk to the stadium site.
Matrix acquired the Legal Center building at the end of last year, and it has been fully occupied since then. The Newark market in general has been tight, Mr. Johnson said, noting that the vacancy rate has stayed well under 10 percent and that bidding was extremely heavy last summer on the landmark Gateway One building, which was ultimately acquired by the Advance Realty Group of Bedminster.
Now, several large leases are expiring and the vacancy rate is expected to shoot up temporarily, Mr. Johnson said, but he predicted the space would be absorbed within a couple of years.
Jeffrey Greenberg, who with his brother Steven Greenberg, heads the Heritage Management Company, said it had not been very difficult to lease space at 550 Broad Street, which the company purchased a year ago, when it was 50 percent vacant. Fleet Bank had vacated 75,000 square feet at the time of the purchase. "We've leased 100,000 square feet in small blocks," Mr. Greenberg said. "The building is now 85 percent occupied."
Mr. Greenberg's building is three blocks from the proposed arena site and thus, he said, would derive less direct benefit from arena construction than will the Gateway Center and other buildings clustered around Penn Station. Currently, he said, rents around the station run in the low $30's per square foot annually, while his building commands rent in the low $20's per square feet.
"My feeling is the city doesn't need the arena to revive," Mr. Greenberg said, "but the arena is coming because the city has already made the strides forward to become a 24-hour community.
"That being said," he added, "the arena is going to be a great complement and amenity."
Jack Fatigati, a senior vice president with the Garibaldi Group, said he thinks there are other potential projects that would have a much greater and more lasting impact than an arena.
"Let's build a river walk," Mr. Fatigati said, "and generate a transformation like that beside the Hudson River, from 42nd street to Chelsea Pier" in Manhattan. He added, "The goal is a livable city, not just a workable city, and I think you have to ask the question: why put up an arena -- another destination people will go inside, stay a few hours and then leave?"
"I happen to love Newark," the broker said. "I think it is underestimated and underrated, but I'm not sure an arena is what it needs. If you look at any world-class city, there is a walkable river. The Passaic is not the Seine, or even the Hudson, but we are working on it.
"I don't think the arena will make us world class."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dudley D. Ryan of Trammel Crow, atop 100 Market Street in Newark, overlooking the 40-acre site proposed for a professional sports arena. (Richard Perry/The New York Times) Map of New Jersey highlighting downtown Newark.

HEADLINE: Insurance Employees Learn to Pack Light 

BYLINE:  By ABIGAIL SULLIVAN MOORE 

 BODY:
WHEN someone gets laid off at one of the major insurers here, employees call it "getting voted off the island," a reference to the television show "Survivor," in which competence often has little to do with a contestant's ability to stay on the island.
 "They also say, 'They put your torch out,' " said Timothy T. Gilchrist of Canton, a survivor of layoffs at Aetna, the Cigna Corporation and Value Health. 
 Survivor jokes aside, the layoffs, including those announced by Aetna in late September, are a reminder that the local insurance industry is not quite what it used to be.
Since 1989, the number of insurance industry jobs in the Greater Hartford area has shrunk about 10 percent, from an estimated 54,480 jobs to about 49,000 today, said John Tirinzonie, state labor economist for the Connecticut Labor Department.
With most of the job losses occurring in the early 1990's as insurers changed the way they did business, the collapse of the commercial real estate market and high state business taxes, the Hartford area's economy is "still struggling to find its voice," said Fred V. Carstensen, director of the Connecticut Center for Economic Analysis at the University of Connecticut. 
While the Hartford economy has gradually begun to diversify, "it doesn't yet have the set of policies, initiatives and companies that promise long-term success," he said.
Meanwhile, the people who have worked for the insurers for much of their lives are struggling, too. Many have been able to stay in the area only by engaging in a high-stakes employment hopscotch as they jump from company to company with each insurer downsizing.
Local employment experts said the trend is likely to get worse with the nation's weakening economy. Aetna, the world's second-largest health insurer, announced in September plans to cut 2,750 jobs, 317 of them in Hartford, from its work force during the next year in an effort to become more competitive and position itself for profitable growth, said Fred Laberge, an Aetna spokesman. It is not ruling out future cuts, he said.
"There are individuals here who are willing to compromise on their job specifications and responsibilities," said Roger Abate, a vice president and managing director at People Management Northeast, a career transition and executive search firm in Avon. "They are willing to look for a job a notch down to increase their possibilities and stay in the area."
Unable to find positions locally, other people are making tough "executive commutes" to New York, New Jersey and Philadelphia, spending weeknights away from home, he said. "Some are starting their own businesses.
"There's a great resistance to uprooting the whole family," Mr. Abate said, also noting the appeal of the Hartford area's school systems.
Karla Hammond, a vice president at People Management, said some employees have been caught in a revolving door for years. "It's not uncommon to see someone here downsized out of companies three times in five years through no fault of their own," she said. 
Ann Gruden of Vernon who was first laid off with a severance package in 1984 after 20 years at Aetna, said: "A lot people have skipped around. I kept saying, 'Whom haven't I worked for?" '
Since then, Ms. Gruden's employers have included a pharmaceutical association, a temporary agency, the Hartford, and then Cigna. 
When Cigna sold its life and annuity business to the Lincoln National Corporation in 1998, "they bought me, too" Ms. Gruden said. But, earlier this year Lincoln laid off Ms. Gruden. She is now a consultant.
"I used to joke that I never left my desk in nine months and was in three different companies," said Bruce G. Whitney of West Hartford when the Travelers health care operations merged with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to form Metrahealth in 1995; shortly after, that company was bought by United Healthcare. In 1998, United Healthcare laid off Mr. Whitney.
"Looking back it was the best thing that ever happened to me," he said. "I was working myself to death. I was scared and nervous. I had a young family and a house."
Three months later, Mr. Whitney, also an ex-Aetna employee, landed his current position in health care economics at Cigna. 
"The first week at Cigna, I saw someone I shared a cube with at Aetna in 1985," he said. "More and more, I walk down the halls at Cigna and I see people that I worked with at United Healthcare." 
It was not always this way. Some people, of course, switched companies in search of opportunity, but, in the past, most people tended to stay put.
"You stayed forever," said Tony Drapelick, the managing director of the Hartford office of DBM, an international human resources consulting firm. "Twelve years ago, the people who came through our doors were all long-term employees. It hit them quite hard." 
Throughout the 60's, 70's and early 80's, a maternal culture ruled Hartford's old-guard insurers. "There was a sense that you were hired into a family and became part of the family," Ms. Gruden said.
Mr. Gilchrist, who started at Aetna in 1990, said: "I remember being told by my boss after my first year, 'You're really working out.' You'll have a job for life.' " 
A short time later, however, Mr. Gilchrist's marketing job became a nonstaff consulting position. After consulting for Aetna and Value Health, a specialty managed health care and insurance company in Avon, Mr. Gilchrist moved full time to Value Health in 1994.
"I worked from 8 a.m. to 1:30 a.m. for the first five months, plus weekends," he said.
But Value Health was sold in 1997. "Twenty days later we were laid off matter-of-factly and as a group," Mr. Gilchrist said.
Months later, Mr. Gilchrist was rehired to direct Internet activities for Aetna, where he worked until 2000. Then, as Aetna prepared to sell its financial and international business to ING Group NV, "I began to look for another job," Mr. Gilchrist said. Ultimately, he wound up at Cigna. 
Because of a department reshuffling on Mr. Gilchrist's first day at Cigna, "I was demoted," he said. "My ID card was still hot in my pocket."
Eighteen months later, he said, "I got laid off the day I got back from my honeymoon." Before calling his bride with the bad news, he lined up some consulting work with a friend.
Not surprisingly, many employees' attitudes have changed toward their employers and job prospects. 
"People don't see loyalty as they did years ago," Ms. Hammond said. 
Mr. Drapelick said that younger employees seem to understand that it is just a job.
When they are laid off, "they have much less anger, much less disappointment," he said. "That doesn't mean some aren't disappointed. There's an understanding that these things happen. No one says today Mother Aetna promised me a job."
Employment experts also speak of their clients' determination to balance their work and their personal life.
"I decided a long time ago from my own work perspective that I wanted to strike a balance between the community that we live in and the work that we would be doing," said Michael E. Rawlins of Glastonbury, who was laid off three times at Aetna, once on the same day as his wife, during the early 90's.
Now a director at Mass Mutual, Mr. Rawlins speaks warmly about Aetna. Some layoffs were necessary, he said. "They always treated me fairly," he added.
Being laid off has not changed Mr. Whitney's attitude toward his work. "The company provides me with a job and I owe them to do the best I can in that job," he said.
As for Mr. Gilchrist, he is now a very optimistic senior vice president of operations at Integrated Loan Services, a Rocky Hill company that provides research and document processing services for companies that make loans.
"There's a lot of integrity there," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Aetna, far left, announced layoffs in September. Above, Roger Abate, a managing director at People Management Northeast, and Karla Hammond, a vice president. Left, Ann Gruden of Vernon was first laid off in 1984 by Aetna.; Timothy T. Gilchrist of Canton has endured several layoffs. (Photographs by George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Softness in Fairfield's $2 Million Home Market

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
SALES of houses at the highest end of the Fairfield County market in Greenwich, Darien, New Canaan and Westport have flourished in the past three years, but now, many brokers say, the market for homes selling for $2 million and above is softening.
 Houses at $500,000 and below are moving briskly, however, keeping inventory tight in that price range. At the high end, though, listings are increasing as sellers try to cash in before interest rates rise and prices fall further. 
"The tremendous amount of negative news is delaying people from buying homes," said Russell Pruner, owner of the Greenwich brokerage that bears his name. "In September of 2001 we represented 9 houses over $4 million for sale all over town; in September of 2002 we had 35 houses over $4 million. Now houses are coming on the market at an accelerated rate. We have 146 homes over $4 million, and through the first nine months of this year we put only 53 of them under contract, many with price reductions." 
Marjorie Rowe, owner and president of Preferred Properties, a Greenwich-based company that deals only in the top of the market, said: "We normally have a very active market within Greenwich, for people moving up to bigger homes." Typically, half of all sales are to people who are already residents of the town, she said, "but it's nothing like that now. A lot of people here are in the brokerage business -- they don't know when the pink slip might come. They're treading water."
Greenwich historically is affected less dramatically by economic cycles than other Connecticut towns, and recent figures seem to bear out this fact. Statistics from the chief operating officer of Preferred Properties, William Burke, showed the company's sales of homes with prices of at least $1 million was 139 in the third quarter of this year compared with 137 in the corresponding quarter of 2001 and 127 in 2000. Four homes priced over $6.5 million were sold in the third quarter of 2001; six homes at that price level were sold this year. 
Around the county, home sales have generally been strong so far this year. In Greenwich, Fairfield, Westport, Darien and most other towns in the county, sales of properties selling for more than $1 million are higher than the levels of the previous two years.
Still, brokers representing some high-end sellers who have had their homes on the market since early 2002 have watched buyers walk away after concluding that the house was not worth the price.
One Westport seller offered her 6,200-square-foot house on an acre for $5.8 million in January. Built in 1999 and loaded with desirable features, it has four bedrooms, five full baths and three half baths, a media theater, family room, flat screen televisions and built-in audio throughout the house, an office, exercise room, a long covered porch overlooking the Saugatuck River and a deepwater dock that can accommodate a 35-foot boat. 
W E had offers," she said, requesting that her name not be used, "but one backed out, another hesitated to go to contract. Finally a third was willing to close early, for $3.925 million." The transaction was completed on Oct. 30. 
"People want to get their money out now," said Dee Cohen of Prudential Connecticut Realty, who was a co-broker on the property with Miriam Luck. "They know that come Thanksgiving the house will just sit for months."
Michael Murray, the manager at Prudential in Westport, said: "There are about 120 homes from $1.5 million to over $3 million on the market here, but we've only had 34 transactions. People are not paying top dollar; consumer confidence is down. When a house lingers for four to six months, people who have a legitimate reason for selling -- not just testing the market -- get realistic, so we've been experiencing price reductions of $300,000 and $400,000, or 10 to 15 percent."
Gino Kelly, owner of Kelly Associates in Darien, has also had numerous price reductions in the $3 million and above range, from 5 to 10 percent, "but reduced from euphoric levels," he said, "not unlike prices they traded at in the past. There just are not as many people out to buy a $5 million house." He is representing the owners of a $9.8 million property, on the market since May, reduced by $700,000 from $10.5 million."
Cautious buyers can also affect custom home building. A Greenwich couple engaged a builder to plan a large house not to exceed $6.5 million, but "the builder's projections went far beyond the expectations of the buyers," said Barry Hawkins, the buyers' lawyer, "and the deal crashed. My fee and the architect's fee were paid, but the house never got built."
While some high-end buyers pay cash, more of them are taking loans, making down payments of $500,000 to $1 million. "The loan-to-value ratios are not what you'd see at the lower price levels," said Todd Martin, chief economist at Peoples Bank, "where a buyer puts down 10 percent on a $400,000 house. If prices fall, they are going to fall more on the expensive homes, so the lower the loan-to-value ratio, the better for the bank." Most of the bank's mortgage loans are jumbos, from $300,700 up.
In May of 2000, he noted, when the 30-year fixed rate was 8.5 percent, the monthly payment on a $500,000 mortgage was $3,840. When rates hit 5.99 percent early last month, that same mortgage cost $2,994 a month, and the $3,800 payment could have supported another $153,000 worth of loan. At the recent level of 6.29 percent, the monthly payment is $3,124.
"We were very busy with loans hitting all-time highs," Mr. Martin said, "but that's simmered down as rates have risen."
Last year a flurry of new construction on the Norwalk waterfront resulted in eight sales of $1.8 million to $3.4 million; this year homes priced from $1.7 million to $7.3 million were among 18 high-end sales, including some in the Rowayton section, said Carol Ann Falasco of Coldwell Banker. But they took an average of 151 days to sell this year, compared with 33 days last year. Price reductions have varied from $50,000 to hundreds of thousands, she said, while some properties sold at list.
In New Canaan, anything over $2.5 million sold within 100 days six months ago, said Paul Bruenich, president of William Pitt Inc. "Now it's 200 days. There's a lot of new construction, but prices are flat with downward pressure, and inventories are starting to build."
ACCORDING to Carolyn and David Klemm, owners of Klemm Real Estate in Washington, Litchfield County, people looking to join the A-list of county residents, which already includes Henry Kissinger, Dustin Hoffman, Frank McCourt, Mia Farrow, William Styron, Kevin Bacon, Michael J. Fox, Jim Dine, Skitch and Ruth Henderson, Richard Widmark and Ivan Lendl, by buying a second home there should do so now.
Nine prime properties pictured in a recent company advertisement had been reduced by $150,000 to $750,000, including a 10-room house on 6 acres, reduced to $995,000 from $1.2 million; and an estate on 47 acres, with a guesthouse, caretaker's cottage and pond, originally listed at $5.5 million and now priced at $4,750,000.
The Klemms specialize in high-end properties. "Our customers aren't relocation people or daily commuters," Mrs. Klemm said, "but our business has been affected by corporate troubles, the stock market and unemployment. Sellers are beginning to price their houses more realistically. The seller's market is over."
Because of the county's reliance on a second home market, Liddy Adams of Prudential Litchfield, noted: "The farther away from New York, the sooner activity and prices drop. You don't see ads saying 'won't last' any more. Even summer rentals sat empty this year or rented for only one month." 
William Raveis, owner of William Raveis Real Estate, which has its headquarters in the town of Shelton, expects Fairfield County to continue to be high priced and maxed out in terms of land and traffic, with construction limited by town ordinances against teardowns.
"But corporations continue to move into the state," he said. "UBS Warburg moved in 3,000 people -- a lot of young guys making $200,000 to $300,000 a year, able to buy their first homes in the $600,000 to $1 million range. Cities that were not acceptable in the past," he noted, "may benefit. Maybe Bridgeport will become a corporate headquarters, or Waterbury. New London has land, and since Pfizer moved in, it's a hot spot."
"Prices in Fairfield remain high because of the demand from New York people with tremendous incomes," he continued. "If salaries and bonuses on Wall Street were adjusted down to meet the hue and cry to do that, it would have an impact on the ability to purchase expensive homes. So would interest rates moving up to 8 percent."
