HEADLINE: As Diesel Goes Up, Businesses Say Prices May Follow 

BYLINE:  By JEFF HOLTZ 

 BODY:
JIM PALMER hopes an increase in the cost to pumping fuel into his trucks does not result in a rise in the cost of pouring milk at the table.
 Mr. Palmer, fleet manager for Guida's Milk and Ice Cream, which deploys 115 trucks from four Connecticut locations, said the recent 44 percent increase in Connecticut's diesel fuel tax would cost his company an additional $60,000 a year and could force Guida's to raise prices within the next six months. 
 "We've been able to hold the line on our product pricing, but we don't know that we can do it indefinitely," he said. "We hoping that the tax is repealed soon so that we won't have to impact our customers." 
Michael McGuffie, the owner of New England Bark Mulch and Playground Surfacing in Winsted, has already increased his prices by more than 5 percent to make up for the added cost of running 30 trucks.
"Nobody has enough margin in their business nowadays not to pass it on," he said. "It just isn't there."
The diesel tax increase was agreed to in a special session of the State Legislature in June, which was held to rework the budget in the face of a growing deficit.
Chris Cooper, a spokesman for Gov. John G. Rowland, said recently that the increase "was a product of bi-partisan negotiations between the governor and General Assembly."
Mr. Cooper said the eight-cent hike enabled Connecticut's diesel tax to remain competitive with that of neighboring states.
"Some difficult decisions had to be made based on the state's fiscal situation," Mr. Cooper said. "Over the past eight years, the governor cut taxes in the state by $2 billion dollars, and every family and every business enjoyed the benefits of those tax cuts. But after seven years of budget surplus, we face some lean times. Clearly, the choices before the Legislature and the governor were not easy ones, and this is an example of that."
But many in the business community said the increased tax, which went into effect Aug. 1, is escalating the costs of goods and services and damaging the state's economy.
Michael J. Riley, president of the Motor Transport Association of Connecticut, a lobbying group of 1,200 companies, said the state's 30-cent total per gallon tax on diesel fuel was not competitive with places like Massachusetts, New Hampshire and New Jersey, whose numbers are closer to 20 cents.
Mr. Riley said the increase was keeping many interstate truckers from filling up in Connecticut.
"When a truck stops in Connecticut, it spends more money here by the driver buying food, or getting repairs, or picking up supplies, or going to the movies, or staying at a motel," Mr. Riley said. "All those economic activities generate revenue to Connecticut businesses and tax revenue to the state."
One state official, Marc S. Ryan, said the tax increase was partly designed to cut down on interstate truck traffic in Connecticut. Mr. Ryan, the state's budget director, said the hope is that there will be decreased truck congestion on the highways and lead to savings on road maintenance and repairs.
"We felt this tax was the least harmful to the economy," he said. "There are a lot of states doing all types of tax increases, and we think this one has a relatively modest impact."
Gerard Barrieau Jr., the president of Barrieau Moving and Storage in Hartford, which primarily moves families within the state and around the country, has passed on a 4-percent fuel surcharge to his customers because of the higher diesel tax, which he calls "discriminatory and counterproductive to doing any kind of positive business in Connecticut." 
He said he believed the politicians should have split a smaller increase between diesel and gas.
"Not that many trucking companies vote, compared to the number of people who drive automobiles who vote, and it's an election year," Mr. Barrieau said. "This is pure politics."
State Representative Andrea L. Stillman, vice chairwoman of the Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, said the diesel tax increase came at the recommendation of the governor. She added that it was too early to tell whether the increase will have a significant impact on prices.
"I don't think it's a very big increase," she said. "I think there are increases in other costs of goods and services that might increase prices over all. I don't think it's strictly Connecticut that could be impacted, if at all."
But Carroll J. Hughes, a lobbyist for the refuse hauling industry, said the schools, restaurants, apartment complexes and municipalities serviced by the five large companies in the Hartford area that he represents would soon be seeing an increase in the cost of trash removal.
Mr. Hughes said his clients' vehicles are more reliant on diesel fuel because of frequent stops and compaction systems.
"They had just increased their prices about four weeks before the tax was imposed because of the major tonage charge that was passed on by the Connecticut Resource Recovery Authority to try to pay off the Enron losses," he said, referring to the $220 million dollars in state funds loaned to Enron by the authority. "So they basically felt uncomfortable about sending out another increase so soon.
"They will be passing it on, but it probably won't happen for another month or two." 
Some legislators said they did not agree with the diesel tax increase, but were in favor of the overall budget. Some said they will review the performance of the tax in the next legislative session.
"This wasn't an issue that came up in a cavalier fashion," said Moira K. Lyons, the speaker of the House. "As with everything, we will be having a larger shortfall moving forward in the new year, and at that point we are going to be looking at everything. We clearly will be looking at this tax to see if it has had a negative impact on business, and if it has not been the revenue provider that we thought."
In the meantime, homeowners using oil heat are already seeing the cost of heat go up, said Jim Vitali, the president of Tuxis Ohr's Fuel in Meriden.
"Unfortunately, in the oil business, the prices fluctuate so much on a daily basis, they may not see it specifically associated with it, but it's there," he said. "Unfortunately, it can be blamed on some world crisis than on this diesel fuel increase."

HEADLINE: Hard to Shake Labels: Disabled and Jobless 

BYLINE:  By MAGGIE JACKSON

 BODY:
Cathy Sam has been looking for a secretarial job for more than a year, and sometimes, even though she lands an interview, she literally cannot get in the door. Ms. Sam, who has cerebral palsy, can be interviewed only at companies that can accommodate her wheelchair.
 "When they call, I have to make sure to tell them I have a disability," Ms. Sam said as she waited in line to enter a job fair in Manhattan last week for people with disabilities. "Sometimes they're not accessible, and I can't do the interview." 
 The city's job market is bleak for many people, but for those with disabilities, the picture is especially discouraging. Although some companies are doing more to recruit and accommodate them, the disabled face particularly daunting obstacles, notably employers' skittishness about hiring them and, in a weakened economy, stiffening competition for scarce openings from highly skilled rivals without physical impairments.
For some, the frustration of a fruitless search for work is reaching near despair. Many people with disabilities consider themselves an overlooked minority, whose status has improved only marginally since the signing of the 1990 Americans With Disabilities Act. The law prohibits discrimination against disabled people and mandates that most employers make "reasonable" accommodations for them.
While definitions of disability vary, about 20 percent of Americans age 21 to 64 -- or 30 million people -- have a disability, according to the latest census data. Of those, 57 percent were employed nationwide in 2000, while just over half of disabled people age 21 to 64 were employed in the New York metropolitan region, the census data showed.
More recent data for New York is unavailable, but anecdotal reports from disabled job seekers and from the nonprofit and governmental groups that help them point to a worsening market.
"People with disabilities have been left out of the whole employment process, even back in the 1990's when the economy was booming," said Jeffrey Klare, an organizer of the Disability Career Expo last Tuesday and chief executive of Equality Staffing, which specializes in placing people with disabilities.
"We're not looking for charity," he said, "we're looking for opportunities."
The stigma of having a disability is so strong that many with "invisible" impairments, like mental illnesses, try to keep their condition secret while job hunting. "You tell them everything but that," said Burdy Jean-Louis who was found to have schizophrenia at age 16.
The job fair at the New Yorker Hotel drew about 800 job seekers who dropped off their resumes and questioned representatives from more than 30 corporations, nonprofits and government agencies, including Microsoft, HSBC Bank USA, Pitney Bowes, I.B.M., the Customs Service and the National Security Agency. Seeing-eye dogs and their owners squeezed past sign-language users and people in wheelchairs.
But for all the welcoming atmosphere, many could not shake an ingrained suspicion that the event might be mostly window dressing. "You guys are going to look over these resumes, aren't you?" one participant demanded of Monica Reed, a consultant representing Bristol-Myers Squibb. Ms. Reed said yes, but suggested looking for jobs posted on the company Web site.
Such skepticism was voiced repeatedly by the job-seekers. "The concern for them is, are these companies here to hire, or is this just a dog and pony show?" Mr. Klare said. He timed the fair to follow National Disability Employment Awareness Month in October.
Jose Goico, who has a visual impairment, said interviewers were dubious when he applied for work in bulk duplicating, although he held such a job at the New York City Department of Environmental Protection for eight years. He has done temporary work and taken courses since being laid off in 1997. "I've gone to a lot of job interviews, and they're always concerned about how I'm going to do it," Mr. Goico said, shifting a white cane so he could hand in a resume. 
Still, in the last decade, many companies have taken steps to help, partly because of the federal disabilities law and partly because the business case for a diversified work force is gaining acceptance. More than 80 percent of companies have made their sites accessible to the disabled and 60 percent have modified equipment to accommodate them, according to a study in 2000 by researchers at Cornell. And half of American companies and 60 percent of large corporations questioned in a 1999 survey of 813 companies by the Society for Human Resource Management in Alexandria, Va., said they actively recruited people with disabilities.
In recent years, for example, I.B.M. named 35 line managers nationwide to help their division interview, hire and accommodate people with impairments. The company also visits college agencies for the disabled, not just job fairs, when visiting campuses.
"We've moved away from the moral obligation to do something right, to the strategic necessity to do this," said Jim Sinocchi, a wheelchair-user who is I.B.M.'s director for diversity communications and a chairman of its executive task force on people with disabilities. 
Nationwide, the job market for some disabled people has improved in the last decade. The employment rate of disabled people age 18 to 64 who say they can work rose to 56 percent in 2000 from 46 percent in 1986, according to the National Organization on Disability in Washington. But for some, that is scant comfort. "People have the legal protection to work and have many outlets and resources to get work, yet there's a strong culture of discrimination," said Brewster Thackeray, a spokesman for the nonprofit group.
Advocates for the disabled also say they are at greater risk of being laid off, sometimes because they have less seniority than their colleagues and sometimes because of their spotty job histories. In New York, the market is tough in the custodial, mailroom and retail sectors, but better in nonprofit and hospitality fields, agencies report.
"We placed people in the spring and summer, and they are getting laid off," said Susan Jouard, director for community relations for Fedcap Rehabilitation Services, the city's largest nonprofit group that trains people with disabilities for entry-level jobs. Fedcap placed 44 people in the private sector in the first nine months of 2002, compared with 54 people in the year-earlier period.
"It's harder to find a permanent job, harder to get your foot in the door," Ms. Jouard said. "They're not on a level playing field with the other candidates out there."

HEADLINE: Farmer Moves Cheese Back To Grass Roots 

BYLINE:  By MARGE PERRY 

DATELINE: VERNON 

 BODY:
JONATHAN WHITE loves mold. His face lights up when he talks about the humidity and temperature under which his three favorite strains of mold flourish, and his background as a cheese maker and a scientist is evident. 
 But in the next breath, he sounds more like a theologian. 
 "There is a magic to the alchemy of converting milk to cheese," Mr. White said. "We coax a process that would happen innocently in nature, and it is like re-enacting creation. When I watch my cheeses in the later stages in the ripening room, it's like making babies." 
It is the combination of science and philosophy that impassion Mr. White, a Hoboken native, in his newest venture, Bobolink Dairy, a 200-acre farm in Vernon. He established Bobolink shortly after leaving Egg Farm Dairy, an award-winning cheesemaking company that he founded in 1993 in Peekskill, N.Y. At Bobolink, he goes further back in the cheese-making process. This time, he starts with raising his own cows.
"I know milk from cows who graze in pastures rather than feeding on grain in the barn makes better-tasting cheese," Mr. White said while working in his kitchen. "And I want to create a model for sustainable farming. I want to show farmers that cheese making can help liberate them from the bad economics of American industrialized farming. And this life, on the farm, is just better for my family."
As if on cue, his wife and partner, Nina, comes into the room just as the first of a stream of friends nudges up to the kitchen table, piled high with bags from the nearby farmers' market in Warwick, N.Y., wine glasses, freshly baked breads, vases overflowing with fresh-cut flowers, plates and short lengths of 1-inch steel pipe. 
All the while, Mr. White, 46, hops up and down from the crowded table, tending still more breads in his large commercial oven, sauteing the famous black dirt garlic grown in this region to make pasta sauce for the children, tossing rosy chops of grass-fed veal with more of the garlic and sel gris -- and never losing his train of thought.
"Cheese making in the United States has been industrialized from the start," he said. "Truth is, the industrialized raw milk market turns dairy farmers into serfs, slaving away to barely earn enough money to feed their families. But the old dairy farming story is, you might lose a penny a pound, but you'll make it up in volume." 
Mr. White believes that by showing farmers how to go back to raising cows in pastures, rather than confining them in barns, he can help increase the farmers' profits. Grazing cows produce less milk than confined cows, but at substantially less cost, he said. In his model for making a grazing dairy farm successful, Bobolink naturally produces cheese. "And, of course, grazing cows produce superior milk, and you can taste the difference in the cheese," he said, smiling broadly.
His newly arrived cows -- "pregnant teenage redheads," he said with boyish glee -- will not produce milk until January, so the cheeses he is selling now are made on an Amish farm in Lancaster, Pa., under his tutelage, then ripened in one of two Bobolink ripening rooms. It is during the ripening process, as they develop their moldy rind, that the cheeses are imbued with the complexity and depth of flavor for which Mr. White became known at Egg Dairy Farm. 
Mr. White bartered for the Amish cheeses, as he barters for much of what his family eats. He taught the Amish farmers how to make mold-ripened cheese, and in return he takes a portion of the cheeses to ripen and sell on his farm. The Amish farmers, for their part, taught Mr. White how to raise cows that graze freely on grass pastures and hay.
The kinship of cheese to cows led seamlessly to raising chickens. The neighbors and associates to whom Mr. White offered knowledge and a seat at his table led to the addition of sheep in his pastures (he taught the sheep breeder to make cheese in exchange for 12 of the animals) and horses in his stable (from a neighboring farm) as well as ham on his table (cured by his Amish collaborators) and advice, when he needs it, on matters like growing the ideal grazing grass for cows.
Philosophical and economic reasons aside, cheese made from cows that are allowed to graze freely on pastures, rather than confined in a barn and fed grain from a silo, does taste different. The difference is also apparent by the smell in the ripening rooms. Most Bobolink cheeses are ripened no more than 90 days, and the herbaceous aroma is evident early in the process.
As quickly as the pungent smell hits the nose, the eyes adjust to the dim lighting and a muted rainbow of golden, turquoise and garnet growth on the cheeses appears. Like boys before they grow whiskers, the less-aged cheeses have barely a hint of fuzz, while the mature blocks have a dense growth of more deeply colored fur covering their surfaces.
Mr. White carefully wipes the soft mold from a wheel of his Frolic cheese. Frolic, the Amish word for a neighborly collaboration like a barn raising, is a good word to describe many of Mr. White's endeavors both on his farm and off. 
On a personal level, farm life allows the Whites' three children -- Jacob, 9; Tobias, 11; and Paula, 14 -- to flourish. Jacob is autistic, and is especially peaceful in the company of cows and when baking bread, his parents said. "The physical release of getting the kids outdoors gets them integrated the way nothing else can," Nina White said. "They love being in a lot of open space, of having a lot of room to function." The Whites believe that farm work can lead to more fulfilling and productive roles for developmentally challenged men and women, and they say they hope to start an internship program on the farm toward that end. 
This may seem a bit too idealistic a picture of life in a bygone era, but at the heart of it all is a 21st-century businessman. 
"The Internet is great -- I can be a global village cheese maker," Mr. White said. "I'm not using distributors and not offering credit to retailers. I keep it simple and there's no hassle about getting paid. It's a quality-of-life thing for my family, and I want to show other farmers they can produce high-quality, economically and ecologically sustainable products. And I do plan on paying for college! I may not get rich and retire tomorrow, but I'll make a decent living."
The Whites' retail shop on the farm at 42 Meadowburn Road in Vernon is open every Saturday from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Additional holiday hours and more information on visiting Bobolink or ordering products online are on its Web site, www.cowsoutside.com. The shop sells Bobolink cheeses ($15 a pound) and wood-fired hearth breads ($2.50 to 3.50 a pound) and smoked salmon from Perona Farms ($22 a pound), which Mr. White carries, he said, to "support my habit."

HEADLINE: New Curbs on Predatory Loans 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
GEORGE POPE doesn't read well.
 Mr. Pope, 62, a disabled former tool and die maker, has lived in the same wood-frame home on Farmers Boulevard in Southeast Queens since he was 6 years old. Now he is facing foreclosure. 
 A mortgage broker knocked on his door in 1998 and persuaded Mr. Pope to take out a refinance loan with monthly payments of $535. Mr. Pope lives on $558 a month in Supplemental Security Income. 
"Not being able to read," he said, "I got a loan that was predatory and I didn't know it."
Had Mr. Pope signed the same loan papers after April 3, 2003, he would not be in danger of losing his home. That is when a new New York State law -- praised by advocates as a pioneering step against predatory lending -- goes into effect.
The New York law "is a watershed event in the national movement toward predatory lending legislation," said George W. McCarthy, a housing economist at the Ford Foundation who monitors foreclosures across the country.
Sarah Ludwig, executive director of the Neighborhood Economic Development Advocacy Project, a fair-credit access organization based in Manhattan, said: "It's a huge victory for New Yorkers because, for the first time, this state has strong protections for borrowers against some of the worst abusive practices. It puts New York among a handful of states that have addressed this problem through comprehensive legislation."
Most of the laws either passed or pending in that handful of states -- including a strong version awaiting a vote in the New Jersey Senate -- start by specifying what constitutes a "high cost" mortgage. They do that by setting a threshold on the annual percentage rate that the borrower pays, or on the level of points and fees added onto the principal.
High-cost loans can be perfectly legal. But they become illegal if the lenders engage in certain practices that the laws, in varying ways, proscribe as predatory -- including, for instance, loan flipping, balloon payments or, most important, not certifying that the borrower can afford the payments.
A bill following that basic approach, but with provisions that both advocates of legislation and banking officials say would be among the toughest in the nation, was recently passed by the New York City Council. It was vetoed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who objected to several provisions. But Council officials say they have enough votes to override the veto.
For Assemblywoman Aurelia Greene, who as chairwoman of the New York State Assembly Banks Committee was the lead sponsor of the new state law, "it ranks as one of my greatest accomplishments because it represents such a large cadre of citizens across the state." Ms. Greene, a Bronx Democrat, said her committee had gathered data on "large numbers of people losing their homes upstate, so it's not just the city."
"What really motivated me," she said, "was a moment three years ago when we held hearings. A 90-year-old woman testified that she was about to be evicted. She was deliberately duped."
Predatory lending is the dark seam of the otherwise legitimate and necessary subprime mortgage industry that has expanded exponentially over the last decade, serving borrowers with bad or merely blemished credit histories. But as the subprime market has surged, so, too, has predatory lending.
The New York law, signed by Gov. George E. Pataki on Oct. 3, follows much the same footprints as legislation passed in recent years by North Carolina, Georgia and California -- measures that go further, in differing ways, than federal regulations prohibiting predatory practices.
And while Connecticut passed a law last year that, in the estimation of several advocates, did not advance the federal regulations, the New Jersey Assembly overwhelmingly approved a strong bill in June that is now being debated by the State Senate, and which Gov. James E. McGreevey has publicly supported. "It's unpredictable what the Senate may do," said the bill's chief sponsor, Assemblyman Matt Ahearn, a Democrat from Fair Lawn, "particularly since there's a 20-20 tie in the Senate."
In New York City, on Oct. 23, Mayor Bloomberg vetoed a bill, passed 44 to 5 by the City Council, that in one significant way -- a stricter version of a legal concept called "assignee liability" -- would have gone further than any other legislation in the nation.
Under assignee liability, a victim of predatory practices has legal recourse not only against the lender who originated the loan, but also against financial institutions in the so-called secondary market. That is, any financial entity that bought shares in what are called "bundles" of securitized mortgages -- and that includes the biggest financial houses on Wall Street. (The victim could sue for damages or to have the loan entirely reformulated.)
The City Council bill, however, takes assignee liability even further: barring the city from doing business with any entity that originates predatory loans or buys them as part of a bundle. And Council Speaker Gifford A. Miller, its chief sponsor, says he has the 34 votes needed to override the veto.
As Ms. Ludwig, the credit-access advocate, put it: "What's significant is that the city would be saying that no municipal dollars will go to any financial institution engaging in abusive lending practices, with potentially huge implications if you think about how much money gets invested by the city's pension funds and all the contracts the city undertakes."
The secondary market in securitized mortgage bundles, Ms. Ludwig added, "ensures a steady reinfusion of cash to the lenders so they can continue the cycle."
Representatives of major financial institutions contend, however, that the City Council's assignee liability provision would damage the availability of mortgages to the vast majority of subprime borrowers. Michael Williams, vice president for legislative affairs for the Bond Market Association, said, "Because our members would weigh the tradeoff between participating in the subprime market or the municipal market, there will be a retraction in the availability of credit." The association represents the city's major bond underwriters, including Lehman Brothers, Goldman Sachs and Citigroup.

Delinquent Borrowers
Subprime Loans Rise; Foreclosures Surge
The movement to prohibit predatory lending is a reaction to the surge in subprime lending for both home purchases and refinancings -- and a parallel explosion in foreclosures.
Between 1993 and 2000, according to data collected by the Federal Reserve, the proportion of subprime loans jumped from 2 percent of the national mortgage market to 13.4 percent. In the refinance segment alone, subprime loans bounded to 25.3 percent of the entire refinance market in 2000. 
And since 1993, foreclosures have risen by 68 percent, with actions against subprime borrowers far outpacing those against prime-market borrowers.
Citing the Federal Reserve data, Dr. McCarthy at the Ford Foundation pointed out that in 1993 there were 6.9 million loans originated in the entire mortgage market, of which 126,000 were subprime. By 2000, when a total of 7.8 million loans were made, 1.1 million were subprime. "The prime market had no growth, while the subprime market increased by a magnitude of 7," Dr. McCarthy said.
"Importantly," he continued, "while foreclosures in the prime market have fallen since 1993, foreclosures in the subprime market were high enough to push the overall market to all-time highs for foreclosures." In 1993, there were 401,000 foreclosures in the entire market. This year, based on projections by the Mortgage Bankers Association, there will be 677,000 foreclosures -- a 68 percent jump. "And that includes a 20 percent drop for foreclosures in the prime market, taken separately," Dr. McCarthy said.

Fraudulent Practices
Targets: Refinancers, First-Time Buyers
Given the two segments of the market -- home purchase and refinance -- predatory lending essentially takes two forms.
In the home-purchase category it is, particularly, first-time buyers seeking loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration who are targeted. Typically, real estate brokers, acting as "one-stop shops," buy rundown properties for low prices, often at foreclosure auctions, and "flip" them at higher prices. They hire contractors to perform cosmetic repairs, then tell fledgling buyers that no inspection is needed.
The brokers employ appraisers who intentionally overstate the value of the properties. They provide a lawyer for the buyer at the closing, when the borrower signs a thick stack of documents. And in qualifying the mortgage, they often falsify the buyer's income -- attesting to, perhaps, rent from nonexistent tenants -- to secure an F.H.A.-backed loan.
"Let's say the property is worth $150,000," said Josh Zinner, coordinator of the Foreclosure Prevention Project at South Brooklyn Legal Services. "The loan won't be for that amount; it will be for the over-appraised amount, say $225,000." 
"The borrower ends up with a property in lousy shape, often with significant structural defects," Mr. Zinner continued, "and with an unaffordable mortgage covering far more than the value of the property."
When the buyer almost inevitably goes into default for nonpayment -- or, perhaps, cannot afford a second loan to pay for repairs -- the lender forecloses. And after the foreclosure auction, the lender will be reimbursed through the F.H.A. insurance for the full over-appraised value.
Most predatory practices, however, involve a refinance loan in which brokers or fraudulent home-repair contractors, acting as bird dogs for lenders, go door to door in poor neighborhoods.
They target people who bought at a low price, or an older person on a fixed income who may have purchased in the 1950's or 60's, and whose property values have climbed significantly.
"The typical borrower is equity rich but cash poor," said Ms. Ludwig of the neighborhood advocacy project, "and, therefore, these loans are unaffordable. People end up jeopardizing their most valuable asset and, sometimes, their only real asset -- the home."
The house may need a new roof. But the repair contract will add other items -- a remodeled bathroom, perhaps -- leveraging the borrower into a higher-cost loan. "At that stage, the broker takes over, refers the loan to a lender, adds broker's fees onto the principal," Mr. Zinner said. "These fees often bear little relation to the value of services provided." The fees are labeled as points -- a term used in most borrowings to describe loan costs beyond the interest rate -- with each point representing 1 percent of the principal.
Often, refinance loans are packed with unsecured debt, perhaps from high-interest-rate credit cards, again jacking up the principal. And while the interest rate may be lower when that debt is folded in, the home is now at risk as the loan's collateral.

Victims of Predators
Minority Borrowers Are Often Exploited
Loan terms that are beneficial for prime mortgages are likely to be predatory in the subprime market. Balloon payments, for example, may be appropriate for a co-op that plans to restructure its underlying mortgage after a certain period, or for the home buyer who is moving in a few years. (With balloon payments, lower interest is paid for, perhaps, five years, but then the entire principal comes due.)
But in a predatory scenario, while a balloon loan seems affordable at first because monthly payments tend to be low, many borrowers are shocked when the entire principal comes due and -- unable to pay it -- they are served with a foreclosure notice.
"And that is used by brokers and lenders to insure that the homeowner will need to refinance, yet again, to avoid foreclosure," Ms. Ludwig said, "while the broker and lender hit the cash register again, collecting more points, more fees, stripping out more equity and putting the borrower in a new loan that yet again does not benefit -- typically -- her."
The burden falls disproportionately on African-Americans. 
In 1999, the Department of Housing and Urban Development conducted a study, "The Unequal Burden: Income and Racial Disparities in Subprime Lending," which found that upper-income African-American homeowners across the nation were twice as likely to hold subprime loans as low-income white homeowners. In the New York area, high-income African-Americans were four times as likely as low-income whites to have subprime loans.
Not surprisingly, it is the uninformed who are most preyed upon. In 1999, Dr. McCarthy said, Fannie Mae, the federally chartered mortgage purchase corporation, analyzed its portfolio and found that half of its subprime borrowers should have been in the prime market, paying lower interest rates and fees.

New York State
When a Loan Becomes Predatory
The new New York State law takes several steps to protect the uninformed -- including, significantly, prohibiting any mortgage a borrower cannot afford.
The law defines a loan as high cost, though not necessarily predatory, in two ways. First, if it carries an annual percentage rate that is higher than 8 percentage points above the prevailing rate for a Treasury bond that matures over the same period. (The annual percentage rate is not just the interest rate, but the actual annual cost once points and fees are factored in.)
A mortgage is also high cost, the law says, if the points and fees exceed 5 percent of the principal. A $100,000 loan, for example, would be designated as high cost if $5,000 in points and fees were added on.
High-cost loans become illegal, the law says, if they employ certain predatory practices or don't meet certain requirements:
*No loan can be made "without due regard to repayment ability," determined by "independent verification" of the borrower's income, assets and debts.
*Loan flipping -- refinancing a loan without "tangible net benefit" to the borrower -- is prohibited. "Sometimes borrowers have loans flipped four, five times and are left with no equity as points and fees strip out the value of their homes," Ms. Ludwig said.
*Balloon payments -- defined as "a scheduled payment that is more than twice as large as the average of earlier scheduled payments" -- are prohibited within the first 15 years of the loan.
*Lenders are required to provide borrowers with a list of HUD-certified mortgage counselors.
*Under assignee liability, a borrower may take legal action against either the originator of the loan or against any entity that subsequently bought a securitized bundle including the predatory mortgage -- potentially leading to a refund of all points and fees or reformulation of the entire loan. And for the first time, a borrower can raise violations of the law as a defense against foreclosure.
George Pope, the disabled tool and die maker from Queens, might have been protected by the new state law.
Mr. Pope underwent cardiac catheterization this past Monday at Elmhurst Hospital Center after his fifth heart attack since Sept. 3, 1993, the day fire gutted the home he has lived in for 56 years -- a house for which the original mortgage had long before been fully paid.
Mr. Zinner of the foreclosure prevention project said Mr. Pope had first been victimized by insurance adjusters and home-repair contractors who left the fire-damaged house with serious code violations -- and Mr. Pope still under a mountain of debt to pay for the repairs.
In 1998, Mr. Pope took out one loan to finance that debt. Soon after, another broker talked him into flipping. "He took out a $58,467 loan to refinance the loan he had taken out only five months previously," Mr. Zinner said. "He was getting Supplemental Security Income of $558 a month, and the new payments were $535 a month."
"They told me the second loan was going to pay off the first one," Mr. Pope said. "I didn't understand what that meant."
Between the broker's fee, the origination fee and something called a yield spread premium, the points on the new loan came to 6.3 percent. The yield spread premium "is a payment from a lender to the broker in exchange for bringing the loan in at a higher interest than the borrower otherwise would have qualified for," Mr. Zinner said. "In this case the broker was already receiving a fee financed out of the proceeds of the loan, raising the principal. So the broker's getting paid two ways here."
"Although this loan was very abusive," Mr. Zinner continued, "it did not violate federal or state law as it existed at the time the loan was made."
To stave off a foreclosure sale scheduled for last September, Mr. Pope filed for bankruptcy, which is pending, and asked for legal assistance from the foreclosure prevention project. Of the lenders, he said, "They took my dream and ran with it."

New York City
A Strict Measure Causes Debate
The New York City Council bill that Mayor Bloomberg vetoed -- but could come up for an override vote on Nov. 20 -- would set even stricter thresholds than the state law for what constitutes a high-cost loan: an annual percentage rate of 6 percentage points, rather than 8 percentage points, above the comparable Treasury bond; and points and fees that are no more than 4 percent, rather than 5 percent, of the overall loan amount.
"We believe New Yorkers don't want their government doing business with people involved in predatory lending," Speaker Miller said. "We also know that a lot of banks and securities firms that do business with the city are good actors and are not engaged in these practices."
"But some may have affiliates or are tangentially involved in these practices," the speaker continued, "and we want to give them a chance to cure those practices without dragging their names through the mud." The bill calls for the city comptroller to confidentially approach a financial entity that has knowingly or unknowingly participated in predatory lending and give it an opportunity to remedy the problem. Ultimately, the comptroller could bar that entity from municipal business for three years.
Bertha Lewis, executive director of New York Acorn, an organization that has stridently lobbied for predatory lending legislation, believes the mayor "should be proud to sign this law, because New York City could say it only does business with companies that set the highest standards."
But in his veto message, Mayor Bloomberg called the bill defective, saying, "It would enact legal requirements that conflict with, and would be pre-empted by, those established elsewhere in state law."
And while not directly addressing the financial impact of the bill's assignee liability provision, the mayor wrote that "it proposes a lengthy and administratively burdensome scheme that prohibits the city from doing business with financial institutions that either engage in such practices themselves or have investments that include loans that were obtained through such practices."
That, he said, "would curtail the executive powers of the mayor by injecting the comptroller into the city's contracting process and into enforcement and implementation of the law."
Michael P. Smith, president of the New York State Bankers Association, said that if the City Council bill became law, it had the potential to restrict the availability of credit in the subprime market. "We have city legislation where the thresholds are well below the state level," Mr. Smith said. "There is a reluctance on the part of many banks to make loans over the thresholds, thereby shrinking the high-cost market."
There is, however, some indication that predatory lending legislation might not shrink the market.
In July, at his company's request, Kenneth Posner, a mortgage analyst at Morgan Stanley, conducted a nationwide survey of 280 managers of companies that offer subprime loans, including some at major lenders like Household Finance and CitiFinancial. Pointing out that the findings are not specific to any state, Mr. Posner said the study found "that 84 percent of our respondents thought changed lending practices were having a neutral to positive impact on volume" -- the number of loans originated. And, he said, the branch managers expected volume to increase by about 35 percent this year over last.
"Thirty percent of the branch managers, in fact, saw the standards as good for business by improving borrower confidence," Mr. Posner said. "Enhanced disclosures are making borrowers feel more comfortable about the lending process."

HEADLINE: The Rules in New Jersey and Connecticut 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
WHILE Connecticut passed a law a year ago that virtually mirrors federal predatory-lending statutes -- and, therefore, in the opinion of consumer advocates, did not advance the protection of potential victims -- a stronger bill was passed, 61 to 7, by the New Jersey Assembly on June 13 and is now being debated by the Senate.
 "Our state's bill certainly is one of the strongest in the country," said Ken Zimmerman, executive director of the New Jersey Institute for Social Justice, an advocacy group. "It takes the legitimate interests of both victims and responsible, mainstream lenders into account." 
 The New Jersey bill defines a "high cost," mortgage as one that carries an annual percentage rate higher than 8 percentage points above the prevailing rate for a comparable Treasury bond, or points and fees that exceed 5 percent of the principal.
The loan becomes predatory if it does not meet certain requirements, or if the lender engages in certain practices. Among the requirements, a lender must accurately certify a borrower's ability to repay the loan. A borrower may not finance more than 2 percent of the principal for points and fees, either by making the points and fees part of the loan's principal or by paying them with a separate loan. If points and fees are financed, rather than being paid up front, the borrower must receive counseling from a credible third party.
The bill also includes an "assignee liability" provision, under which, if the loan violates the law, a borrower can seek legal redress against a lender or a financial entity that has purchased the mortgage. The law's provisions also can be used as a defense against foreclosure.
For the bill's chief sponsor, Assemblyman Matt Ahearn, Democrat of Fair Lawn, the assignee liability provision "is key."
"The bank advocates say we are abrogating hundreds of years of common law," Mr. Ahearn said. "But when business people deal with each other, they're on equal footing. When it's a consumer, particularly senior citizens, dealing with a slick lender, the balance of negotiating power swings far to the side of the lender."
The Connecticut law reflects the less stringent requirements of the federal Home Ownership and Equity Protection Act, which was enacted in 1994. It defines a loan as high cost if its annual percentage rate exceeds a comparable Treasury bond by 10 percentage points, or if its points and fees are more than 8 percent of the principal.
The Connecticut law prohibits, among other things, balloon payments on loans with terms of less than seven years and extending a loan to someone if the monthly payment exceeds 50 percent of the borrower's monthly gross income. It contains a limited assignee-liability provision.

HEADLINE: Goodbye Rat Race, Hello Road Race 

BYLINE:  By NANCY HAGGERTY 

 BODY:
TWELVE years ago, Don Fink didn't know how to swim.
 That is somewhat amazing, considering that Mr. Fink, 44, a resident of Short Hills, is now a full-time triathlete and coach. 
 Equally noteworthy is that just two years ago, he spent most of his time running from meeting to meeting as Citibank's managing director for private banking in the mid-Atlantic states.
Today Mr. Fink, who was named to last year's Inside Triathlon and USA Triathlon All-American teams, has become one of the world's best triathletes in his age group. 
He took his first steps in that direction many years ago, racing cousins on the sand of the Jersey Shore. He was fast. Success made for enjoyment.
In his junior high school years, his parents would rise to find footprints in the snow leading from their Scotch Plains home. Mr. Fink would get up at 4 a.m. to run every day, believing, as he still does, that regular training leads to improvement bit by bit.
"When I look back, I don't remember anyone teaching this to me, but it's how I've approached it every day," he said. He trains 10 to 30 hours a week 
But Mr. Fink did not spend 30-plus years working to become an international athlete. While attending Lehigh University on a partial track and cross-country scholarship, he quit competitive running because of injuries. After graduating in 1980 with a degree in finance and economics, he ran only to bolster his tennis game. He was highly competitive on the court, but most of his energies were directed toward his banking career.
It wasn't until he married in 1990 that Mr. Fink became interested in triathlons. He started swimming and biking simply because his wife, Melanie, did.
Everything changed after he entered a sprint triathlon (a half-mile swim, three-mile run and 15-mile bike effort) in 1991.
"The fact I didn't do that well made it sort of intriguing to me," he said. Improvement then became a "sort of fun project."
He and his wife were soon spending vacations at triathlon camps or working individually with top coaches. Before and after work, he would train, rising at 4 a.m., as he had in junior high, to put in two to three hours.
"Time went by very quickly,"' Mr. Fink said. "The years just flew by. I had such a demanding job and hobby that a five- or six-year period seemed like a week."
His training, heavy on aerobic development that included constant monitoring of his heart rate, started leading to achievements. In 1997, he became the national 35-to-39-year-old division Long Course (half-triathlon) champion. 
In what free time he had, he found himself writing training plans for friends who were impressed by his results.
In 1998, at the Ironman Triathlon World Championship, the arduous competition in Hawaii that involves a 2.4-mile swim, a 112-mile bike course and a 26.2-mile run, Mr. Fink finished second in his age group and in the top 20 over all. Then, in 1999, he was the first American finisher of any age in the 1999 Ironman European Championship.
But he wasn't satisfied.
"I'd leave a meeting, fly to Germany and run a race, and then fly back the next day," Mr. Fink said. "This was an interesting journey I found myself on, and I wanted to enjoy it more."
So, he left Citibank in spring 2000 on a leave of absence. He has not gone back.
Instead, Mr. Fink, whose costly travel is covered by both national and local business sponsors, is competing at the highest levels and making his living by coaching. A small part of that is a twice-weekly swim class at the Y in Bridgewater. Most of the people who take the class are triathletes. 
"One of the neat things in my life, and it hits me once in a while while on the deck, is the thought that 12 years ago I didn't know how to swim," Mr. Fink said. 
Most of his coaching is by Internet and phone. He oversees 50 triathletes and 30 runners in the United States, Canada and Europe, and he has a long waiting list of potential clients.
"I'm convinced people all have a secret life they want to live," he said. "But it's tough and risky to take that step. I truly believe anybody can make a living at their passion. All that's needed is a little guts. A lot of people with a lot of money are real miserable. I wake up every morning and I'm real excited."
Mr. Fink, who hasn't closed the door on returning to the financial world (he is often glued to the business news on television when training indoors), said his typical client was 30 to 55 years old, married with children and had a demanding professional life.
"It's the most exciting thing in the world," he said. "I'll be at the finish line and see their kids and I can't help but think their lives will change as a result of seeing their father or mother take on an impossible challenge and succeed."
Mr. Fink doesn't coach young professional "elites who have all day to train," because he doesn't find that interesting or challenging.
But that doesn't mean his athletes are not successful.
Kathleen Hughes, 44, of Columbus, Ohio, became a world champion last year, winning the Hawaiian Ironman in the 40-to-44 age group for women. 
Ms. Hughes, the mother of two, said Mr. Fink had played a huge part in her victory. She is a 15-year triathlete who has trained with him for two years. They keep in constant e-mail contact and talk by phone every couple of weeks.
"Other coaches are more cookie-cutter," she said, noting that he adapted her training schedule to her personal life. "He's very interested in you and what your plans are. He's doing this for the passion of the sport."
A New Jersey client, Jeff Liccardi of Warren, agreed.
Mr. Liccardi, 42, didn't know how to swim when he signed up for Mr. Fink's Bridgewater class two years ago. He was also a slow runner, averaging 11-minute miles over short distances. But last year he did his first marathon in 3:15. This year he finished in the middle of the pack in Ironman USA in Lake Placid, N.Y., which attracted more than 1,500 entrants, more than 20 coached by Mr. Fink.
"He was happier when I finished than I was," said Mr. Liccardi, a father of three who owns auto dealerships in New Jersey. 
"He's the most genuine person," he added. "Obviously he's not doing this for the money. He had a great job. I know a lot of successful people. A lot of people don't love their work, but it pays good money. He has the passion to help people. It takes a lot of courage to do that. Most people are afraid to branch out in a different direction. They want to stay in their comfort zone. That's another reason why I respect him."
Mr. Fink's career change struck a nerve with Richard Haig Jr., 39, of Bridgewater, who owns a security and fire alarm company and has been coached by Mr. Fink for a year and a half.
Several months ago, Mr. Haig, the father of two girls, started a sideline business, FeMaleRacing.com, on multisport training.
Without Mr. Fink, Mr. Haig said he wouldn't be placing in triathlons and might not even be doing them. He said he "absolutely would not have the confidence to go into coaching and look at it as a future career."
In addition to expanding his new business, Mr. Haig, who has completed three Ironman-distance triathlons, finishing third by age bracket in the C.E.O. Challenge division at Lake Placid, plans to do the big event in Hawaii.
The time frame is important because he wants to compete for his father, who has cancer.
"There's no question in my mind that we'll get there, and I mean we, because I couldn't do it without him," he said of Mr. Fink.
Mr. Haig quoted Mr. Fink as saying: "At 35, 40 or 45, you can get better every year for 10 years. It's about training."
"How can you argue with him?" he asked. "He's done it." 
Mr. Fink's goal is to break nine hours at an Ironman (his best time to date is 9:03). He is one of only 35 people chosen to compete this month in the Ultra-Man World Championship in Hawaii. The three-day event makes Ironman races look like light training, with a combined 6.2 miles of swimming, 261 miles of biking and 52 miles of running.
"You always want to push beyond and find something that scares you a little bit," Mr. Fink said.
"It's amazing to think that what I loved at 12 I love at 44, and even more," he added. "Sometimes I wake up and say, 'How'd I get here?' "

HEADLINE: A Taste for the Future 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN KURTZ 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
ASIAN pulled-pork spring rolls aren't what 17-year-old Tyeneara Thompson normally has for breakfast. But this isn't a normal day for Tyeneara, a senior at Montgomery Academy here. It's day one of an internship at Maize, one of the city's sleekest restaurants, and for the next three hours Tyeneara will be swapping books and paper for an education of another kind.
 Her project of the morning? Fifty spring rolls, which must be filled and tightly wrapped so they won't burst in the fryer. Halfway through her first roll, she sees filling poking through the won-ton wrapper, so she unfolds it and starts again, hands growing sticky with pork and egg wash. 
 At her side, the executive chef, Doug Gough, notices her frustration. 
"You can do it," he said. "It's like making a burrito."
For the next six weeks, Mr. Gough will be both coach and cheering section, alternately instructing her in the high-octane ways of the professional kitchen and encouraging her when the pressure seems too much. 
People would pay good money for this kind of one-on-one with a chef. But more is at stake than bragging rights. When Tyeneara graduates from high school next spring, she will do so with three years of culinary training, and her sights will be set not on college but on a full-time job. 
While the goal may seem odd to some, it's right on target for students at Montgomery, a public high school for about 230 special-education students that offers a mix of academic and occupational training. Newark is planning to go further, with an ambitious school-to-career program that promises informational speakers, job shadows, mentoring and internships for all 10,000 public high school students in the city. 
"Over the next three to four years, we'll be redesigning all of the high schools," said Jerry Bruno, director of school to careers and college initiative for the Newark public schools. "Our hope is that students will get the knowledge and experience they need to make wise career choices."
Sharde Smith, 17, is also interning at Maize this fall. But unlike Tyeneara, Sharde spends her mornings in the front of the house, trailing the hostess, waiters and waitresses and learning the finer points of restaurant etiquette. Although it's not as exciting as being in the kitchen, she says she welcomes the opportunity. 
"It is hard work but I like it," said Sharde, also a Montgomery senior, whose experience has reinforced her desire to own a restaurant, a dream she's had since she was 13. "I like being on my feet, I like parties, I like serving people."
That special-education students can get such real-world experiences is exciting for Rich Kazanjian, department chairman for vocational education at Montgomery Academy. 
"It's great for their confidence," he said. "Having had the exposure to a restaurant of this level, they won't be intimidated when they move on to other things." 
In the next few years, Montgomery hopes greatly to expand the number of internship opportunities available to seniors in food service, as well as other career tracks. The goal is to rotate the food-service students through a variety of positions and a range of settings, from mom-and-pop establishments to restaurants like Maize.
"We do everything we can to ease their school-to-work transition," said Mr. Kazanjian, a former restaurant owner who ran the school's culinary program for 12 years. "But most of our attention is focused on the kitchen." Then we realized that there are plenty of employment opportunities in the front of the house.' 
According to the National Restaurant Association, the food service industry is the leading private-sector employer in the country. And the number of hospitality-industry jobs is projected to increase by nearly two million from 1998 to 2008, with 115,000 in management positions, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
With so many openings, restaurants are always on the lookout for qualified employees. Maize is no exception. 
"When the restaurant first opened, we had a lot of difficulty getting help," recalled Stephanie Voulgaris, the owner. "There are good people, but we had trouble getting them to come from New York to Newark."
In July 2000, after just two months in business, Ms. Voulgaris became convinced that the solution to her staffing problem lay all around her in the community of Newark.
Discussions with the school district began, and nearly two years later, in April 2002, the first three interns walked through her door. 
In only one week, "you could see the transformation" in the students, said Ms. Voulgaris, who personally oversaw the activities of the two front-of-the-house interns. "But there was a lot of work to do, so I asked if they could come back." 
Everyone agreed, which explains how Tyeneara, Sharde and Tanisha Brown, another Montgomery senior, returned to Maize for another six-week internship this fall. Ultimately, Ms. Voulgaris hopes that some of the interns will return to her restaurant for permanent jobs.
The restaurant's rationale for investing in an internship program is not unusual, according to Katherine Hughes, senior research associate with the Institute on Education and the Economy at Teachers College, Columbia University. During seven years of research for a coming book on work-based learning, Ms. Hughes identified several reasons companies take interns. 
"Some companies, mostly trades, do it because they have trouble getting employees"' she said. "Others do it for philanthropic reasons." 
But even if they "might have gotten their arm twisted in the beginning," she added, "they find it perks everyone up to have a young person around."
After an hour and a half in the kitchen, one of Maize's young interns is finally getting the hang of rolling and wrapping. Rows of spring rolls, 50 in all, lie on a baking sheet ready for the fryer. Tyeneara breathes a sigh of relief. A demanding job, but such is life in the kitchen. 
"It's very hard work, but it's a hard business," she said. "It's a great experience and it will help me when I get my own restaurant."
But right now there's no time for talking. It's 11:52 a.m. and a box of shiitake mushrooms is waiting.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Suddenly, State Universities Have More Allure

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
GROWING up, Jeni R. Mattingly never placed the University of Maryland, her state's leading public institution, at the top of her college shopping list. To her and many of her classmates at Bethesda-Chevy Chase High School, the university's campus in College Park was too big, too close to home and a bit short on cachet.
 Nevertheless, as the college application season heats up, the university figures prominently in the thinking of Ms. Mattingly, 17, and many of her peers. "Everyone I know is applying," she said, with finances being a chief consideration even in a prosperous Washington suburb like Bethesda. 
 Ms. Mattingly says that she is hoping to avoid a large debt burden after graduation and that she wants to be able to travel during summer vacations. Other students cite stock market reverses and the sluggish economy as reasons many of them, and their parents, are looking to taxpayers to pick up much of the bill for college. 
Students have plenty to cope with in applying to colleges, from filling out myriad forms, writing essays and asking for recommendation letters. On top of that came the report last month from the College Board that tuition at four-year public institutions was up 9.6 percent from last year, more than six times the inflation rate. That followed a 7.7 percent jump last year. For private colleges, the increases were 5.8 percent this year and 6.4 percent last year.
The increases mainly reflected constriction in state budgets caused by the economic downturn. "As tax revenues decline, public colleges have searched for other sources of funding and for many, that has led to tuition increases," said Gaston Caperton, the president of the College Board.
Despite the sharp increase, tuition at state-supported colleges in the United States averages $4,081 a year, just 22 percent of the $18,273 average for private institutions. There seems little danger that this mainstay of affordable college education -- for the last 30 years nearly 80 percent of the country's students have been enrolled in tax-supported institutions -- is edging out of broad financial reach.
"Even though they raised the price," said Ms. Mattingly of Maryland's increase of 6.2 percent this year, "it's still really, really low."
Maryland's tuition and mandatory fees, excluding room and board, for in-state students total $5,670 this year -- comparable to those for many other big public universities. But that total is still much less than the average of $25,000 a year, excluding room and board, for Ms. Mattingly's other four options, all private institutions: Mount Holyoke, Bennington and Kalamazoo Colleges and New York University.
The increasing appeal of public institutions is showing up in a surge of inquiries and campus visits. For example, Rutgers, the leading New Jersey state university, says applications for next year are running nearly triple the year-ago pace, while Saturday campus tours have nearly doubled, forcing the school to scramble for extra buses and guides.
Upper-income families, in particular, are more likely to look at state institutions than they did just a few years ago, said Terry W. Hartle, senior vice president at the American Council on Education, an association of colleges and universities. In part, this may be a backlash against the pricing strategy of private colleges, which generally has been to raise tuition enough to extract maximum revenue from those who can afford it and to offer enough aid to attract those who cannot. High tuition -- now more than $28,000 a year at many elite private schools -- is often taken as a sign of quality and, not incidentally to some, it provides some snob appeal.
The sluggish economy and a post-Sept. 11 desire to stay closer to home are among the reasons for the rising interest in public schools. But the trend also reflects ever-keener competition for places in top-notch private institutions.
For their part, several states, including Indiana, Georgia and Connecticut, have made themselves more attractive by establishing honors colleges within their universities that allow top students a free or nearly free financial ride. The idea is to prevent their best students from being recruited by other states and to enhance national reputations, said Howard Greene, an education consultant from Westport, Conn., and the author of many books about colleges. "These are some of the best bargains around," Mr. Greene said.
OTHER signs of public universities' growing appeal are the huge premiums that the more prestigious ones -- sometimes referred to as "public Ivies" -- command from out-of-state students. While out-of-staters typically pay two to two and a half times the tuition and fees charged to residents, the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor charges $23,738, or three times as much as for state residents, while the University of Virginia charges $19,805, more than four times as much. At the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, where in-state tuition is $3,856, outsiders pay $15,140.
In some cases, out-of-state students may eventually be able to establish residency, to qualify for the lower in-state tuition. Each state has its own requirements, though many will demand proof that a student has had permanent ties for at least a year. Evidence of such links may include registering to vote, getting a driver's license or paying income tax.
Of course, price is only part of any proper calculation of value when choosing a college. A student must "fit" the school in terms of many variables, including departmental and overall academic distinction, social life and the makeup of the student body, because students may learn as much from their peers as from their teachers. Some criteria are hard to judge. A school may have a star-studded faculty, for example, but how much of it is available to undergraduates?
Still, price can be legitimately decisive, particularly if a student intends a career in a relatively low-paying field in which it would be hard to pay off heavy debts. 
While degrees from Ivy League and other expensive private schools still open many doors to the job market, the upper reaches of corporate, scientific and public life are full of graduates of public schools. "The old-school-tie effect is nowhere near what it once was," Mr. Greene said.
Many corporate recruiters seem to care little. "I haven't noticed a distinct difference," said Dawn Towe, a recruiter for the Target Corporation. In fact, she said she finds that private-college students often harbor "unrealistic expectations" about their ability to rise quickly in retailing, where they may not have held even summer jobs.
"They want to be in charge of marketing" almost from the outset, Ms. Towe said. 
Not surprisingly, the greater interest in public colleges has helped them become more selective, too. That means admissions are no longer almost automatic at many schools. What's more, it is often harder to get all the courses needed for graduation in the standard four years. About half the graduates at 100 public colleges covered by a recent Kiplinger's magazine survey took longer than that.
Then there's the issue of financial aid. Families, especially those wrestling with college finance for the first time, may overlook one important factor as they compare costs: that private institutions can provide more aid in the form of grants, scholarships, loans and campus jobs than public schools. About 75 percent of students attending private colleges and universities receive some type of financial aid, compared with about 60 percent of students at public schools, according to the College Board. It said that a record $90 billion was available in financial aid during the 2001-02 academic year, with increases in grants, used more often by private schools, surpassing loans for the second consecutive year. 
"The public sees the posted price, which is dramatically higher" at private schools, said Mr. Hartle of the American Council on Education. "We don't do a very good job of telling people what it's actually going to cost."
TRADITIONALLY, most private schools make admittance decisions on a need-blind basis, without regard to the ability to pay. They then make it financially feasible for students they want. Amherst College, for example, lists a cost of $35,690 for tuition, room and board. But 47 percent of students have been determined to have financial need, with the average annual aid package worth $24,229, according to the U.S. News and World Report annual survey published this year. While 47 percent of students at Amherst graduate with debt, the average amount is a fairly manageable $12,270. Federal tax credits and various tax-advantaged prepayment plans can lighten the burden further.
Even well-to-do families often qualify for aid. "People are surprised to learn that a $100,000 income often qualifies" if, say, there are big medical bills or more than one sibling in college at the same time, Mr. Greene explained.
In fact, as lesser private schools engage in an increasingly fierce price war to fill seats, even elite private schools that are flooded with applicants use their big endowments to offer hefty subsidies to enroll students they desire most.
Public universities, with their lower prices, not only have smaller aid budgets but are also chary about helping out-of-staters. Budget cuts have been severe, suggesting that prices will continue to rise faster than at private institutions.
The best strategy for students, said Peter Warchal, a counselor at Exeter High School in Pennsylvania, is to apply to a "dream" school, to a couple where the chances of getting in are 50-50 and a "safety valve," all with little regard for whether they are public or private. After all, he said, the net price gap is often bridgeable, with financial aid.
Still, Jeni Mattingly will be crunching the numbers. "What it's going to come down to" next month, when many applications are due, she said, "is which school will give me the most for my money."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; 
Packs of Rival Dog Walkers Circle One Another and Growl

BYLINE:  By JON HART 

 BODY:
On a recent Sunday at the Hillside Dog Park in Brooklyn Heights, a Dane, a pit bull and half a dozen other dogs skirmished harmoniously on the fenced-in, sloping, three-acre expanse as their walkers looked on. 
 The playful and serene scene, on a site sandwiched between the Jehovah's Witnesses Watchtower and the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, disguises the bitter rivalries among the local self-employed dog walkers. 
 "Superficially, everyone gets along," said Jessica Johnson, a professional dog walker, as she watched over a Great Dane. "But there are concealed animosities." 
Indeed, dog walking in the vicinity of the popular dog run, which attracts dog lovers from throughout the city, has become a cutthroat business in which walkers can earn from $600 a week up to more than $100,000 a year. In this weak economy, dog walkers are watching both their charges and their backs. At Hillside, back-stabbing and bickering has sullied what was not long ago a vocation for slackers. 
"It got too competitive and too nasty," said Ms. Johnson, who is quitting after two years to attend pharmacy school. "One person went around saying that one walker's dogs were biting other dogs on the dog run. It hurt the walker's feeling, and it hurt her reputation."
One dog walker, Jennifer Bauch, fought back. When she learned that a rival was disparaging her, she confronted the offender in a tight elevator. 
"I told her that I was going to get a restraining order and that she was not going to able to work in my building," recalled Ms. Bauch, who became well known in Brooklyn Heights after she organized a memorial service for a deceased dog lover three years ago. 
Nor have all the tiffs been behind closed doors. One walker aired her grievance at a local movie house. "It was loud enough to be embarrassing," Ms. Bauch said. "This walker said, 'Thanks for stealing my pooch.' "
Ms. Bauch, a lawyer, epitomizes the new breed of walker: an ambitious, animal-loving entrepreneur. She turned to her current occupation after her dot-com employer went out of business two years ago. 
"People think it's a paper route, but I take it very seriously," said Ms. Bauch, a Marisa Tomei look-alike who works as many as 16 hours a day. When she's not singing out greetings to everyone from Montague Street panhandlers to Muffet Jones, president of the Hillside dog run, she is passing out business cards to anyone who, as she puts it, "even glances at a can of dog food in the supermarket." 
Upon request, she serenades her clients with operatic arias. Last Christmas, she presented them with framed pictures of their precious pets. While others struggle, Ms. Bauch picks and chooses her clients. 
"She dumped me," Elizabeth Lippman said. "I was horrified." Ms. Lippman is a freelance photographer whose irregular schedule did not jibe with Ms. Bauch's. Ms. Bauch often refers clients to her protege, a part-time bouncer, but she acknowledges that her competitive juices are still flowing. "When I see someone walking a new poodle," she said, "I'm hit with tinges of jealousy." JON HART

CORRECTION-DATE: November 17, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about dog walkers in Brooklyn Heights misstated the new career of Jessica Johnson, who is giving up that occupation. She is studying to become an emergency medical technician, not a pharmacist.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jessica Johnson is giving up dog walking. "Too competitive," she says. (Edwine Seymour for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
For Banks, Fed's Cut Isn't as Good As It Looks

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
SINCE the start of last year, the Federal Reserve has cut short-term interest rates a dozen times, including the half-point reduction last week. But bank shares have fallen.
 Robert Albertson, a principal and chief strategist at Sandler O'Neill, a New York investment bank, took some time out from a banking conference in Boston last week to talk about the money business. Following are excerpts from the conversation. 

Q. The number of problem loans jumped in the third quarter. Are there many more to come?

A. We are approaching the peak of the nonperforming loan cycle. Telecom is not over, and the energy trading companies are the other shoe left to drop. They are facing a massive liquidity crisis because the capital markets are closed to them. You are going to see some sizable nonperformers in the fourth quarter. But we are through the vast bulk of the problem, presuming we don't dive back into recession.

Q. With interest rates so low, is it a great time to be a lender?

A. No, it is not a great time to be a lender. And I cannot fathom how this recent drop in rates will help the economy, other than psychologically. Banks can't lower their funding costs any further. There will be a margin squeeze here. It's not enough to eliminate a good earnings year, but it will crimp it. But banks don't make that much money on loans. They make money on deposits, and their ability to raise deposits.
Most bank investors hope for lower rates, but they have never got it quite right. Lower rates are not a panacea. They are a drag.

Q. What is the state of loan demand?

A. Loan demand is not picking up yet, although a handful of banks, most recently Bank of America, are saying they are seeing some signs of firming in commercial lending. But it will not take much to spark a commercial lending upswing. The corporate sector is not flush with cash. They want to borrow and need to borrow.

Q. Why are you upbeat about bank and brokerage stocks?

A. Valuations are at the very low end of absolute price-to-earnings ratios, the condition of the industry is extraordinarily sound, and no one ever sees the end of the business loan cycle ahead of time. I want to invest where the damage seems worst at the moment, which is in the corporate banks and the big investment banks.

Q. Do you like J. P. Morgan Chase stock?

A. J. P. Morgan is selling at a market capitalization of about $41 billion. Their consumer bank alone is worth that as a stand-alone entity. So the remaining 70 percent of the organization is being valued at zero. Yet in various areas of commercial and investment banking, it ranks between No. 1 and No. 7, globally. This clearly cannot be worth zero. So the value is extraordinary. Some people are worried about whether the dividend will get cut. It's safe this quarter. But the stock is trading as if the dividend has already been cut.

Q. Will the banks be hurt by lawsuits from disasters like Enron and WorldCom?

A. I am always worried until the regulatory side is tamped down. Once that is done, I don't get that worried about civil claims and damage claims because they usually take a decade to get settled. It took an awful long time to get there in the tobacco industry. This is not the tobacco industry. I find it hard to believe that these things will be more than a first-class nuisance.

Q. Which other stocks do you favor?

A. We are extremely emphatic about Citigroup and Bank of America. My favorite brokerage stock has always been Lehman Brothers.
FleetBoston and North Fork Bancorporation are two smaller ones. And we like a lot of midcap names, particularly in the Southeast. Names in this group include Huntington Bancshares, Gold Banc, Sovran Bank, WSFS Financial Group and First Tennessee National. 

Q. Which stocks would you avoid?

A. Some of the banks that did well for people in more uncertain times, like Wells Fargo, are probably approaching fair value. And it is too soon to be looking at asset managers like Charles Schwab. Those stocks will lag a move in the market by three to six months because right now the retail investor is on the sidelines.

Q. What would worry you about the group?

A. Two things would make me worried. Terrorism is the first, if it impacted the consumer before the economy starts to recover. A lack of a fiscal package from Washington is the second. There has been an overreliance on monetary policy. The Fed's ability to help the economy ended almost a year ago, when it cut rates for the 11th time. We should have begun experiencing the benefit of the rate cuts last year. We did not. Presumably, with the shift in Congress, we have better odds than ever on the fiscal side.
