HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
A SleeperOf a Statistic Could Lead An Awakening

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
WHAT was the most important economic news of last week?
 * The Republican sweep in the midterm elections? 
 * The half-point interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve?
* Word that productivity growth accelerated to an annual rate of 4 percent in the third quarter? 
The election results unquestionably marked a turning point in Washington. President Bush's success in helping Republicans gain control of the Senate and hang on to the House will almost certainly lead to a conservative tilt in economic policy.
The White House is sure to press Congress to make last year's 10-year tax cut permanent. And many Republicans on Capitol Hill want to join the administration in passing a new package of investor tax cuts. In the long run, Republican control could lead to serious consideration of adding private investment accounts to Social Security and rewriting the entire tax code.
The Fed's decision to expend a big chunk of its remaining monetary ammunition also will have important ramifications. Its rate cut, bigger than most analysts and investors expected, suggests a deeper degree of concern within the central bank about the economy's prospects than Alan Greenspan and his colleagues have let on in public.
It also shows that the Fed is following the prescription presented earlier this year in a staff study about how to conduct monetary policy when rates are approaching zero and there are risks of deflation. The study suggested that it would be a mistake to be timid about rate cuts just because there would not be much room to reduce them further.
While Fed officials discount the possibility of Japanese-style deflation afflicting the United States, their willingness to cut their benchmark federal funds target rate to 1.25 percent from 1.75 percent signals a desire to be absolutely sure the economy does not sink into a deflationary bog.
Understandably, the new report on productivity did not generate the headlines given to the election and the Fed. But it arguably means more to the economic outlook in the long run, and maybe in the short run, than the changes in the political landscape or the Fed's willingness to empty its holster.
The 4 percent annual growth rate in productivity in the third quarter brought the annual rate over the past year to a remarkable 5.3 percent. That is the best performance in nearly two decades.
Most immediately, the production surge implies that companies can eke out better profits even if sales growth remains stagnant or low. Better profits, in turn, could support the recent rally in stock prices, easing the pain of anyone with a 401(k) plan and encouraging companies to begin increasing their capital spending. The lack of capital investment by businesses has been the most persistent problem afflicting the economy.
On the negative side, new efficiencies mean that companies can delay hiring new workers even when sales turn up. So the likelihood of a recovery without new jobs is increasing.
THE effects of strong productivity growth would be even more pronounced in the long run. Productivity is the crucial component in determining the economy's capacity to expand without igniting inflation.
Economists define the economy's long-term sustainable growth rate as the growth in the labor force, which is running around 1 percent a year and is likely to continue doing so for the foreseeable future, plus the growth rate of productivity. From the early 1970's into the mid-1990's, productivity was around 1.5 percent. So the economy's speed limit was thought to be about 2.5 percent annual growth.
During the second half of the last decade, productivity rose to 2.5 percent. Though no one expects the current 5.3 percent annual rate to last long, it could well settle at a pace above 2.5 percent. The economic speed limit would then be 3.5 percent or higher.
The implications would be substantial. Unemployment, now 5.7 percent, could fall back toward the 4 percent level. Wages could increase without diminishing corporate profits. Government revenues could swell without increasing tax rates, making it easier for the nation to address problems like assuring the solvency of Social Security and Medicare.
Mr. Greenspan, who thinks companies are just starting to make the most of technology in learning to produce more for less, singled out strong productivity gains last week in reassuring the nation about the economic outlook. But it is doubtful that many, if any, candidates spent time during the campaign talking with voters about output per hour. Productivity may not be a campaign slogan, but it is likely to do more to help politicians meet their economic promises than just about any other factor. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: E Pluribus Unum at the Dance 

BYLINE:  By GUY TREBAY 

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH, Fla. 

 BODY:
IF the easiest thing in the world is nailing Miami Beach in a couple of well-worn cliches -- model/waitress, for instance; Versace mansion; perma-tanned oldsters -- it is much tougher getting at the truth about this complicated sand spit reclaimed from the Atlantic Ocean, a place where reality is better thought of in the plural, a fact never clearer than at the annual homecoming dance of Miami Beach Senior High School. 
 All season throughout the country, high school students have been dressing themselves up for an annual dinner-dance that smacks of Andy Hardy anachronism in the age of Eminem. They have been choosing themes, building crepe-paper arches, staging fund-raising car-wash drives, buying streamers, ordering centerpieces and worrying about the right thing to wear. They have been participating in what seems an inevitable rite of passage for young Americans, until you step back and consider where some of these Americans started their lives. 
 "We're a mutt," Lavina Gangwani, the school's activities director, said last Saturday at the Hyatt Regency in downtown Miami. Ms. Gangwani was alluding to a student population that may set the national bar for multicultural representation, with students who come from 65 countries and speak 24 languages, a majority of them, it is worth pointing out, first-generation Americans. 
"We have Hispanics, African-Americans, South Americans, Europeans, a large Jewish population, obviously, a lot of Asians and even Islamic students," Ms. Gangwani said. 
The principal, Dr. Jeanne Friedman, said, "We have the children of multimillionaires coming to this school," referring to a small group that lives in the gated island enclaves scattered throughout Biscayne Bay. "But we also have students living in cars." That is why it was easy for someone standing in a ballroom of the Hyatt Regency to feel that there are times when the clearest symbol for the American dream might be a little black dress. 
The homecoming theme was the 1950's, as interpreted half a century later after numerous viewings of "Grease." The music was a mixture of mainstream hip-hop, salsa and merengue, played by a man who refers to himself as D. J. Lazaro. A ticket of $40 bought a dinner of chicken fingers and bite-size pizzas and what menus called "a lavish dessert display." 
The flexible dress code prohibited denim but otherwise left the students latitude to dress according to their own ideas of high style. Consequently, some young women wore voluminous crinolined infanta dresses reminiscent of quinceanera parties, the celebrations given in Hispanic communities for 15-year-old girls. Some wore dresses of bootlegged designer logo fabrics commissioned from local seamstresses. Some wore $300 Britney Spears dresses, custom-ordered two months in advance from shops in the Bal Harbour Mall. And some wore thigh-high dresses with plunging backs, of a sort that a certain mediagenic Latino superstar has built her career around.
"J. Lo inspired me a lot because she's sexy but at the same time simple," said Amy Rodriguez, whose fawn-color minidress had deep cutouts and a plunging back. "I wanted something different," she said, "with a little bit showing, but not too much." Pausing to adjust her lace-up platform sandals, Ms. Rodriguez added, "It's still a school."
In modeling herself after Ms. Lopez, Ms. Rodriguez was an anomaly. The lessons of assimilation are subtle, and most of the young women who turned out, among a student body that is 69 percent Hispanic, had chosen dresses sedate enough for a Westchester country club. 
"I was looking for a dress that was not too big," meaning bouffant, and simple shoes, Jessica Del Rio explained, referring to the tasteful jet-beaded sheath she had bought at a store near Calle Ocho, the downtown Cuban commercial strip, and the high-heeled sandals that were a J. C. Penney find. 
"Homecoming is not supposed to be all out," said Ms. Del Rio's escort, Jair Del Rio, a Beach High graduate, whose low-key corduroy Nautica shirt and suede Hush Puppies were a far cry, stylistically, from the zoot suit with patent leather shoes and cane that he wore to last year's prom. "I was tired of the same old tux," Mr. Del Rio explained.
As Ms. Del Rio talked, a natty junior walked past, and someone whistled. 
"Who made the suit?" Mr. Del Rio asked.
"I'll tell you the first name, and you tell me the rest," the young man said. There was a pause and then this word: "Giorgio."
"Head to toe?" Mr. Del Rio asked.
"Almost," the young man replied.
There are rules to employ when preparing for a homecoming dance, as in all important undertakings, Katherine Perez, 17, said. Ms. Perez's own outfit testified to determined shopping and, not coincidentally, could pass muster at Vogue. 
"Rule 1," Ms. Perez said, and it is one observed by many of the students, who began shopping for homecoming in August, "is give yourself enough time in advance." Rule 2 is "don't shop at the mall next to school." Rule 3 is "shop online and shop sales." 
Ms. Perez's platform sandals originally cost $50. She waited until they were marked down 20 percent. Her vest halter top and tweed skirt with a patchwork hem were both bought on EWindsor.com. "I definitely didn't want a prom dress," said Ms. Perez, who also said she stayed away from silks and satins and all black and white. The entire outfit had cost just under $100, running-around money by some standards, but a lavish expenditure in a room where many people had managed to dress up on a budget a third that size. 
There was, for instance, a young woman at the dance in a $300 stretch lace dress bought by her mother at the Bal Harbour Mall, and another whose entire outfit had cost $21, money her mother earned as a janitor there. (Of the 2,560 students at the high school, 82 percent are from an economic category referred to as low-moderate income.)
Looking around the dance floor, said Dr. Friedman, the school's principal, one surveyed a microcosm that took in everything from the "future Robert Rubins of the world" (Mr. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary, is an alumnus) to people who may be criminals. What seemed an undifferentiated, rump-shaking mass on the dance floor was actually something more compelling and precise. Less than a century ago, Miami Beach was a sleepy backwater, where racial restrictions were written into law. Now it is the jittery boomtown that anyone who wants to know the demographic, political and cultural future of America had better consult. 
"The microcosm is right there on that dance floor," Dr. Friedman said. It is not a reality that everyone in America is eager to embrace. But that, she said, is all right. "We all have to share the highways with everybody," the principal added, as she glided onto the dance floor. "Sooner or later you'd better learn how to understand."

(Photographs by Cindy Karp for The New York Times)(pg. 1); HIGHNESSES -- Thomas Morency and Vanessa Viera, the prince and princess of the junior class, at the homecoming dance.; DANCING THE NIGHT AWAY --The Beach High evening at the Hyatt Regency. HEADLINE: Business; 
A Bet on Credit Cards Becomes Messy at Sears

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
WASHING machines, work clothes, power tools and patio furniture. Sears, Roebuck built a rock-solid, if unexciting, image over the years by emphasizing such practical products. Americans shopped at Sears for what they truly needed, and out of that, the company has forged a $41 billion business, not only from selling the merchandise but also from helping to make the purchases possible. 
 About 60 million Americans hold Sears credit cards, and credit provides 60 percent of the company's profits -- far more than at any other retailer. To Wall Street, in fact, the credit business often overshadows what happens inside the stores. 
 But last month, the credit business -- which is the third-most-profitable credit card operation anywhere -- was rocked by the abrupt departure of Kevin T. Keleghan, the executive who ran it for three years. Ten days later, Sears said it would set aside an additional $222 million to cover unpaid credit card debt in the third quarter, driving down its share price 32 percent the day of the announcement. 
Sears's chairman and chief executive, Alan J. Lacy, tried to contain the damage, calling credit a cyclical business and attributing much of the trouble to Mr. Keleghan and to losses from the retailer's gold MasterCard. But this crisis, the third to erupt in the credit division in five years, has left some investors and analysts wondering whether the eagerness to expand on the credit front -- an eagerness mirrored in some of its newer, younger rivals -- is the best attitude for Sears, a 116-year-old retailer.
Mr. Lacy contends, without offering specifics, that the dismissal was justified. "Kevin did something that was unacceptable in the third quarter," he said last week. "He was not forthcoming about what was happening in his business. There are some details I will not share. My statement that I had lost confidence in his credibility is an accurate statement, and it's as nice as I can phrase it."
Mr. Keleghan did not return telephone messages left at his home in Lake Forest, Ill., and a Sears spokeswoman would not provide the name of his lawyer or any other representative.
The troubles come at an especially sensitive time for Sears, which is based in Hoffman Estates, Ill., a Chicago suburb. After several comeback attempts on the retailing side, the company is battling competitors like Target and Kohl's, which offer brand-name products at discount prices in stores that Sears is openly trying to imitate.
About a year ago, Sears embarked on a broad program to overhaul its stores and make them more appealing to the kinds of customers who buy its refrigerators, ranges, plasma TV's and other high-priced products. That effort includes the $1.9 billion purchase of Lands' End in May and the introduction of an apparel line called Covington -- moves that some analysts worry will alienate the traditional Sears shopper.
The grueling competition, however, continues -- at a time when consumer confidence is weak. Many shoppers, nervous about their job security, their investments and the prospect of war, are spending only when they think they have to. Sears shares, which closed on Friday at $24.03, are fetching less than they did just after the terrorist attacks last year and less than half the $59 price reached last spring.
"We think Sears has lost its retail identity, leaving it ill equipped to win much market share," Rozilyn Bryant, an analyst at Morningstar Inc. in Chicago, wrote in a note to investors late last month. "Given a flawed retail strategy and a credit portfolio that's beginning to resemble Pandora's box, we'd avoid the shares unless they fell to $10 to $12."
IN an interview last week, Mr. Lacy said such consternation was out of step with reality. The company's changes on the retail side are moving ahead as planned, he said, and the credit unit's rough patch will be only temporary. "We're a strong company with substantial profit and substantial cash flow," he said. "We've worked through these things before, and we'll work through them again."
The credit division is expected to produce more than $1 billion in profits this year, Mr. Lacy said. Last year, it generated $1.53 billion in profits, up just 1 percent from 2000, according to the Nilson Report, which tracks the credit industry. The credit unit includes Sears credit card accounts as well as about 25 million gold MasterCard accounts. Keeping it profitable requires skilled balancing of risk and reward, experts say, and in a volatile economy, risk can be difficult to gauge.
Before moving to the top job at Sears two years ago, Mr. Lacy headed the credit division. Considering that, some analysts wonder why he did not have a better sense of the problems on the credit side.
When Mr. Keleghan's dismissal was announced on Oct. 7, Sears held a conference call and assured analysts and investors that all was well. Just 10 days later, the increase in bad debt was revealed, and "it was, 'Whoa, a whole new world out there,' " said Deborah Weinswig, a retail analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.
Mr. Lacy's first task, she said, should be to restore investor confidence. "Everyone's been shaken," she said. "The nature of what happened is important, but there was also this false sense of security."
Mr. Lacy says that part of what happened was tied to the cyclical nature of credit cards, and that Sears's troubles with customer delinquencies in 1997 and 1998 were "driven by record personal bankruptcies in America." The company's top credit-card customers, he added, had been "picked off" by banks offering Visa cards or MasterCards with low initial interest rates. Then a wave of bankruptcies hit, leaving Sears with defaulting customers in what Mr. Lacy called "a surprise." 
At the same time, Sears was under investigation for its tactics toward people who declared personal bankruptcy. Across the country, Sears collected money owed by cardholders without notifying the judges presiding over their cases, so people whose debt had been officially erased were still paying their Sears bills. The practice came to light in early 1997, and Sears management, headed by Arthur C. Martinez, negotiated for nearly two years before reaching a settlement that included a guilty plea by the company as well as $475 million in fines and restitution.
A little more than two years ago, Sears decided to fight fire with fire. It introduced its own gold MasterCard, persuading 23 million of the 60 million Sears cardholders to switch. The card offered check-writing and a chance to transfer existing balances to the MasterCard. Sears also started a direct-mail program, signing up two million new MasterCard customers. The direct-mail customers "have not turned out to produce the kind of profitability we wanted," Mr. Lacy said, while there have also been payment defaults among MasterCard holders who previously had Sears cards.
Sears has become the world's No. 2 MasterCard issuer, according to the Nilson Report. "The Sears credit unit has delivered profits that any credit card issuer would be delighted to have as their own," said David Robertson, the publisher of the report. "Over the last few years, analysts have come to view Sears as a credit card company that has a retail arm. It hasn't led the market on the retail side in a long, long time."
At one investment firm, Sanford C. Bernstein, analysts from the financial services sector and the retail sector will team up to study Sears's performance, starting this month.
Mr. Keleghan, who was an executive at American Express and AT&T's Universal card unit before arriving at Sears, guided the creation of the company's MasterCard program. He appears to have been admired by his peers in the credit card industry, some of whom say they have trouble comprehending the reasons Mr. Lacy gave for his dismissal. 
"It doesn't compute," said Paul Kahn, general manager of the Group Advantage Service Corporation, who oversaw Mr. Keleghan when both worked on the AT&T Universal card in the early 1990's. "He is boringly honest," he said, adding that "there is no way" he would have allowed trouble to build. 
In any case, the Sears MasterCard program has run into difficulty. Its accounts cover 37 percent of Sears's $31 billion receivables portfolio, and some of those cardholders were not paying their bills, leading to heftier "chargeoffs" -- the industry term for uncollected bills -- despite Sears's unusually generous policy of not declaring a chargeoff until eight months have passed without payment. Most card companies do so at six months. 
Mr. Lacy said that Sears, while tightening some requirements for its MasterCard, would not change the eight-month rule. "We're focused on economics," he said. In those two extra months, he added, "people have a chance to get a job, a chance to restore their financial health." 
That is one of the many differences between Sears and its rivals. At Target, about 15 percent of pretax profit comes from the credit division, a spokeswoman said, and that may grow as high as 23 or 24 percent in the next few years.
In Minneapolis, its home base, Target has built a separate campus to house its Target financial division and is making a sustained pitch to move its best Target cardholders to its Target Visa card. The card includes a "smart chip" that records information about purchases, which Target's information network can use to distribute coupons to cardholders and otherwise manage sales.
Unlike Sears, Target does not allow cardholders to transfer balances from other cards to its Visa, said Cathy Wright, a Target spokeswoman, and they are not given check-writing privileges. About eight million Visa cards have been issued since the program began in 2000, she said, with about two-thirds of those selected from the ranks of former Target cardholders. The company would not disclose how many Target cardholders it still has.
For the Visa card, no direct-mail applications were solicited, and only the top-performing Target cardholders were offered the card, she added. Interest rates range from 9.9 percent to 18.9 percent, depending on a shopper's credit profile.
Chargeoffs occur after six months, and Target's reserve for bad debt is $450 million this year, up from $261 million last year. The growth represents the increase in cardholders, she said. "Our delinquency and chargeoff rates are what we expected," she said. 
Kohl's, based in the Milwaukee suburb of Menomonee Falls, offers its own card, not a Visa card or MasterCard, said Susan Henderson, a spokeswoman. Chargeoffs occur after six months, and the allowance for bad debt increased last year to $41.3 million from $22.7 million, she said, because of "customer bankruptcies and delinquent accounts due to the economic environment in fiscal 2001." According to Sanford C. Bernstein, the investment analysts, the credit division's profits fell 4 percent last year because of bankruptcies and delinquencies. At the same time, "credit sales have been increasing faster than overall sales."
SOME analysts have expressed concern that beyond generous chargeoff terms, Sears offers other deals -- like zero percent financing and no payments for 12 months -- that make its credit situation more difficult to read. The promotions help drive sales of big-ticket products, particularly appliances, but the worry is that they do not reflect the full amount of outstanding debt on the company's books. 
Mr. Lacy, however, says such deals are necessary to do business today. "Zero percent financing promotions have become an important part of retailing," he said. And he offers an alternative view of the effect of such financing. "Our delinquency rate would be higher if you took out those zero percent balances," he said. "Our chargeoff rate would be higher. And therefore our return on assets would be higher. We're typically No. 1 or No. 2 in return on assets." 
He says his job is not in jeopardy, despite the problems of the last few weeks. "We very purposefully set out on an ambitious agenda to reposition and restructure the business," he said. "The organization has worked very hard to implement those changes." All along, he said, the goal was to fix the parts of Sears that were broken, on the retail side, while expanding the parts that weren't, like the credit division. 
"I guess you could say we've added to the list of things to do," Mr. Lacy said.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Dollars and Euros: A Look Beyond the Parity Line

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
A DOLLAR is now worth less than a euro, and currency analysts say it has even further to fall. They predict that American tourists may be paying $1.05 for a euro next summer, and $1.10 at the end of 2003.
 If that view is right, Americans invested in stocks or bonds in Europe would enjoy a welcome windfall. The dollar's 12.2 percent decline against the euro this year has already been very good to them, reducing losses in stocks and increasing gains in bonds when these performances are translated back into dollars. 
 But investors should not accept the forecast as a fait accompli, because a further fall in the dollar depends on continuing weakness of the American economy. The dollar fell to below parity with the euro last Wednesday, after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates, and some traders and investors apparently viewed the Fed's move as a sign of more months of slow growth. The dollar finished the week at $1.01 to the euro, almost a three-year low. 
A growth surprise, however, could give the dollar a boost. And the Fed's aggressive half-point rate cut makes it more likely that the economy could spurt ahead faster than expected next year.
The dollar also fell to parity with the euro in July but then rallied, confounding predictions of further declines.
Stephen S. Smith, who manages a $2.5 billion global bond portfolio at Brandywine Asset Management, said he decided in July to hedge his European bond portfolio against a dollar rally. Now he is preparing to drop that hedge and benefit from a falling dollar if the American currency slips a little lower. "We may give way to a weaker dollar and a stronger euro next year," he said.
What is strange about the dollar's fall -- and why it could reverse -- is that investors are not buying euros because the economic outlook on the Continent is better than it is in the United States. In fact, the 2003 forecast for the 12-country euro zone shows slower growth than in the American economy.
Instead, the dollar is being undermined by disappointment in American performance. "I never see anyone buying the euro because they are excited by the prospects for euro growth," said Lara Rhame, senior foreign exchange economist at Brown Brothers Harriman. "It is just they have found a reason to sell the dollar." 
Both Ms. Rhame and James McCormick, global head of foreign exchange strategy at Lehman Brothers, said disenchantment with the dollar is centered on forecasts that the American economy will grow about 2.5 percent next year. That is below what economists call the potential growth rate -- the fastest pace at which the economy can expand without creating inflationary pressures. Because workers' productivity is high, the rate of potential growth is 3 percent to 3.5 percent, these analysts said.
The other drag on the dollar, Mr. McCormick said, is the huge size of the American current account deficit, which could reach a record $500 billion this year. When the economy is perking along and foreigners like the stock market, the American economy can attract the investment it needs to cover this deficit.
Now, Mr. McCormick said, the dollar is under significant pressure because the economy "is growing under potential, and that means it is going to be hard to attract the capital to fund the current account deficit." When foreign capital is scarce, interest rates will rise and the dollar will fall to attract more foreign investment.
BUT both Ms. Rhame and Mr. McCormick have caveats, so it may be riskier than it looks to jump into funds promising additional gains from a fall in the dollar, as well as from picking the right stocks or bonds.
Ms. Rhame is expecting a 10 percent decline in the dollar in 2003, but she said that "if we return to potential growth next year, the euro is not going to rally."
Mr. McCormick expects the dollar to fall to a range of $1.05 to $1.10 to the euro in the next six to nine months. But, he added, "if the United States economy can surprise on the upside and get back to potential in 2003, we should get back to the parity range" on the dollar. That is where it is right now.

HEADLINE: Between a Paw and a Sharp Place 

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON

 BODY:
TO give the economy a lift, the Federal Reserve cuts short-term interest rates by half a point, more than most analysts predicted, to their lowest level in more than 40 years.
 Voters unexpectedly give business-friendly Republicans control of both Congress and the White House for just the second time since Dwight D. Eisenhower was president. 
 And stocks fall.
Huh?
Predicting the market is always tough. But the last year has been especially maddening. After holding its own in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was brought low earlier this year by accounting scandals and worry about economic weakness. Then, in October, traditionally the worst month for stocks, the market rallied. The S.& P. 500 tacked on nearly 9 percent and the Dow Jones industrial average climbed more than 800 points, almost 11 percent. 
But last week, the rally stalled. After rising on Wednesday in the wake of the Fed's rate cut and the Republican takeover, the S.& P. 500 fell by more than 3 percent over the next two days.
So what's next? Are these declines just a blip? Did the market really bottom out at the beginning of October? Or is the rally a hiccup? Four times since March 2001, stocks have gained more than 10 percent. Each of the first three times, the rally fizzled and the market wound up lower than it was before.
Unfortunately, those questions have no easy answer. Risks of war, terrorism and more accounting scandals have compounded the usual economic and political uncertainties.
Looking at the same set of statistics, economists and strategists can plausibly argue that the United States will post solid growth next year, or fall back into recession. Though it increases the odds of business-friendly legislation, including limitations on lawsuits and jury awards, the Republican takeover of the Senate also raises the chances of a tax cut whose benefits would go mainly to the very wealthy, with uncertain economic benefits.
Wall Street cannot even agree on what corporate earnings are. Optimistic strategists look at the S.& P. 500's "operating earnings," which factor out one-time restructuring charges and other expenses that companies have persuaded analysts should not be counted against them. On that basis, the S.& P. 500 is expected to earn roughly $48 a share in 2003.
If that calculation is right, the price-to-earnings ratio of the S.& P. 500, based on expected future earnings, is about 19, and stocks are more reasonably valued than they have been since 1994. Stocks look especially attractive relative to 10-year government notes, which are paying 3.85 percent, the lowest rate in more than a generation.
But skeptics argue that investors need to look at reported earnings after charges; on that basis, earnings this year will be closer to $30 a share. By that measure, the S.& P. 500 is trading at a P/E ratio of 30, far above its historical average. By other measures, stocks are also quite expensive; the dividend yield on the S.& P. 500 is only 1.8 percent, well below its historical norm.
The threat of terrorism and the potential for war with Iraq, meanwhile, lurk in the background. Few analysts expect a prolonged war, but any war is still expected to cost $50 billion to $100 billion, a price tag that will probably have to be borne by the United States. And what will happen to Iraq if and when its leader, Saddam Hussein, is ousted is far from clear.
The risks of future terrorist strikes are unknowable. Even small attacks in the United States could damage consumer confidence and put the economy in a tailspin; some analysts said auto sales fell so far in October partly because people in the Washington area were worried about being shot by the sniper on exposed car lots. An attack on the scale of Sept. 11 would rock the markets and the economy.
There is no consensus on the market's direction, so here are three of the most plausible scenarios, ranging from sad to happy.

Gloom and Doom
Consumer spending has been the brightest spot in the American economy this year. But market bears worry that consumers have become far too dependent on easy credit, a trend that cannot last.
With housing prices rising and mortgage rates low, many homeowners have repeatedly refinanced their homes, taking on more debt each time and spending the proceeds. That refinancing boom, along with a surge in zero-interest car loans, has left consumer debt at a record high. Eventually, consumers will have to pull back, said Steven H. East, the chief economist at Friedman, Billings, Ramsey & Company, a regional investment bank based in Arlington, Va.
"Consumers have too much debt," he said. "Even debt at zero percent is debt you have to pay back. And corporations have too much debt."
With economic growth anemic and a strong dollar keeping imports cheap, Mr. East expects the United States to avoid deflation only narrowly over the next few years. He and others predict that inflation will be only 1.25 percent in 2003.
But investors have not yet accepted that when inflation is low, corporate earnings tend to grow very slowly, Mr. East said. In the long run, profits grow about 7 percent a year, and inflation represents about half of that increase, he said. But with inflation so low, companies will struggle to generate that level of profit growth. So, relative to bonds, Mr. East said, stocks are not as cheap as they appear.
"A real challenge for the equity market is to come to grips with a lower rate of inflation and nominal earnings growth," Mr. East said. "You have very low Treasury yields mainly because inflation is very low, and because inflation is very low, you can't value earnings as you have in the past."
Mr. East would not offer a specific target for the S.& P. 500. But he said he did not believe the index should trade above its historical average of 16 times profits, even with interest rates so low. For the S.& P. 500 to reach that level, it would have to fall to 800, near the lows it set in July and early October.
Zachary Karabell, a senior economic analyst at Fred Alger Management in New York, is almost as pessimistic. He figures that economic growth in the United States and worldwide will probably sputter for at least the next year. "It wouldn't take much to have a double-dip" recession, he said. "What's going to lead companies to really think more aggressively about new spending?"
With the economic outlook cloudy, Mr. Karabell does not see particularly cheap stocks anywhere. Although he does not expect a major decline, he does not see reasons to buy now, either.
"We're in this kind of chugging-along phase," he said, "and there is absolutely nothing on the horizon that suggests we're going to break out on the upside."

The Worst Is Over
Charles Pradilla, the chief investment strategist at SG Cowen, is slightly less glum.
"I don't think we're still in a recession," Mr. Pradilla said. "I think we're in an anemic recovery." He puts the odds that the economy will slide back into recession as high as 20 percent. Even so, he expects stocks to rise moderately over the next year. "I think the bear market is over," he said. "We've been in this bear market a long time. We've done our time in stir."
Mr. Pradilla argues that stock prices have fallen far enough that valuations are now reasonable. And after two years of deferring capital spending, companies will have to increase spending next year on information technology and software, as well as other big projects, he said. The revival in spending will help profits at technology companies, which remain a very important part of the market, he said.
Further, accounting standards have improved after the scandals this year, Mr. Pradilla said. With executives now required to certify their companies' financial results and the Securities and Exchange Commission aggressively bringing enforcement actions, companies will now be more careful. Over time, he said, investors will grow more comfortable that corporate profits are real.
"You put all that together, it doesn't mean you've got a great bull market, but this is what you need to end a bear market," he said. He predicts that the S.& P. 500 will rise about 6 percent by year-end, to 950 -- and to 1,065 by the end of 2003. The increase will be slow but broad, with no single sector dominating the gains, Mr. Pradilla said.
"There are no themes -- there is no Internet, no telecom convergence," he said. "It'll amaze people by being completely unthematic."
Steve Oristaglio, the co-head of investments at Putnam Investments in Boston, which manages $250 billion, offers a similar forecast, for similar reasons. Like Mr. Pradilla, he expects capital spending to recover. Computer and software prices "have come down, equipment has been fully depreciated, and more powerful equipment is out there," Mr. Oristaglio said. "Productivity will continue to surprise on the upside, and that will give corporations the confidence to continue to have a rise in fixed business investment."
In addition, Mr. Oristaglio said he expects profits to recover solidly next year. After two years of job cuts, companies are running leaner and more efficiently than they were at the peak of the boom, so any increase in sales will have a big impact on profits, he said.
The threat of deflation is overstated, he added; with the Federal Reserve pumping money into the economy, inflation will begin to pick up in 2003, hurting bonds and helping stocks. Buoyed by higher profits and solid productivity and economic growth, the S.& P. 500 should reach 1,050 to 1,100 by the end of 2003, Mr. Oristaglio said.
The best-performing stocks will probably be those companies whose fortunes are closely tied to overall economic growth, he said. He especially likes retailers and financial companies.
Tobias M. Levkovich, an equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, said investors had not yet accounted for the fact that Republican control of Congress could significantly benefit major industries. The biggest gainers, he said, will probably be financial and insurance companies, drug makers and manufacturing stocks that face large exposure to asbestos claims. Even if big limitations on asbestos lawsuits are not passed, businesses in general will gain from a more conservative federal judiciary, he said.
"We do know one thing, and that is that Bush is going to get a lot of his judicial appointees through," Mr. Levkovich said. He figures that the S.& P. 500 will reach 1,000 at the end of this year and 1,075 by the end of 2003.

Don't Worry, Be Happy
If the S.& P. 500 does reach 1,075 in the next 14 months, it will have gained 20 percent, a very healthy return.
But Wall Street's most upbeat strategists expect even more. Abby Joseph Cohen of Goldman, Sachs, who made her name in the late 1990's for her consistently bullish, and accurate, predictions -- though she did not predict the downturn -- said the index would hit 1,150 as early as next November, a gain of more than 28 percent.
Corporate balance sheets are in surprisingly good shape, with companies easily able to service their debt, and productivity continues to rise strongly, Ms. Cohen said. On Thursday, the Labor Department reported that productivity grew at an annualized rate of 4 percent in the third quarter.
"We have the world's most productive workers, best-trained and best-educated workers," Ms. Cohen said. "We also have a corporate sector that is in pretty good position."
The bears are overestimating other risks, Ms. Cohen said. The risk of Japanese-style deflation is minimal, because the American banking system is much stronger than its counterpart in Japan. And concerns about corporate accounting, although real, are overblown, Ms. Cohen said.
"S.& P. 500 companies have already made accounting adjustments of more than $200 billion in the last four quarters," she said. "The data now are much cleaner than they've been in a long time."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
A Head Wind for Apartment-Building Trusts

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH HARRIS 

 BODY:
LOW interest rates have been a bonanza for homeowners, but they have hurt investors in real estate investment trusts that own apartment buildings.
 Through Thursday, shares of apartment-building trusts have fallen 8.5 percent this year, underperforming the overall market for real estate investment trusts, or REIT's, which have risen by 1.1 percent, according to the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts. 
 David M. Lee, manager of the $114 million T. Rowe Price Real Estate mutual fund, said he sees the current weakness of apartment-building REIT's as a buying opportunity and has been increasing his holdings.
REIT's trade in the same way as stocks. They own and operate income-producing real estate and are required to pay most of their annual income as dividends. 
For REIT's that focus on apartment buildings, low interest rates have been a problem because they have made home ownership more affordable. That reduces demand among renters. Roughly 68 percent of American families own homes, up from 64 percent in 1994, according to Green Street Advisors, a real estate research firm in Newport Beach, Calif. 
"We are at record levels of single-home ownership and I'm not sure that trend or head wind can get substantially worse," Mr. Lee said. 
Vacancies in apartment buildings, meanwhile, have risen to 10.5 percent this year, from 9 percent at the beginning of 2001, according to Torto Wheaton Research, based in Boston. "Single-family housing is eating everybody's lunch," said David Shulman, managing director and senior REIT analyst at Lehman Brothers.
Low interest rates have also stimulated construction of apartment buildings, even though demand for apartments has tapered off. "The demand for apartments in 2001 was negative for the first time ever," said Lee Schalop, a real estate securities analyst at Banc of America Securities. "Not only is single family getting all the new households, but it is taking the old ones, too."
Robert W. Gadsden, manager of Alpine Realty Income and Growth, a mutual fund, said apartment-building REIT's were not likely to perform well in the short term: "None of these issues are abating -- interest rates are low, jobs are being cut, new supply continues -- we really need to see the economy improve."
Mr. Lee said he believes that the sector will rebound gradually after the economy improves. As of the end of September, his biggest holdings of apartment-building REIT's included Equity Residential, based in Chicago, and AvalonBay Communities, based in Alexandria, Va.
Timothy J. Pire, managing director at Heitman Real Estate Securities and co-manager of the $100 million PBHG REIT mutual fund, prefers apartment-building REIT's geared to middle-income residents. "The middle of the market apartments rent more by necessity, and you probably won't lose them to the single-family homes," Mr. Pire said. 
A favorite is United Dominion Realty Trust, based in Richmond, Va. It holds a national portfolio of middle-income properties, with some exposure to Washington, a market that he said had held up better than many regions during the downturn.
On the other hand, several analysts said they were concerned about REIT's with holdings in the Southeast, particularly in Atlanta. Mr. Shulman cited Post Properties, based in Atlanta, and Gables Residential Trust, based in Boca Raton, Fla. Declining occupancy and rents have depressed Post's funds from operations, a commonly used measure of REIT financial strength, he said. The company said last week that its funds from operations dropped by 27.5 percent in the third quarter, versus the period last year. Mr. Gadsden said Post's shares, down 29.9 percent this year, are trading well below book value, making them attractive. 
Last week, Gables reported a 10 percent increase in funds from operations for the third quarter, versus the period a year earlier. Marvin R. Banks Jr., the chief financial officer of Gables, said its properties are diversified. Houston, the site of its largest holdings, has been a strong market this year, he said, with rents up more than 5 percent. He added that rentals to corporate customers and revenue from management of apartments not owned by Gables have been strong. 
Still, Mr. Shulman said that he is concerned that Southern markets will not have a speedy recovery and that Gables may need to finance its dividends by selling properties. 
Mr. Banks said that even if some short-term factors were troubling, long-term trends favored the sector. Through 2020, census estimates show that the number of new renters will surge as baby boomers' children hit their peak renting years, he said. 
"During the last 12 months, we've been at this low point that has coincided with a recession and low mortgage rates, so if your holding period is three months, REIT's are not where you should be, but if it's 12 months or beyond, it's a safe bet," Mr. Banks said.

HEADLINE: Falling From Grace, Often to theA-List 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
FOR anyone in the private sector, the rise and very public fall of Harvey L. Pitt as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission would appear to be a career-stopping performance. Mr. Pitt had earned a stellar reputation in Washington as a securities lawyer with ample blue-chip corporate ties. Then, after a stormy 15 months laden with missteps, he made an election-night resignation that appeared as if he wanted to sneak out of town while no one was looking.
 Who would hire someone who failed so publicly, who was excoriated by the same business publications that once sang his praises? 
 But if history is any indication, the outlook for Mr. Pitt may not be so bleak. Many in business -- as well as old Washington hands -- who have had their names tarnished and reputations sullied have discovered that there is life in the private sector after public disgrace, and a potentially profitable one at that. 
Members of Congress who have resigned or who have been forced out are making money as lobbyists for Fortune 500 companies. Wall Street executives who went to the White House and were caught up in the Clinton scandal machine have bounced back, more successful and richer than ever. Cabinet secretaries and other politicians whose lurid sexcapades were grist for the tabloids are active in major corporations. Even nannygate dust-ups that scuttled cabinet appointments in both the Clinton administration and the first Bush administration are now distant memories for the businesswomen involved.
Just last Thursday night, at a glittery black-tie dinner in New York sponsored by the Aspen Institute, a study group, talk turned to Mr. Pitt. During predinner cocktails, one prominent New York lawyer said Mr. Pitt had a promising future, made even stronger by his S.E.C. tenure and the insights he picked up there.
"Harvey Pitt is going to be the hottest ticket coming out of Washington," said the lawyer, Robert A. Profusek, a partner at Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, sipping from his drink. "I know his phone is ringing off the hook with law firms trying to hire him. He's an excellent lawyer, and a lot of people think he is a victim. People don't look at him here the way they do in Washington. I also think, from his point of view, he's going to want to prove that he is not damaged goods."
Others may disagree. In fact, there is no clear picture of life after a public tumble; the future is often determined by what caused the fall, like simple poor performance and a political tin ear, as in the case of Mr. Pitt, or more serious mistakes, as in the cases of disgraced politicians and executives who faced criminal charges. A person's network of contacts is also a factor, not to mention sheer likability.
Even professional headhunters have a hard time divining that line.
"Life diminishes when you go to Washington and you stumble," said E. Pendleton James, a senior adviser at Whitehead Mann, an executive recruitment firm, and a former head of personnel in the Reagan White House. "There is a diminution in the value of your acumen to corporate America. But, having said that, it depends on how one falls or fails."
In dozens and dozens of cases, Americans have been a forgiving lot. The half-life of a scandal can be short, redemption can be swift and the main lingering effect of a public downfall is often the celebrity it brings.
"Washington has a long and honored history of forgiving and forgetting when it comes to getting knocked around in public positions," said Kenneth A. Gross, a partner in the Washington office of Skadden Arps Meagher Slate & Flom, who has represented many prominent politicians. "Short of being actually convicted, after a period of time in which there is some delicacy on the issue, all that people remember is that you are famous. Then they want you at all the A-list cocktail parties."
That may shock some people, who believe that malfeasance or mistakes in public service should not be overlooked so easily, let alone rewarded. They bemoan the cavalier way in which people are often welcomed back with open arms and minimal consequences.
Of course, Mr. Pitt, or anyone else in his position, is unlikely to receive an invitation to rejoin an administration. Washington is too much the fishbowl for that. 
"The vetting process for top government jobs is getting extremely complicated," said James J. Albertine, president of the American League of Lobbyists. "You are talking about basically standing naked in front of the world and having every blemish you ever dealt with shown to the world. And that increases the higher the job is. It's becoming a real issue because no one is perfect and even if they are a perfect person, they often get killed by the scrutiny anyway."
But the private sector often shrugs off Washington's scandals and bungling.
The Clinton scandals caught two prominent Wall Streeters, who incurred only minor bruises. One was Roger C. Altman, who was forced to resign as deputy Treasury secretary in 1994 amid a cloud of criticism over his inaccurate testimony in Congressional hearings about the Whitewater scandal. After leaving Washington, Mr. Altman founded Evercore Partners, a boutique investment bank that had no trouble lining up clients like CBS, Dow Jones, NBC and AOL Time Warner. And though Mr. Altman cited the news media as a cause of his problems, Evercore later bought American Media Inc., publisher of The National Enquirer, the splashy tabloid. 
Mr. Altman declined to be interviewed.
The other big Wall Streeter was Bernard W. Nussbaum, a veteran corporate lawyer, who resigned as the Clinton White House counsel after questions were raised about his role in Whitewater. He was later cleared of any wrongdoing.
"Life hereafter is fine," said Mr. Nussbaum, who returned to his desk as a partner at Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz. By the accounts of many who know Mr. Nussbaum, his business has only grown since leaving Washington. Mr. Nussbaum, too, agrees that memories are short when it comes to Washington headlines.
"People get driven out over public relations things," he said. "Things are twisted to make them seem egregious when it is really nothing. That is why other areas around the country are not like Washington. People in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco are sophisticated" and quickly forget, he added. 
OBVIOUSLY, executives flame out within the corporate world, as well, sometimes almost as publicly. The last year has produced a bumper crop of chief executives who have been charged with running afoul of the law. And hardly anyone expects the likes of Samuel D. Waksal, the former chief executive of ImClone Systems, L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief of Tyco International, or Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron -- all indicted -- to find jobs in public companies anytime soon, if ever. 
Albert J. Dunlap, the former chief of Sunbeam who was despised by many and nicknamed Chainsaw Al for his slash-and-burn treatment of employees, is probably equally unemployable.
Still, corporate America has often been forgiving of its own. Several executives who have left in disgrace, even after civil charges, have been rehabilitated. After a time in purgatory, when they set themselves up as consultants or investors, people like John H. Gutfreund, the former chairman of Salomon Brothers who was forced out after failing to inform the authorities about illegal bidding at the firm, and Lawrence Kudlow, who had worked as chief economist at Bear, Stearns and in economic posts in Washington before his troubles with illegal drugs were revealed, have rebounded. Mr. Gutfreund now works as senior managing partner at C. E. Unterberg, Towbin, while Mr. Kudlow is co-host of "Kudlow & Cramer" on CNBC.
Who knows what will happen to Martha Stewart over the long haul? It's unclear whether her legal problems will force her out or taint her brand. 
Though incompetence or disagreement with management have also caused the public fall of many top executives, oddly their fate is less predictable. Jacques A. Nasser, forced out of the top post at Ford Motor in October 2001, by the Ford family, has yet to land a new job. Nor has Jill E. Barad, who was drummed out of Mattel's top job, nor Robert W. Pittman of AOL Time Warner.
In fact, some of these executives may be treated more harshly by their brethen than those who have tripped up in the capital. "There is more understanding for someone who has stumbled in Washington than for someone who has taken a company and driven it downhill," said Gerard R. Roche, senior chairman at Heidrick & Struggles, an executive search firm. 
UNLIKE Mr. Pitt and other public servants, most of these ousted executives can find comfort in their overstuffed golden handshakes, which can run into the tens of millions; they don't need to work. But Washington awards a trump card -- lasting access to power. Many corporations are willing to overlook an ethical lapse or a subpar performance and put those with Washington expertise on their boards, to use them as lobbyists or to make them partners in business deals.
Consider Robert L. Livingston, a Louisiana Republican who was on the verge of becoming the House speaker but who resigned from Congress in 1998 after confessing to adultery. Today, he is one of Washington's most sought-after lobbyists, heading the Livingston Group, which took in $3 million in 2000, the most recent data available, with a client roster that has included General Electric, Lockheed Martin, Raytheon, Oracle and 44 others.
"I was almost speaker of the House and I could have been if I had chosen to stay," Mr. Livingston said. "I was in demand then, and I've been in demand ever since I've left."
The same is true for Bob Packwood, a Republican from Oregon who resigned in disgrace in 1995 after an ethics committee unanimously found he had forced himself on nearly two dozen women in his office, including a 17-year old intern. Mr. Packwood reported lobbying income of $1.4 million in 2000 and his client list includes Northwest Airlines, United Airlines and Verizon Communications.
"It takes a while," Mr. Packwood said. Reflecting on the process, he added: "In the real world, they're not going to touch you if you go about moaning and complaining. But if you just go about your life, the real world is pretty forgiving."
So forgiving, in fact, that former Representative Dan Rostenkowski, a Chicago Democrat who served time in prison for misuse of public funds (he was later pardoned by President Clinton), was even appointed to a corporate board. His opinions on tax issues -- drawn from his long tenure as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee -- appear on the op-ed pages of major newspapers, including The Wall Street Journal.
Last year, when Mr. Rostenkowski was named to the board of American Ecology, a radioactive- and hazardous waste services company, where he served until last April. In announcing Mr. Rostenkowski's selection, the company made it clear that it was looking to capitalize on his connections in the capital.
"We look forward to Mr. Rostenkowski's contributions based on his 36 years of outstanding Congressional service," said Jack K. Lemley, the company's chief executive at the time. "His knowledge and expertise is particularly valuable to American Ecology's efforts to further penetrate the expanding federal government services market." 
Henry G. Cisneros, a former Clinton cabinet secretary, pleaded guilty in 1999 to lying to the Federal Bureau of Investigation about payments to a former mistress, but he has decidedly recovered from charges that could have resulted in a 90-year prison term. 
First, Mr. Cisneros became president and chief operating officer at Univision, the nation's largest Spanish-language television broadcaster. In August, he formed a partnership with the Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation, one of the largest homebuilders in the United States, to develop low-cost housing in San Antonio.
Many other examples date from earlier years.
Tony Coelho, who resigned from Congress in 1989 over a controversial junk-bond investment, has made millions as a businessman and even returned to politics when Al Gore hired him to be his campaign chairman before the 2000 election. After resurrecting himself with a brief stint on Wall Street, Mr. Coelho has held positions on 11 corporate boards, the most prominent being Kistler Aerospace.
Michael K. Deaver, who was chief of staff in the Reagan White House, is now one of Washington's most powerful public relations executives; he heads the Washington office of Edelman Public Relations. His conviction on felony perjury charges in 1987 for lying to Congress and to a federal grand jury, and a suspended prison sentence, matter not at all.
Michael P. Castine, who also worked in the Reagan inner circle and is now a managing partner in TMP Worldwide, an executive recruiting firm, recalls the day he brought an old friend -- one caught up in a Washington scandal -- to the Senate dining room. "Six or seven senators of both parties came up to him," Mr. Castine recalled. "Rather than avoiding him, they embraced him." The man simply had too much influence and too many connections to ignore. 
Of course, someone who is tainted, yet has successfully regained footing as a lobbyist or by starting a business, hasn't necessarily gained full redemption. Cracking A-list corporate boards is a taller order, and is likely to be even more so now that the spate of corporate scandals has made all boards more sensitive to public opinion.
"With the enormous scrutiny taking place, corporations only want people who are squeaky clean on their board," said Mr. Roche, the executive recruiter. "It used to be that boards could wink at some of these folks. Not any more. And if you want to put someone on the audit committee, they've got to be up for sainthood. We do work for the AT&T's and the Alcoas of the world. They are not looking for the Bob Packwoods."
Some people applaud the trend. Charles Lewis, executive director of the Center for Public Integrity, bemoans America's forgetfulness about transgressions by public officials. "They have a public trust, and if they violate it, they should be on the hook," he said. "It's a privilege and a magnificent opportunity to serve the public in these important positions. If they can't cut the mustard, then goodbye."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Party of the Rich; 
China's Congress of Crony Capitalists

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: BEIJING 

 BODY:
AFTER a 20-year transition, the world's last major left-wing dictatorship, the Communist Party of China, has transformed itself. It is now, arguably, the world's last major right-wing dictatorship.
 With the convening of the 16th Congress in its 81-year history, the party is rewriting its constitution to declare that it represents "advanced forces" -- capitalists -- as much as workers and peasants. Rich people have begun joining the party. A few may be invited to join its policy-making Central Committee. 
 This is China's baldest acknowledgment since veering from orthodox socialism in the late 1970's that it will make workers and peasants fend for themselves. Dictatorship of the proletariat has failed. So the party is giving plutocracy a chance.
Jiang Zemin, the Communist Party chief who plans to retire after the Congress adjourns, has buried the last real pretenses of socialism. "All legitimate income, from work or not, should be protected," he told the party Congress on Friday. 
The old China defended the working class against the capital class. In the new China, Mr. Jiang said, "the fundamental interests of the people of the whole country are identical."
This new strategy marks a calculated gamble to "keep up with the times," as Mr. Jiang said repeatedly, by mimicking capitalist-oriented authoritarian regimes, like the old South Korea, Taiwan and Chile. The fact that those countries have long since become democracies does not disturb party officials. They argue that the transition took 30 years in South Korea and Taiwan. China has just begun.
IT could work -- at least for a time. China's output is on track to grow 8 percent this year, faster than any other big economy, and private business has become the leading force for growth. In fact, the state-run companies that once dominated here now make up, by many calculations, only a third of economic output.
Foreigners have invested more money in China so far this year than anywhere else, including the United States. All that money is flowing because the party has used its near-absolute power to create favorable conditions for capitalists. 
Companies setting up factories in Guangdong or Shanghai can employ workers from the hinterlands, often paying them less than $100 a month for 12-hour days. Migrant laborers can stay in cities only so long as their employers need them; without urban residence permits, they have no local rights. The government does not allow independent unions. There is no collective bargaining.
Corporate tax rates are low. Rich people have only begun to pay income tax. Much of what the government does collect in taxes it uses to build roads, high-speed trains, telecommunications networks and air and shipping ports -- tens of billions of dollars spent each year to support the infrastructure of commerce. It has also indulged in vanity projects, like a new $600 million headquarters for China Central Television and the grandiose Shanghai and Beijing opera houses, all designed by well-known Western architects.
Among wealthy nations, the United States is considered stingy when it comes to social benefits and health care spending. But by percentage of its economy, China makes the United States look profligate. In other words, it does not make rich people share their wealth. The gap between rich and poor has grown almost as fast as overall income, meaning that inequality is increasing nearly in lock step with the country's development.
Such statistics alarm some old-school party members and outspoken intellectuals. Bao Tong, a former top-level government official who lost his post after the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989, wrote a scathing letter criticizing Mr. Jiang's plans to embrace capitalists. "It implies that it is now time for the party to admit the unspoken truth and formally declare that it has become China's party for the rich and the powerful," he wrote.
Other critics say that opening the party to businessmen will delay a needed political reckoning. "The economic elite love money, not democracy," wrote Kang Xiaoguang of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. Such views could be widespread, but it is hard to tell, since Mr. Jiang has closed the main leftist academic journals where criticism of his policies was being expressed, including the one that published Mr. Kang's essay.
Mr. Jiang would not agree that his party has abandoned the poor. China, he argues, is still in the "primary stage of socialism." Later on, contradictions between the working and capitalist classes may become acute and the poor will vanquish the rich. But not in the primary stage, which could last 100 years. Capitalism has to blossom before it can be uprooted. It might be called trickle-down Marxism.
The risk of such thinking, some critics say, is that China may aim to recreate the dictatorships of South Korea and Taiwan and miss, becoming Marcos's Philippines or Suharto's Indonesia instead. Those two countries also tried to combine capitalist economies with strongman rule, but were felled by economic stagnation and corruption.
To avoid such a calamity, China should do less for the elite and more to create a populous middle class, said Cui Zhiyuan, an associate professor of political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who is currently a visiting scholar at the National University of Singapore. 
Professer Cui said the test will be whether China's new leadership, led by the largely unknown Hu Jintao, a longtime party apparatchik, spreads the country's emerging wealth. It needs to spend more on rural health care, to subsidize the poor western regions, to retrain workers fired by failing state companies and to improve education.
He cites one statistic to support his case: to encourage exports of manufactured goods, China now gives up more money each year in export tax credits than it spends on all social welfare programs combined.
"You over-privilege one sector like that at the expense of all the others," Professor Cui said. "Unless China can create a real middle class, it will be just another capitalist dictatorship."
He may be right, but China's Communist Party seems unable to escape the paradox of its continued existence. It has entered the 53rd year of uninterrupted rule, and has 66 million members. But in the party's careerist tradition, many new members are successful capitalists who joined -- became Communists -- to help themselves make more money.
Communism, then, has become crony capitalism. The party is betting that this shift will help it create enough jobs to employ the millions of urban unemployed, as well as millions more among China's vast, impoverished rural population, many of whom are seeking better lives by moving to the cities and industrial zones. 
If this plan works, power will remain entirely with the Communist Party. It's a vision of China's future than appears to include everything but democracy.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Big Plans, No Cash; 
The Education Election

BYLINE:  By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
WHILE political analysts saw the elections as a show of support for the Bush administration, there was another clear message in the balloting: voters still care about education. 
 In state after state, while other ballot initiatives failed, voters showed strong support for smaller classes, afterschool programs, college scholarships, school construction and universal preschool, even when the price tag was daunting and there was no clear source for the money. 
 "No question, voters are high on education," said Julie Bell, education program director at the National Conference of State Legislatures. "The programs that passed, like class-size reduction and preschool in Florida and afterschool in California, they're big-ticket items, but they're also intuitively appealing. Parents say: 'Yeah, smaller classes make sense. Yeah, preschool makes sense. Yeah, I like the concept of merit scholarships.' " 
In flush years, state legislators eagerly expanded such programs, she said, but as the economy faltered, they pulled back to protect the basic education budget. 
"Voters considering an appealing program don't have to be as cautious, because they don't decide where the money will come from, and what else will have to be cut," Ms. Bell said. "It's going to be fascinating to watch. I have no idea where the legislatures are going to find the money." 
The most striking example of education's voter appeal was probably Florida, where Gov. Jeb Bush won a handy victory -- but so did Amendment 9, the class-size reduction referendum he campaigned against. 
All fall, Governor Bush argued that the amendment, the most restrictive in the nation, would cost $27 billion over eight years, so much it would force tax increases and "blot out the sun." In October, he was even recorded, unawares, saying he had "devious plans" to block the plan if it passed. 
Post election, he has offered no specifics on where he will find the money to limit classes to 18 students from kindergarten to third grade, 22 from fourth through eighth grade and 25 in high school, not to mention paying to make free preschool available to every 4-year-old in the state, as another successful initiative requires. 
Florida ranks near the bottom among states in per-capita education spending, graduation rates and SAT scores, and increasingly, as Florida's school-age population has exploded, parents have found their children in huge classes, sometimes meeting in gym bleachers, auditorium balconies, teacher's lounges or the portable classrooms sprouting next to school buildings. 
Considerable research shows that students do better in small classes. For many parents, it is simply an article of faith that when teachers can give more time to each student, greater academic achievement will follow. 
But there are real concerns about how the class-size amendment will play out. Finding $27 billion -- if it does end up costing that much -- is no easy task in a state whose annual budget is only about twice that. Then, too, there are concerns that requiring so much spending on class-size reduction will block raises for teachers, making it harder to attract good candidates -- and whether hiring thousands of new teachers to fill thousands of new classrooms will flood the schools with unqualified teachers. 
"They've really put themselves up against a wall," said Michael Griffith, policy analyst at the Education Commission of the States. "Usually, when this kind of initiative is passed, they create some funding source, like a lottery. But Florida's isn't tied to any funding mechanism, and they didn't ensure that the state had to keep up its same spending on education, so they'll probably have to shift old education money over to class-size reduction." 
A larger question, nationwide, is just how big the education slice of the state-budget pie should become, at a time when, Mr. Griffith said, education is already the largest piece. 
Right now, it seems, education reigns supreme. In Michigan, for example, voters rejected a measure that would have taken revenues from the state's tobacco settlement away from its merit scholarships, and given them to health care.
TENNESSEE, meanwhile, lifted its ban on gambling, opening the way for a lottery whose proceeds would likely go toward financial aid to college students. 
California voters, too, were generous to education. Even though the state has a $24 billion budget deficit, voters approved the largest bond issue in state history -- $13 billion for school construction -- and passed Proposition 49, the Arnold Schwarzenegger-sponsored measure for tutoring and afterschool programs. 
"It's all well-intended, and we know all these programs can work, but if you don't have enough money, you're going to have to cut something else that's really vital," said Mr. Griffith. "Do you want larger classes and no band or sports, so you can pay for after-school activities? I didn't hear those questions raised during the campaign, but they should have been."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In a time of reduced budgets, a Miami high school holds classes in a gym. (David Friedman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: China's Chameleon Communists 

 BODY:
Behind the scripted spectacle of their weeklong party congress, China's Communists are trying to do something remarkable. They are seeking to anoint leaders and select a message that will maintain a Leninist monopoly on power in a China that long ago abandoned the last vestiges of Communist economics and ideology. Americans, like most Chinese, can watch these events only passively from the outside. But people everywhere have a stake in how smooth a transition this emerging power can make to the post-Communist era. 
 The congress will make a visible effort to attract the loyalty of a rising entrepreneurial class. New membership rules permit billionaire businessmen to become card-carrying Communists. Some of these will now be elevated to party offices. The congress will also sanctify the "three represents" formula associated with its outgoing leader, Jiang Zemin. The doctrine stands Marxism on its head by proclaiming the Communist Party's duty to represent not only workers and peasants but also the capitalist class. Delegates will also choose the new Central Committee, which will formally designate the next generation of party leaders. 
 Whether this congress prepares a successful leap to the future will not be known right away. One requirement, surely, is a clean generational succession in which old leaders, for the first time in China's modern history, voluntarily yield power. That prospect has now been clouded by Mr. Jiang's last-minute maneuvering to retain the kind of behind-the-scenes clout Deng Xiaoping wielded long after his official retirement. Unclear lines of authority and a new leadership weakened at the start are not what China needs. What it does need is a decisive attack on rampant corruption. Graft has eroded the party's moral authority and sparked violent discontent among those who feel bypassed by China's recent economic growth.
Ultimately, there can be no smooth transition without a loosening of the party's repressive political grip. Democracy, the natural complement to China's emerging market economy, is disturbingly absent from Beijing's current agenda. The defeat of party reformers before the Tiananmen Square crackdown has made political liberalization an unmentionable subject in Chinese leadership circles. That silence makes a mockery of the Jiang doctrine. China's 1.3 billion people cannot remain excluded from discussions of their future.

HEADLINE: Jobless, Not Partying 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 It was extremely distressing to read "Partying Like It's 1999" (Oct. 20) and learning that many financial-sector unemployed, with considerable assets, also receive $405 a week unemployment benefits, which they consider "pocket money," and spend their time partying and on worldwide vacations. 
 A vast majority of unemployed New Yorkers no longer receive any benefits and struggle daily just to survive as the much-needed 13-week extension of benefits remains stalled in Congress. 
I unfortunately speak from experience. I have spent 25 years in New York City tourism, a sector severely impacted by 9/11. I did receive disaster assistance for the self-employed, for which I am grateful, but payments ceased in June. Without the kindness of neighbors, friends and local merchants I don't know how I would have survived to date and haven't a clue how to survive until next spring without the urgently needed extension.

CONSTANCE CURTIS
New York
