HEADLINE: San Jose Journal; 
Rooting for Rain And for Relief From Feral Pigs

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 9 

 BODY:
It has been raining cats and dogs here for two days, and people here are glad. Maybe this means it will finally stop raining pigs.
 "The hope is that the pigs will head back to the hills," said Lindsey Wolf, who lives in California Maison, a condominium development at the south end of town. "Now that we have rain, people are waiting it out and hoping for the best." 
 For the last few months, the condominiums and nearby neighborhoods have been under siege by marauding wild pigs. Hungry and thirsty pigs that walk miles for a meal. Huge pigs that outweigh many of the people who live here. Abundant bands of pigs that enjoy nothing more than gouging the succulent lawns and, when stuffed, making more pigs.
"The grass is torn up 100 feet from my front door," Ms. Wolf said. "There is a big gravel area to the side, but they are not interested in that at all. They go right for the lawn."
San Jose is not your average pig town. The capital of Silicon Valley, it has an international airport, a convention center and a new downtown development, Santana Row, which opened the other day with a Gucci store and apartments that are reported to rent for as much as $15,000 a month.
Almost everyone who cares about the city's reputation is fed up with pig talk. "It is not something we will answer questions about," said a spokeswoman for Compass Management Group, the property managers for California Maison.
But San Jose is also one of those cities that look and act something like amoebas, taking new shapes and consuming almost everything in their way. The city and its suburbs in Santa Clara County have crept toward the ranches and scruffy slopes to the east, territory that state wildlife officials say was staked out long ago by the pigs.
"The wild pigs are worse this year than in the past, but the problem is common," said Lt. Dave Fox, a warden with the State Department of Fish and Game. "There are subdivisions and homes where there used to be farms and ranches. Santa Clara County happens to be the hot spot. Next year it will be somewhere else."
As these things go in California, the pigs have a long history here. Some of their ancestors were the barnyard variety, arriving with prospectors in the 1840's and 50's. (Though most ended up on a spit, some made a run for it.) Another bloodline can be traced to Russian wild boars, which were introduced for hunting on some big ranches, including those owned by William Randolph Hearst, in the 1920's and 30's.
"There was interbreeding, and now we have these pigs in almost every county in California," Lieutenant Fox said.
A short drive from San Jose, at Joseph D. Grant County Park, the pigs are fixtures in the grasslands and along hiking trails. Ms. Wolf, the condominium resident, says she happened upon two sows with 23 piglets in a hike at the park in the spring. 
"The babies, oh my God, they are cute," she said. "They look like little striped watermelons. The bigger ones, well, you have to like pigs to think they are cute. The first time I saw the male boars, I thought they were heifers. They are so big I thought they were some breed of small cow."
No one can say for sure, but it is believed the incursion of the pigs into San Jose is a result in part of the unusually dry summer and fall. Before this week's storms, the last recorded rainfall in San Jose was on May 21. The dryness apparently bothered oak trees, which dropped fewer acorns, normally an autumn staple for the pigs.
Tom Pederson, an assistant chief of law enforcement for the State Department of Fish and Game, said the pigs were hardy and, when necessary, traveled long distances for a decent meal. Supper usually amounts to grubs and earthworms, but, pigs being pigs, it can extend to include just about anything they find in the dirt.
The pigs generally show up after dark at California Maison. Though usually content to eat and run, they have been known to chase the occasional unsuspecting resident.
Lieutenant Fox says there has been a pig population explosion in the last 10 years as development has crowded out agriculture. In the old days, farmers and ranchers would keep the pigs in check by shooting them. The meat was even donated to soup kitchens. 
Now there is little hunting in Santa Clara County, and the health authorities prohibit serving meat that is not federally inspected.
"Generally, there isn't enough hunting pressure on these pigs in urban areas," Lieutenant Fox said. "Where there is a lot of hunting pressure, we don't have these problems. They have such a reproduction potential that they, more than deer, can get out of hand real quickly."
A miniature pig-trapping industry developed, but with thousands of the animals roaming the hills, no one believes that is a lasting solution. In the past, when trappers attracted public attention, animal welfare advocates rallied to the pigs' defense. (Te captured pigs were ending up in dog food.) The trapping of 4,000 pigs on Santa Cruz Island off Southern California recently began, but only after four years of planning.
So almost everyone in San Jose is counting on the heavens for some pig relief. By late today, the skies had responded nicely with more than an inch of rain, with an equally dismal forecast until Sunday.
"Once there is something to eat somewhere else, hopefully they will go," Ms. Wolf said. "I guess we will find out in a few weeks."

GRAPHIC: Photos: San Jose, Calif., has been invaded by wild pigs like those above on Santa Cruz Island, off Southern California, where 4,000 are being trapped. At California Maison, residents pointed out damage by pigs. (Associated Press); (Peter DaSilva for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Tiny Bird vs. Ski Slopes, With the State in the Middle 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, N.Y., Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Across most of the big-business, big-resort ski industry, from the Tiffany-tinged aeries of Aspen to the sunny slopes of Stowe, the tale of the Bicknell's thrush would likely have a familiar ring to it. Environmentalists and resort owners would stake out the usual positions and say the usual things about bottom lines versus biodiversity, and private gain versus public good. 
 Here at Whiteface Mountain, not far from Lake Placid, the environmental cliches do not work. This ski resort is owned by the people of New York and operated by a state-chartered agency called the Olympic Regional Development Authority. It is one of only a handful of government-owned ski resorts in the nation. The goal is not profit, but economic development, in a remote and snowy corner of the Adirondacks where livelihoods rise and fall on the vagaries of the tourist dollar. 
 And that has put the Bicknell's thrush at the center of some strangely conflicted agendas. One arm of New York State, through the Olympic Authority, contends that the resort must expand significantly over the next few years, offering new trails and amenities -- including a fancy mountaintop restaurant -- if it is to keep from faltering and falling behind its corporate competitors. Another mandate, expressed through state conservation law, requires New York to protect mountaintop bird nesting areas, like the fir forests where the elusive nut-brown thrush returns every spring from its winters in the Caribbean.
"The state knows what it must do," said William Cooke, the director of government relations at Audubon New York. "If this comes down to a choice between improving ski area trails or protecting these birds, I don't see where the state can put in the trails, knowing that it would put birds over the edge."
A spokesman for the Olympic Authority, Sandy Caligiore, said the state also knows it must continue to build up Whiteface and Gore Mountain -- the other ski resort it owns here in the Adirondacks -- or lose market share, and thus the jobs that the State Legislature has ordered it to create.
"To be competitive, we have to put money into snowmaking and grooming and all those things that bring people here," he said.
The Whiteface expansion would require the removal of about 55,000 trees from the summit and slopes of Little Whiteface Mountain, a process that could begin as early as next year, pending approval by the Adirondack Park Agency, which governs development in Adirondack Park. 
Bird experts say that while the Bicknell's thrush is not endangered, its habitat is. In the northeastern United States, they say, acid rain hurts both the trees where the bird nests and the snails it eats. In the islands of the Caribbean, especially places like Haiti, development pressures and poverty have destroyed many of its wintering grounds.
And for the Bicknell's thrush, they say, habitat is everything. Like many migratory species -- and human visitors to the Adirondacks for that matter -- the birds return year after year to the same mountaintop. If the terrain is transformed, the birds might adapt and find nests elsewhere, the experts say, or they might not nest at all. The Olympic Authority's own consultants, on the other hand, say that based on research conducted in Vermont and elsewhere, thinning the trees here would in fact improve thrush habitat. Environmentalists have not expressed serious concerns about other species on Little Whiteface. 
But this is the storied Adirondacks, the ultimate high ground of environmentalism in New York, and that too makes everything different about the battle of the Bicknell's. Protecting the Adirondacks became state business a century ago, with a constitutional amendment that the lands here, with certain exceptions, remain forever wild. 
It is the nagging question of those exceptions -- in the language that governs development at Whiteface, the "appurtenances" required for skiing -- that define the battleground over the Bicknell's thrush.
"Skiing is an anomaly in a protected forest, and that makes every exception important," said Michael G. DiNunzio, the director of research and education at the Adirondack Council, a conservation group. "I'm afraid the Bicknell's thrush could be nickel and dimed to death."
Environmentalists say that fighting a state-owned ski resort can be both harder and easier than battling a private land owner. When a local conservation group called New York Rivers United questioned Whiteface officials recently about water use from the west branch of the Ausable River, for example, the group simply filed a request under the federal Freedom of Information Act. That is not something a private corporation would have to comply with.
Other environmentalists say they fear that the Olympic Authority might be allowed to do things that a private company could not, precisely because of its government status. 
The proposed summit restaurant and lodge, for example, would be visible for miles in many directions. Private developers have mostly been barred from building anything that would spoil the wilderness effect that backpackers and nature lovers come here to seek.
Mr. Cooke at Audubon New York said that he remained optimistic, because New York's bird conservation rules have tended to work well, and because he believes the state will have to follow those rules.
Mr. Caligiore at the Olympic Authority said the question of impact on the Bicknell's thrush would be "revisited."

Boisvert for The New York Times) Map of Lake Placid, New York, highlighting Whiteface Mountain

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
Small Tribe's Cry: Give Us a Casino, or Give Us Your Backyard

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. 

 BODY:
IT would be so much easier if we could just blame the Indians.
 After all, it is the proposal by the Golden Hill Paugussetts for a casino in Bridgeport that is driving Connecticut even crazier about traffic. It is highlighting, again, economic dysfunction in Bridgeport. And class tensions in mostly affluent Fairfield County. And historic mistreatment of Indians. And the curious settlement of old wrongs with new slot machines. And . . . 
 "I find it very difficult to believe that our nation is allowing a separate nation within our county," a Fairfield real estate agent, Joan Neiley, said after a Chamber of Commerce lunch on Wednesday about the casino. "How can that be? Someone is asleep at the wheel."
Surely that's precisely what some Paugussett real estate broker said circa 1640 upon seeing the first Saab arriving from New Amsterdam.
Of all the proposed (or threatened) Indian casinos in New York and Connecticut, perhaps none carries as much history and unfinished business as this one about 50 miles north of New York City.
A historical plaque in City Hall explains the root of the controversy: "The site of Bridgeport was owned by the Pequonnock or Golden Hill band of the Paugussett Indian tribe."
The tribe now claims 350 members, and its only remaining original property is a log house on a quarter-acre lot near a residential development in Trumbull. A sign calls it Connecticut's "oldest continuing reservation." And surely its smallest.
The tribe, led by a former social worker, Chief Quiet Hawk, and backed by a big development company, expects a decision next month on its second try for the federal recognition it needs to open a casino and entertainment emporium. If the tribe is denied a casino, the chief said, it will go to court seeking payment for 750,000 acres that it claims was stolen, which includes many fancy Fairfield County addresses.
Translation: let us try to be rich like you, or we'll try to make you poor like us. "If we're turned down," the chief warns, "the tribe will be very angry."
It's not just Indians who have been rubbed raw. At the Chamber of Commerce lunch at the Patterson Club in Fairfield, 150 people nodded as Jeff Benedict, head of a statewide Alliance Against Casino Expansion, described Connecticut as "under the gun." He made a strong case that casinos offer mostly low-paying jobs and weaken surrounding economies. And adding cars to the chronically clogged Connecticut Turnpike is like force-feeding cheeseburgers to a heart patient.
The Chamber's president, Mark Hawkins, said area businesses could lose employees to the casino. "It's a tight labor market as it is," he said.
No one at the Patterson Club wanted to pit poor Bridgeport against the rest of robust Fairfield County. "They have nothing against Bridgeport," Mr. Hawkins said. "They want it to survive, even thrive."
THOSE warm wishes were hardly solace to the 200 union workers and neighborhood leaders who rallied for the casino the next day in Bridgeport's desolate East End, eager for jobs and gambling revenues that the Indians promise the city.
Bridgeport's unemployment rate is almost twice the state average, and its property tax rate is at least twice that of nearby suburbs. It has a minor league ballpark and an arena, but a long-planned waterfront development has produced little but land clearing. Also, Mayor Joseph P. Ganim is scheduled to be tried on federal corruption charges in January.
Paugussetts aside, many in Bridgeport feel like a forgotten tribe.
Through intermarriage, most Paugussetts are black, and some people have intertwined the fate of the Indians with the treatment of all minorities. The state N.A.A.C.P. recently called them "fellow sufferers of indignity and discrimination."
With at least six tribes looking to operate casinos in Connecticut, most politicians oppose them. That includes Gov. John G. Rowland, even though the ailing state budget relies on slot machine revenues from Connecticut's two casinos. Few here have forgotten that in the mid-1990's, the governor supported gambling in Bridgeport when, among others, casino moguls like Steve Wynn and that one-man Tribe of Trump nosed around the city.
"This is a shift of power," said Charles Tisdale, a long-serving civic leader and adviser to the tribe. "This is an urban tribe. I grew up with the brothers in the ghetto."
So is the tribe to blame for the casino? Hardly, Chief Quiet Hawk said. "I don't like gambling," he said.
But federal law allows it for Indians, he said. And the forgotten tribe that Bridgeport has become needs something big. "If you give me ITT," the chief said, "I'll take that." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: North Korea Told It Must Dismantle Nuclear Arms Project Promptly 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 9 

 BODY:
The United States, Japan and South Korea called on North Korea today to dismantle its nuclear weapons development program in a "prompt and verifiable manner."
 At a meeting here, the three allies also pledged to seek a peaceful resolution of the crisis caused by North Korea's recent admission that it had been secretly developing nuclear weapons, in violation of a number of international agreements. 
 "North Korea can benefit from greater participation as a member of the international community, but that participation rests on North Korea's prompt and verifiable dismantling of its nuclear weapons programs," said a joint statement issued after the meeting.
However, diplomats here said the discussions, which were held at the assistant foreign minister level, had failed to achieve a consensus on whether to punish North Korea for having broken its commitments or how to do it. 
The meeting today comes amid an intense flurry of consultations leading up to a meeting scheduled for Thursday in New York of the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization, or KEDO, an international consortium that has been building two light-water nuclear reactors for North Korea as part of an agreement with the country that obliges it to surrender its nuclear materials.
Among the three allies, the United States has been pushing for the hardest line, with the Bush administration saying it has no interest in talking further with North Korea until it complies with the nuclear weapons agreements it recently acknowledged violating. 
Douglas J. Feith, under secretary of defense for policy, said this week that there was a "fundamental disagreement" between the United States and South Korea over how to deal with the North's nuclear program. In pointed comments to reporters after meeting with Japanese officials here on Friday, Mr. Feith said "there should be a penalty, not a reward" for North Korea's behavior.
Some administration officials are believed to favor the suspension of oil deliveries to North Korea that the United States provides as part of the Agreed Framework, the 1994 commitment by the North not to produce nuclear weapons that led to the start of the power plant construction.
Under the consortium's division of labor, South Korea agreed to provide the nuclear cores for North Korea's new reactors, which are believed to be less prone to weapons proliferation than North Korea's own reactors, which are now under international surveillance. Japan, meanwhile, has committed itself to providing much of the financing.
"It is important to deepen our understanding of each other's positions,"Japan's foreign minister, Yoriko Kawaguchi, said in a statement on Friday. 
But despite routine comments emphasizing their common ground, each of the United States' main allies in the region has displayed serious reluctance to support any hard-line approach to North Korea.
South Korea's departing president, Kim Dae Jung, has staked his legacy on reconciliation with the North and has resisted the American approach by pressing on with a series of economic cooperation agreements with North Korea at a time when Washington is calling for more pressure.
Indeed, South Korea announced new agreements with North Korea on cross-border cooperation today while the meeting in Tokyo was under way. "Inter-Korean relations are on a path toward reconciliation and peace, even though they are affected by 'turns and twists,' " Mr. Kim said.
Japan, for its part, is locked in talks to normalize relations with the North. Although Japan has said North Korea must comply with its nuclear commitments before new economic cooperation begins, security issues have been trumped here by the drama over the fate of five Japanese citizens kidnapped by North Korea in the late 1970's and early 1980's.
The five are now visiting Japan for the first time since then and their every move is recorded by television crews. Japanese diplomats appear more eager to persuade North Korea to allow the children and spouses of the five to join their relatives here, rather than risk a diplomatic rupture by backing harsh penalities related to the nuclear weapons issue. 
North Korea, mindful of the intense Japanese attention to the kidnapping victims, warned Japan on Friday that if it pressed the nuclear issue it would destroy any progress made so far in normalization talks.

An article on Sunday about a call by the United States, Japan and South Korea for North Korea to dismantle its nuclear weapons program misstated a comment by Douglas J. Feith, the United States under secretary of defense for policy, about the views of the United States and South Korea on how to deal with the North's program. He said, "I wouldn't say that there is a fundamental disagreement" between them. He did not say there was a fundamental disagreement.

HEADLINE: COVER STORY; 
A Man of Convictions and Contradictions

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

 BODY:
THE most startling moment in a new two-part documentary about Jimmy Carter comes in a postscript. "I don't have any doubt in my own mind that if I had devoted four more years to the Israeli-Palestinian relationship," Mr. Carter says blandly in an interview shown after the first segment, "we may very well have avoided the conflict and the suffering that has taken place since then."
 That blinkered self-confidence -- arching over his own political disgrace, the rise of Islamic fundamentalism, the assassination of Anwar Sadat and a host of other impediments to peace not resolved by the 1978 Camp David Accords -- is a leitmotif of "Jimmy Carter," the 12th presidential biography produced as part of the "American Experience" series by WGBH in Boston. 
 In the interview, with the Georgia Public Broadcasting Service, Mr. Carter outlines his legacy as a statesman to Gwen Ifill, the host of the PBS program "Washington Week." But in the documentary itself, the team of historians, journalists and former aides who reflect on Mr. Carter's star-crossed presidency are more absorbed by his inner contradictions. Those contradictions help explain how this puzzling leader won lasting esteem and the 2002 Nobel Peace Prize two decades after his defeat in one of the biggest landslides in presidential history.
 President Carter was dealt awful cards by history: the energy crisis, the hostage-taking in Iran, the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. His own character flaws, however, sealed his fate.
 "What makes him complex is that he's got that kind of hubris and arrogance and also this Christian humbleness," Douglas Brinkley, a Carter biographer, says in the documentary. "That's the battle he is constantly finding himself in."
 "Jimmy Carter," written, produced and directed by Adriana Bosch, a producer at WGBH, was completed in September just a few weeks before the Nobel committee in Oslo announced Mr. Carter's prize, but it is nonetheless timely. The filmmakers took a long look at Mr. Carter's post-presidential years, examining his lonely return to Plains, Ga., in early 1981 and his decision to focus his attention on poverty and human rights through the Carter Center at Emory University in Atlanta. His post-presidential deeds include building housing for the poor through the volunteer organization Habitat for Humanity, monitoring election fraud in Panama and campaigning to combat river blindness in Africa.
 Almost two-thirds of all Americans were born before 1976 and have some recollection of the Carter years. Ms. Bosch, a Cuban emigre, has more familiarity than most. In 1984 she was finishing a Ph.D. on Mr. Carter's foreign policy in Nicaragua (she concluded that his noninterventionist policy helped cement the Sandinista regime) when she was hired as a researcher at WGBH. She worked on many biographies -- Ulysses S. Grant, Winston Churchill -- but a proposal to do a piece on Mr. Carter in 1993 was scratched. It seemed too soon.
 "If we had done it then, we would have missed Haiti, North Korea and Iraq, all the things that helped him win the Nobel Prize," Ms. Bosch said. She said the documentary gave her a better appreciation of Mr. Carter than she had when studying his foreign policy in Central America.
 Scenes of Mr. Carter in Cuba last May playing softball with Fidel Castro and calling for an end to the United States embargo, in labored Spanish, demonstrate his convictions and also the willful self-righteousness that has irritated his successors in the Oval Office, Democratic and Republican.
 That willingness to breach former-president etiquette and criticize American policy while traveling abroad was one of many reasons Mr. Carter and Bill Clinton did not get along. It was also one of the factors that led the Norwegian judges to select Mr. Carter for this year's prize; the jury chairman told reporters that Mr. Carter's prize was meant as a rebuke to President Bush and his policy in Iraq, insulting both Mr. Bush and Mr. Carter. (In the first part of the interview, Mr. Carter disregards the slight, repeating what he said at the time of the controversy: other judges had disagreed with the chairman.)
 Mr. Carter's image as a decent but vacillating leader out of his depth in the White House is undermined by biographical material that reveals the confidence, stubborn certainty and relentless ambition that got him to Washington. It spans his determination to attend the Naval Academy in Annapolis and his tenure as governor of Georgia, where he rode roughshod over the State Legislature. His victory in 1976, however, is repeatedly described as a "miracle."
 Ms. Bosch and her team dug up lots of old films, from scratchy home movies of the Carters as a young Navy couple to Sadat in a white leisure suit preparing to storm out of Camp David. Television images of bygone periods can evoke nostalgia. But even at a distance of a quarter century, there is not much in that era to get misty over.
 There was the post-Watergate euphoria of watching Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter wave off their inaugural limousine to walk hand in hand down Pennsylvania Avenue. Within a year, economic recession, the Burt Lance banking scandal and a scattered agenda had eroded public confidence in Mr. Carter, the Bible-carrying peanut farmer who had promised a government as "compassionate as the American people."
 In the documentary, Hendrik Hertzberg, a New Yorker writer who served as Mr. Carter's White House speech writer, puts it rather ruefully: "Jimmy Carter was exactly what the American people always say they want."
 The so-called "malaise speech" in 1979, at the height of the energy crisis, in which a preachy Mr. Carter appeared to blame Americans for their woes, is almost as painful to watch now as it was then.
 "You cannot be but awed by his determination and his will," Ms. Bosch said. "Getting from that hole in the wall that is Plains to the White House was a great accomplishment. But to go from a failed presidency to the Nobel Peace Prize was an even greater one. Believe me, he was nobody when he got back to Plains."

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 11-10-02: ECONOMICS OF OIL; 
Where the Oil Is

BYLINE:  By Noam Scheiber

 BODY:
There have been few more encouraging developments in the war on terror than a statement Vladimir Putin made in Germany about six weeks ago. "In case of regional conflicts breaking out, Russia is prepared to supply more oil," the Russian president announced. "And I say this loud and clear."
 Today the United States imports roughly half the oil it uses, and one quarter of its total imports comes from the Persian Gulf. It goes without saying that easing our dependency on Middle Eastern oil producers could greatly simplify our foreign policy. The question is whether it's possible. 
 At first glance the signs are encouraging. Russia now produces seven million barrels of oil per day, second in the world only to Saudi Arabia. The Caspian republics to its south -- mainly Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan -- already produce two million barrels per day and have at various points been hailed as the "next Persian Gulf." Together the three former Soviet states could be producing 13 million barrels per day by 2010. Elsewhere, capacity in Latin America is expected to grow by three million barrels per day over the next decade -- as much as the United States currently imports from any one country. And technological advances are making it cost-effective to extract oil off the coast of West Africa and the Gulf Coast of the United States and to refine oil in Canada and Venezuela that was until recently unusable. West African production alone could rise by from 4.3 million to 6.8 million barrels per day over the next 10 years.
But the optimism quickly fades upon closer examination. For starters, much of the newly extracted oil will simply replace declining output from existing fields. Norway is now the second-largest non-OPEC exporter of oil in the world, but earlier this year its oil ministry announced that the country's oil production had begun to decline, a drop-off that will reach 5 percent by 2005. Oil production in the United Kingdom, which currently outstrips that of Iraq, hit its peak three years ago. Production in Mexico, the fourth-largest supplier of oil to the United States (behind Canada, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela), is poised to peak in the next five years. Many analysts predict that overall non-OPEC production will begin to decline some time this decade, even after all the new supply is brought online. 
And even the sources of rising production aren't without problems. Much of Russia's vast reserves lie in Siberia, where the country's primitive pipeline infrastructure makes shipping a nightmare. Russia is currently able to export less than half the oil it produces. But that still puts it years ahead of its Caspian neighbors -- whose reserves most analysts concede have been massively overhyped anyway. In Nigeria -- which today accounts for 8 percent of oil imports to the United States and has the proven reserves to produce one-third more oil by 2007 -- more than 20 raids by militants depressed oil production by 5 percent in 2000. And Colombia, once a top exporter to the United States, until very recently suffered such frequent guerrilla attacks on its 500-mile oil pipeline -- five bombings a day at the peak -- that it had to petition the United States for $100 million in "counterinsurgency" aid to keep a major oil company from fleeing.
True, advances in drilling technology have made it financially feasible to extract oil from ocean depths of 5,000 to 10,000 feet, opening up fields off the coast of West Africa and Florida that would be more safely insulated from sabotage. But extracting oil from deep in the ocean is still much more expensive than extracting it from the ground. Most estimates suggest Saudi oil could be profitably sold for between $2 and $5 per barrel. By contrast, according to Steve Andrews, an independent energy analyst, deepwater oil must fetch a price of $14 to $16 per barrel before drilling becomes profitable. Likewise for oil extracted from tar sands in Canada and certain areas in Venezuela; that oil is so heavy and viscous that the refining costs were once prohibitive. 
And yet the biggest obstacle to freeing ourselves from Middle Eastern oil has nothing to do with politics or chemistry or engineering. It has to do with an iron law of economics. Oil, after all, trades in a globalized market. As such, its price is determined by the interaction of global supply and global demand. And since any large producer can affect the oil supply, any large producer can affect oil prices. Which is to say, as long as the Persian Gulf states' 600 billion-plus barrels of proven reserves (262 billion in Saudi Arabia alone) give them control over the vast majority of the world's discovered oil -- and few now believe there are any major oil "provinces" still waiting to be found -- no amount of help from Vladimir Putin will solve our problem.

HEADLINE: The Doctor Is Involved 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA 

 BODY:
DR. ANTHONY MAZZARELLI is not your usual customer at Sandy's, a cramped, kitschy place the size of a small railway car that serves breakfast at all hours on the western fringe of residential Center City Philadelphia.
 "I come here every morning, just because," Dr. Mazzarelli said, wedged into one of Sandy's back booths. "Many times, there is a 50-year-old guy and an 80-year-old guy and we just trade stories. This is the kind of place where you find out what people really think." 
 It is surprising that Dr. Mazzarelli has even the barest moment to eat breakfast, let alone chat with his elders. At 27, he has the kind of packed resume that might make even the most manic workaholic breathless just reading it. It ought to be enough that he is in the last year of a six-year program at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in Camden and the University of Pennsylvania that is allowing him to get law and medical degrees together. At the same time, he is also getting a master's degree in bioethics at Penn. 
Oh, yes, and then there is his internship with Michael Smerconish, a Philadelphia radio talk-show host, and the summer associate's job that Dr. Mazzarelli recently finished with the prestigious Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter. And the class on medical ethics at Drexel University that he began teaching after the original instructor bowed out. And, in his spare hours, his habit of sending production notes and story ideas to the producers of the NBC-TV drama "E.R.," where he served as a medical adviser in the summer of 2001.
But all that is secondary to the focus of his nascent career.
"My passion is Camden," he said. "Of the cities in the United States, it is arguably the poorest. I've had the privilege of going to medical school there and learning from my patients about their lives. It is important to help revive the city."
Dr. Mazzarelli is going back to Camden next year, after finishing his degrees, for a residency in emergency medicine at Cooper Hospital. Until then he will be visiting the city often to check up on the clinic he started as a medical student in 2000, the Healthcare Outreach Project, a student-run clinic designed to give primary medical care at no cost to those without insurance. 
The clinic is the spur that gained Dr. Mazzarelli his latest honor, being named by the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce as one of its 10 Outstanding Young Americans for 2002. In the past, this award -- given to "the best, brightest, and most inspirational leaders America has to offer" -- has gone to folks like Bill Clinton, John F. Kennedy, Arthur Ashe, Bill Bradley and Christopher Reeve.
Dr. Mazzarelli's mentors believe he belongs in that company.
"If we want the ideal physician, the physician leader, the commitment to community and commitment to patients, Anthony is that model," said Dr. Paul R. Mehne, the associate dean at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School. "He is the renaissance medical student. Everything he does is a learning experience. He gets everyone around him excited about whatever he does."
Dr. Mazzarelli shrugged off a suggestion that his crammed schedule was unusual.
"My work is all connected," he said. "It's not as if I am doing carpentry. Everyone in modern society is busy."
But he does acknowledge being proud of the Healthcare Outreach Project.
"We saw a need, as did everyone, and thought we, as medical students, could address it," he said. "Many people said, 'Oh, you'll never be able to set that up.' But we just didn't take that seriously."
The clinic is open four hours a week to patients who drop in. In addition, Dr. Mazzarelli and his fellow students persuaded specialists on staff at Robert Wood Johnson to donate time for some follow-up care. The medications come from a grant from Pfizer, the big drug company, and the Association of American Medical Colleges. Dr. Mazzarelli said that this year, every second- and third-year medical student at Robert Wood Johnson is giving two weeks of time to the project.
"I am now merely an adviser, making sure those people who gave us promises in the beginning will keep up with them," he said. "It is the foundation of what good medical care should be."
Dr. Mazzarelli grew up about 10 miles north of Camden, in the middle-class suburb of Cinnaminson. Both his grandfather and his father were chiropractors, and he was fascinated by medicine from a young age. He was a soccer and track star in high school and went to Washington and Lee University in Virginia, where he was captain of both the soccer and track teams while still making Phi Beta Kappa and graduating summa cum laude in biology.
He is clearly not the shy type. And he revels in his multimedia life. He got the e-mail address of an "E.R." producer and persuaded the fellow to let him come to the set as an unpaid intern in the summer of 2001.
"It may be good or bad, but more people get their information about medicine from places like 'E.R.' than anywhere else," Dr. Mazzarelli said. "I wanted to make sure it was presented correctly."
Though "E.R." forbids him to disclose exactly what he has told the producers about specifics on the set, he said that, in general, he suggests nuances about medicine to make sure the shows do not look foolish. He has appeared in the background of a couple of scenes. The producers said he even inspired a minor character last season: a woman, majoring in both law and medicine, who ended up as a patient in the emergency room.
"Anthony is really interested in medical ethics, and that includes communicating to the public," said Dr. David Magnus, the graduate studies director at Penn's Center for Bioethics, where Dr. Mazzarelli is getting his master's degree. "We have to reach out on many issues and be on TV and in the newspapers to make people aware of ethical problems. He is really savvy about that."
Mr. Smerconish has given Dr. Mazzarelli a lot of leeway in researching topics for his radio talk show on WCAU-AM, occasionally putting him on the air as an expert.
"Take the smallpox vaccination issue -- he was the perfect person to talk about it," said Mr. Smerconish, who also sometimes relies on Dr. Mazzarelli's research for commentaries that he does for KYW-AM, the all-news radio station in Philadelphia, and a column he writes for The Philadelphia Daily News.
"His biggest problem after his residency will be figuring out what to do," Mr. Smerconish said. "He could be in law, in medicine or in media or perhaps all three. He's going places, but he's not someone who offends. That is his greatest strength."
Dr. Mehne at Robert Wood Johnson said he was ecstatic that Dr. Mazzarelli was coming back to Camden to do his residency, saying that he could really have gone anywhere. But Dr. Mazzarelli said there was really no choice.
"I would love to be part of the solution of bringing Camden back," said Dr. Mazzarelli, who has been appointed to the Camden Committee for Emergency Preparedness and Public Health. 
"My fiancee and I have talked about buying a place and moving to Camden," he said, knowing that most other successful doctors would not relish living in one of the most impoverished cities in the country. "Otherwise, I'm just like everyone else who only talks a good game."

HEADLINE: The Truck Stops Here 

BYLINE:  By MARC FERRIS 

 BODY:
WHEN Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg halted New York City's plastic and glass recycling last summer, he disrupted routines that had taken years to establish. "It still feels weird throwing away glass jars," said Chris Kelly, a Manhattan resident. "Now I have to think about the garbage again."
 The confusion rippled into the suburbs. "I got a lot of calls," said Mari Anne Gallagher, program administrator at the recycling unit of the Westchester County Department of Environmental Facilities. "Everyone thought all of recycling was halted, especially in the southern part of the county. I still hear it: 'Isn't our recycling suspended?' " 
 No, it is not. 
Westchester has been able to manage its refuse as well as it has in large part because of the way it has handled recycling and reuse. 
So far Westchester has avoided New York City's refuse woes -- because planning and capital expenditures over the last 20 years have provided at least a temporary cushion against the vagaries of the garbage market. The collection, sorting and disposal of municipal solid waste, including household garbage and recyclables, hazardous materials and bulk goods, occur within the county's borders largely under county auspices. New York City, which closed the Fresh Kills Landfill on Staten Island in 2001, is dependent on contractors to truck its refuse out of state, at substantial cost to taxpayers. 
"We've pointed to Westchester as an example of how to conduct a successful recycling program," said Laura Haight, senior environmental associate with the New York Public Interest Research Group in Albany. "New York City has certain collection problems that the county doesn't have regarding high rises, but Westchester's investment in its recycling facility cuts processing costs and it lets them do a better job of marketing their material." 
But Westchester's success doesn't mean the county is worry free when it comes to recycling, or waste removal in general.
The county's disposal space is expected to reach capacity in 2009. Siting another ashfill in the county will be almost impossible -- appropriate sites are scarce in this increasingly populous area and no municipality wants one -- and there is no sign that the average 1,000 pounds of household garbage generated last year by every man, woman and child in the county will abate. That's not counting 71,335 tons of municipally collected recyclables or the 324,219 tons of garbage and recyclables collected by private haulers serving local businesses. 
"This is on our radar screen already," said Robert N. Matarazzo, the deputy commissioner of the county's Department of Environmental Facilities, which spent almost $40 million on solid waste in 2001. "Years go by very quickly in this business." 
But garbage rarely generates controversy in Westchester these days because it disappears at bargain prices, and the topic is cloaked in euphemisms. Better to call the final resting place for the county's nonrecyclable household trash the Sprout Brook Disposal Facility than an ash heap. And there are no dumps, only landfills. 
Solutions to the garbage problem have always reflected the short-term cultural orientation that created the situation in the first place. In the horse and buggy days, municipalities took their garbage to open pits scattered around the county or loaded it onto barges, where it was dumped at sea. After World War II, towns built open-pit incinerators, many of which still tower over local public works garages. Schools and apartment buildings fired their own incinerators, too, but the federal Clean Air Act of 1972, along with protests against the particles discharged through the unfiltered smokestacks, shut them down. From 1924 to 1986, most residential waste ended up in the Croton Point Landfill. In 1995, the county spent $50 million to cap it and monitor the leacheate and methane gas. 
THE county reports a 42 percent recycling rate for municipal waste, and every ton diverted to a recycling plant costs $28 to process instead of the $72 it costs to dispose of a ton of trash. New York City hovered around 20 percent, as do Yonkers, Mount Vernon and Pelham Manor. 
The county's requirement that businesses and residents separate their trash for pickup helps boost the county's overall rate. Private carters recycled at the impressive rate of 47 percent. Most of the material they collect -- trash from office buildings and other businesses -- includes a large proportion of paper and cardboard. In 1982, as the Croton dump -- er, facility -- neared its capacity, Westchester legislators created a Refuse Disposal District to coordinate waste removal and pool costs. Thirty-six municipalities joined; seven villages and towns in the northeastern part of the county chose not to participate. In New Castle, North Castle, North Salem, Pound Ridge, Somers, Lewisboro and Bedford, homeowners contract with licensed private haulers. 
Private haulers have attracted considerable scrutiny by the county. Organized in 1999 and modeled after a similar regulatory agency insituted in New York City, the county's Solid Waste Commission now licenses the industry, which had been dominated by organized crime. So far, competition has returned and rates have dropped, said Mr. Hogan. 
The lack of public sanitation departments has not caused problems, although in Lewisboro, recycling can be a sore spot, said Thomas D. Herzog, town supervisor. Private carters are allowed to collect comingled recyclables and separate the loads at a waste transfer station, where the contents of small trucks are loaded onto bigger ones and taken to the next destination. "I have dutifully separated my garbage into bins and watched, from my window, as the truck pulled up and the guy dumped everything into the back," Mr. Herzog said. "When I asked the carters about it, they said, 'Don't worry, we separate everything at the transfer station.' I don't really believe that." 
Private carters would separate recyclables if it were economically viable, but the only material valuable enough to remove from the trash is corrugated cardboard, said John Mazzucco, the county's sole full-time sanitation code enforcement officer. 
"Things do slip through sometimes, but as a whole the system works," he said. "I'm not looking to make guys spend more money, because that's passed to the waste generator. I want to find a way to make it work for both sides." 
New York State passed its recycling law in 1988, which charged counties with the task of developing a recycling program. County legislators responded by spending $20.8 million for an M.R.F. -- known as the "Murf" -- the Daniel P. Thomas Material Recovery Facility in Yonkers, a monument to the function-over-form school of architecture just south of the toll booths on the New York State Thruway across from Home Depot. 
Illustrating the degree to which source-separated recycling has permeated the culture of garbage collection, Irvington recently bought a spiffy new truck with two compartments: one for paper, the other for glass, metal and plastic, which eliminates the need to make two runs. 
Municipalities dump at the Murf free of charge; private haulers are barred (they go to private murfs and transfer stations around the county run by the waste management companies). There, the material is separated, the paper and aluminum are baled, and trucks take them to middlemen around the region. The plant has the capacity to break its product down even further and cater to specialized markets. 
"One paper mill in New Jersey, within 20 miles from here, wants just newsprint, not the glossy inserts," said James J. Hogan III, director of environmental management at the Department of Environmental Facilities. "Marcal wants inserts, junk mail, colored paper and magazines. If it is economically logical, we are prepared to break our material down even further." 
The facility only processes plastics coded 1 or 2 -- detergent jugs, milk containers and soda bottles. Unmarketable crisp plastic, coded 3 to 7, is removed by hand and placed into the garbage stream. Gray cardboard -- cereal boxes and the like -- gets the same treatment.
"I would prefer not to have that come in at all," said Mr. Hogan. "We don't want to downgrade our material." 
Glass, which usually comes in broken, cost $170,000 to process and ship last year, but is accepted at the Murf to encourage broader compliance with the law, said Mr. Hogan. The county also collects household chemicals, computer equipment and tires several times a year at various locations and disposes of them out of the county. White goods, including washing machines and refrigerators collected on bulk pickup days, are sold to scrap metal dealers. 
Yard waste, which constitutes one-third of the waste stream from April through December, represents recycling's next frontier. Responding to a state directive in 2000, the county stopped sending grass clippings, leaves, branches and brush to the incinerator since it was recyclable as compost. As with other recyclables, it will take time for market forces to catch up with the law. 
"Yard waste doesn't yield the tipping fees that food waste does," said John Crockett of Mother Nature's Farms in Carmel, who is exploring how to expand his composting capacity. Mr. Hogan offered him $17 a ton to accept the county's yard waste; private haulers pay him $45 a ton to dump food waste at his plant. It costs $58 a ton for private haulers to "tip," or drop the the waste, at the Peekskill incinerator. 
Mr. Crockett is also concerned about the use of herbicides used to kill crabgrass and dandelions. The county, he said, is "going to have a problem getting rid of yard waste if I can't prove that the finished product is pesticide-free."
"Organic growers are not going to want it," he said. 
Modifying people's behavior represents another obstacle to the economical disposal of yard waste. "Change is hard, especially in the villages, where people are used to a high level of service," said Mayor Brian Monahan of Dobbs Ferry, which stopped picking up grass clippings last year. The village brings other yard waste to the county transfer station in Yonkers under a program initiated by the county to collect leaves and brush and transport it to commercial composting facilities. 
NONRECYCLABLE household trash collected by municipalities within the Refuse Disposal District goes to the huge incinerator in Peekskill. Its smokestack bears as much resemblance to its forebears as a rotary phone does to a cellphone. It is equipped with pollution control devices to reduce, but not remove, mercury and dioxins. 
The Peekskill plant is known as the Resource Recovery Facility, or Resco. Almost as imposing as its neighbor on the Hudson River waterfront, the Indian Point nuclear plant, the enterprise is now jointly operated by the county and Wheelabrator, a subsidiary of Houston-based Waste Management, which also has a contract to run day-to-day operations at the Murf. At the plant the trash is burned at 2,500 degrees and turned into energy, enough to power 53,000 homes when operating at capacity, which is sold mostly to Con Edison. The plant also generates $6 million annually for the coffers of Peekskill as part of the complicated deal allowing it to be situated within the city. 
Inside, huge piles of garbage are lifted by giant cranes, which load the boilers. The plant can only accept household garbage; barred items include construction and demolition debris, industrial or bio-medical waste, hazardous material or appliances, which can jam up the works and cause a pit fire. Though solid waste facilities are frequent NIMBY targets, the people at Crystal Bay caterers thought nothing of opening their business a stone's throw away from a nine-story garbage incinerator.
"Most people don't give it a second thought," said Joanna Orsini, director of sales and marketing. "The property is maintained well and there have been no unusual odors or anything of that nature." 
Burning garbage begets the problem of residue disposal. Thomas B. Maillet, plant manager, says the ash is non-toxic although others question that assertion.
For the past 18 years, trucks filled with garbage ash have shuttled between the incinerator and the Sprout Brook Disposal Facility at the site of a former quarry in Cortlandt near the Putnam County border. The ashfill is predicted to reach capacity when the contract with Wheelabrator runs out in 2009. Costs to transport the ash out of the county would be passed on to taxpayers and consumers, since private haulers also dump refuse at the plant. 
Separated by a thin line of trees, the Sprout Brook winds north of the ashfill and its water is diverted to create a beach. The mountain of ash, mixed with lime and topped by gravel, rises from the Sprout Brook valley to the height of the surrounding ridges. Rainfall leacheate is collected, tested and sent to the Peekskill Water Treatment Facility, downstream from the disposal site. 
Though technologically advanced, the site remains a stopgap, like the solutions of old. Standing atop the pile, which will eventually contain more than two million tons of material, the site manager Mario A. Parise gazed into the distance at a bulldozer grooming the contents of another 30-ton truck in the fourth quadrant, the project's final phase. The barren surroundings look like a moonscape strewn with bits of charred metal. 
"If we could find a way of reusing half of it, say, it would at least cut down our overall intake and buy some time," Mr. Parise said. "But it's always going to be a problem." 

By Any Other Name
 The refuse collection and processing business has its own argot. Below are some terms used to talk about trash. 
MRF (pronounced "'murf") a material recovery facility better known as a recycling center
Tip fee The cost, per ton, that haulers pay to dump a load of refuse
Yard waste grass clippings, leaves, shrubs, small trees and other organic refuse
White goods A category of refuse that requires special handling. It includes washing machines, refrigerators and other large appliances, whether or not they are white.
Transfer station The spot where small private and municipal trucks empty their contents into bigger loads 
MSW Municipal solid waste, the catchall for recyclables and trash generated by households and businesses
Comingled recyclables two classes of recyclables mixed together, to be sorted at a private or public murf 
OCC old corrugated cardboard
OTD old telephone directories
ONP old newspaper
Waste generator You 


The Next Frontier: Leaves and Grass
TWO years ago, James J. Hogan III, the county's recycling czar, gave municipal managers a new headache when he banned organic yard waste from the Peekskill incinerator.
He pledged to develop a program that would centralize the collection and disposal of 134,708 tons of grass clippings, bushes, hedges, leaves and small trees collected by the municipalities in 2001. Private carters collected 59,790 tons. 
The county arranged with the city of Yonkers to open a transfer station for yard waste last year. The county contracts with Waste Management, a private company, which trucks the material to commercial composting sites outside the county and the tip fee, $11 a ton, is subsidized to encourage participation. The program cost the county $468,433 last year, which was offset by selling the capacity at the Peekskill incinerator that would have been filled with yard waste to private haulers at market rates. 
Of the 37 eligible municipalities, 18 are participating, but Mr. Hogan's plan to make the recycling of yard waste as automatic as the collection of paper, glass and plastic is encountering growing pains. Mr. Hogan prefers to persuade rather than to crack down on lax towns and villages; penalties are light as long as a good faith effort is shown. 
Instituting change into garbage collection routines is like turning a battleship around. The market is just catching up to the influx of organic refuse. Municipalities that dispose of their refuse within their borders can cut costs considerably, but finding appropriate sites is not always easy. In remote areas of the county, many homeowners have enough land to start a compost pile or dump leaves and grass without adverse affect. 
"It's really no problem," said Thomas D. Herzog, supervisor of the town of Lewisboro, which is outside the county's disposal district. Some residents pay a private hauler to remove organic waste. In the part of town that has small plots, the town vacuums up the leaves, which are taken to a composting site in town that is rented from a private landowner. 
In lower Westchester, open property is more scarce. In 1996, Scarsdale responded to resident complaints and closed its composting facility, across from the pool, and created ballfields from the reclaimed land. The village used a private carter to dispose of its refuse until it joined the county's consortium last year. Hastings-on-Hudson closed its composting center along the Old Croton Aqueduct Trail in June and is weighing its options. 
The county helped Eastchester, where a horse stable helps mask the composting odors with manure, become self-reliant. 
"Before it all went into the garbage, but we've reduced the rate of removal to half of the cost of waste," said Pete Bonhag, superintendent of highways.
With the county's support, the town's compost site accepts yard waste from the villages of Tuckahoe and Bronxville; town crews turn the pile regularly, creating rich fertilizer. Residents help themselves. 
The policy has fostered other creative partnerships. The public works departments in Rye and Port Chester share equipment and reduce the cost of removing yard waste. Port Chester borrows Rye's wood chipper and uses the chips for landscaping in public parks and sidewalks. Taking the small trees out of the waste stream lowers the city's disposal cost. In turn, Port Chester collects Rye's green waste at a discount and takes it to Yonkers. Amount saved for each city: about $1,200.
"It's a win-win-win situation," said Joe Carlucci, general foreman at the Rye Department of Public Works. "It saves money, it's good for the environment, and we're creating a useful product."
 MARC FERRIS

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ABROAD; 
Great White Way? Try Great White North

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
There is no place like New York City -- except maybe Canada. 
Last week, "Rudy!," an unauthorized biographical movie about the city's previous mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, began shooting on the mean streets of Montreal.
 Eh? 
 "I guess they are going to show him watching baseball games at the Skydome or eating pommes frites, rather than eating at Patsy's," Representative Anthony Weiner, a Democrat who represents portions of Brooklyn and Queens, said Wednesday. He was speaking at a rally on the steps of City Hall, where members of the Screen Actors Guild and other film industry unions joined him to call for new federal tax credits to encourage American filmmakers to make their movies at home. 
"Everybody is going to be talking with that weird accent," he added.
"Rudy!," which is scheduled to be shown on USA Network early next year, is based on Wayne Barrett's unauthorized biography of Mr. Giuliani. The movie begins with 9/11, then goes into a series of flashbacks about Mr. Giuliani's private life, trysts and all, and his rise to political power. James Woods stars as the mayor and Penelope Ann Miller plays Donna Hanover, his wife.
"It is unheard of that anything about Rudy Giuliani should be done in Canada," said Jim Hovey, the Eastern regional director of Local 600, the cinematographers' guild.
But, according to USA Network, New York will get at least a cameo role in "Rudy!" "We are paying a premium to do that," a network spokeswoman said, "and we do support any efforts that would make production in the U.S. more economically feasible."
A spokeswoman for Mr. Giuliani declined to comment. But a source close to him said, "Shooting this in Montreal will speak to the authenticity."
Authentic or not, Canada is unquestionably, a cheaper place to make movies than New York, and "Rudy!" has struck a new nerve in an old debate.
In 1998, the Canadian government instituted a tax credit, equal to 11 percent of labor costs, to encourage film and video production. Several provinces, including Quebec, offer additional subsidies, which allow United States producers to save 22 percent or more on wages. Throw in a weak Canadian dollar and, voila: money now migrates north like geese in spring.
New York has been hit particularly hard by the change. From 1999 to 2001, feature film spending in the state plummeted to $167 million from $695 million, while spending in Canada rose to $1 billion, up from $413 million. According to some estimates, Canadian subsidies have cost New York nearly 11,000 jobs and $26 million in local tax revenue.
Canadians won't take the blame. 
"Incentives of various forms are used in many jurisdictions, including plenty in the United States," said Peter Lloyd, who heads political and economic relations at the Consulate General of Canada in New York. 
"This company called USA Network should be true to its name and employ people here in the United States of America," Representative Weiner said.
 ERIKA KINETZ

GRAPHIC: Photos: Which City Hall for Rudolph W. Giuliani? Montreal's, at left, or New York's, below. (Above, Andre Pichette for The New York Times; inset, Getty Images); (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hiya, Society 

BYLINE:  By LAURA PEDERSEN; Laura Pedersen's novel, "Beginner's Luck," will be published in paperback in January by Ballantine Books.

 BODY:
JENNY EDRINGTON looked warily at the double entree of pan-seared beef tenderloin and braised short ribs. "For some reason," she said, "people with money never cook their meat." Her husband is a hunter, she said, so she "knows what raw flesh looks like." To be safe, she ate around the edges.
 Ms. Edrington, cheerful in a black gown, was in town from Festus, Mo. (pop. 9,660), to attend a benefit for the Christopher Reeve Paralysis Foundation at the New York Marriott Marquis in Times Square. And she had foreseen food-related problems. "I had a snack right before I came," she said, "because rich people don't eat too much." 
 The new New York is a long coach ride from Edith Wharton's old one. Back then, society members remained ensconced in their private clubs, while barkeeps stayed in their bars, scullery maids in their sculleries, and footmen on their feet. 
More than a century of democratization has changed all that. But in the world of benefits in recent years, the "high" has dropped even farther out of high society. 
"It's only since the early 1990's that everything has loosened up," said Pamela Fiori, editor in chief of Town and Country magazine, one of the last great chronicles of the wealthy. Some old-guard cultural events, like the opening-night gala at the Metropolitan Opera, attract a fairly homogeneous crowd. But most "society" benefits now draw people from all different backgrounds. 
Competition for money has powered this change. The long bull market and cutbacks in government money for the arts, medical research and education have fostered enormous growth in philanthropy, with the number of American charities rising by almost three-quarters in the last decade. But then the stock market leveled out, and although giving hasn't decreased, it has not increased as it did in the 90's.
As a result, more and more fund-raisers are jostling for a fairly constant amount of dollars.
To meet the challenge, organizers of charity benefits are courting a wider pool of potential guests. Many charities have also reduced the required donation from $10,000 and $5,000 a plate to $1,000 and even $500. To offer prospective guests from the less-than-lofty classes more of the tastiest bait -- celebrities -- they are asking board members to call in favors or even pay stars an appearance fee. 
New York is a major site of the new, unbuttoned benefit, simply because it is the fund-raising capital of the country. The New York writer Calvin Trillin, a popular master of ceremonies at such evenings because he is so funny, recalls many occasions when the benefit chairman stood to announce that more than $1 million had been raised. "It's almost a nightly occurrence," he said.
New York's philanthropic prominence has helped it adapt quickly to this new, more competitive landscape. "They're the ultimate realistic city," said Barbara Goldsmith, the social historian. "They're quick and creative when it comes to adjusting to changes in climate and economy."
All of which helps explain why Ms. Edrington, a research coordinator at Washington University in St. Louis, was in the grand ballroom of the Marriott Marquis for the Reeve benefit one weekday night earlier this fall. Her experience, and that of other neophyte benefit attendees, suggest that the traditional society benefit may have clinked its last crystal, or, at least, that exclusivity is not what it used to be.
What was Ms. Edrington's final verdict on her meal, which also included a chocolate truffle cake? Given the skill of the comedian who was the night's featured performer, she decided it was a good thing that she didn't overeat. "I was trying to be elegant in my nice clothing," she said, "but was busting a gut laughing at Robin Williams."
OSCAR WILDE once said that with an evening coat and a white tie, anybody, even a stockbroker, could acquire a reputation for being civilized. But formal dress is not necessary these days, as the Reeve affair showed. Although most of the men wore tuxedos, the women were outfitted in everything from evening gowns to standard-issue cocktail dresses and pantsuits. The crowd resembled the city itself, a mix of ethnicities and occupations, interspersed with pockets of business titans and celebrities.
The benefit, billed as a "Magical Evening Celebrating Christopher Reeve's 50th Birthday," drew 1,000 guests. Tickets were $750 a person, or $1,000 for seating near the front, closer to the celebrities. Included in the price of admission was the performance by Mr. Williams, a friend of Mr. Reeve's from Juilliard and the first person to make him laugh after he was paralyzed in 1995 by a spinal cord injury.
Following a cocktail reception, at which waiters in white jackets circulated with trays of Champagne and seafood and filet mignon hors d'oeuvres, guests were ushered into the hotel's grand ballroom. Tall lavender candles and magnificent 16-foot-high flower arrangements dotted 100 starched tablecloths in bright autumnal colors.
Fame may be the biggest draw in the newly democratic world of benefits. This evening was no exception: a dozen celebrities were dangled before the crowd. In addition to Mr. Williams, the roster included Michael Douglas, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Barbara Walters, Alan Alda, Kim Cattrell, Richard Belzer, Al Roker and Ron Meyer, president of Universal Studios.
Two high school seniors from Orange County, Calif., Alison King and Katy Carew, had no problem choosing a favorite from that lineup. Alison, in a peach gown, and Katy, in sophisticated black, had traveled 3,000 miles to see Ms. Zeta-Jones, wife of Mr. Douglas and his co-star in the film "Traffic."
"She's so gorgeous," Ms. King said of her idol. "But I wanted to see if the camera really adds 10 pounds." After having a good close look, the verdict was in. "She's so much prettier than she is in the movies," Ms. King said. "If that's possible." 
Nora Ponte of Summit, N.J., wearing a sequined gown, had come in part to see a different idol: Barbara Walters, one of the hosts. "Barbara Walters is an inspiration to all women," said Ms. Ponte, who has two daughters, 12 and 15. "She was the first to do so many things. And now she's older and still enjoying her life and career."
At such events, celebrities are sprinkled among hoi polloi, to spread the wealth, so to speak. And sitting next to fame is even more rewarding than seeing it on a distant dais. Ted Voss, a marketing consultant, was pleased that the guest to his right was the mezzo-soprano Denyce Graves. 
Karen Van Essen, who had flown in from Denver, was supposed to have Mr. Alda at her table. The seating plan changed at the last minute, but she still did well. To her right was Richard Belzer, a star of the television show "Law and Order: Special Victims Unit."
"He was very nice," Ms. Van Essen said, "and when he got up, he said that he had to get more popcorn, which I thought was very funny." 
She knew that some people in the room were celebrity-hunting, but she professed herself uncomfortable with such sport. Not so Patrick Rummerfield of O'Fallon, Ill., who bagged a picture of himself with Shauntay Hinton, Miss U.S.A. 
"I'm having the photo blown up and telling all my friends back home what an outrageous time I had," Mr. Rummerfield said.
He kept himself busy asking attractive women to dance, starting at the registration table. Handsome in his black tuxedo, he had a one-of-a-kind opening line based on his hard-fought recovery from the paralysis he sustained in a 1974 car accident: He tells women that he is the world's only fully functioning quadriplegic. 
The celebrity auction that followed the banquet offered guests an additional fix of fame. Prizes included attending a Knicks game with Billy Crystal, for $10,000; lunching with Gwyneth Paltrow and Calvin Klein at Klein's Madison Avenue boutique ($13,500); and a quadruple-header that involved meeting Elton John, visiting the set of "The Sopranos," enjoying a night on the town with a cast member, Joe Pantoliano, and spending a little time with Jason Kidd of the New Jersey Nets after a game with the Knicks ($16,000).
Tansa Mermerci, a Turkish-born jewelry designer who scored her invitation through the Turkish Embassy, came less to see than be seen. Self-promotion fits nicely into these new gatherings, and Ms. Mermerci found the event a good setting to display the jewelry she designs. Some pieces incorporate handmade blue glass beads dotted with black; the beads offer protection against the evil eye, not that she needed any on this festive evening. 
Chie Imai, a Japanese clothing designer, took advantage of the many photographers present to do a little promotion, too. Dressed in a Japanese kimono, she distributed cards announcing the imminent opening on East 59th Street of Chie, her store featuring her fur designs.
As charity benefits extend bigger welcome mats, shtick is a natural, too. Following the real auction, Mr. Williams proceeded to offer his own version, which included World Series tickets to see the Mets (for the optimistic), a two-week vacation anywhere in Saudi Arabia, and $500,000 to see Christopher Reeve raise his hand. Then Mr. Williams segued into a mock press conference, pretending to be Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld. "I don't know where, I don't know when, but something very bad is going to happen," he said. "No more questions, please."
NO laughs could completely bridge the gap between the famed and the ordinary, however. When Ms. Edrington met Mr. Williams in person, she said, "he bent over and said, 'What's up,' in this funny voice, and shook my hand. He was just as I imagined he'd be."
But, she continued: "You don't really know what to say. It's not as if you're going to invite a celebrity over to a Sunday barbecue or they're even going to remember you." (Although sometimes they do: Mr. Voss, the guest seated next to Denyce Graves, was the lucky recipient of two pieces of largesse: Ms. Graves gave him house tickets to "Carmen" at the Metropolitan Opera and invited him backstage afterward.)
Ms. Edrington said her only disappointment was that not all the glossy names on the invitation showed up. (Many sent video greetings.) 
"There were a few twinkles here and there, but out of the almost 50 names on the invitation, I expected more stars would be here," she said. "I'd wanted to see Arnold Schwarzenegger, to find out if he's really that big."
Aside from the lightly cooked meat, Ms. Edrington was for the most part pleased with the meal, which was prepared by George McNeill, one of the nation's 55 master chefs. She found the hors d'oeuvres -- shrimp, dim sum, sushi and won tons -- "tasty, trendy and nice to look at." But she was puzzled by the smoked salmon appetizer, which was described on the menu as a combination of rosette and tartar.
"I know I'm just a commoner," she said, "but I saw a lot of other faces saying, 'What is this?' " She also heard forks clanking as they examined it. 
For Ms. Edrington and everyone else, of course, securing money for spinal cord research was the evening's primary purpose. The benefit organizers did well, raising $2 million. "Where else can you raise this kind of money?" said Brian Heir, a physical therapist and native New Yorker.
That sum was raised by guests who had a variety of perspectives. Some had personal connections to the cause. Jeff Leeper, a stock trader from Boulder, Colo., who had learned about the benefit while surfing the Internet, plays polo. He worries about the danger of the sport, especially since Mr. Reeve sustained his injury in an equestrian competition.
Connie Michalik had come from Colorado with her husband, Craig, because she is determined that her son Richard, who was paralyzed in the 1999 shootings at Columbine High School, will someday walk again.
"Christopher Reeve has been so good to us," Ms. Michalik said. "He sent a tape to the hospital and has been a constant source of inspiration." 
Ms. Imai and a friend, Junko Larrabure, have also been inspired by the Reeve Foundation. 
"In Japan, if a handsome and famous actor like Christopher Reeve had been paralyzed, he would be ashamed and seclude himself, and you would never see him again," Ms. Larrabure said. "We are looking for ways to change that and capture the same type of spirituality and inspiration that we feel tonight."
For New Yorkers who want to do good and take advantage of this city's bounty of benefits, the gossip columnist and consummate New Yorker Liz Smith has some advice. 
"You can't go to everything," she said. "The thing to do is pick one organization and become a regular supporter. It's a big town and this is a way to become an important part of one thing. Sure, lots of people go for the wrong reasons, but that's all part of it. The amount of money they raise is the mystical amazing thing about New York." 
Ms. Edrington, who said her heart was in her mouth as her taxi barreled from the airport into Manhattan, had a slightly different take on the mystical amazing thing about New York: 
"I'm surprised that more cars and taxis aren't all banged up with the way you people drive."
