HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
A Strong Rally Is Tempered by Doubts in Late Afternoon

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Shares closed higher yesterday for the first time in three sessions but pared earlier gains after a late-afternoon profit warning from the Philip Morris Companies, the cigarette maker, tempered the optimism. 
 Before the announcement from Philip Morris, the three major stock indexes had enjoyed a strong rally for much of the day, buoyed by rosy outlooks from technology bellwethers like Oracle and Cisco Systems and positive comments on an economic recovery from Federal Reserve officials. 
 "A lot of people came in today and said the market sold off yesterday, so they took the market up," said Todd Leone, a trader at SG Cowen. "And then around 3 o'clock, they said there is economic news coming out at the end of the week, Iraq is still weighing, the rate cut is over, earnings are over, there is not a lot to look forward to -- so let's take some money off the table." 
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 27.05 points, or 0.32 percent, rising to 8,386, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 6.76 points, or 0.77 percent, to close at 882.95. The technology-heavy Nasdaq index rose 30.37 points, or 2.3 percent, to 1,349.56.
Shares of Philip Morris, the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, weighed heavily on the Dow, plunging $5.95, or 13.8 percent, to $37.03. The company said it could not confirm its 2003 forecast because of soft domestic-tobacco volume. It cited an influx of cheap imported cigarettes. 
After the warning, the Standard & Poor's tobacco index slumped more than 13 percent, making it the worst-performing S.& P. industry group. 
Other losers included utilities, whose shares have been under pressure since at least seven companies said they had received subpoenas from a United States attorney in California investigating their roles in the state's power crisis. 
Shares of the Southern Company slid 8.5 percent, to $25.17, after it said it had received a subpoena. 
Shares of Cisco, seen as a benchmark for the health of American companies, rose 71 cents, or 5.8 percent, to $12.87 after the company said its backlog of orders was up from September. Analysts use such data to gauge future sales.
Oracle rose 45 cents, to $9.50, after the chief financial officer, Jeffrey O. Henley, said he expected a turnaround for the technology industry next year. He forecast a return to growth in 2003 for Oracle after two years of revenue declines.
Shares in Motorola, the maker of wireless telephones, rose 37 cents, to $8.75, after the company said it still expected to meet earlier forecasts for the fourth quarter. 
Federal Reserve officials played down worries about the future of the economy yesterday, setting an upbeat tone that economists expect the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, to echo today in comments before Congress. 
In response to questions from the audience after an address to an economic and investment conference in Pittsburgh, the Fed's vice chairman, Roger W. Ferguson Jr., said, "I remain optimistic that our aggressive policy will reignite a recovery that has showed signs of stalling."
Nevertheless, traders said issues like a possible military strike on Iraq and concerns about crucial economic data later this week had ultimately dampened the market's euphoria. 
"It was our first rally attempt, and hopefully we'll get some more attempts," said Donna Van Vlack, director of trading at Brandywine Asset Management. "There is enough incremental bad news that the weight is just the wrong way today."
In the bond market, Treasury prices were flat, losing strength to a rally in equities and the chorus of up-tempo comments from the Federal Reserve.
Much of the action was technical, with investors taking profits on longer-dated debt and unwinding a little of the huge curve-flattening trend seen in the last week.
Still, the risk of war with Iraq kept cautious investors in bonds, as did doubts about the ability of last week's rate cut from the Fed to revive the economy soon, no matter what officials may say.
The price of the Treasury's 10-year note rose 1/32, to 101 8/32. The yield was unchanged at 3.85 percent.
The price of the 30-year bond was unchanged at 108 29/32. The yield was also unchanged at 4.80 percent.

HEADLINE: Blackstone Group May Purchase Auto Parts Business From TRW 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
TRW, the military contractor that has agreed to be sold to Northrop Grumman, is close to a deal to sell its automotive parts business to the Blackstone Group for about $4.6 billion after months of stop-and-start negotiations, executives close to the discussions said yesterday. 
 The deal could be announced by next week, the executives said, though they cautioned that the talks could still fall apart. TRW came close to selling the automotive parts business in August for about $5 billion to Blackstone and the Carlyle Group, but the deal collapsed when the bidders had misgivings about the price. 
 Now that the asking price has come down and the Carlyle Group has dropped out, TRW and Blackstone have agreed to the deal in principle and are working out the details, the executives said. Blackstone and Carlyle decided to part company after several disagreements about how much they would bid, the executives said.
Northrop had planned to sell TRW's automotive unit itself once the deal with Northrop was completed, but the quick sale by TRW will make integrating the companies easier and will help it reduce debt more quickly. Northrop is still waiting for approval of its TRW deal from Pentagon and antitrust officials. TRW had agreed to sell its aeronautics business to Goodrich for $1.5 billion before its deal with Northrop to make itself even more attractive.
The auto parts business generated $10 billion of the company's $16.4 billion revenue in 2001, but it has faced increased competition in recent years in addition to a sluggish United States economy. 
After TRW rejected Northrop's initial offer and the bid turned hostile, TRW said in March that it would spin off the automotive unit within nine months. At the time, it said that it had begun preliminary talks with other companies that had expressed interest in buying all or part of the business.

HEADLINE: Retail Giant Asks Court to Protect Its Name 

BYLINE:  By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 

 BODY:
Victoria's Secret, which sells women's lingerie and sleepwear through hundreds of stores and millions of catalogs, would seem to have little to fear from Victor's Little Secret, a gift and novelty shop selling sex toys and "Everything for Romantic Encounters" from a strip mall storefront in Elizabethtown, Ky.
 But "if there can be one store in Elizabethtown, Ky., there can be 1,000" similarly named stores around the country, ultimately diminishing the value and the very meaning of the Victoria's Secret brand, a lawyer for Victoria's Secret told the Supreme Court today in a major trademark case. 
 Victor Moseley, who opened the shop in 1998, named it Victor's Secret after himself, but changed the name to Victor's Little Secret a few months later in a futile effort to satisfy a sharply worded complaint from Victoria's Secret. Today, his lawyer urged the justices to "keep trademark law within proper bounds" by requiring Victoria's Secret to show that it had actually been harmed by the name of the smaller establishment. 
Mr. Moseley was appealing a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, which issued an injunction barring him from using the Victor's Little Secret name and leading Mr. Moseley and his wife Cathy, to call their store Cathy's Little Secret. The appeals court held that it was sufficient for Victoria's Secret to show "an inference of likely harm." 
The justices amused themselves by wondering aloud about such hypothetical variations on famous names as Kodak monkey wrenches, Budweiser bug spray and Delta peanuts. But no one doubted that there was a significant legal issue before the court: the justices' first opportunity to interpret a 1996 federal law, the Federal Trademark Dilution Act. That law expanded protection for owners of trademarks by giving them a tool to use against behavior that falls short of actual trademark infringement but that dilutes the "distinctive quality" of a trademark.
The concept of "trademark dilution" appeared elusive, and the justices pressed in vain for a precise definition. Trademark infringement, which requires proof of consumer confusion, has been recognized by federal law for much longer and is not easy to prove. Victoria's Secret sued Mr. Moseley for infringement as well as dilution and lost on infringement, an aspect of the case that is not before the court.
James R. Higgins Jr., representing Mr. Moseley, said a company with a famous trademark should not be able to win a dilution case without showing "objective proof" that consumers' perception of the famous product had changed in a manner that had an adverse economic impact. The change in perception could be demonstrated by surveys, he said.
Mr. Higgins's argument was based on the text of the statute, under which the owner of a famous trademark can obtain an injunction against the use of a similar name that "causes dilution of the distinctive quality of the mark." By basing the injunction on speculation, he said, the Sixth Circuit achieved "a result contrary to the actual words, 'causes dilution.' "
Justice Stephen G. Breyer was sympathetic. "There is a pretty significant speech interest on your side of the case," he told Mr. Higgins.
Other justices sounded impatient. "Why is there not a public interest in saying you can't copy someone's name?" Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said, adding, "Your client doesn't come off well in this case."
Representing Victoria's Secret, Walter E. Dellinger said it was "critically important" to permit owners of famous trademarks to sue promptly at the first misuse. "The diminution of value may not be identifiable until it's too late," he said. "If you can't show that Victor's Little Secret produces a kind of harm, how can you stop the second, or third, or 500th?" 
The argument in Moseley v. V Secret Catalogue, Inc., No. 01-1015, included a historic moment, the 157th and final Supreme Court argument by Deputy Solicitor General Lawrence G. Wallace. Mr. Wallace, who has represented the government as a lawyer in the solicitor general's office for nearly 35 years, plans to retire. No one now alive has argued as many cases, and no career civil servant has ever argued as many.
On behalf of the Patent and Trademark Office, Mr. Wallace argued that a dilution claim did not require proof of economic harm but did require a showing that consumers were "diminished in their capacity to recognize the famous mark."
Before Mr. Wallace's argument, Chief Justice Rehnquist noted the occasion and congratulated him for his "many years of quality advocacy and devoted service." Then, looking up from his prepared remarks, the chief justice added: "That doesn't mean we are going to rule in your favor."

HEADLINE: Briton Is Indicted In 92 Hacker Cases 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Nov. 12 

 BODY:
An unemployed British computer system administrator was indicted here today on charges of hacking into 92 United States government computer networks, including some operated by the military and NASA.
 Government officials immediately said they would seek to extradite the Briton, Gary McKinnon of London. 
The extradition, if successful, would be a rare move in international cybercrime cases. 
 Mr. McKinnon, 36, was indicted on seven counts of computer fraud and related activity and one such count in New Jersey. He faces a maximum penalty of five years in federal prison and a $250,000 fine for each count of the indictment.
"McKinnon is charged with the biggest hack of military computers ever detected," as far as the number of computers involved, said Paul J. McNulty, the United States attorney for the eastern district of Virginia.
Mr. McNulty said officials found no link between Mr. McKinnon, who they said used the code name Solo, and any terrorist group. While Mr. McKinnon was probably searching for classified documents, Mr. McNulty said, no such information was compromised in any of the attacks.
Mr. McKinnon gained access to information from networks on military bases throughout the country; two of the computer systems were at the Pentagon. One intrusion shut down the network that serves the military district for Washington for three days, officials said.
Federal officials in New Jersey said Mr. McKinnon was charged with tapping into a network of 300 computers at the Earle Naval Weapons Station in Colts Neck, N.J.

PERSON: Vincent James Landano 

HEADLINE: Vincent J. Landano, 63; Cleared in 1976 Murder of Newark Officer 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS

 BODY:
Vincent James Landano, who fought a successful 22-year battle to clear himself in the 1976 murder of a Newark policeman, died on Monday at a hospital in Toms River, N.J. He was 63 and lived in Manville, N.J. 
 The cause was a heart attack, said his wife, Camille. 
 Mr. Landano had served 13 years of a life term in state prison when he was released in 1989 by a federal judge, who ruled that the prosecution had systematically withheld evidence. 
In 1994, a state appeals court voided the conviction and returned the case to Hudson County, which proceeded with a retrial. Mr. Landano was acquitted of the murder in the second trial, in 1998.
At the time of his arrest, Mr. Landano, known as Jimmy, was a 37-year-old Staten Island resident, an unemployed construction worker and a former heroin addict who had served prison time for theft.
He was accused of the shooting death of Officer John Snow during the robbery of a check-cashing office in Kearny, N.J., on Aug. 13, 1976. Officer Snow had been delivering $46,000 in cash to the Hi-Way Check Cashing Service. 
Mr. Landano, who at trial was implicated by co-defendants, was sentenced to life plus 15 years, and in the following decade he became a jailhouse lawyer, according to Neil Mullin, his longtime lawyer. When he was not pressing for an appeal, he was a leader in various social-awareness programs at East Jersey State Prison in Rahway, including those intended to steer young people away from crime.
In 1989, after long-stored and undisclosed documents turned up showing witness accounts that could have cleared Mr. Landano, a federal judge overturned the conviction and released him. Eventually, a new trial was ordered in state court in Hudson County.
In a second trial, Mr. Landano was acquitted of the murder charge amid suggestions that members of a motorcycle gang who were originally charged in the case had falsely implicated him to shield one of their leaders, a boyhood friend of Mr. Landano's.
Through it all, Mr. Landano became a symbol for frustrated police groups -- who sought justice for Officer Snow from a man they viewed as unrepentant -- and for civil rights lawyers who portrayed him as a victim of prosecutorial misconduct.
Besides his wife, Mr. Landano is survived by a brother, Andre DelCroix, and two sisters, Lucille Forissi and Roseanne Barone, all of Staten Island. Also surviving are two daughters from a previous marriage.

HEADLINE: Corporate Leaders Are More Pessimistic Than the Fed 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
Federal Reserve officials expect the economy to improve soon, but corporate executives remain skeptical.
 Most chief executives of large companies plan to cut jobs next year to respond to economic growth that they predict will remain meager, according to a survey released yesterday by a prominent business group. 
 Offering a more optimistic view, several Federal Reserve officials gave separate speeches yesterday arguing that the economy was slowing gaining strength.
"There is no question that an economic expansion, an economic recovery, is under way," Gary H. Stern, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, said in a speech in La Crosse, Wis. 
Since the economy began weakening in 2000, executives have consistently offered more pessimistic forecasts than Fed officials or Wall Street economists have, and the executives have been more accurate so far. Last week, the Fed cut its benchmark short-term interest rate for the 12th time in the last two years, acknowledging that the recovery is weaker than it expected.
In the survey of executives, conducted by the Business Roundtable, 60 percent said they planned to eliminate jobs next year, and 11 percent thought they would add to their payrolls. The average company planned to reduce employment by almost 2 percent. 
"We're a pretty pragmatic crowd, and we're right in the middle of this," said John T. Dillon, the chief executive of International Paper, explaining the worries of executives. "And we recognize that our economy and our companies are operating at far less than potential."
Mr. Dillon, who is also chairman of the Business Roundtable, called the current growth rate anemic and said he was concerned by signs that consumer spending was slowing.
While very few executives foresee a new recession, almost two-thirds predicted that the economy would grow less than 2 percent in 2003, a rate that would almost certainly cause unemployment to rise.
Anthony M. Santomero, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, said yesterday that he thought growth would be 3 to 4 percent next year. Private economists expect the economy to grow 2.8 percent, down from their earlier forecast of about 3.5 percent, according to Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a newsletter.
The economy could still fare better than the largest companies next year if small businesses or government agencies add many workers.
The survey, the first of its kind by the Business Roundtable, was conducted during the last two weeks, and about 125 of the group's 150 members responded. The members run many of the nation's biggest companies, including Citigroup, Coca-Cola, General Motors and I.B.M.
At a regularly scheduled meeting today in Washington, the executives will discuss how the government should stimulate the economy, Mr. Dillon said.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, is scheduled to testify to Congress today about his view of the economy. When the Fed reduced its benchmark rate last week, by half a percentage point, to 1.25 percent, it signaled its concern about recent weakening but said it did not expect to lower rates again in the near future.
In their talks yesterday, Fed officials said that the continued overhang from corporate America's investment binge in the 1990's and the uncertainty of a possible war with Iraq had hampered growth in recent months. The Fed also released a survey of bank officers yesterday, showing a modest tightening of lending standards since the summer.
But the strength of the balance sheets of banks, the paring of companies' inventories, healthy increases in productivity, last year's tax cut and the interest rate reductions should all strengthen the economy in the coming year, officials added. 
Speaking in Pittsburgh, Roger W. Ferguson, the Fed's vice chairman, said, "The pieces are in place to engender a gradual strengthening in economic activity." He added that corporate investment in new factories and equipment "appears to have bottomed out and may be increasing."
Chief executives seem slightly less sanguine about such spending. Although almost three-quarters of them expect their sales to rise next year, only 19 percent say their investments will increase next year, and 24 percent project a decline. The remainder -- 57 percent -- say their capital-spending budget will remain roughly the same, according to the survey.

HEADLINE: New York's Law on Wine Is Ruled Unconstitutional 

BYLINE:  By BENJAMIN WEISER

 BODY:
A federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that New York's law barring the shipment of wine from outside the state directly to consumers was unconstitutional.
 The judge, Richard M. Berman of United States District Court, found the law, which requires out-of-state wineries to sell wine in New York only through wholesalers, to be discriminatory and intended to protect New York wineries. 
 He said the law provided "an impermissible economic benefit and protection to only in-state interests." 
The judge did not immediately strike down New York's alcoholic beverage laws and the system by which producers must sell through licensed wholesalers and distributors who sell to retailers who then sell to consumers.
But he scheduled a hearing for Dec. 5 at which he said he would entertain proposals on how to solve the constitutional problem. One possibility, he said, would be to eliminate the direct-shipping ban; another would be to eliminate exceptions in the law, like the one that allows wineries in New York State to sell directly to consumers.
But if the ruling stands, it would appear to clear the way for New York consumers to order wine from California, Virginia, and other states in person or on the Internet, and have it shipped directly to their homes.
"I'm thrilled," said Robin Brooks-Rigolosi, a Manhattan resident who was one of the plaintiffs.
"The most offensive part about the law," she said, "is that it was perfectly legal for me to order a bottle of wine from 400 miles away in New York State, but it was illegal from across the Hudson."
The plaintiffs were represented by the Institute for Justice, a libertarian advocacy group in Washington whose vice president, Clint Bolick, said the case was one "in which the wholesalers have really circled the wagons to protect their monopoly."
"This is a very good day for New York consumers," he said.
A spokesman for Attorney General Eliot Spitzer said, "We will review this decision, and confer with the governor and the Legislature as to whether they want us to appeal."
Lawyers for the wholesalers who were sued said they were reviewing their options. One lawyer, Randy M. Mastro, said, "New York's system, like that of most states, is an accountability system that makes sure that anybody who traffics in alcoholic beverages within the state is present and accountable in the state, and therefore can be held accountable for their actions."
Another lawyer, Howard Graff, said he felt a strong case had been made for the state's significant concerns "other than protectionism, but obviously the court disagreed."
In his ruling, Judge Berman made it clear that he felt the law erected an unconstitutional barrier against interstate commerce. He noted that the 21st Amendment allowed states to regulate the importation and sale of alcoholic beverages.
But he said that the legitimate state interests protected by the 21st Amendment, like promoting temperance, banning the sale of wine to minors and raising tax revenues, could be addressed through other nondiscriminatory means.
"One thing is certain," Judge Berman noted. "The central purpose of the 21st Amendment was not to empower states to benefit local liquor industries by erecting barriers to competition."
One of the plaintiffs, Juanita G. Swedenburg, co-owner of a small family winery in Middleburg, Va., said she was delighted at the ruling. New Yorkers visit her winery, she said, and are unhappy that they cannot ship wine home. "A number of them are really very cross about it," she said. "You wouldn't want to hear what they say."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL; 
Yanks' Magic Number Is . . . Lower

BYLINE:  By Murray Chass 

DATELINE: TUCSON 

 BODY:
Brian Cashman says you will not see this number next year: $175,327,055
 "We were at a number last year," Cashman, the Yankees' general manager, said yesterday. "We will not be at that same number this year. But what that number is, I'm not going to tell you." 
But the number will not be $175,327,055.
That was the Yankees' payroll this year, at least the payroll that will count when it is computed next year at this time. When it is, the Yankees will learn how much they owe the tax man. The competitive balance tax, which is what the commissioner's office calls it rather than the luxury tax, was not in effect this year. If it had been, the Yankees, based on the number the payroll won't be next year, would have paid $10,207,234.63. Combined with a revenue-sharing payment that is projected to be $45 million or more, the new labor agreement would cost the Yankees about $55 million next year. But the payroll won't be $175,327,055.
"Our payroll will be lower," Cashman said. "It just hasn't been determined how, whether it'll be via the trade market, via the free-agent market or a combination of the two. How, ultimately, we do it remains to be seen, but we will do it."
If Cashman has said it once this week at the general managers' meetings, he has said it hundreds of times. He has said it to every general manager he has talked to. He has said it to every reporter he has talked to. And he might have even said it to resort guests, desk clerks, bellmen and housekeepers. He has not said it to pool boys because he hasn't had time to spend at the pool.
In fact, when he received a call in his room yesterday from another general manager seeking a meeting near the pool, he was wearing shorts and a T-shirt and asked his caller if he minded meeting in casual clothes because it was the first time he had changed out of his everyday clothes.
Cashman is determined to cut the Yankees' payroll because he has been told -- no, ordered -- to cut it. George Steinbrenner is in a constant state of fuming over the new labor agreement and its economic implications for the Yankees. 
In a lobby conversation with a reporter Sunday, Cashman said, "Whatever I do, I have to cut payroll."
The reporter mentioned that baseball people snickered when they talked about the Yankees' cutting their payroll.
"Those are the same people," he said, "that dropped the collective bargaining agreement on us, and they were snickering and laughing after they did that."
The Yankees are taking it personally. But a look at the numbers shows why most of the other clubs were after the Yankees' money, justified or not.
Payrolls for competitive balance tax purposes cover each team's 40-man roster, are based on the average annual value of each contract and include $7.7 million in benefit costs. 
The Yankees' 2002 figure, the one you won't see next year despite rampant skepticism, was $45 million ahead of No. 2 Texas. The next largest difference between two teams was $10.6 million. The average difference between teams among the other 29 that followed in the payroll order was $3.1 million.
The amount by which the Yankees exceeded the Rangers' expenditure was more than either of the bottom two payrolls, those belonging to Tampa Bay and Montreal. Put another way, add either of those bottom two payrolls to the Rangers' payroll and the total falls short of the Yankees' payroll. Or this way: The Yankees' payroll was four times greater than the Expos' payroll.
"Our payroll is too high," Cashman said. "It doesn't need to be where it's at. It has no relationship to winning." How did it get there? "By a lot of hard work."
If baseball people weren't skeptical just at the idea that the Yankees would cut their payroll, they note that the Yankees didn't win this year -- at least not in Steinbrenner's definition of winning -- and suggest that the owner won't sit still if his lower-payroll team is falling short again. 
The tax threshold next year will be $117 million. Teams whose payrolls exceed that level will pay a 17.5 percent tax on the portion above the threshold. So even if the Yankees knocked $20 million off the number you won't see next year, they would still pay a tax of $6.65 million.
The approximately $3.5 million difference would hardly dent Steinbrenner's cash reserves. He has squandered more than that on a utility infielder.
Only two other teams this year had payrolls that exceeded next year's threshold. The Rangers would have paid $2,383,902 on their $130.6 million payroll, the Los Angeles Dodgers $526,609 on their $120 million payroll.
This year's World Series champions, the Anaheim Angels, ranked 15th in competitive balance tax payrolls at $77.2 million. The team they beat, the San Francisco Giants, was ninth at $96.2 million. Combined, their payrolls fell about $2 million short of the number you won't see next year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Players like Rondell White, left, and Raul Mondesi could be affected by an edict for the Yankees to cut payroll. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Ohio Firm's Woes Ripple Across Health Care Business 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL ONEAL 

 BODY:
The rapid collapse of National Century Financial Enterprises Inc., a large provider of cash flow financing, is sending hundreds of health care companies and their affiliates scrambling to avoid big financial trouble.
 Two of National Century's largest clients have sought Chapter 11 protection from their creditors, while the dubious status of two of the company's bond deals worth $3.3 billion has set off a spate of threatened legal action against National Century, J. P. Morgan Chase, Bank One and other firms involved in the asset-backed securities. Amid the meltdown, National Century's chairman and chief executive, Lance K. Poulsen, quit both posts on Friday and left the company, which is based in Dublin, Ohio. 
 Yesterday, the PhyAmerica Physician Group of Durham, N.C., one of the largest physician-management groups, announced that it had filed for Chapter 11 protection in Baltimore. The move followed a similar filing in Brooklyn on Friday by Tender Loving Care, a unit of Med Diversified Inc. and the nation's second-largest home nursing company. 
A spokeswoman for Med Diversified, based in Andover, Mass., said the parent company itself was close to bankruptcy. In an attempt to avoid a filing, it is planning to sue National Century, J. P. Morgan, Bank One and others for $1 billion in Massachusetts state court as soon as today. The company contends that the three companies failed to protect its interests in the two troubled bond deals. Another National Century client, Amedisys of Baton Rouge, La., said that it, too, planned legal action against National Century, Morgan and Bank One.
The legal free-for-all began in late October when National Century stopped making payments to hundreds of its clients amid its own financial woes. That called into question the value of $3.3 billion worth of bonds National Century had issued. Interest payments on those bonds are backed by health care receivables bought from companies like Med Diversified and PhyAmerica.
Red flags prophesying National Century's troubles -- from legal woes to management issues -- were in plain view for years. Yet until Oct. 25, Moody's Investors Service rated National Century's bonds AAA, the highest investment rating it had to offer. (Moody's has since downgraded the bonds to junk status.)
The company's bond sales also had the imprimatur of three of the nation's biggest financial institutions: Credit Suisse First Boston underwrote the bond sales, while J. P. Morgan and Bank One served as trustees. In addition, two J. P. Morgan bankers sit on National Century's board -- and one, Hal Pote, heads its audit committee.
Representatives of Credit Suisse First Boston, Morgan and Bank One all declined to comment.
National helped cash-short companies like Tender Loving Care pay expenses by purchasing their receivables -- future payments owed by insurers and government entities like Medicare or Medicaid -- and repackaging them into bonds.
The hospitals, rehabilitation facilities and other clients of National got weekly payments of cash -- about 80 cents on the dollar. The rest was split between bondholders in the form of interest payments and National Century, which took a cut for arranging the financing.
These kinds of bonds, called asset-backed securities, have been around for years, usually backed by mortgages, credit card debt or any other sort of asset with a regular stream of payments. In recent years, however, the assets being securitized have been ever more exotic -- like health care receivables and even truck- driving-school student loans.
Unlike mortgages, however, health care receivables are a dynamic, revolving pool of cash. Money comes in and out daily as health care companies deliver new receivables and old ones are paid.
The trustee bank is supposed to maintain a reserve fund worth 17 percent of assets to protect bondholders from defaults. This is a big reason for the bonds' investment grade rating.
This complex brew began to boil over in May when the Fitch rating agency warned that it might downgrade National Century bonds, which it did in July. It cited "increasing levels of defaulted and rejected receivables" and a lack of information from the company. This made it harder for National Century to issue new bonds, and the company soon ran into trouble finding the money to pay its clients.
In response, National Century began taking money from the reserve funds of two bond trusts -- NPF VI and NPF XII. When J. P. Morgan, as trustee for NPF VI, asked for documentation as to how this was acceptable, National Century stopped taking money from NPF VI and eventually replaced it. 
But the trustee of NPF XII, Bank One, is said to have made no such demand, so the company took about $300 million from that reserve fund, draining it to almost zero. At first, bondholders assumed the money went to buy new receivables. But in their motion filed in the Franklin County Court of Pleas in Columbus, Ohio, they say Mr. Poulsen admitted using it for other purposes.
Fitch pulled its rating altogether on Oct. 28. Moody's, which had affirmed its AAA rating after the initial Fitch downgrade, kept the bonds at investment grade until Nov. 6.
(Standard & Poor's Inc., the other big ratings agency, stopped following National Century's bonds in 1995 because "we didn't think there was adequate infrastructure to keep on top of the pool" of receivables, said Ted Burbage, a managing director in S.& P.'s structured finance group.)
There were other signs of trouble, too. National Century has been the co-defendant in several suits, one of them charging fraud; it was settled for $4.7 million. Moreover, public records as far back as 2000 show that National Century was advancing significantly more cash to one of its biggest clients -- PhyAmerica -- than it was due. In a press release Monday, Med Diversified claimed that it, too, was overfinanced, contending that National Century had advanced it an excess of money so that it could collect more fees.
National Century may have overfinanced its clients because the process is hard to manage. But the company or its board members also owned big equity stakes in many of them -- including a 33 percent stake in Med Diversified. The bondholder motion filed in Ohio on Friday claims Mr. Poulsen admitted that National and related parties own equity in 56 percent of the companies whose receivables it buys. If true, that would be a conflict of interest since it puts National Century on both sides of the transaction most of the time.
Investors are now questioning almost every figure released by National Century. In a conference call with Moody's on Oct. 30, bondholders were told that instead of turning over every 60 days as they had expected, the receivables in NPF XII were turning over every 180 days. There were significantly fewer performing assets in the trust than the $2.1 billion bondholders expected.
Outside experts are now trying to sort out the books. National Century's independent board members -- two J. P. Morgan bankers, including Mr. Pote -- have pushed the company to hire a turnaround firm called Alvarez & Marsal to manage the company. Bondholders have retained the investment bankers Houlihan Loke Howard & Zukin to perform a forensic audit of the receivable pools. But for the largely unregulated business of securitizing health care receivables, the damage may already have been done.
"You had one extremely bad apple, but there's going to be enormous disruption in the market," said an executive at a competing health care receivables company, who asked not to be named. That is a problem, since many health care companies face long delays in collecting claims and do not have the cash to operate until they are paid.
"Take away any kind of liquidity and a lot of companies will go out of business," the competitor said.

HEADLINE: A Walkout By Teachers Is Averted In Ridgewood 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD LEZIN JONES

DATELINE: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 12 

 BODY:
The Ridgewood school board and the union representing its teachers reached a tentative contract agreement late today, averting a strike in one of New Jersey's highest-achieving school districts.
 The agreement came during the second day of intense negotiations between the two sides. This morning, the union representing the district's 420 teachers, counselors and aides voted against striking today, telling its members to report for work because progress was being made in the talks. 
 The tentative pact ended two days of anxiety for many parents in this affluent Bergen County suburb who were steeling themselves for the prospect of the first strike in the district's history. 
Around 7:30 tonight, Karen Joseph, the chief spokeswoman for the union, the Ridgewood Education Association, quelled all talk of a walkout in the 5,200-student district by announcing that a deal had been agreed upon.
She declined to reveal the terms of the contract, saying they would be presented to union members at an early-morning information meeting on Wednesday. A ratification vote has not yet been scheduled, she said.
"The bargaining team is satisfied," she said.
Earlier today, school district officials said they were confident that an agreement would be reached. "Reasonable people can do reasonable things," said Bill Carbone, a district spokesman.
The major sticking points in the talks, which began before the last contract expired in June, were medical insurance and salaries. The union wanted its members to be covered by the New Jersey State Health Benefits Plan, which covers most of the state's teachers, police officers, firefighters and other public employees.
The school board's contract proposal would have required all newly hired union members, including teachers, to join a preferred-provider organization to receive medical benefits. Under that proposal, teachers currently employed by the district would be allowed to keep their insurance plans.
School board officials said the switch in benefits for new teachers would not save Ridgewood appreciable money in the short term. But some board estimates put future savings as high as $600,000 a year.
In the previous contract, the board won the right to have new employees join a preferred-provider plan for three years and then be eligible to choose a traditional plan. The board's most recent proposal would have eliminated that option.
The union countered that the state plan would also offer significant savings and said that a switch to that plan would alleviate high premiums for its members. Ms. Joseph, the union spokeswoman, would not say how that issue had been resolved. 
Wages have been another contentious issue. The district has proposed 4 percent pay increases in each year of a three-year agreement. The union has long argued that increases for the district's teachers, whose median salary is $65,000, should be comparable to recent raises in other district. It asked for increases of about 6 percent each year.
The contract talks have riveted this village of 18,000, where the school district, whose students consistently have among the highest SAT scores in the state, is a source of intense civic pride. The union and the school district have taken turns playing to the news media and selling their positions to the public in impromptu news briefings.
Many parents here were anxious about the possibility of a strike and some seemed resigned to the likelihood that one would be called.
"The teachers got to do what they got to do," said Liz Youmans, 42, who has three children in Ridgewood schools. "I support the teachers." 
Other parents noted that the current uncertain economic climate made such negotiations even harder. 
"It's a difficult situation," said Liz Gordon, the mother of three students in the district. "Both sides have some right in their positions. I just hope they can come to the middle."

HEADLINE: Japanese Growth Falls to 0.7%; Slower Pace Expected This Winter 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
Japan's economic recovery slowed during the summer, with third-quarter growth dropping to 0.7 percent from 1 percent in the spring, figures released early today showed.
 And with growth in exports falling and consumer spending looking weak for the coming holiday season, economists predict that the summer's annual growth rate of 3 percent will evaporate this winter. 
 "The economy continues to pick up, but as I expected the pace has become more moderate," Heizo Takenaka, the minister for economic and fiscal policy, said today.
On Tuesday, his office scaled back its assessment of Japan's economy for the first time in a year, citing the slower exports and risks from a weakening in overseas economies. 
"We have hopes that the signs of improvement in the economy will continue, but there are various uncertainties that will require close monitoring," Mr. Takenaka said, adding that "concerns over the outlook for the U.S. economy and continued depreciation in Japanese stock prices are increasing risks" to the nation's economy.
While today's figures showed a healthy 0.8 percent increase in personal consumption for the quarter, one forward-looking economic indicator -- private capital investment -- fell 0.9 percent. 
Economists predict a sluggish winter for Japan. In the United States, the most important export market for Japan, the sales of computer chips and cellphones have been soft, and electronics exporters like Sony and Hitachi have been trimming back their sales forecasts.
Making matters more difficult for exporters, the value of the yen has risen 5 percent against the dollar over the last three weeks. Alarmed, the finance minister, Masajuro Shiokawa, threatened on Tuesday to take action to weaken the currency. "If the yen were to rise further, I think it would be unnatural," Mr. Shiokawa said at a news conference.
Consumer spending, which accounts for some 56 percent of economic activity here, is expected to decline further as workers receive shrinking December bonuses.
The stock market has been plumbing new 19-year lows, with the benchmark Nikkei index late this morning at 8,410.53. Unemployment is near a postwar high at 5.4 percent; insecurity about the future is prompting a nation of habitual savers to spend even less than usual.
Economists say that the pessimism gripping many Japanese is holding back entrepreneurship and growth. And that pessimism is deep, according to a survey of 1,061 people conducted last weekend for Kyodo News. Some 71 percent of those responding said the government's latest plans to combat deflation would not solve anything. Only 4 percent expressed any optimism that Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi would succeed in improving the economy.
Mr. Koizumi has said that dealing quickly with the country's banking crisis -- substantially a matter of bad loans -- should be a top priority, even if that might harm the broad economy in the short term. But 61 percent of those surveyed said reviving the economy should come ahead of solving the bank crisis.
Last Friday, the Japanese financial services agency released figures indicating that bad loans at the 15 largest banks had reached $395 billion, 36 percent more than previously estimated.
Mr. Takenaka, whose plans for rapidly addressing the loan problem have been thwarted in recent weeks by bankers and their conservative political allies, also estimated that the banks would ultimately have to write off $128 billion worth of loans, 47 percent above the previous estimate. "The bad loans that the banks are publicly owning up to make up 10 percent of Japan's gross domestic product," Takeshi Kimura, a member of the government's task force on bad loans, told a foreign investment fair here over the weekend. "But there are experts who say the problem is actually five times as big. Even if bad loans are 15 or 20 percent of G.D.P., that's a crisis."
What progress there has been in shaping up the banks has come at a snail's pace. For example, the Mizuho Financial Group, an unwieldy product of a three-way bank merger, is taking three years to complete a reorganization that will prune its work force and branch network by 15 percent.
"The bad-loan problem will be solved, but in 10 years, not in 2," an American bank executive here said.
A history involving widespread political interference in the economy has left Japan with rigidities and inefficiencies that inhibit growth. Not least are the heavy subsidies for farmers, which now total 1.4 percent of the gross domestic product -- more than farming's total contribution to the economy, according to a World Trade Organization report released on Friday. "Sustained recovery would appear to hinge on structural reforms," it said, adding that an important element "is regulatory reform, particularly to reduce economic intervention in several sectors."
In an economy where many officials continue to think they can pick winners better than the market can, Mr. Shiokawa, the finance minister, estimated that the government would pump $83 billion into a new agency that is meant to rehabilitate deeply indebted companies.
Japan accounts for half the economy of East Asia, but most of its neighbors are growing and it is not. The World Bank estimated last week that East Asia as a whole would grow 5.4 percent this year and about the same in 2003, but that Japan would contract 1 percent this year and manage only 0.8 percent growth next year.
Still, even a stagnant Japan is wealthy by many standards. "Japan is often compared negatively with our neighbor, China," said Takahiro Miyao, an economist and media critic. "But journalists tend to confuse direction with levels. Japan has a very high level of income; in China, the per capita income is one-fortieth that of Japan."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Webster Resigns as Head Of Account Oversight Board
William H. Webster stepped down as head of a new board overseeing the accounting profession. With Mr. Webster's announcement, both the board and the Securities and Exchange Commission, which selected the members of the accounting panel, are without leaders.
 The resignation has thrown into disarray a board that was the centerpiece of Washington's response to corporate and accounting scandals that have undermined investor confidence and plagued the markets. Page A1. 

Executives More Skeptical Than Fed
Federal Reserve officials expect the economy to improve soon, but corporate executives remain skeptical. Most executives said economic growth next year would be meager. But Gary Stern, left, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, said: "There is no question that an economic expansion, an economic recovery, is under way." C13.

The Dow Jones industrial average gained 27.05 points, rising to 8,386. The Standard & Poor's index added 6.76 points, to 882.95. The Nasdaq index rose 30.37 points, to 1,349.56. C13.

Company's Woes Hit Health Care
The collapse of National Century Financial Enterprises, a large provider of cash-flow financing, is sending hundreds of health care companies and their affiliates scrambling to avoid bankruptcy court. C2.

The Challenge for Southern Africa
For many young democracies in southern Africa, changing the complexion of the corporate world is the next challenge. White minorities in South Africa, Namibia and Zimbabwe continue to dominate local economies and aspiring black executives continue to struggle. A1.

Documents Tie Gore Aide to Enron
Senator Fred D. Thompson, Republican of Tennessee, has released documents detailing how one of Al Gore's presidential campaign officials, Johnny Hayes, was paid to do consulting work for Enron during the campaign. C7.

Six months after deregulating its power market in hopes of promoting competition and encouraging investment, the government of Ontario backtracked and said it would freeze electricity rates. World Business, Section W.

U.S. Examining Contamination Case
The government is investigating whether corn genetically engineered to make a pharmaceutical or industrial chemical might have leaked into soybeans meant for the food supply. C7.

Retired Andersen Partner Files Suit
A retired partner of Arthur Andersen, who lost $2.2 million in benefits when the firm collapsed, is suing three accounting firms, saying they unjustly enriched themselves at the expense of about 1,000 retired Andersen partners and their spouses. C7.

Reuters Loses Merrill Contract
Reuters, the loser in a closely watched contest with Thomson Financial to replace Merrill Lynch's antiquated market-data services, moved quickly to cast its loss of the multiyear contract as a victory for common sense and disciplined control of profit margins. But with the contract potentially worth $1 billion, it was not at all clear that analysts accepted the company's rationale. C12.

TRW Close to Sale of Auto Unit
TRW is close to a deal to sell its automotive parts unit to the Blackstone Group for about $4.6 billion, executives said. C10.

Justices to Review Internet Case
The Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that requires libraries to install filters on computers providing Internet access to adults as well as to young patrons. A24.

No Study, but the Loan Still Clears
Investors and developers seeking to move quickly to obtain loans are buying insurance policies as an alternative to the more time-consuming process of having buildings and land parcels examined for environmental contamination. Commercial Real Estate. C10.

HEADLINE: Age Counts in Hiring, the Older Jobless Find 

BYLINE:  By JOHN W. FOUNTAIN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 10 

 BODY:
Robert Linn expects that each day could be his lucky day, though it was winter the last time he had a job, and the wind is blowing cold again.
 An accountant, Mr. Linn was laid off nine months ago as a controller at Aon Risk Services. He still has a monthly $2,600 mortgage and tax payment on his four-bedroom house in Winnetka, a suburb north of here, and the expense of raising a family. He and his wife, Fleury, who works part time, have a daughter who is a freshman in high school and are looking ahead to college costs. 
 Mr. Linn's savings and state unemployment benefits, he said, are enough to tide them over until he lands a new job, although continued news of layoffs and a saturated market of highly qualified, and younger, workers offers little solace. 
At 58, Mr. Linn -- like many other Americans 50 or older who have lost their career jobs in a new, less-predictable economy -- worries that he may never have another job as good as the one he had, which paid more than $100,000 a year. Like Mr. Linn, some of the older unemployed say their hard luck in job hunting has less to do with their qualifications and ability than with their age. 
Age is "very definitely a factor," Mr. Linn said. 
"There are very few ads that say 10-plus years of experience or 15-plus years of experience," he added. "In other words, if you have more experience than that it's a presumption that you're overqualified or they don't want people that are older." 
His resume does not hide his age, and he said, "I respond to those ads and get no responses."
Economists do not know whether the downturn affects those in their 50's and 60's more than younger workers. A study by the International Longevity Center-USA, a research group in Manhattan, showed that times were changing for older workers. In the recession of the early 80's, the study said, men ages 45 to 59 were less likely to lose their jobs than those 25 to 39. By the recession of the early 90's, seniority did not provide as much security, and older men were just as likely to be laid off as younger men.
If and when some older workers land jobs, some experts say, they tend to find lower-paying, more temporary, low-skill or impermanent service or consulting jobs instead of those that they have dreamed of, those they have spent their lives building reputations and careers.
The problem is not age alone, said Hilarie Lieb, a Northwestern University professor of labor economics.
"The economy is not as strong as it was in the past, and demographically, there are a lot more people hitting this age," Professor Lieb said about workers over 50. "People expect to earn more when they have more experience. So they tend to be higher-salaried workers, which can be a deterrent for employers."
Mayer Freed, a professor of labor and employment law at the Northwestern Law School, said that "it's not such an unusual pattern for people to lose their jobs" in a sputtering economy and at a point in their careers where it can be hard to find re-employment at comparable levels.
"There is probably some preference given by employers to younger workers, and in principle, that's illegal," Professor Freed said. "Federal law is quite clear that it is illegal to base decisions like that on age. But it is not easy to enforce that law."
Some employers may prefer younger people, he said, expecting them to stay longer after investing time and money training them. 
"It may also be a result of stereotyped thinking, that people are on a downward slope once they reach a certain age," Professor Freed said.
A result is that older prospects are often left out in the cold. George Putnam, an economist with the Illinois Employment Security Department, said laid-off workers 55 or older were in general 10 percent less likely than 35-year-olds to find work. 
That may be bad news in light of the figures that show the Chicago unemployment rate through September at 6.3 percent, up from 5.4 percent in 2001. Statewide, the rate was 6.3 percent, up from 5.6, and nationally it was 5.6, up from 5 percent. 
Workers across the spectrum have been affected. Bogdan Polowniak, a union bricklayer for 20 years, made $30.15 an hour until he was recently laid off. Mr. Polowniak, 47, wearing an American flag bandanna on his head at an unemployment office here, said he was wondering whether his best days were behind him. He is married with three children.
"There's work going on, but not enough for everybody," Mr. Polowniak said. "I think they're always looking for younger people. They're stronger, faster. The older you get, you slow down a little bit."
His friend Stan Puckowski, 51, who went to the office with him and is also a bricklayer, considers himself lucky not to have a family to worry about. But, Mr. Puckowski said, being jobless means that he has no money to send to relatives in Poland.
If not for his veteran's benefits, Charles Curtis, 51, an unemployed construction worker, said he would "be in trouble." Mr. Curtis said that his unemployment benefits had run out long ago and that he was living off food stamps. 
"I'm out here trying every day to work," he said. "It's just discouraging."
What is an older worker to do?
Like Mr. Linn, Tom Walsh, 60, has turned to Operation ABLE, which stands for Ability Based on Long Experience. The agency here helps unemployed workers, with emphasis for those over 50, in finding jobs and training. Mr. Walsh, a computer programmer, lost his job a year ago in layoffs at Sears, where he had worked for 15 years.
"I've had people tell me I'll probably never work in that field again," he said. "I'm a little more optimistic."
Mr. Walsh lives in suburban Park Ridge in a $300,000 house. He and his wife, a personnel manager, have two children. He figures that he is far better off than some people who have lost their jobs, because "in my case it's not a case of how we're going to put groceries on the table."
Meanwhile, Mr. Walsh continues to hunt, as well as hope.
The good and bad news, said Durant Hunter, president of Whitehead Mann, a recruiter based in New York City, is that people over 50 are hired every day, though he said that was the exception rather than the rule. 
"As an executive recruiter," Mr. Hunter said, "I have rarely had someone say, 'Can you find me someone over 50 for this job?' It is almost always, 'Find me someone 35 to 45.' "
Mr. Hunter added that most people did not have such notable success. 
Mr. Linn, an accountant at an insurance company for 19 years, until 1999, has had two jobs since then, including the one at Aon. He said he had not given up hope. Dipping into savings "probably means I'll just have to work longer," Mr. Linn said. 
He said he believed that "the economy is getting better," though he heard from a friend that an advertisement for a controller's position in a newspaper drew 800 responses.
He intends to keep looking, he said, figuring that someone somewhere is looking for "a participative and collaborative manager that gets things done and meets deadlines in a timely and accurate manner."

HEADLINE: Tornado Rips Tradition From a Town 

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN 

DATELINE: CARBON HILL, Ala., Nov. 12 

 BODY:
For people here, schools are not just buildings that can be rebuilt bigger and better. They are singular places, of community tradition, memory and pride.
 That is why it was so devastating this summer when Carbon Hill High School burned to the ground. That is why, five months later, teachers, parents and children feel about as uprooted as downed trees after a tornado on Sunday ripped apart the city's only other school, Carbon Hill Elementary. 
 It was not the fanciest building in town. In some ways, the aging brick campus on top of the hill looked kind of sad. "But I hear it every day, 'It was where I went and my daddy went and my daddy before that,' " said the school superintendent, Alan Trotter. "Already I'm getting pressure to rebuild the elementary exactly where it was. If we don't, all hell will break loose."
No power. No phones. No heat. These are practical worries in a post-tornado town. But as residents in Carbon Hill, a poor mining enclave in northwest Alabama, begin the slow crawl back to normalcy, it is the loss of institutions, like churches and schools, that is truly overwhelming.
Even the students, who should be ruling the streets thanks to the sudden godsend of a week off, seemed upset.
"It's good we don't have to go to school," said a seventh grader, Craig Tyndall. "But it's bad because we don't have a school."
He spent the day drifting around with a band of unwashed boys (many homes are without water), watching new power poles get planted in the ground.
The streets here smelled like fresh pine from all the giant trees split by the wind. Starting at daybreak, men in beat-up tractors came steaming in from the farmlands, volunteering to help. With cigarettes hanging out of their mouths they cut up tree limbs and dragged them away.
Around lunch, several women arrived in town with plastic bowls of food covered in sweating Saran Wrap. Others cooked beef stew at a Red Cross shelter.
According to Mayor James Richardson, half the homes in Carbon Hill were damaged by the tornados that swarmed the area on Sunday night. Ten people in surrounding Walker County were killed, most of them by falling trees. More than 50 people were injured.
But, looking ahead, it is the public schools, the mayor said, that pose the biggest problem.
"Kids got to be in class," Mr. Richardson said. "And it's like a bad omen. Losing both of our schools in one year? How are we supposed to handle that?"
In Carbon Hill, population 2,100, more than 60 percent of the students are on subsidized lunches. Many fathers are out-of-work coal miners, anchorless after the mines that gave Carbon Hill its name dried up. The city budget is around $2 million a year, less than half the cost of a new elementary school.
But the gritty economic situation is also a reason people here are so attached to their schools. College is not on everyone's radar screen. Many people who are born here stay here. In this self-contained world, the memories from the good ol' days are deposited just down the street.
"Oh, buddy, high school," said Tabitha Keene, a nursing student who used to go to Carbon Hill High. "If only these walls could talk. Maybe it's good they're not standing anymore."
This summer the first blow came.
It was June 27, around 9 p.m., when the high school burst into flames.
The cause was an electrical fire. The school, built in 1936, was destroyed.
Since then, the 330 high school students have been shoehorned into 18 aluminum trailers. For lunch they ate next door at the elementary school, which actually is K through 8, though everybody still calls it "the elementary."
But that all changed Sunday night. At 7:18 p.m. -- the yellowed wall clocks are frozen on the minute -- a tornado packing winds of 200 miles an hour arrived at the school with a vengeance. It sucked the roof away. It toppled brick walls. It grabbed gravel from the playground and hurled it through the school's windows, leaving so many neat little holes it looks as if someone peppered the school with a machine gun.
"It's a total loss," said Mr. Trotter, as he surveyed the 40-year-old school today. "We'll salvage what we can. We'll bulldoze the rest."
Mr. Trotter said that a few months ago when he suggested finding a new location for the high school, he received "a whole bunch of angry letters."
"Everybody in this community really identifies with these schools," Mr. Trotter said. "They are hubs. People don't want them to change."
The other hubs in the community are the numerous churches that dot the hillsides. Many were heavily damaged, including a rural Baptist church that was leveled and the oldest black church in the county, which now has an oak tree on its roof.
This evening, officials decided the only solution to the school problem was to have both the high schoolers and the 540 elementary students share the portable classrooms, at least until more trailers can be found. The younger students will go to school in the morning; the older ones will come in the afternoon. One idea for subsidized meals was giving the younger kids a sack lunch to eat on the bus ride home.
"It's been an unbelievable year," said the Walker County chairman, Bruce Hamrick.
As night fell on Carbon Hill, candles flickered in many windows. With more than 100 utility poles down, electricity is not expected back on for another week.
Without TV or video games, teenagers had little to do but stand in sweatshirts outside of cold homes and talk in the darkness.
One thing was kind of nice, though. The smell of wood-burning fires. If Carbon Hill has anything these days, it is plenty of freshly sawed firewood.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Chief Executive Is Replaced at CMR

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK 

 BODY:
David Peeler, the president and chief executive at CMR in New York, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending in major media, has left the company.
 The company said yesterday that Mr. 
Peeler, who had worked for CMR since 1995, was succeeded, effective immediately, by Steven J. Fredericks, 56, who had been president and chief executive at JassNet, formerly Yack Inc., an Internet program guide in New York. 
 Justine Carroll, a spokeswoman for CMR, said that the management of Taylor Nelson and Mr. Peeler had disagreed on various issues, and as a result, the company thought it was best to part ways.
Calls to Mr. Peeler at CMR were answered by an employee who said he was no longer with the company; Mr. Peeler did not respond to messages left on his cellphone.
Mr. Peeler joined CMR as a senior vice president and general manager of the Agency/Advertiser Group in 1995 and became president and chief executive in 2000.

HEADLINE: Settling Accounts, But Not Minds; 
Holocaust Survivors Relive Past In Case Against Swiss Banks

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
In his Manhattan office, Robert M. Kaufman thumbed a fresh photocopy of a list his father compiled in 1938 to comply with Nazi laws requiring Jews to itemize their property. Among the possessions in the family's Vienna apartment, his father told officials 64 years ago, were two baskets, 42 soupspoons and a 10-by-13-foot carpet.
 "This has brought back so many memories," said Mr. Kaufman, who is now 72 and a prominent New York lawyer. The details on the form he first saw this summer, he said recently, brought back images of a life long ago, before his family came to the United States as refugees in 1939. He could picture, he said, the apartment he last saw as a 9-year-old, with its big Viennese stove where he had once slyly warmed a thermometer to avoid school. 
 Robert Kaufman is among nearly 40,000 people who have filed claims under a $1.25 billion settlement of a class action suit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn in 2000. The suit was the definitive American legal case against Swiss banks on behalf of Holocaust victims for lost or looted Nazi-era accounts. Mr. Kaufman and about 500 others were among the first to receive payments this past year, which ranged from $1,200 to more than $4 million. 
But the process, some of the claimants say, has stirred up recollections of everyday life before the Nazi era. The judge in the Brooklyn case, Edward R. Korman, set up a tribunal in Zurich to review claims, and the lawyers there sometimes provoke powerful emotions when they call survivors to gather information.
"They are sitting in their house doing their everyday activities," said Dov Rubinstein, a lawyer who helps run the tribunal, "and then you call them and you take them back 60 years."
To make claims, people all over the world are reconstructing family histories and studying old documents, as Mr. Kaufman did when investigators sent him his family's property form. The histories are used to try to establish a family relationship to depositors who were victims of Nazi persecution.
Erna Frischer, an 83-year-old widow from Forest Hills, Queens, said in a recent interview that there were few days when she did not think of her father, who died as the war was beginning, or her mother, who was killed at Auschwitz. Even so, she said, the claims process "brought it all again to the surface."
An 80-year-old retired scientist, who loathes the attention that a sudden cash award will bring and insisted on anonymity, said a young lawyer at the tribunal helped him prove family lore that a bachelor uncle named Leo had a Swiss account. Recently, he received $160,000. (In many of these cases, the amounts of lost deposits cannot be determined precisely, so the awards are estimated based on a study of similar accounts and adjusted for inflation.)
"I accepted it," the retired scientist said, "as a gift from the time of darkness."
On file in the Brooklyn court are hundreds of award decisions that Judge Korman has approved so far.
"The claimant stated," one says, "that his cousin, who was Jewish, was sent to Auschwitz in May 1944 and that because he had a hunched back, he was sent to the crematorium upon arrival."
A woman submitted an aging postcard her mother had received describing an uncle's trip to Switzerland. Neither of them survived the war.
One man wrote that he went with his father to the Swiss bank where the father opened an account in 1933, and that he could describe the interior of the bank building. 
Another man recalled the password for the Swiss account. Several said parents told them the money in Switzerland was for their schooling.
Another woman wrote of her fear that the Nazis might torture younger members of the family to get information about Swiss accounts. In the decision granting her claim, it was noted that her mother "died from starvation in the Budapest ghetto in January 1945, never disclosing the account numbers."
The investigations uncovered lost family stories. A Czech woman submitted a claim for the account of her father, a Prague patent lawyer. Using databases of Holocaust victims and matching them to Swiss bank records, investigators at the tribunal showed that the woman's aunt also had accounts, seven in Lausanne, Basel and Zurich.
The aunt, a concert singer, was killed in a concentration camp in Poland. The tribunal concluded it was unlikely that any relatives had obtained the money because of Swiss banks' practice of "withholding or misstating account information in their responses to inquiries." The banks have argued that such misleading actions were aberrations, not policy. The award to the Czech woman, approved last week, was $4.8 million.
Mr. Kaufman's journey through memories of long-ago Vienna began when a distant relative told him that she had noticed the names of his deceased mother, grandmother and a maternal aunt on a published list of people who had once held Swiss accounts. He was astonished, he said. Though he had heard of the Holocaust lawsuit, he had no idea that it had anything to do with him.
"Sixty years and suddenly this appears," he said. "I think I had tears in my eyes all that day."
Mr. Kaufman, a partner at the Proskauer Rose law firm in Manhattan and a former president of the City Bar Association, began gathering documents. He sketched out the family tree. Death certificates had to be pulled out of files. In the stark terms of many of the claims, he described the trauma of those times. He and, later, his older sister, he wrote, had been sent to England on the rescue trains known as the Kindertransport. He was 9 when he traveled alone in December 1938.
His mother joined them in 1939 with his father, he wrote, "who had first been arrested and sent to Dachau because he was Jewish."
The toll on Mr. Kaufman's family continued even after their escapes. Although his uncle and aunt, the younger sister his mother fussed over, also made it to England, his uncle was placed in a psychiatric institution where he later died. In 1945, his aunt committed suicide by walking in front of a London bus.
The 60 employees of the tribunal in Zurich compare the information provided by claimants with unpublished bank records and government filings. When a tribunal lawyer sent Mr. Kaufman that Jewish property census form from 1938, his parents' handwriting and the detailed catalog of their holdings down to their saltshakers, transported him.
"I was picturing our apartment in Vienna," he said. "I hadn't thought of it in 30 or 40 years."
The image of the big stove where he had mischievously warmed the thermometer came back. The memories, he said, made him feel closer in particular to his father, who had painstakingly listed those items so long ago. Even in Vienna, Mr. Kaufman said, his father had been a remote man. "He was much more reserved when he came out of Dachau," he said.
Years after his father died in 1976, the English family who had taken in Bobby Kaufman from the Kindertransport sent Mr. Kaufman a letter that his father had written in 1945. It demonstrated his reserve.
"It was a sunny Sunday," his father wrote, "just a few weeks after I had been released from Dachau concentration camp and a few days after I had left Nazi-dominated Vienna, when the train carried me, a free man again, through the plains of England. And I shall never forget the change which Bobby had undergone, whom I had last seen half a year earlier, shy and timid as if ever expecting an insult or something worse. And whom I found a happy youngster."
Holding that letter, Mr. Kaufman said it had surprised him because his father had not actually visited with him at the time, but had only watched him, apparently, from a distance. "In a way," he said of the claims process and its unexpected legacy from his father, "this gave me much more of a connection than I had ever had before."
Once in the United States, he said, his father, a successful importer in Vienna, never seemed to adapt to the country he had been forced to adopt.
When Mr. Kaufman got a check this summer, he decided to use the money to benefit refugees and immigrants, like his aunt, mother and grandmother, who had opened those bank accounts in Switzerland.
Under Judge Korman's order, claimants under 75 are being paid 65 percent of the awards that are based on estimates until there is some indication that the $800 million set aside to cover the bank claims will be adequate. (The rest of the $1.25 billion settlement fund is being used to pay the claims of other Holocaust victims, including slave laborers who worked for German and Swiss companies and refugees who were denied entrance to Switzerland during the war. More information can be found at www.crt-ii.org, the Claims Resolution Tribunal's Web site.)
In the decision recommending that Judge Korman award Mr. Kaufman about $200,000, the tribunal said there was no evidence that his relatives had ever received their deposited funds. But the bank records, the decision said, suggested that "it is plausible that there was a coerced transfer to the Nazis" of money in at least two of the accounts.
It took more than 60 years, Mr. Kaufman said, for the small step of returning money to the people who owned it. "And almost all the people to whom it happened," he said wistfully, "are dead."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
KODAK CLOSES PLANTS AND CUTS ABOUT 1,500 JOBS

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 The Eastman Kodak Company is closing two manufacturing operations in New York and Mexico, as well an aerial imagery business in Canada, cutting up to 1,500 jobs as it struggles to rebound from a two-year slump in film sales it attributes to a downturn in the economy. Kodak said it would close its single-use camera plant in Rochester next July, laying off about 500 people. Production will shift to plants in China and Mexico. The company will also shut its sensitizing operation in Guadalajara, Mexico, next April because of overcapacity in the imaging industry. About 300 jobs will be cut, but the plant will continue to employ 3,000 people. Kodak also announced plans to cut 550 jobs in its global manufacturing and logistic units, 150 positions in research and development, and 140 jobs at its Citipix business in Quebec City, which it is closing.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Niagara Falls: Senecas Get $80 Million Casino Loan 

BYLINE:  By Iver Peterson (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

 BODY:
 The Seneca Nation of Indians has secured an $80 million loan for its planned casino, but at a high rate of interest. 
The five-year loan was obtained from a Malay casino developer, Lim Kok Thay, at 29 percent annual interest, Steven G. Horowitz, Mr. Lim's lawyer in Manhattan, said yesterday. The loan was first reported by The Buffalo News. The interest rate reflects the high risk, Mr. Horowitz said, adding that the casino has not been approved by all regulatory agencies, is not scheduled to open until New Year's Eve, and in temporary quarters at that. "The governor is a big supporter, and that makes a big difference," Mr. Horowitz added. Iver Peterson (NYT)

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
DICKINSON, EILEEN DURNING

 BODY:
 DICKINSON-Eileen Durning, who was President of the New York State Higher Education Services Corporation (HESC) under Governor Hugh Carey, head business researcher for Time and Fortune magazines, and Chairman of the Time, Inc. unit of the Newspaper Guild, died peacefully on Saturday in PA. She was 82. Eileen Mary Durning was born in The Bronx in 1919. She graduated from the Horace Mann School for Girls in 1937, cum laude in Economics from Bryn Mawr in 1941, and received her M.A. in Economics from Columbia in 1942. From 1943 to '47 Mrs. Dickinson was Time's head financial and business researcher; Fortune head researcher 1947 to 1955. She traveled the world for Fortune and interviewed Albert Einstein among others. In 1955 Eileen headed the NY State Publicity Division of the Commerce Department. Governor Harriman congratulated Commissioner of Commerce Edward T. Dickinson Jr. "on obtaining the services of a woman with a national and world-wide background of industrial and financial writing experience". Commissioner Dickinson and Eileen married in 1957, had two children, Mary Elizabeth and Edward T. III, and lived in Garden City. Eileen stayed at home with the children for ten years. Her husband died in 1969. She returned to work in 1971 as Executive Assistant to the President of Ithaca College. She was one of the first women to serve on the Board of Directors of a publicly held utility (NYSEG). In 1975 she was appointed by Governor Carey as President of HESC, which distributes over one billion dollars annually in financial aid to NY State college students. 
She served there until Governor Cuomo appointed her as his Special Assistant to analyze the impact of decreased federal revenue sharing upon NY State programs. She served on the Boards of: The Catskills Center for Conservation and Development, the New York State Health Advisory Council, Columbia Opportunities, and the Onteora Club. She was the daughter of Harry M. Durning, Collector of Customs for the Port of New York, and Johannah Hayes. Her daughter Mary Elizabeth Dickinson, her son Edward T. Dickinson III, M.D., two grandchildren, Alexander and Stephen Dickinson, her brother Harry M. Durning Jr., and her sister Dorothy Malloy survive her. Eileen was loving, funny, feisty, brilliant without trying, kind, joyous, and an inspiration to all who had the good fortune to encounter her. She will be missed. In lieu of flowers the family would like donations to either Bryn Mawr College, 101 N. Merion Ave, Bryn Mawr PA. 19010, or the Democratic National Committee. Funeral will be at 10:30AM on Thursday November 14, at St. Patrick's Church in Malvern, PA. Wake on Wednesday, November 13 from 7-9 PM at the Mauger Givnish Funeral Home, 24 Monument Ave, Malvern PA, 19355. A memorial service will be held in the summer at the Onteora Club in Tannersville, New York.
