HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook; 
Lofty Debut At Houston Theater

BYLINE:  By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Nov. 6 

 BODY:
Keith Reddin's provoking but uncertainly balanced new play, "Frame 312," seems to be about how a significant public event -- in this case the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in 1963 -- resonates in private lives, in this case those of a suburban family some 30 years later. It doesn't quite work; the unlikely connection to the assassination that Mr. Reddin imagines for the family doesn't entirely square with the family's problems. A frustrating result is that the playwright's idea of the relationship between past and present remains hazy. 
 Still, the play, which posits a conspiracy theorist's explanation for the unsatisfying conclusions of the Warren Commission, has a sexy "what if?" flavor. And when I saw the play at the Alley Theater here, people left excited and rightly tweaked. 
 "Frame 312" began performances recently at the Alley's second space, the Neuhaus Stage, which was rebuilt and reconfigured after a flood destroyed it in the wake of Tropical Storm Allison in June 2001. It is a worthy enough show, but no one would argue that it is the theater's most significant opening of the fall. (Nor was a second new play, "The General From America" by Richard Nelson, a drama about Benedict Arnold starring Corin Redgrave, which just completed a run on the Alley's main stage and will move to the Lucille Lortel Theater in Manhattan later this month.) 
The big news was the opening of the Alley's Center for Theater Production earlier this month. Capacious, well appointed and unusually situated, it is designed to help propel the 55-year-old Alley to the top rank of American regional theaters. 
The 75,000-square-foot center sits aerielike in five floors on top of a 13-story parking garage behind the Alley. It includes a mammoth scene and prop shop with a 56-foot-high ceiling, a spacious costume shop and three rehearsal spaces, as well as offices for administrative, artistic and production workers that will undoubtedly be the envy of cramped and cranky regional theater employees everywhere.
It is an oddity, for its size, sure, and for its peculiar visage; there are windows on the building's top five floors, but below that, the garage shows a 13-story concrete monolith to downtown. 
Perhaps more remarkable is that the center has been bought and paid for during a declining national economy, not to mention local scandal. (Enron was a major donor to the Alley.) Further, this is a state that is not exactly known for its generosity to the arts. 
"Not that we wouldn't welcome the help," said Paul R. Tetreault, the Alley's managing director. "But we don't really have government support for the arts down here in Texas. We plan on raising $50 million without it."
The Alley's success in fund-raising is a testament to a distinct inclination in this city toward philanthropy in general and the arts in particular. Just a few blocks from Alley, a new $92 million arts palace, the Hobby Center for the Performing Arts, opened in the spring, finances largely in place, adding two theaters and more than 3,000 seats to a downtown arts district that already had 12,000. 
"There is no more viable fund-raising community in the country, as far as I'm concerned," said Bud Franks, the president and chief executive of the Hobby Center.
To wit, without public money (unlike, say, the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, which has been lobbying strenuously for state support for its new building), the Alley has raised $23 million (including the $10 million cost of the center) in two continuing campaigns. The center was relatively inexpensive because the Alley, which is alone among downtown arts institutions in owning its building, has also owned the five top floors of the parking garage since it was built on Alley-owned land in 1984. Initially, the theater wanted to put an auditorium in the space, and construction of a proscenium stage was begun, but it was halted in the mid-1980's when the oil business flagged and financing dried up. The space has been used largely for storage ever since.
The new center is "an absolutely unique situation," said Gregory Boyd, the Alley's artistic director since 1989. He added, "No other theater can do this unless they have 75,000 square feet in a downtown building sitting around unused."
For the next phase of expansion, the Alley expects to complete one of its campaigns -- for capital improvements -- by raising $9 million by the end of 2003. The money would help overhaul the building that houses the theater's main auditoriums. The renovation would expand the lobby and include a cabaret, cafe and bookstore, among other amenities, allowing the Alley to program performances and related events like classes and discussion groups and remain open from morning until after midnight. The goal is to function as a welcoming destination, something downtown Houston sorely needs.
The second campaign, a $20 million drive to increase the theater's endowment, is expected to allow the Alley to double the size of its resident acting company from 12 to 24 people and to commission plays for them. (Already raised is $2 million.)
All of this is aimed at what Mr. Boyd said he hoped would be a renewed commitment to the company aspect of a theater company, namely the development of actors, writers and plays. Theater companies have built a lot of buildings in the last decades, Mr. Boyd said, but are theater companies buildings? 
"Who are the actors who are 20 now who will play Lear in 20 years?" he said. "A focus on company means you choose your plays driven by how to develop your company of actors. You do 'Henry V' because you have an actor who needs to do 'Henry V.' And you have to encourage writers to write big. With a company of 24 actors, we can do that."
As cases in point, Mr. Boyd mentions a young company member, Ty Mayberry, who will play Hamlet at the Alley next spring, and the playwright Mr. Reddin, whose next play, an ambitious work about the 19th-century Luddite rebellion, was commissioned by the Alley and is being rehearsed by company members at the new center.
"Frame 312," Mr. Reddin's current play, opened in London in March and had its American premiere at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta earlier this fall. In the play, a contemporary family goes through the kind of squabbling that signals an ordinary dysfunction. The mother, Lynette (Carlin Glynn), is in her 50's and has just become a widow. Her grown children, who dislike each other, are Tom (Jeffrey Bean), the elder, who is in a marriage strained by financial problems and the unexpected difficulties of caring for twin daughters, and Stephanie (Jenny Maguire), who is an alienated, cynical, smart-mouthed depressive. They have gathered in the backyard of Lynette's suburban home to celebrate her birthday, an occasion that quickly grows acrid with bickering and resentment. The American family, late 20th-century version: fragmented, chafing, combustible.
But like the Neuhaus Stage, where the play is being presented, "Frame 312" makes most of its hay out of a historical moment. The Neuhaus was once a cramped box with seats surrounding the stage floor in the Alley basement. But when it was wrecked by the tropical storm, its reconstruction instantly became the first priority in the Alley's expansion plans. It reopened in January with a larger and more flexible space, more accommodating to contemporary playwrights not accustomed to envisioning theater in the round. The stage now has a back wall and the audience is on three sides. Its extended length is nicely exploited by the director of "Frame 312" Peter Masterson, who mimics the play's shuttling back and forth in time between the 1960's and the 1990's by setting the different decades at opposite ends of the floor.
The play turns on a secret. Lynette is based on a real woman, a secretary at Life magazine who was among the earliest viewers of the film of the Kennedy assassination taken by a now-famous bystander, Abraham Zapruder. In Mr. Reddin's imagination, she has become the only survivor of the film's initial viewing. And now, 30-some years after the event, Lynette also has incontrovertible proof that the conspiracy theorists have been correct all along about a second gunman. 
The play, which seems to promise some revelations -- or at least insights -- into the assassination, is disappointing in that regard, making references to familiar details from the Zapruder film and to various conspiracy theories but focusing mainly on the imagined tale of how Lynette became centrally involved. 
And just as Mr. Reddin does not seem to know what Lynette's predicament means, neither do the actors. In an otherwise well-directed and well-performed production, none of the characters manage to seem credibly thunderstruck when Lynette reveals that she, an ordinary housewife, has for three decades kept to herself the answer to one of the most provocative mysteries of the last half of the 20th century. 
The play's unsatisfying conclusion made me think about the responsibility of having a good idea. It is an advantage, but you have to exploit it. The Alley Theater, with its new center and its big plans, is in that very position right now.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Alley Theater in Houston has new space above a downtown parking garage. (F. Carter Smith for The New York Times)(pg. E1); Paul R. Tetreault, left, managing director of the Alley Theater, and Gregory Boyd, its artistic director. (F. Carter Smith for The New York Times); Carlin Glynn plays a woman with a secret in Keith Reddin's "Frame 312" at the Alley's Neuhaus Stage, renovated after storm damage. (T. Charles Erickson)(pg. E6)

HEADLINE: Fed Chairman Praises Mexico As 'Safe Haven'in the Region 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 

 BODY:
While some Latin American countries are suffering from severe economic problems, Mexico and Chile have remained "relatively insulated," apparently reflecting investors' feelings that these countries are committed to sound economic policies, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said today. 
 Mr. 
Greenspan, in a speech delivered to financial experts in Mexico City, specifically singled out Mexico. The country has been faring much better, he said, since it put in place the North American Free Trade Agreement, instituted a floating exchange rate and developed stable fiscal policies. 
 "This country now seems to be viewed by international investors," Mr. Greenspan said, "as a relative 'safe haven' within the region." 
That was a turnaround from the two decades before 1995 when the Mexican economy was battered by several crises, he said. 
A copy of his prepared remarks were distributed in Washington. 
Meanwhile, Argentina has struggled with a recession in the last four years, and Brazil has faced its own economic woes, Mr. Greenspan said. Brazil's new president, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, campaigned on the promise of helping Brazil's poor. 
Mr. Greenspan, in his speech, did not discuss the course of interest rate policy in the United States or the state of its economy, which has been improving, but in fits and starts. 
He is scheduled to deliver his views to Congress on the outlook for the economy on Wednesday before the Joint Economic Committee.
Last week, Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues cut short-term interest rates by half a percentage point, the first rate reduction this year and the 12th since January 2001. 
Policy makers hope the latest rate cut will energize economic growth by motivating consumers to spend more and businesses to ramp up investments.

HEADLINE: Rarity of Black-Run Businesses Worries South Africa's Leaders 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: RUSTENBURG, South Africa 

 BODY:
The white mining magnates huddle around the head table, sipping sauvignon blanc and talking commodities at a gala luncheon for the Anglo American Corporation's platinum mine here. Patrice Motsepe, the lone black businessman at the table, jokes about fitting in.
 He nods toward Barry Davison, the chairman of Anglo American Platinum, the world's largest platinum mining company. "He's from the good-looking side of my family," Mr. Motsepe quips and the table roars its appreciation. 
 In many ways, Mr. Motsepe is indeed part of the family. He owns three gold mines and employs about 5,500 workers; five months ago his company, African Rainbow Minerals, became the first new gold company to be listed on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange in more than a decade. 
But these days, Mr. Motsepe often seems a lonely pinstriped figure in a sea of white faces. 
Eight years after the end of apartheid brought black politicians to power and black-controlled companies to the stock exchange, South Africa is faltering in its struggle to build a successful class of corporate titans from its fledgling black elite. 
For many of southern Africa's young democracies, changing the complexion of the corporate world is the next challenge. Repressive white governments no longer control this region, but their legacy lingers in the low skills and the lack of capital of many blacks. White minorities in South Africa, Namibia and Zimbabwe continue to dominate local economies and aspiring black business exectives continue to struggle.
In 1998, nearly 35 black-controlled companies were listed on South Africa's stock exchange, accounting for about 7 percent of the market capitalization. This year, 23 black companies account for about 2.2 percent of the market capitalization, a decline attributed to a stock market slump, spiraling debt and poor management. 
Whites, about 12 percent of the population, still control the economy, the mines, banks, factories and farms. Distressed by the slow pace of change, the government is enacting new legislation and stepping up pressure on industry to help increase the number of black-owned businesses and black executives. 
"We've got to open up and broaden the ownership of the economy," said Mr. Motsepe, 40, who is considering listing his company on the New York Stock Exchange next year. "In the boardrooms, I'm often the only one."
Members of South Africa's new black elite have enough cash to buy sprawling suburban homes and luxury cars, or join previously exclusive clubs to play golf, but they lack the money to acquire meaningful stakes in the biggest companies, which include some of the world's largest mining houses.
Officials say that must change. By 2014, President Thabo Mbeki's cabinet recently announced, South Africa's black majority should hold major (as yet largely unspecified) stakes in the economy, which is Africa's largest.
The news has left white business executives and foreign investors jittery; whites own more than 70 percent of the land and dominate the banking, manufacturing and tourism industries. White-run companies control 95 percent of the country's diamond production, 63 percent of platinum reserves and 51 percent of gold reserves, officials say. 
Everyone agrees that such lingering inequities are untenable. White executives often point to Zimbabwe, where long-simmering frustrations over glaring racial disparities in land ownership have exploded into violence. South Africa hopes to avert a similar crisis by setting up an orderly system to give blacks a more substantial slice of the economic pie. 
But no one -- least of all government officials, who must juggle competing priorities -- knows exactly how to achieve that goal without causing the kind of economic collapse now seen in Zimbabwe.
While trying to redress the effects of apartheid, which barred blacks from owning businesses and from quality education, officials must heed the concerns of anxious whites, who fill a large share of the tax coffers. 
Earlier this year, panicky investors sold off millions of dollars in mining stocks after they learned that the government was suggesting, in a confidential memo leaked to the news media, that 51 percent of the mining industry should be in black hands by 2010.
Business analysts say the target is impossible to meet, unless the government plans to force mining companies to sell their assets below market rates. The government denies any such plans.
Officials said the 51 percent figure was merely a position for the months of negotiations that yielded an agreement with white business executives in October to increase black ownership of the mining industry to 26 percent over the next 10 years.
The companies have promised to form joint ventures with black companies, to hire blacks to provide goods and services and to train blacks for management. The government has forged a similar agreement with the gas industry. Accords are also in the works for other sectors, including financial services, electricity and tourism. 
Also in October, President Mbeki signed into law a bill that will provide mining licenses to companies based on criteria that include whether they are working or planning to work with black companies.
Next year, Parliament is expected to vote on a bill that will call on industries to set specific targets for black ownership, define empowerment and set codes of conduct.
The notion of legislated black empowerment still jars many white industrialists, but the months of meetings with black officials, particularly in the mining sector, have alleviated most substantive concerns. In recent months, share prices have recovered as investors have regained confidence in mining's future.
"Much of the mistrust that existed is being dissipated, hopefully on both sides," said Mr. Davison at Anglo Platinum. He is also the president of the Chamber of Mines, which represents the largest mining companies.
"If we're to avoid the economic and social and political trauma in countries such as Zimbabwe, we have to assure that the issues that have arisen there don't arise in South Africa," he said in an interview.
"More people in this country have to feel that they are part of the system, that they are benefiting from the system, that the system is working with them and for them, and not excluding them. I don't think there's any doubt that government and industry are in total agreement on that issue." 
But he and other white executives are quick to point out the enormous challenges. First and foremost is the question of skills and capital. 
Most of the blacks who have snared controlling shares in companies have had to borrow to finance their deals. Between 1994 and 1998, banks and other institutions were eager to lend money and support to talented entrepreneurs and to prominent blacks who lacked management experience, to compensate for the damage of apartheid and to win favor with the new black government.
Big mining and insurance conglomerates began spinning off subsidiaries and handing them to people like Dr. Nthato Motlana, an old friend and personal physician of Nelson Mandela, South Africa's first black president, and to Cyril Ramaphosa, a trade unionist who helped lead the negotiations that led to apartheid's demise. 
The early performance of the newly black-controlled companies exceeded expectations. In 1997 the leading "black chip" companies outperformed the Johannesburg Stock Exchange. Then came the 1998 crash. 
Plummeting stock prices and mismanagement ignited a shareholder revolt at Dr. Motlana's company, which in 1994 had become the first black company to be listed on the exchange. Five years later he was ousted and his company, New Africa Investments Ltd., was reorganized to offer more accountability to shareholders. 
New Africa Investments passed into white hands, as did other companies, and lending institutions became much more wary of such "black empowerment deals." Many companies that survived -- including Mr. Ramaphosa's media and cellphone conglomerate -- are stronger now, but they are small in number. 
Some analysts complain that ordinary blacks see little benefit from these companies because many black owners rely on white managers.
Others fear that the fierce competition among white businesses for the small pool of black partners will lead to a surge in the number of black front companies, which cover for white companies seeking contracts.
The minister of minerals and energy, Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, spends much of her time trying to allay those fears. She says white businesses have promised to help raise money to help black entrepreneurs finance new deals. She emphasizes training to ensure the development of black managers. 
She firmly dismisses critics who say the government is moving too fast. Black voters are already marching and protesting unemployment and demanding economic advancement. The government, she says, must act now to avoid "an agitated society."
"If you are on the side of established business who are benefiting and have always been benefiting, it's easy to tell people it's fast," Ms. Mlambo-Ngcuka said in a telephone interview from London, where she was meeting with mining analysts. "For people who have waited all their lives, it's not fast."
She said her efforts were already showing signs of success: white companies in the gas industry have begun to sell subsidiaries to black companies. In the beginning of 2001, blacks owned 5.8 percent of the industry; by the end of that year, they owned 14 percent.
The BusinessMap Foundation, which tracks black economic empowerment, points to such successes. "There was zero black participation at the mainstream corporate level before 1994," said Jenny Cargill, the founder of BusinessMap. "Now you have some substantive black companies in the economic mainstream of South Africa."
But whether South Africa can significantly de-racialize its economy by 2014 remains to be seen. Ms. Cargill said there was no precedent in Africa for such a dramatic change in a country committed to the free market. (After colonialism ended, many African nations simply nationalized white-owned companies, which resulted in the near collapse of some industries.) 
"It was a gamble the first time around," said Ms. Cargill of the early efforts to set up black-controlled companies quickly in a country that lacks significant black capital. "This time around, it will still be a gamble."
There was much applause in May when Mr. Motsepe's company was listed on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange. But Mr. Motsepe, who runs the chamber for black businesses, was keenly aware of the failures that preceeded him. He was also aware of his strengths.
He knows his industry, having worked as a lawyer specializing in mining. He has hired experienced and accomplished managers. His gold company, which he founded in 1997, has found a comfortable niche: buying older, underutilized gold mines from bigger companies and making them profitable. 
Mr. Motsepe believes South Africa will change. But he said black excutives must keep their eyes on the bottom line if they are to succeed. 
"We have to prove that we are competent and that we are realizing value," he said. "You are only as good as your last quarterly results."

HEADLINE: Under Mayor's Latest Plan, School Cuts Total $215 Million 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER and ABBY GOODNOUGH

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will announce plans to cut roughly $215 million in education spending when he outlines a battery of budget cuts later this week, city officials said yesterday.
 Some of the cuts were put in place during the summer and fall, while others will be rolled out during the rest of the fiscal year, which ends June 30. 
 City and school officials have vowed to keep the reductions from affecting classroom instruction, saying they would move to eliminate administrative costs and staff positions, possibly with some layoffs. Some educators questioned whether the cuts could be made without hurting after-school programs and counseling services. 
Bloomberg administration officials noted that they were not holding the Department of Education to their original target, which would have cut more than $350 million this year. 
The proposal calls for cutting about 4.5 percent of the $4.8 billion that the city contributes to the Department of Education's $12 billion budget, the rest of which comes mostly from the state and federal governments.
The mayor had initially called on all departments to cut their spending by 7.5 percent. Although the schools were spared some cuts, the education cuts will still be a fourth of the roughly $850 million that the mayor plans to cut out of the city's $42.3 billion budget tomorrow, officials said.
While it does not immediately affect teachers or other classroom personnel, the proposal threatens to re-ignite one of the biggest budget battles of last spring, when schoolchildren, the teachers' union, hip-hop artists and celebrities held repeated protests against education cuts.
The reductions are being sought by a mayor who has, to a great extent, staked his reputation on improving public education in New York City. In June, Mr. Bloomberg succeeded where many of his predecessors had failed when he won control of the school system. The old Board of Education was disbanded, replaced by a new Department of Education, answerable to him. The mayor even took the symbolic step of moving school administrators to the Tweed Courthouse, right in City Hall's backyard.
Now that the city is in a fiscal crisis caused by the slower economy, the effects of the attack on the World Trade Center and unsustainable levels of spending in recent years, officials, including allies and some adversaries of the mayor, say the mayor's hands are tied. The city faces a shortfall of up to $1 billion this year. That amount is projected to balloon to $5 billion to $6 billion next year. So the city must make significant cuts and raise revenues, and of the portion of the budget that the mayor can control, the biggest expenses are among the hardest to cut: the Education, Police and Fire Departments.
The Bloomberg administration is already asking the City Council to increase the property tax rate by as much as 25 percent, which would raise $1.2 billion in the second half of this year, and $2.5 billion next year. Council members, who are being asked to approve the tax increase before the January bills are sent out, are balking at its size. Cuts to popular core services like education will also be difficult to swallow for a Council that has made "Education First" its slogan.
Mr. Bloomberg's aides would not publicly confirm or deny the cuts. Jordan Barowitz, a spokesman, said only that the mayor would announce his plans tomorrow. 
The cuts come just months after the city agreed to a contract that raised the salaries of teachers by 16 to 22 percent, in part for agreeing to work longer days. Those raises were paid for this year largely with a one-time infusion of state money, and city officials have raised concerns about how they will pay for them next year, when the expense will remain but the state money will not.
The first $100 million in education cuts began over the summer, started by the former schools chancellor, Harold O. Levy, and put into effect by his successor, Joel I. Klein, who ordered an additional $50 million. They were aimed at long-term planning money, unspent summer school money and significant purchasing reductions, school officials said.
Last week, Mr. Klein asked superintendents to cut their budgets by 10 percent, expecting to save $16 million more. His memo told them that "actions cannot affect any school-based services or personnel." Officials said such cuts, which are due today, could eliminate 100 positions from district offices.
Until late last week, school officials said, they thought those cuts, totaling about $166 million, would be enough to satisfy the city. Then the department was told that it needed to cut an additional $40 million to $50 million, which officials said could affect after-school and counseling programs and could reduce as many as 400 positions from the central administration, mostly by attrition. One official said layoffs were possible.
Still, school officials said that, even with the difficult cuts, relations with City Hall were much better than they were before the mayor controlled the school system. 
The school system was spared the brunt of the cuts in the budget that the city adopted in June. Mayor Bloomberg had originally proposed cutting $358 million in education spending, which the City Council vigorously opposed. After the complicated deal that gave raises to the teachers and control of the schools to the mayor, the state provided aid to restore about $300 million of that proposed cut.
In that round of negotiations, Council members said they were unwilling to cut education until tax increases were considered. Now, with large increases front and center, it is unclear how the Council will receive the proposed cuts.
Chris Policano, a Council spokesman, said that he would have no comment on any proposed cuts until they were announced by the mayor. 
Councilwoman Eva Moskowitz, a Manhattan Democrat who leads the Council's education committee, said: "This is a system that is plagued by a certain amount of waste and inefficiency, and I am all for eliminating it. But I have yet to see a budget cut that gets to that inefficiency. It always seems to be the case that the chalk or the after-school programs or the things that are really critical get cut. My hope is that this will be different."
Bertha Lewis, executive director of New York Acorn, which led many of last spring's demonstrations, said her group would protest the new round of education cuts.
"This is outrageous," she said. "There has got to be something that is held harmless. If, in fact, he is the education mayor, why, why would he even look at education? We already know that our school kids are not getting their fair share."

HEADLINE: Full-Service, Full-Size: Big Stores in Manhattan 

BYLINE:  By MARIANNE ROHRLICH 

 BODY:
FOUR giant home-and-lifestyle emporiums best known to mall shoppers are opening in Manhattan, from SoHo to the Upper East Side. They offer one-stop shopping and the breadth of service that small "boutique" stores cannot easily deliver -- amenities like in-house decorating services and in-stock merchandise that can be delivered the same day.
 "The economics of the retail business today is based on scale," said Gordon Segal, the chief executive of the Crate & Barrel chain, which tomorrow will open its second Manhattan location, a 28,000-square-foot store, at the corner of Houston and Broadway, in an 1894 landmark building designed by McKim, Mead & White. 
 Mr. Segal signed the lease with some anxiety just after Sept. 11 but watched with relief as his business picked up and decided to reach out to a customer who "doesn't travel to Madison Avenue." 
"There is so much competition now you have to be able to develop your own product," Mr. Segal said. "It's a harder and more competitive environment than it's been in 40 years." 
The second floor is devoted to room vignettes, with an emphasis on apartment living, including storage ideas and well-designed sleep sofas, as well an area-rug department. 
Buy Buy Baby, a six-year-old chain, will open its first store in Manhattan on Monday, at the corner of 26th Street and Seventh Avenue in Chelsea. The chain, which stocks everything from pacifiers to nursery furniture for children up to 3 years old and promises same-day delivery, is owned by Jeffrey and Richard Feinstein (their father, Leonard Feinstein, founded Bed Bath & Beyond in 1971).
Jeffrey Feinstein cheerfully referred to his 40,000-square-foot store as filled with "category killers" -- vast arrays in each category of baby product. "For example, we have 24 running feet, floor to ceiling, of safety gadgets," he said. That includes cabinet locks, oven locks, cushioned doorknob covers, even toilet locks.
Uptown, Robert Villency and his son, Eric, are overseeing two new furniture stores. Eric Villency, the president of Maurice Villency, a chain of stores started by his grandfather in 1932, is running its sophisticated new store on Third Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets, with an expanded selection beyond contemporary furniture. Shoppers will find everything from leather trays to bed linens. Robert Villency, oversees the new Roche-Bobois store on Madison Avenue at 35th Street (formerly Maurice Villency), which sells modern furniture from France. To lure customers from smaller stores, both offer decorating services from window treatments to floor coverings.
While some New Yorkers are unhappy about large stores moving in, Murray Moss, owner of Moss, said he welcomed the diversity. He pointed to the origin of lower Broadway as a street of emporiums. "Some people confuse the presence of large stores with a mall," he said. "In a sense, Ladies' Mile, with its department stores on lower Broadway, was an early mall, and those big stores replaced the small millinery shops. Now we miss the early department stores. I like any store that has a point of view and strong visual merchandising."
Jeffrey Feinstein says mothers will delight in amenities like the private nursing rooms in his stores. Most important, he said, is the one-stop shopping only a large store can offer. "Once they see a big store with everything in one place and plenty of space to shop in, they are sold."

HEADLINE: Cable and Wireless Says Overhaul Will Be Costly 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
Cable and Wireless acknowledged today that the cost of overhauling its money-losing data services unit would be far greater than analysts had anticipated. It also reported a $7.2 billion loss for the first half.
 Shares of Cable and Wireless plunged after the announcement. In London trading, the stock closed down 36 percent, to 83 pence. American depository receipts -- each representing three shares of the company -- closed down $2.20, to $4.05, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Since becoming chief executive of Cable and Wireless in 1999, Graham M. Wallace, has set about transforming the company, which was founded 130 years ago to supply telecommunication services to Britain's colonies. He has made it a provider of data services like Web-site operating and high-speed Internet connections for multinational corporations. Along the way, he made several acquisitions, including two recent purchases in the United States, the Web-site operating companies Digital Island and Exodus.
But the shift into data services came as the market began collapsing under the pressure of too much supply and a weakening economy that drove prices for these services down sharply.
A growing number of investors have called for Mr. Wallace's resignation in recent months, as they watched the value of their holdings dwindle. But Cable and Wireless ruled out the possibility of senior management changes today, when its chairman, Sir Ralph Robins, told a gathering of analysts that the board continued to back Mr. Wallace and his restructuring efforts.
The centerpiece of the plan, intended to stem losses in the data division, known as Cable and Wireless Global, is to scale back operations in the United States and Europe by eliminating services to small and medium-size businesses in those regions, and instead focus solely on large multinational corporations. The changes will save about $:400 million ($650 million) a year, the company said.
Some analysts said they were disappointed that Cable and Wireless had not left the United States market entirely.
"A complete exit from the U.S. may turn out to be the preferable strategy," Richard Barker of Credit Suisse First Boston said. "But there is an awful lot of money and management credibility invested in this global approach, and that makes it hard to pull back completely."
The reliability of Cable and Wireless executives suffered a further setback today, analysts said, when the company disclosed that revamping its data business, including the elimination of 3,500 jobs and the closing of 19 of 42 data centers, would cost $:800 million ($1.3 billion), about double what some had predicted.
Most of the extra cost is related to exiting lease obligations, which turned out to be far more expensive than the company had estimated, Michael Williams of WestLB Panmure said.
"One of the big issues with this company is credibility," Mr. Williams said. "Once again, they've undermined their own credibility."
Cable and Wireless also said today that it lost $:4.5 billion in the six months ended Sept. 30, compared with a loss of $:567 million a year earlier. Revenue fell 6 percent.
At one time, Cable and Wireless had a cash surplus of roughly $8 billion. But after making recent acquisitions, and buying back shares, the company said its cash reserves had declined to $3.6 billion.
Cable and Wireless is not alone in being caught by the downturn in demand for data services, Mr. Williams said. "But they misjudged, as did rivals, how ugly the market could get."
